So I'll take the contrarian view here and say Oppenheimer is basically kind of bad. I don't think we'd be seeing these sorts of reviews if the movie was promoted or hyped up less. Very sad but true. I did my best to conceal my serious disappointment while I was at the theatre, didn't want to seem a party pooper. I went to the theater hoping I was going to be watching a genuine revival of Hollywood or something along those lines- that I would lean away from speed, colour, and volume, just a little bit back towards pacing, character, narrative. I understand it is a blockbuster film, I was just hoping the needle would move somewhat in the other direction of the general trend in a film such as this. No such luck.What we do in fact get is a basically relentless exposition dump scored to the Inception soundtrack. The main character doesn't have much character, the supporting characters don't have enough air to breathe after all the rapid-fire delivery of exposition and information about what's going on to develop personalities of their own on screen, for the most part. The soundtrack is indeed relentless and I began to suspect that it was so constant in order to cover up the fact that there's not really much of any narrative tension in the movie.If you go watch this in theatres you will find yourself occasionally buffeted by explosive walls of sub-bass at peculiar times (the actual detonation of the bomb is actually one of the quieter explosions in the movie).I think what bothers me the most is that there is so much budget, so much acting talent, loaded into this movie. And for all the resources allocated to this project, the result is basically uninspiring, emotionally flat, basically attempting to buffet you into having a reaction through momentum. It shouldn't be like this considering the movie's subject matter ie, people talking in labs, boardrooms, over glasses of wine, in lecture halls. It's just not the right way to film this sort of plot.You've already seen it, I'm sure you liked it, but for me, it's a sore disappointment and shows that Hollywood cannot really do it anymore.Final gripe: seeing Oppenheimer reclining in his La -Z-Boy in the nude after smoking hot sex is extremely stupid, but also funny. So perhaps not a gripe.

You'll have to have your wits about you and your brain fully switched on watching Oppenheimer as it could easily get away from a nonattentive viewer. This is intelligent filmmaking which shows it's audience great respect. It fires dialogue packed with information at a relentless pace and jumps to very different times in Oppenheimer's life continuously through it's 3 hour runtime. There are visual clues to guide the viewer through these times but again you'll have to get to grips with these quite quickly. This relentlessness helps to express the urgency with which the US attacked it's chase for the atomic bomb before Germany could do the same. An absolute career best performance from (the consistenly brilliant) Cillian Murphy anchors the film. This is a nailed on Oscar performance. In fact the whole cast are fantastic (apart maybe for the sometimes overwrought Emily Blunt performance). RDJ is also particularly brilliant in a return to proper acting after his decade or so of calling it in. The screenplay is dense and layered (I'd say it was a thick as a Bible), cinematography is quite stark and spare for the most part but imbued with rich, lucious colour in moments (especially scenes with Florence Pugh), the score is beautiful at times but mostly anxious and oppressive, adding to the relentless pacing. The 3 hour runtime flies by. All in all I found it an intense, taxing but highly rewarding watch. This is film making at it finest. A really great watch.

A mind-blowing masterpiece of cinema Oppenheimer is not just a movie, it's an experience. Christopher Nolan has outdone himself once again, creating a stunning biopic that explores the life and legacy of one of the most influential scientists of the 20th century. The film is a visual feast, shot in IMAX and 65mm film, with breathtaking cinematography and practical effects. The cast is phenomenal, especially Cillian Murphy, who delivers a career-best performance as the brilliant and tormented J. Robert Oppenheimer. The screenplay is smart, complex, and emotional, weaving together historical facts and artistic liberties in a captivating way. The music by Ludwig Göransson is haunting and powerful, enhancing the mood and tension of every scene. Oppenheimer is a cinematic masterpiece that deserves all the praise and awards it can get. It's a must-see for anyone who loves movies, history, science, or just great storytelling. It's the best film of 2023, and possibly of all time.

With a duration of 180 minutes, we are granted the virtue of witnessing a masterful representation of how the human being can set aside their own humanity when obstinately clinging to their ideals. It is truly admirable how the film delves deeply into moral themes and how its messages impact and move the audience, leaving an indelible imprint on the human psyche. The unique narrative of this film far surpasses any other production based on historical events, even if the latter may not be rigorously precise. However, it is precisely in this imprecision where its charm lies, for the film does not seek to be a mere documentary; rather, it is an emotional and profound portrayal of a range of feelings experienced by the protagonist throughout the film, including guilt, resilience, anguish, and many others.Accompanied by a masterful soundtrack, the film stands out for its raw and evocative scenes that immerse the viewer in a palpable silence, creating an almost eerie intrigue. Even if the audience might lack knowledge in the scientific terms addressed by the film, it is astonishing how Nolan manages to construct such a complex plot centered around the creation of the atomic bomb and its consequences, while remaining accessible and comprehensible. This achievement is an undeniable asset, considering that some directors deliberately aim to complicate their works in pursuit of a perceived quality, whereas here, an extraordinary balance is struck between depth and narrative clarity.Moreover, it is delightful to observe the meticulous approach taken in addressing the inherent problems associated with the potential catastrophe that an atomic bomb could unleash upon our planet. Literally, the film portrays the devastating impacts of such a disaster, while conceptually, as the plot unfolds, various meanings underlying the concept are interpreted.Another outstanding aspect lies in how the film refrains from presenting an absolute idea regarding religion or beliefs prevailing within its context. Although the word "communism" is frequently mentioned, the film refrains from imposing the notion that this movement holds an absolute truth, a common occurrence in numerous instances. Furthermore, the absence of computer-generated effects (CGI) in favor of a classic cinematic style enhances the film's audiovisual spectacle, heightened by the visual impact of brilliantly executed black and white scenes. It is truly gratifying to appreciate this seventh art form in its pure essence through these sequences.Without further ado, it is worth noting Cillian Murphy's remarkable performance, which stands as one of the finest in its genre. Therefore, I wholeheartedly recommend the complete viewing of "Oppenheimer," a cinematic masterpiece that undoubtedly deserves to be experienced in a theater to fully appreciate its exquisite audiovisual effects.

Oppenheimer is not a film, it's a symphony that we could never before fathom. In my opinion, it is one of the most important films to ever exist. I remember feeling like this regarding a few films, such as this past year's phenomenal all quiet on the western front but this movie is the biggest and scariest true account of what it means to be alive. The deep sadness that overcame me after experiencing this film glued me to my seat. The fact that our supposed holier than thou goverment could inflict so much pain on a single man really broke me.Below is an in detailed look into different aspects of the film.Overall the whole movie is an impressive showing of scientific innovation in cinema but most of all, this film took a step to storytelling that has not been seen before. The cinematography was breathtaking. The use of practical effects helps add a magical effect of realism to the film. The sound mixing was definitely an upgrade from tenet. As far as orchestration, I have never been more blown away. I had chills the whole time. I quiete enjoyed the attention to detail in the costumes, they really felt like the best choice for each and every charector. As far as acting goes, I'll save Cillian for last. RDJ gave in my opinion, his best performance of his career. Emily blunt really did phenomenal, I absolutely adored her in the scene where she finds oppenheimer distraught over the loss Tatlock. I loved how Matt Damon helped anchor cillians Oppenheimer, giving use the most balanced performance. Some supporting parts stood out to me. I felt goosebumps ever time I saw Dane Dehaan, his menacing smile was truly amazing. Kenneth Branagh and Rami Malak gave great performances given the screen time. My favorite supporting actor had to have been Alden Ehrenrich. He had in my opinion one of the best scenes in the film. Finally, the man of the hour, Cillian Murphy. Never in my life did I think I'd get to see a performance of this caliber. Cillian held us from the first time we see him. Every breath was perfection. You can not teach the talent the cillian holds. He has such a unique talent of fully opening himself to the emotions necessary for the charector. This gives his performance such realism. His ability to emote just using slight movements in his face and eye truly sold the performance. The scene with Gary Oldman truly shows this ability. We see Murphys face as he is attempting to plea with Truman. His pleas going unnoticed broke me and seeing the slight welling of tears in his eyes as he realizes Truman does not care about him sold the scene.No movie in my opinion can be the best movie ever. That statement is far to subject but to me, I feel I can say that this is the most important movie to date, not only to cinema, but to life.

I've seen this movie three times in theatres and could easily see it three more. It's got incredible scope, breakneck pacing, and a kind of narrative and character-generated complexity you don't see in a lot of Hollywood releases. What I like most, though, is how Nolan continues to treat his well-known themes in new and interesting ways.I find a lot of Nolan's movies cold. I'm not a huge fan, for example, of Interstellar, Inception, or Tenet. All suffer from a kind of conceptual overload where the narrative framing appears front and centre as "innovative", but often at the expense of my investment. Interstellar looked beautiful, and some of its set-pieces (particularly the black hole) were incredible--but it wanted to tell me directly about love and the scientific/evolutionary benefits of love, and so, in my view, ended up becoming sappy and heavy-handed, particularly by the end. Instead of offering a mystery, the tesseract stood as a great-big, obvious allegory for love and time: of timeless love, actually, which, in my view, *ick*.Inception, while slick and original and thrilling and "layered" (obviously), completely forgot any sense of place. The whole movie lacked, for me, any kind of texture. While it's true the story "really" takes place on a plane over the ocean--and arguably the movie is about a kind of corporate emptying out of place as a result of globalization--the film embraced this placelessness rather than really offering it as a problem, and so all the sets took on the same colours, tones, and shades. It felt either like I was in a corporate office for the whole film, or maybe even more ironically, it felt like the whole movie was made with CGI: Nolan found a way to give reality the same effect as CGI, to turn reality into a dream--yes, I get it, maybe that was the point. But why dream in so one-note a way? Why dream about corporate offices? I'd level this same critique at Tenet, too. The end battle in the placeless city reminded me of the conceptual dream-space of Inception, and the plane crash near the beginning was more of a concept than a set-piece.But since this is, in fact, a glowingly positive review of Oppenheimer, I also need to mention there are these other Nolan films, like Dunkirk and The Dark Knight, which care deeply for place and enable the textures of the physical world to do their beautiful, filmic work. Oppenheimer belongs (ambiguously) in a kind of in-between place with respect to these two sides of Nolan's filmography, which is one reason I think it's so fascinating. On the one hand, you've got Los Alamos and the incredible visualizations of scientific concepts that erupt into full force on screen in the Trinity Test. You've also got Oppie's education in Europe and his various classrooms. Lastly, you've got the windowless, government rooms where the law does its work. On the other hand, much of Oppenheimer deals with transforming theory (or abstraction) into reality. Thus, abstraction takes on, for the first time in my opinion, real dimensions in Nolan's story. And while the movie is still cold (a coldness that Murphy's performance excels at) it feels intentional here, rather than a side effect of Nolan's narrative innovations in some of his previous films.This is his best movie about turning theory into reality (a problem he explores most openly in The Prestige, Inception, Interstellar, and Tenet). At the same time, there's the world that must experience the consequences of this new reality, which is treated with much more care. Los Alamos is gorgeously rendered--though I would have liked to see even more of it in order to tip the movie truly into the second category. The one-note textures of these prior films return in the trial scenes, though again, on purpose here. Oppenheimer's scientific visualizations compel interest in ways that the dreams in Inception never can for me. And the Trinity Test is Nolan's best piece of filmmaking yet. The fire is theory-made-real--but it's distorted, defamiliarized, and its consequences (in the form of sound-engineering) don't hit until a little later.The movie's three-hour runtime enables characters--rather than theories--to take centre stage. Oppenheimer is complex and certainly not a great man, in terms of the "great man" theory of history. We see him, by turns, as the "great improvisor" (says Dr. Rabi) and as a weak man who cannot look at the consequences of his own actions. The time to make this film is now--with both the threat of nuclear war on the horizon, and as AI technology encroaches with its own theory. The film never judges, which enables the audience to judge. It's so careful in its build-up, and so rapid in its pace, that it never feels slow--or rather, its slowness feels purposeful.Nolan loves to repeat lines in his films, like refrains. In The Prestige it's the line about love, where a character asks if a woman loves him, and she says: "Not today." In Inception, it's the lines Leo and Marion say on the train tracks. There are many other examples scattered about Nolan's filmography. Here, we get a number of repetitions that never feel contrived. We do sometimes get historical figures speaking in more of an artsy, "foreshadowy" register that real people don't use: "You see outside the world we know, Oppenheimer"; "Don't alienate the scientists in case you need them, Oppenheimer" (which, spoiler, he does); "You are an American Prometheus who gave them the ability to destroy themselves", etc. But I'm more than willing to look past this atificiality because the film does so many other things so well--like the repeated scenes with Einstein. They, to me, give order to Oppie's life as the movie portrays it, and they lead to a beautiful ending that really makes the film for me. I'll probably see it again before it goes out of theatres.The film is something only Nolan could make, and I love the ways it's a Nolan film, but better than any Nolan film that's come before. Not only is it a great story told so skillfully--but it's also an example of the evolution of an artist I truly admire. Nolan made theory into reality. So did Oppenheimer. And the marriage is fascinating to contemplate--both for its successes and its flaws.I've felt the movies lacking in reality recently (like MI7, Indiana Jones, and certainly Barbie). Sure, I could go sit under a tree for a while if I want a dose of reality, but I'd probably spend the time making up some idiotic theory anyway.

Nolan has truly outdone himself with "Oppenheimer," proving that his previous works like Dunkirk, Tenet, and Interstellar were merely warm-ups for this three-hour, R-rated, adult drama filled with intense dialogue. It's a nostalgic throwback to the time when Hollywood used to create such thought-provoking movies. This might even be the last of its kind, or perhaps studios will learn from the underwhelming summer movie slate and start taking more risks instead of sticking to formulaic focus-group-approved films."Oppenheimer" delves into mankind's relentless pursuit of technology to better our lives, only to discover that it may ultimately be the thing that leads to our downfall. The timely comparison with AI adds an extra layer of intrigue. Unlike his previous mind-bending film, Tenet, Nolan keeps the plot more straightforward here, but he still plays with timelines to keep us on our toes. However, if you're not familiar with the historical context, some of the fast-paced dialogues may fly over your head as Nolan doesn't spoon-feed the audience. Things like who was the president at the time, what were the foreign policies back then, and some technical things like isotope export to Norway. But don't worry, they're not most important things for you to enjoy this masterpiece.For those well-versed in the era, "Oppenheimer" feels like a riveting three-hour, 300-million-dollar documentary, providing an insider's view of the Manhattan Project and actual Senate hearings.Now, some fans may complain about the sound mix and the movie's length. True, IMAX cameras tend to record sound louder than standard ones, and Nolan's aversion to ADR (Dubbing) may lead to some sound issues where the music overshadows the dialogues, especially during IMAX-shot scenes.As for the runtime, I must say, every minute is justified in "Oppenheimer." Not a single scene feels unnecessary, and each line of dialogue contributes significantly to the story Nolan seeks to tell. In an age when people binge-watch eight hours of shows in a week, a three-hour immersive experience in front of an IMAX screen hardly feels long, especially when it's for what might be the best movie of the year.

OPPENHEIMER, starring Cillian Murphy and directed by Christopher Nolan, is definitely a treat for history buffs, but this film in particular is about the origins and/or the summarized development of the atomic bomb and therefore everything that shall come after, but really this film explores majorly the psychological turmoil of its subject: Oppenheimer himself, all during an age of McCarthyism and quote-on-quote government-sponsored censorship of not only entertainment, but political dissent. While I was initially disappointed by 'Oppenheimer's' departure from Nolan's signature fantasy time-travel themes, it's still a great movie.'Oppenheimer' delivers an impressive portrayal of a true story. The film excels in its storytelling, compelling acting performances, and captivating cinematography that deftly plays with light and darkness, all while embracing a distinct 1940s aesthetic. The seamless integration of visual effects and music enhances the overall experience, effectively building suspense that had me on the edge of my seat. Moments of humor artfully contribute to a well-rounded emotional journey.However, similar to Nolan's past work, like 'Tenet,' there were instances where the dialogue proved challenging to discern, highlighting the need for improved audio clarity. While the commitment to historical accuracy is commendable, there is a noticeable lack of diversity among the cast. Additionally, certain instances of nudity felt gratuitous and could have been omitted without diminishing the story's impact.In summary, 'Oppenheimer' shines through its compelling storytelling, stunning visuals, and skillful suspense-building, despite minor setbacks.

As a fervent devotee of Christopher Nolan's remarkable filmography, I found myself regrettably disenchanted by his latest venture, "Oppenheimer." My cinematic palate is one that appreciates complexity and richness, nurtured by Nolan's previous masterpieces like "Interstellar" and "Inception."Yet, "Oppenheimer" disappointingly fell short in maintaining this high standard. An incessant, omnipresent soundtrack seemed to overwhelm every scene, making it feel more like an extended movie trailer than an immersive experience. The heavy-handed attempt to force emotions felt like overindulgence, akin to a chef excessively using truffles in every dish.The narrative structure, another signature of Nolan, felt inappropriately forced in this biographical context. An attempt at sophistication through multiple timelines - a technique that worked brilliantly in "Inception" - felt unnecessarily convoluted in this setting.The dialogue, unfortunately, resonated with clichés and lacked the depth required to build emotional ties with the characters. The ceaseless time and character shifts added confusion rather than clarity, often making it difficult to follow the narrative.However, it wasn't all disappointing. The film's saving graces were the stunning cinematography and impressive performances, reflecting Nolan's enduring visual style and his knack for extracting great performances from his actors. But overall, the film did not live up to the expectations, making me wish for the measured and patient storytelling of "Dunkirk."In summary, "Oppenheimer" came off as an ambitious attempt that unfortunately missed the mark. Despite its impressive visual style and acting, the film felt more like a prolonged trailer than a satisfying, immersive Nolan experience.

I just watched this movie, and it is an ambitious film in portraying Robert Oppenheimer. The cast which you may know were in the movie and some you didn't know had small roles were all excellent. I thought Murphy and RDJ were the standouts. The one role who I thought seemed superfluous was Florence Pugh's character. To me she didn't seem too vital to the story aside from seeing her boobs in IMAX. Nolan could've put anyone in that role, and it would have had the same superficial effect. Aside from that the only quibble I have is the score is sometimes so loud that I could NOT understand what some of the characters were saying. As for the rest of the film it was relentless in telling Oppenheimer's story. It was as well made as cinema can get nowadays. You were absolutely immersed in the mid to late 40's . So much so that if you aren't a person even mildly knowledgeable about the subject then you may get lost as this film does not hold your hand in explaining what is occurring.

This is not possible without Nolan's previous projects. The non-linear storytelling, the thunderous score reverberating the tension. The storytelling being told masterfully via the cinematography. The sound design calculatingly setting the tone. Those techniques have been refined for a razor sharp 3 hour bio of one of mankind's most important/ awful creations. The more you come in with knowledge of the events, the more you'll get out of it. And still a great entry point for those who want a kinetic re-telling of of a complex subject.It's not a definitive account of what happened. Only journalistic & historical accounts can expand on each person's viewpoint & experience. This is mostly Oppenheimer's viewpoint. The tension, complexity & foresight he was burdened with having; all captured into the art form we love most. The collaborative acting talent enhances each performance to the stratosphere. It's so rare for a story like this to be told on this scale. A gem.

Don't miss this in Imax (also sit a little further back than the middle;)

Wow, what a monumental & sensational film! Nolan reinvents the three-Act structure to extraordinary effect. A mesmerising and powerful drama that unfolds like a thriller; Nolan builds the tension to a breathtaking climax, but thereafter does not let go, when it morphs into a thrilling and tense courtroom drama. I felt moved, literally due to the combination of the immense rumbling of the sound and the images of space and stars and nuclear explosions etc. I actually got goosebumps and thought 'this is exactly what I want when I go to the movies. I want goosebumps.'I loved how Nolan reminds us that this is a film about ideas, not mathematics. Einstein and Oppenheimer were not mathematicians, Einstein had to seek help from mathematicians to express his ideas in the language of mathematics. Mathematics is a useful language but ideas are what will save the human race if we are to be saved at all.I have to say, if you have little to no interest in science or the history of science a lot of the name checks are going to go over your head. A lot of satisfaction was gained by actually understanding who these people were they were talking about. I mean, 'oh thank goodness I know who they're talking about.'Yes, the cinematography is beautiful but at a budget of £100 million it had better be. Yes, Cillian Murphy is excellent - I totally believed he was a theoretical physicist which is no small feat. Yes, it's long, but I didn't check my watch until two hours in and I never felt bored.The sex scene complaint I think was unwarranted. It wasn't that bad or shocking. Although I agree it wasn't entirely necessary in an interrogation room although I understand it lent a surreal flavour to the story.The cameos I hardly noticed to be honest. There was Remi Malik who did an okay job but it wasn't overkill as others are saying. I do think Matt Damon was out of his depth in that role. Someone with real depth ad gravitas was what was needed there and I don't think he has that as an actor yet. Also Josh Hartnett felt out of his depth playing an intellectual- I didn't buy it. Tom Conti as Einstein did feel a little odd but Einstein has been parodied so much I can't see how else you could play him. Emily Blunt was great as usual.As far as the sound drowning out dialogue complaints go, I didn't have a problem with it so either I got lucky but I also wasn't too bothered if I missed some dialogue because a lot of this film is about the feels and those goosebumps I mentioned which the film has plenty of. I hope that translated to non-IMAX cinemas because a lot of this was done through sound and score. Again, I had no problem with that almost-continuous score which reminded me of PT Anderson's Magnolia which has this underlying tension playing almost non-stop throughout. Loved that!Overall, I'm glad I saw it but the true test of a great film is, would I watch it again? And this is what makes it a 7-8 film because I'm not sure that I would. I'm not sure there is a story in there that warrants a return visit but I could be wrong. I absolutely hated Magnolia the first time around whereas now it's one of my favourite films.So for now it's a 7 from me. You can safely ignore the one star reviewers. Christopher Nolan does not do one star movies.

I'll begin by saying Oppenheimer is technically very impressive (cinematography, acting, sound, etc.). Absolutely top notch Nolan on display as always. Where the movie distinctly falls short, however, is the sheer uncompromising amount of *stuff* the movie wants to tell you.The film is about Oppenheimer's initial days as a physicist, and the early discovery of nuclear fission, and Oppenheimer's role setting up Los Alamos, and the preparation for/execution of the trinity test, and the infiltration of Los Alamos by soviet spies, and Oppenheimer's personal ethical considerations over the bomb's use, and Oppenheimer's personal shortcomings with regards to womanising/arrogance, and Oppenheimer's investigation post-WW2 regarding possible communist links, and Robert Downer Jr.'s character's dislike of Oppenheimer and attempts to get himself instated on the board of some form of senate comittee at the expense of Oppenheimer's career (yeah I also thought that was a little shoe-horned in there). There's just sooo much content; everything's rushed to cut down the runtime, and no moments get time to breathe.If you're dead-set on telling the Oppenheimer story then maybe focus on part of it and give it time to shine. Either tell the 'what Oppenheimer did' story (the setting up of Los Alamos and the creation of the atomic bomb) or the 'how Oppenheimer felt' story (his reactions to the bomb, ethical conundrums, and how those things affected his life after WW2).Or, I dunno, maybe just focus on the actual Manhattan Project? To somewhat paraphrase the old scriptwriting adage - 'Is this the most interesting part of your war-bomb story? If not, why aren't you focusing us that?'

Nolan's Oppenheimer (2023) is astonishing as it is confrontational about humanity's folly. Everyone who knows the background of these historical events would be looking forward to how the a-bomb was created, and the explosion. But what I saw the inner turmoil of brilliant mind in the life of J. Robert Oppenheimer / Oppie.Favorite moments in the film:When Oppie (as a student) meets Niels Bohr, and Bohr gives an amazing piece of advice: "The important thing isn't can you read music, it's can you hear it. Can you hear the music, Robert?" When we endeavor to do something, it is not that we have to skillful immediately. It is not about the ability to do, it is having the heart, the desire to pursue and perfect it.Really like seeing pieces of literature that Oppie read, like the reference to John Donne's Holy Sonnet 14, and especially when there was a shot of T. S. Eliot's "The Wasteland" - this is one of my favorite pieces of literature ever, and Eliot one of my favorite poets. He would later write "The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock" (one of my favorite poems about the psyche of the modern man, it is simply eloquent and positively unnerving), is a great echo of the life of Oppenheimer.When Einstein told Oppie that the Manhattan Project/fighting WW2 was his generation's fight. - "Robert, this is not mine, it's yours." Einstein was someone Oppie sought advise from, and during this time wherein he had to make a great decision, Einstein's response was for him to rise up. A Moses-Joshua moment.In a scene in Los Alamos, Oppie dons a military garb, to which one of his senior colleagues, Isidor Rabi, tells him to change out of it. "They need us for who we are, so be yourself... only better." The scene reminded me of David going to battle against Goliath as who he was-- a shepherd. And like David, Oppie defeated his Goliath - however, with great moral turmoil.Every moment that Oppie realized the consequences of what the Manhattan Project caused. Especially the basketball court gathering (THIS WAS GUT WRETCHING) & the White House meeting. Cillian Murphy's acting was so moving, I cried just trying to comprehend the weight of the guilt he was burdening.When Oppie was waiting on Kitty before she was to testify on his behalf. And he was so assured his wife would not leave him, despite everything that he has done. And she does arrive and defends him wholeheartedly. Despite the imperfections of their relationship, that is a marriage worth emulating. Kitty (Emily Blunt) was such a fit for Oppie - she had what he lacked, they were truly help-mates. Unlike, Oppie's tumultuous relationship with Jean Tatlock, which in itself was as destructive as the a-bomb.Key takeaways:
Oppie was a brilliant mind, but he was lacking in many aspects. He was not able to do practical / laboratory work, but his thoughts and theories about space and dying stars were magnificent and terrifying. While he was good at improvising, and creating and thinking, he oddly lacked social skills. He was so consumed with theory, with his thoughts, with his imaginings. But as the film repeteadly states: "Theory will only take you so far." And the reality of things are more terrifying than theories."We imagine a future, and our imaginings horrify us." - OppenhiemerThe persecution that Oppie went through when he went against further government plans for a bigger bomb underscores the folly of geniuses - how they are lacking in understanding the wretched politics of the world. After being lauded as a hero, he is marked as a hypocrite-martyr. A scientist who created a powerful bomb- he gave humanity a weapon to destroy itself- and yet he advocates against it. Towards the end of the movie, he is confronted with the question as to why he should feel any moral conflict about a professional, scientific and technical endeavor. And you can just see the struggle for words in Oppie's eyes. It was simple: of course it is a moral dillema despite it being a straightforward scientific creation. Of course it is! Everything that happens to us and because of us on this earth is of a spiritual moral level. That is because in our very core we know that the imaginings of our mind, our soul, is just an echo of our spirit. We all have a touch of divine in us because we are created in the likeness, in the image of God. And I truly believe that the real life Oppenheimer was touched of God. And Oppie was aware of that one way or the other - he thrist for this spiritual knowledge. The site for the Little Boy bomb test was named by Oppie as "Trinity" after John Donne's poem about the "three person'd God" - Holy Sonnet 14. He had the pull towards the divine, the spiritual- towards YHWH, but he looked for it elsewhere unfortunately. Again, the tragic folly of man. This is the triumph and tragedy of J. Robert Oppenhiemer.Overall, Nolan weaves an excellent thriller that throws the question that Oppenheimer dared to answer, and had the misfortune of bearing forever the guilt sprung from it:"Do I dare
Disturb the universe?"
from T. S. Eliot's "The Love Song of J. Alfred PrufockIt is one of the best cinematic experiences I have had to date. Found a kindred-spirit in Oppie; cried a lot. Simply Brilliant.

I love Christopher Nolan and Cillian Murphy, plus I'm a physics nerd so I was looking forward to this movie more than any other in recent memory. Interstellar is my favorite movie of all time partially because the focus on science, namely quantum mechanics and general relativity (and our inability to rectify them).Oppenheimer barely dips a toe in the water regarding quantum mechanics. There are a few moments when I thought they were about to talk about physics, but they turn into a single comment (light is both a wave and a particle) and then move on."Oppe" is portrayed as an emotionally fragile weakling with very limited ability in his profession, and his main talent is just managing people and the project. I don't feel this is an accurate portrayal because he truly was a prolific physics mind. The film meanders through his life with flashbacks and the opposing perspective of Strauss. It's mostly historically accurate with some annoying BS sprinkled in, such as when Oppe asks Einstein to check Teller's calculations on starting an unstoppable nuclear reaction.The first half of the movie is quite good and then after they test the bomb it started to go downhill.I had never heard of Benny Safdie (who plays Teller) before so I'm not sure if his face is always wet due to a medical condition or if something about his character necessitated this. Either way, it was weird.Jason Clark seemed to be overacting a bit. He was so angry and loud during his interrogation of Oppenheimer and it didn't add anything to the film. If I was watching at home I would have cut the volume in half to endure it.Overall Oppenheimer is portrayed as fairly unlikeable, and the amount of animosity Strauss has for him doesn't make sense. Strauss is unlikable too so I found myself thinking "who cares" throughout most of the second half of the movie. Who cares if his Oppenheimer's security clearance gets renewed or not? Who cares if Strauss gets confirmed in his new position? After enduring 3 hours of this I wouldn't have cared if they both got hit by a car.

I was so hyped for this film as I briefly lived in Los Alamos, New Mexico and have family involved in the US nuclear projects of the past. Seeing it today was an incredible letdown. I don't even know where to begin with the mess of this film.Let's see, there was little to no mention of Richard Feynman. Having read Surely You're Joking, Dr. Feynman, a book which covered a lot of this project, I figured he would have at least been mentioned in the movie. But all I saw was a brief showing of someone who I assume was supposed to be him, playing the bongo drums during one scene.Then there was the dialogue. I have some hearing loss, but can understand most movies relatively well. The dialogue of this movie was so muddled and almost impossible to hear a lot of over the constant overly dramatic string music at nearly every scene! Do we really need this dramatic music at nearly every scene in a very long movie like this? I recall previous Nolan movies had the same issue. But this one seemed much worse to me. There were several other irritating audio moments as well, involving two out of place, loud, repetitive banging sounds where my girlfriend had to hold her ears.Beyond that, they left out the Enola Gay, the bombing of Japan, lots of science of the making of the bomb, and the list goes on and on. Most of this movie was just showing how Oppenheimer was being accused of being a communist over and over and over and over with this awful, overly dramatic music drowning out the dialogue. It was truly a torturous mental experience watching this.Then there was the wife. My girlfriend came to me laughing after the movie asking what was wrong with her, as she seemed so angry in nearly every scene. She didn't want to take care of the kids, and was an overly emotional, crying mess in almost every scene. I don't know what Mrs. Oppenheimer was like in real life, but I can't imagine it was anything nearly a large mess as this character was in the film.I don't like giving out 1/10s, and I almost never do it. But this film truly deserves it.

Wednesday, July the 19th. Opening night in Paris. The audience exits the crowded room in dead silence, having witnessed yet another masterpiece from the director who doesn't require any introduction. While being so typically Nolan, Oppenheimer also separates itself from the rest of his filmography. No Tenet-like action sequences, no mind-bending elements, no confusing timeline. The movie unfolds slowly but surely, and the 3 hours go by without being felt. The final hour in particular, might just be the best I've witnessed in a long time.As for the actors, the performances are as stellar as you could expect and probably have already heard. Cillian Murphy does an Oscar-worthy job at portraying a brilliant yet troubled Robert Oppenheimer, RDJ is (for the better) unrecognizable and delivers probably the most subtle and complex performance of his career. Emily Blunt oscillates between vulnerability and strengh masterfully, and the rest of the star-studded cast does an equally amazing job.When it comes to the soundtrack, Ludwig Goransson's work is superb. Powerful at times, it can also be very subtle, almost fading into the background noises. But when it comes back at the front of the stage, it will give the viewer goosebumps and sink him into Oppenheimer's internal struggle.Hindsight might be needed in order to properly judge this film, but it is my opinion right now that only The Prestige and Interstellar (maybe) surpass it in Nolan's work.

Magnum Opus! Is the word and feel that comes when you are watching this film. I am very grateful for having the opportunity to cherish this epic film by Christopher Nolan. It is grand - it is cinema at its finest. This film is one of the most important ones as it directly affects and influences our lives. It is about the man who gave the world the power to destroy itself!For the unversed, there are certain standards that Nolan always meets in his films- one of the biggest out of these standards is his nonlinear way of storytelling. He has always advocated for a nonlinear timeline in all of his films and Oppenheimer is no exception despite having a straightforward story (since it is kept true to history). The nonlinear form of screenplay can confuse a lot of people but for me it is a true mastery in the art of film making and demands full attention from the audience. This is an idiosyncrasy in Nolan's films. The second standard of Nolan (that I will talk later in the review about) is the use of practical effects and completely rejecting the use of CGI or keeping it as minimal as possible.The film was very fast paced. Despite having a 3-hour long runtime, it felt just like a 90 mins film and that is quite impressive. It takes you away for a ride. Massive respect for Nolan for sticking to the runtime and not cutting it down as many producers are very wary of longer runtimes. Jennifer Lame has become my favorite editor lately. The way she edited this movie and also the most complex Nolan film - tenet is extra ordinary. Despite having a nonlinear screenplay, the film makes complete sense at the end. And this is the beauty of the way of writing - it keeps you engaged till the very end. The way Nolan kept a mystery till the very end of a biopic based on historic facts is out of the world. This is why Nolan is one of the greatest because only he can do something like that. The ending of this film is one of the best I have ever seen and completely moved me to tears.The film delivers on every level. The acting is astounding. The ensemble cast did this movie justice. Everyone was in their A game. Cillian Murphy gave one of his best performances and I have no doubts about him getting an Oscar for this. I would specifically highlight Robert Downey Jr. Oh! Goodness! What a treat it was to watch him play the character of Lewis Strauss. His performance blew away my mind. You will all realize this once you watch the movie. Supporting cast consisting of Matt Demon, Emily Blunt, Florence Pugh, Rami Malek were all exceptional. Josh Hartnett was a ditto carbon copy of Ernest Lawrence. Hoyte van Hoytema's cinematography is clinical. He always delivers despite whatever challenges Nolan puts in front of him. He has a vision of his own that totally reflects in the film.The subject matter of this film is very sensitive. It beautifully dissects the mind of extreme genius and consequently reveals its flaws. That was the whole point of this film. This film differentiates between what it is to theorize something in the safety of your minds and how that thing eventually comes out in practice in the real world. Even geniuses have flaws. What a person intends and what is actually derived from it can be skewed in a world of manipulators. The ego of people and the sadness and dread of understanding the governance of the world sends chills down the spine. There is literal chaos and insanity out there.This film is as much political as much as it is scientific - that is the true nature of almost all scientific advances in the 20th century. This movie depicts reality and the reality is sad. It has very few creative liberties. Ludwig Görransson delivers magnificent scores for the film that depicts true dismalness of the story. It is not a cheerful one. It imbibes anxiety, fear and confusion and that is exactly what this film demanded. My favorite track that stuck with me is "can you hear the music?" - this piece of work absolutely depicts the essence of a scientist's unique way of thinking in a very hopeful way.The film is perfect. It is grand and I loved every second of it. The explosion, which was recreated practically and no CGI was used, was astounding and the realism it portrayed cannot be matched with CGI. The scenes where Oppenheimer was envisaging his theories was depicted perfectly. That is exactly how a great scientific mind works. It works on a completely different level. The way Nolan kept a mystery till the end is mind blowing. Each and every thing that Einstein said was deeply profound. And the ending where Einstein's and Oppenheimer's exchange is revealed blows this film completely out of the park! That was extremely scary and contemplative. That was sheer brilliance from Christopher Nolan and that is why I love him. I cherish his work. He is a maestro! And this movie left me devastated, which is exactly what Nolan wanted!A true masterpiece. The greatest film ever made! - 10/10.

'Oppenheimer' is indeed an intriguing movie with a constellation of A-list actors all delivering stellar performances. The title is aptly chosen as it is primarily a biopic that intricately charts Oppenheimer's life trajectory. It delves into his early interests in quantum mechanics, the genesis of the idea to create a bomb, his struggle for inclusion in the program due to his affiliations, and the painstaking process of assembling a team to actualize the bomb. The movie also depicts the only explosion he witnessed - the Trinity Test - and emphatically highlights that he was not present in Japan during the actual bombings. Most importantly, the movie poignantly portrays his post-war change of heart and his subsequent fight against the further development of atomic weapons.Remembering that this is a biopic, not a war or science movie, is crucial when approaching 'Oppenheimer'. From this perspective, the movie indeed delivers. However, I'm rating it 6/10 rather than 10/10 due to several shortcomings.Firstly, the trailer is somewhat misleading as it gives an impression of a movie primarily about the atomic bomb rather than Oppenheimer's life. This discrepancy could potentially misguide the audience's expectations. Secondly, the runtime of the movie feels excessive. There are portions that could have been trimmed down to achieve a smoother flow without sacrificing the narrative's complexity and detail. There were times when the pacing lagged, and I found myself checking the time, which detracted from the overall experience.Thirdly, while the non-linear narrative style can be an effective tool for creating suspense and atmosphere, it can be confusing for those not well-versed in Oppenheimer's life. The lack of clear timestamps during the transitions between flashbacks and flash-forwards makes tracking the events challenging.Lastly, I think the hype surrounding the movie is somewhat overblown. Currently, it stands at a 9/10, which in my opinion, overstates the movie's overall quality. By rating it a point lower, I hope to contribute to a more accurate representation of its value.In summary, 'Oppenheimer' is a commendable biopic that could have been improved with clearer marketing, tighter editing, better chronological markers, and less hype.

I'm still processing how good this is man.This film was fire (Literally)Oppenheimer (2023) is an extraordinary film that captivated my senses from start to finish. This historical drama, directed by the brilliant Christopher Nolan, weaves a mesmerizing narrative that delves deep into the life of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the brilliant physicist whose work changed the course of history during World War II.From the moment the film begins, the audience is transported back in time to the tumultuous era of the 1940s, and Nolan's impeccable attention to detail immerses us into the historical setting effortlessly. The cinematography is awe-inspiring, and the breathtaking landscapes blend seamlessly with the authentic period settings, bringing Oppenheimer's world to life.The casting is nothing short of perfection. Cillian Murphy delivers an Oscar-worthy performance as J. Robert Oppenheimer, capturing the complexity and inner struggles of the enigmatic physicist with unparalleled depth. His portrayal is nuanced and compelling, allowing us to empathize with Oppenheimer's moral dilemmas and the burden he carries as the father of the atomic bomb.The supporting cast, including talented actors like Jessica Chastain, Michael Caine, and Tom Hardy, further enriches the movie, elevating it to cinematic greatness. Each character is beautifully crafted and contributes significantly to the story's emotional weight.One of the most impressive aspects of Oppenheimer is its intelligent and thought-provoking script. Kudos to the screenwriters for expertly exploring the ethical questions surrounding scientific discoveries during wartime, the moral responsibilities of scientists, and the consequences of unleashing such powerful weaponry on the world.The film's score, composed by the incomparable Hans Zimmer, is nothing short of a symphonic masterpiece. It amplifies the emotional impact of every scene, pulling at our heartstrings and enhancing the overall experience.Christopher Nolan's direction is, without a doubt, a work of art. His ability to interweave historical events with human emotions and philosophical musings is nothing short of genius. He masterfully guides the audience through a rollercoaster of emotions, leaving us contemplating the consequences of our actions long after the credits roll.Oppenheimer is not merely a historical retelling; it's a powerful reflection on the frailty of humanity, the pursuit of knowledge, and the consequences of playing with forces beyond our comprehension. This film will undoubtedly leave a lasting impression on anyone fortunate enough to witness it on the big screen.In conclusion, Oppenheimer is an unparalleled cinematic experience that deserves every single one of its five stars. Christopher Nolan's visionary direction, outstanding performances, breathtaking cinematography, and emotional depth make this film a true masterpiece. It is a must-watch for anyone who appreciates the power of storytelling and the impact of historical events on the course of human history.

A Masterpiece in every sense of the word, the editing and masterful score kept me invested and engaged during the whole 180 minutes.The sound kept me on my toes, and the performances are so DAMN good. Cillian Murphy, Emily Blunt, Robert Downey Jr. And Matt Damon show that they are absolute elite performers. Alden Ehrenreich was the surprise package, fantastic everytime he was on screen.The trinity test sequence is one of the best movie scenes this century, my favorite of the year.Nolan's best movie since Inception and if he doesn't win the Best Director Oscar for this, I'm afraid he will never win it, and I personally thing that would be a tragedy.

It's by far Christopher Nolan's best work and easily the best movie released in the last 10 years. It is a little bit long coming in at 3 hours and 9 minutes, but it's worth it.It's a star studded cast that actually delivers, unlike some of the ones in the past with that many superstars in one movie. Cillian Murphy delivers an Oscar worthy performance. Robert Downing, Jr., despite playing to roll of a horrible person, gives his best acting performance to date. The fact that Florence Pugh is only in like 8 scenes just shows the star power this movie has.Overall, it is a masterpiece and a must see.

Oppenheimer has offered the audience an outstanding story, casting, and definitely acting. Cillian Murphy and Robert D. Junior have excelled and went beyond everything they've done before, and showed everyone how great they are. The music was employed perfectly, and it was successful in heightening the emotions of every scene (kudos to Ludwig Goransson)I'm not gonna lie that I was disappointed by the small scale of the explosion (as everyone expected a more dramatic one), but in exchange, we had amazing dialogues, drama and acting!This movie is an Oscar worthy production, and it's definitely THE BEST movie of the year!

This movie is nothing other than perfection. The characters, the plot, cinematography, acting, all was 10/10.I've seen some reviews suggesting it was too long, but I feel like the ending wraps up the story so nicely that it makes up for the length of the movie. For me it felt more like the movie was 2,5h long because of the mesmerising ending!Some of the scenes were the best I've ever scene regarding the cinematography. The scene where Oppenheimer speaks in front of Los Alamos after the bombings was nothing short of amazing. Also the build up to the Trinity-test raised my bpm to at least 140!Would definitely recommend watching the 70mm because of Nolan's stunning Cinematography.

It is an incredibly well done movie! It was confusing at times, just for the confusion to be an excellent catalyst for the ending. It was truly shocking!!!! I was never bored during the film, and it kind of felt like three movies in one, that thoroughly connected. The movie may not be what y'all are expecting, but it is a truly great piece of cinema. It gives great insight into the time period and the man's life. The whole movie flows seamlessly, and definitely deserves to be watched multiple times! One of the most incredible things that I realized 2/3rds of the way in, is that the actors did such an amazing job that I truly forgot it was the same actors for the majority of the movie. I truly dropped my jaw remembering that Cillian Murphy is the man planning Oppenheimer, but also played Scarecrow (in Nolan's BatMan Begins); they feel like two completely separate human beings! The only one who felt like himself was Robert Downey Jr., but that was pretty much because he was the only one who didn't have a completely different voice from his usual self. Downey Jr.'s performance was still magnificent to be clear! The whole movie is truly a masterpiece and should be remembered as an American classic!!!! I never say this, but during the last 30 seconds I had goosebumps, it was a truly, deep and meaningful, emotional experience.

Today I watched Nolan's Oppenheimer and it was good.To start off I think that Cillian Murphy and most of the other cast did really great. I think the acting in this film is genuinely very good, most of the actors really transform into their characters, even some smaller role actors have the opportunity to show a lot of range in this film.The story is definitely my favorite part, I enjoy almost all of it and think this is one of the best tales to be told on the big screen. I think Nolan also did a good job writing a 3 hour long film without to much of it feeling like it needed to be cut out, it's not easy to do. There are a couple moments that are incredibly visceral and really make you question the philosophy of what's happening here.My huge problem with this film is the technical aspects however and there is a unfortunately a good chunk of it that I do not love. For starters, the cinematography in this film feels like a downgrade from every Nolan I've watched(haven't seen tenet).Half of this film, no, 75% of this film is just shot reverse shot close ups that are so insanely unimaginative that it really boggles my mind that they didn't just pull the camera back a little bit. Like, your sets are actually pretty neat, can you PLEASE pull the camera back from Oppy and show me the laboratory their in?? Maybe show me a bit more scenery and not a close up shot reverse shot? We did get some genuinely Jaw dropping scenes, however for the most part it just often was so bland.The cinematography also doesn't help the fact that this movie has some really adhd editing going on. So many different scenes happen and so many different characters come in so quickly that it's actually bordering on bloated. It really felt like there was like 30 cuts on average per minute in this 3 hour long film and that's just eye straining sometimes. Like we're cutting back and forth between areas and times and it's just so much information overload...Also the mixing, as per Nolan standard, renders certain scenes absolutely unintelligible on a big screen. Maybe it's fine for home video or with subtitles, but, especially near the end, some scenes the vocals are just buried in the mix so badly. I cannot hear over the music that is not normally in the scene why is it so loud...And uh yeah the music was fine, I really don't have much to say about it. I guess it serviced the film well in some parts but I found it to be generally forgettable. Like I really loved the music in some of Nolan's older works (dunkirk and memento in particular) but this particular soundtrack didn't blow me away or anything. No pun intended.Overall, I still enjoyed this movie despite what I believe to be pretty annoying flaws. It has a lot of payoffs, it's a very VERY good story and writing(barring one kinda cringe scene with Florence Pugh), and it really is fantastically acted by the main actors. I definitely do not regret watching this movie but I do wish that some elements didn't feel kinda phoned in.Low - Mid 6/10.

The movie was too long and there were too many characters introduced. Also, the story was not told in a linear fashion, so you didn't always know what was happening. The last third and parts of the first third of the film were not really necessary. I had expected more.Acting was also rather poor, because the backgrounds of the other characters were not told, because everything was focused only on the main character Oppenheimer. So it was an impressive ensemble of actors, but all actors remained very pale in their roles. The supporting characters could have just as easily been cast by no-name actors. Cillian Murphy in the leading role was good, but not Oscar worthy.The camera wasn't good either, as there was too much focus on close-ups and too few white-angle shots.I didn't like the picture either. It was too dark and colors were barely shown.The best thing about the film was the soundtrack. It was very well nuanced and in tune with the film.In general, it can be said that biopics are not Nolan's genre. Spielberg (Schindler's List) and Scorsese (Aviator) can do that worlds better. Moreover, there are already excellent documentaries and books on the Manhattan Project.

I though the movie was a breath air for Hollywood, all year bad movies have been pumped out, but this feels like it has heart. Unlike certain other movies, this one does not rely on bad jokes to take up most of the runtime.I very much enjoyed the fact that this film did not shy away from the repercussions of the A-Bomb, or the effects of the Bomb on Oppenheimer's life.In conclusion, this movie is will most likely be the winner, or runner up, of "The Best Film of Summer 2023" (behind Barbie of course) (just kidding). This film will stick with me for the rest of my life, because of the stunning Cinematography, Writing, Acting, and Directing by Christopher Nolan.
