Oppenheimer is an excellent personal history and a story of international cooperation in physics. There is an interest in philosophy and morality, but no understanding of the actions and consequences. All the time there is too much political witch hunt and game in the US and too few mentions and scenes of the effects of radiation, humanitarian crisis and suffering in Japan.The film could have used many more pictures of the victims and a reminder that nuclear power should never have been used in history and should not be used in warfare in the future, not in this decade and not in the decades to come.An apology is completely absent at state level.

I don't think any other movie will cast this perfectly and deliver a dominating performance from each character. Nolan proved why he's one of the greatest storytellers of this generation. The Acting, Cinematography, Music, Background score, Screenplay, Direction, and everything were so perfect.No wonder Robert Downey Jr. Said this is the best movie he has been part of it, his character arc and the way he delivered in the end were amazing.Emily Blunt's character blew me away, I wasn't expected such character and acting performance from her.Cillian Murphy and Christopher Nolan carried this movie's 1st frame to last, incredibly talented people and delivered their peak skills.I wish this movie wins at least 4-5 Oscars, they all deserve that appreciation and recognization for their incredible contributions to this generation.

I waited so long to see the film, and it was worth it. I'm a big Christopher Nolan fan and I've seen his most popular films and I had high hopes for the film.The visuals of the film were beautiful and the cinematography made the film enjoyable. However, the pace was a little slow and at times felt a little boring. Although I expected more from the film, it was still surprisingly well done.I thought the film would have been more about the atomic bombs, but the film was about Oppenheimer as the title is Oppenheimer. And don't get me wrong, i am totally fine with that. Oppenheimer is a great historical figure that everyone should know about.I highly recommend going to see the film as soon as possible and if you can then choose the imax theatre.

Very different than Nolan's recent films, especially the Sci-Fi ones, but shows that Nolan can master the Biopic/Drama genre just as well as he can any other genre he tried to tackle yet.The film is 3-hours long but goes through very quickly and enjoyably. Without spoiling anything, the film presents important and very relevant subjects, and doing so while being non-stop entertainment and a comprehensive character study and a study of our society on a very high pace.Without mentioning anything specific, there was one scene that caused almost every single person in the theatre to move nervously in the seats, non-stop for a long period of time, being one of the most intense scenes I ever watched in a movie and reminding me of the true power of the cinematic experience like no other movie did in recent years.The year is only half-way through but right now this is my top pick for the upcoming awards season. Picture, Writing, Directing, Acting, Score-- Oppenheimer is a winner on all fronts. A rare feat for filmmaking and a salient reminder that cinema is not dead.I highly recommend this film to everyone. Watched it once already, and going back to the theatre for at least a few more times soon.

Probably the best Nolan movie ever.The pace, the story, the acting, the music, the cinematography, the choice of format, the EMOTIONS! It all comes together perfectly.This movie deserves a 10/10. Cillian Murphy's acting is flawless. The supporting cast elevate his performance to a whole other level. This is based off history. Academics who are forced to make a weapon of mass destruction and the turmoil that comes with it. Morality, guilt and elation is all portrayed beautifully. I would love to see it again for the first time and have my mind blown all over again.This movie is a masterpiece in every way.This is film-making at its finest. Hope Nolan keeps it going and makes more films like this.

There is a moment. Right after the detonation. We see the horrific realisation on his face in a realm of silence. The pure form of terror in its most subtle form as he understands what he has done. And just for a moment you realise along with him that the world has been changed.When the final scene finished playing and the score came to its conclusion there was a brief period of stillness throughout the audience as everyone momentarily considered what they had just witnessed. And for the first time in my cinematic experience I was just lost for words. As everyone left their seats and my dad and my friend spoke to me I just sat there pondering the meaning of it all, barely replying. And then I realised myself that I'd never been affected by a film in that way before. There are those that I have enjoyed more than this, that have brought out more emotions in me and even those that I consider better made. But the visceral experience that was. It was just phenomenal.Perhaps I have been blown away to an extent that isn't widely felt. But I think that most of us can agree that Nolan has presented us with his masterpiece no matter how it compares to his previous filmography and what we prefer or not. By placing all the elements of this film together with all the hard work so many have put into it we have been delivered something of brilliance. A hauntingly beautiful score from Ludwig Göransson which gave me chills whenever it played that masterful crescendo of power. The incredible sound design that packs an almighty punch emphasising the true power behind these horrifying creations. The alluring cinematography of Hoyte van Hoytema suitably demonstrating both claustrophobic discomfort and breath-taking pictures of art. The screenplay exhibiting the true power of words both from those spoken by real life figures and Nolan's careful hand. The performances of the cast as a whole bringing these people to the big screen in fascinating ways but most notably of Cillian Murphy and his outstanding and without a doubt Oscar-worthy take on Oppenheimer and of Robert Downey Jr reaffirming his acting prowess in the portrayal of Lewis Strauss. And finally, the considerably fantastic direction of Christopher Nolan to administer this truly wonderful experience which somehow feels like a culmination of all his work that came before.I can't say it was without flaws unfortunately. I felt at points it became a little dragged out which took me out of the experience and the editing also felt a little too choppy to the point where it was hard to follow sometimes. However, the pacing may have been from my own fault of focusing too much on the adrenaline fuelled sequences of visceral sensation preventing me from admiring the significance of the sections of lower tempo and the editing was clearly deliberate to present the chaotic nature of the reality behind this complex period in modern history.I spent a few brief instances looking around at the audience And it reminded of my love of the cinematic world. The silence as everyone is completely immersed in what we are being shown. The impossible task of tearing your eyes from the screen. The pure engagement of this new world that you have been transported to. That is what film is about.But truly, above everything, despite any of my overall opinion of entertainment or issues with the film. It was one of the greatest filmic experiences I've had and I honestly just cannot decide on how I feel about it all. It has completely thrown me.There are numerous fantastic sequences within the film but the one that stood out to me was the ending. I will not unveil what it is or does but I was so overwhelmed with pure emotion that my eyes just glistened and a tear rolled down my cheek. With one final crescendo after all the symbolism, all the visual cues, all the foreshadowing, all the exploration of humanity, the consequence of action, the power of comradery, the fear of man. Nolan brings the hammer down with a consideration of reality and what we have done.And it is terrifying.

A very well crafted and intriguing look into the man who changed the world forever but it's not for everybody...As a fan of Nolan and of all things history, I was excited to watch a film about J Robert Oppenheimer and prepared for it not to be a typical Nolan Movie. Whilst this is masterfully created and feels great in IMAX, it's not a movie that will resonate with everybody especially those who aren't interested in the subject matter.Oppenheimer is a character study into the thoughts of the so called 'Father of the Atomic Bomb' leading up to the Manhattan project prior to when the atomic bomb was created and its aftermath when Oppenheimer had a bigger but different voice within the atomic energy scene.I enjoyed insight into the world of a Theoretical Physicist and the dynamic between the science community and that of the US Army. Whilst this isn't a science based film that goes heavy into the detail, we did get to see Oppenheimer's rise through the field and several interesting discussions with his peers. We also get an insights into his personal life. Like many geniuses, he had a few skeletons in his closet.The acting from Cillian Murphy and Robert Downy Jr was immerse as was most of the performances from the supporting cast. The sounds design was excellent and the testing of the atomic bomb was my favourite scene followed by the hearings. However my favourite part of the movie was Ludwig Goransson's dark, scientifical score. There were so many scenes where you felt the score elevating the mood or tension.This movie is not for everybody. Whilst I enjoyed the movie and was especially intrigued by how Oppenheimer was viewed by those around him. It's a three hours long dialogue heavy character piece that I wouldn't necessarily recommend to all of my friends. I didn't find it slow but there are parts that are slower than others and viewers that aren't interested in the subject matter or who miss story beats may struggle to stay on board or remain invested. Whilst this isn't my favourite Nolan film, it's masterfully made and an intriguing, insightful work into a man who changed the world forever.

I mean I don't know what most people saw here, but this was a bore fest. Amazing cast, great acting , superb cinematography and sound. But that's about it. Except few moments in the movie, rest was complete borefest. Half my theater was sleeping after 45 minutes. Werner Brothers might buy some reviewers to give great reviews and Nolan fan boys might go ga ga over it,.but that's usual with most of his movies. Box office, it won't last over few days.I mean majority history of the atomic bomb was left put. The challenges with the actual science, material, building up those towns , the race for the bomb . Nothing. All interesting things were left put and the movie focuses on boring tale of oppenheimers trial. Seriously. You missed the most interesting part of that history.

Christopher Nolan depicts an epic biopic of the life of Oppenheimer. There isn't a single flaw with this movie. The pacing is perfect, with the use of time jumps Nolan provides an entertaining look into the life of J. Robert Oppenheimer. The artistic use of black, white and color gives the viewer two different perspectives on the movie. The acting performances from Cillian Murphy, Robert Downey jr and the entire supporting cast are nothing short of exceptional and just go to show that Nolan's casting is perfect. Once again Nolan has proven he is not limited by genre by making his best work. Truly a masterpiece, I expect it will pick up various awards as what I believe to be movie of the year.

From the direction of Christopher Nolan. To the amazing soundtrack that makes every intense scene get you on the edge of your seat. To the beautiful acting of Cillian Murphy, and Robert Downey Jr., and Matt Damon, and Emily Blunt, and so many more. When I went to the theater watching this film, I thought in the back of my head that I knew the story and I knew the outcome. But Christopher Nolan still manages to dive deep down in reveal the story in ways I never thought. It's gonna be one of the best movies for a very long time. The only thing I can say is go out watch this movie. And do not miss a second of it because every scene and every word spoken matters. I can't wait to see what Christopher Nolan cooks up next!

During the Cuban missile crisis, the crew onboard B-59, one of the four Foxtrot-class Soviet submarines sent to waters around Cuba, had been out of contact with Moscow for days. Infrequently picking up civilian radio transmissions, the nuclear-armed submarine was too deep to be in sync with the outside world, to know if war had already been broke out, as it's been busy hiding from American naval pursuers. Captain Savitsky and the Political Officer Maslennikov decided to launch a nuclear torpedo, the authorization of which normally requires only the confirmations from the two officers. The launch, according to military estimates, would have caused a chain reaction, resulting in a thermonuclear conflict destroying the better parts of the northern hemisphere. With reputations preceding him, Executive Officer Vasily Arkhipov utilized the special circumstance requiring the confirmations of all three officers, objected to the launch, preventing the onset of nuclear war. Roughly 20 years later, a similar fate was averted when officer Stanislav Petrov at the command center of the Soviet early warning system Oko decided that the multiple reports of intercontinental ballistic missile launch were false alarms, disobeying military protocols requiring him to relay the alarms up the chain of command (at the likely cost of his entire life and career), otherwise leading to a retaliatory attack with unimaginable consequences.These incidents were the closest that the world has ever been to annihilation. They also weren't what this film was about. But, upon learning them, one should have a different understanding of what it was trying to say.What critics of this movie won't recognize, is that the hundred-million dollar project that puts us in the shoes of a man who can only be either likened to Prometheus, the one who brought life to humanity, or Shiva, the one who would bring it to its demise, was destined to be flawed from the get go. Christopher Nolan, who also wrote the screenplay, had a hefty burden of balancing the different aspects of the theoretical physicist's life: by design, it's bound to overemphasize the science and the politics, because one simply can not exist on its own without delving deep into the other, thereby stretching the runtime even further. Art is not about capturing the different faces of a three-dimensional solid body on a two-dimensional plane (like Descartes wrote in his Discourse). In fact, it can't. The film wasn't trying to be a biopic, laying out that special someone's life story, dramatizes his achievements and downplays the parts that don't contribute to them. Nor is it trying to be a political documentary that confronts the horrendous and grotesque realities behind these doomsday gadgets (as a matter of fact, it barely touched upon them, unlike Mick Jackson's nightmarishly-realistic Threads, a film literally everyone must see). It's only a few peeks into certain fragments of Oppenheimer's life, those that when taken together help us define his ego, his resolve, and his ordeal.It should then come as little surprise, in a three-hour long picture with seldom time to breath, with scenes literally bereaved of an opening and a closing, and with imageries and sounds designed like a ticking time bomb, that the two female supports never got the chance to develop into coherent personalities and make a lasting impression, that the experiences of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki atrocities were completely glossed over. These are less flaws than byproducts of this sort of structural arrangement. Like the man himself, whose legacy is as self-contradictory as peace and armageddon, the distance between which now becomes the pluck of a single lower-rank officer, the film, being about the author behind the first atomic bomb, ipso facto fails to do justice to the humanitarian consequences of the Trinity Test, which are patently undeniable and morally complicated. Likewise, the picture, being about something with immeasurable implications which only a few could fully comprehend (much less deal with), can pay no more respect to Oppenheimer's personal life than the field equations can to Albert Einstein's acquaintance with Kurt Gödel. Given these confines that came with the material, Nolan and his team did the absolute best they could. If Memento was the proof of his editing talent, and Inception was that of his creative talent, and Dunkirk was that of his directing talent, this picture should be the proof of his audacity.

This movie is long and mostly dialogue but the time passes by quickly. Unlike other Nolan movies, this one doesn't have any fast paced action sequences but relies on characters, dialogue and the score to drive it along. Most bad reviews on here are from people who don't have an interest in the subject matter or were looking for an action packed blockbuster.This however is a different Nolan film that is in a masterclass. I haven't seen many dialogue films that have used the score to drive along the story so well. It is booming throughout and keeps the audiences adrenaline up through the long runtime up. The fast paced change of timelines keeps viewers on their toes and engaged.As someone who believes the movie is only as good as its music I'd say this is a homerun. It must be seen in Imax or with surround sound to truly be appreciated.

A typical Nolan film that forces the audience to have full engagement and use their head throughout the entire film to fully understand the surrounding plot. The plot is designed perfectly and depicts Oppenheimers life much more deeply than I suspected walking into the theatre. The cinematography was beautiful, as expected with Nolan. The music and theme was fantastic. The acting was absolutely phenomenal, and Nolan's ability to build each character deeply was crucial to the plot. Finally, the ending was perfect, it brought everything together and gave the audience a chilling sensation as they left the theatre with a jaw dropping experience.

In my opinion, Nolan made an excellent movie that talks about Oppenheimer, the plot is not only about the atomic bomb, it also has to do with the Manhattan project and what happened after using the bomb, the cast is perfect, all the performances are good, but the performances by Cillian Murphy, Robert Downey Jr. And Emily Blunt are spectacular, Ludwig Göransson's soundtrack is very good, the direction and photography is impeccable, I loved that they didn't use cgi, for all those reasons it's one of my movies Nolan's favorites and they will possibly win many Oscars For example, Best Supporting Actor for Robert Downey Jr. Best Picture and the Oscar for Cillian Murphy.

Wow, a three non-stop caprivating hours at the cinema. Fantastic acting actoss the board, especially from Cillian, Robert and Emily, they all deserve Oscar nominations.The music is tremendously captivating and Ludvig should win another Oscar for this one.As should Nolan himself for the script, the directing and the movie.Loved how the hearing and interrogation drives the movie forward in such a fast paste. The three hours felt very short.Also very interesting way of story telling to portray the the publicly available narrative and Oppenheimers personal narrative in black and white and colour respectively.Can't say which one is better, this one or Inception.

This film is a masterpiece of Christopher Nolan.The paradox of the invention of the Atomic bomb is incredible and we can see this over the entire film.The role that Cillian Murphy played was perfect and we can see both happiness and sadness in the caracther along the movie, it deserves a Oscar award.The sound and the images in general of the film was really Nolans work, the caracthers of the movie were with a very good image.This film is all about Oppenheimer and the other caracthers are just like a accessory of the film, just his wife and strauss have a little more development.In general a great movie!

There is two movies inside one. The first one is a hodgepodge of events and characters with a course on quantum physics. Tough to follow and uneven. Second part is much better but Nolan makes the first nuclear blast so suspensful that you do not have the energy to follow him mentally through the rest of the movie (Another 45 min at least of Salieri-themed intrigue). Of course, its a beautiful movie with top actors but it has a problem about the general structure of the story. It does not have the narrative fluidity of a Spielberg movie. Nolan is a great master technician but watching his movies always gave me the impression that he is directing his films while admiring himself in a mirror.

Up until Dunkirk, I loved Nolan's films. I saw Interstellar 3 times in the theater. The Dark Knight trilogy may be my favorite in the superhero genre. I had high expectations going into Oppenheimer. Sadly, I was falling asleep and checking my phone by the end of the first hour. So boring. The only thing in this film maybe worth watching only when it's available at home were the performances. Murphy and Damon mostly.Idk, I feel like all these people calling it a masterpiece are saying they like this movie because that's what they've been told to think. I don't see how anyone could've walked out of this film entertained in any sense of the word. I wanted to walk out an hour before it was over, which I can only remember doing a couple times in my life. The only reason I stayed was because my nephew wanted to see the end and I didn't want to ruin the experience for him. Thoroughly disappointed.

This movie is near perfect. A wonderful character study/political drama that ultimately reminds us all the potential of being sent back to the Stone Age. The potential of having Nukes sent to you at any moment is akin to having a gun held to your head 24/7. What if you grow up in a society that was born with a gun to its head? It's easy to forget it's there.The movie masterfully brings to life the story based on the book, American Prometheus. I saw this movie twice and after the first time I was amazed, after the second watch I thought it was absolutely perfect!I was not only be shocked but disappointed if this doesn't take away a lot of Oscars and awards, especially Cillian Murphy!! Murphy solidified himself as one of the great actors of our generation here. In the world of film, Christopher Nolan holds a high bar for storytelling. With 'Oppenheimer,' he once again proves why he's at the top of his game. I'm fully aware that critiquing the work of an auteur like Christopher Nolan could be perceived as snobbish. Hence, I'd try to be objective in this review.Firstly, it's a biopic. There's nothing quite unique about a biopic as the imaginative works of Nolan like the Inception or Interstellar. Hence, there is only so much he can do to be creative in directing Oppenheimer. It's just history, and there is nothing much to spoil there. This movie is a take on the personal predicaments and political persecution of scientist Dr. J Robert Oppenheimer who headed the Manhattan Project which resulted in the creation of the atomic bomb and as a consequence millions of innocent people lost their lives in the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.Secondly, there is a known pattern of human behavior which always targets the best of us when their job is done. Meaning, eminent scientists being harassed by the system once they have achieved great success is a recurring theme. We find that in the story of Alan Turing in the Imitation Game, in the story of Nambi Narayanan in Rocketry and so many others. It is common to find scientists working on technologies of strategic importance being framed for treason or similar cases and then being questioned for their loyalty to their nation. It's simply an occupational hazard. What can I say? Never build things for the government!Thirdly, movies about American supremacy growing out of the Second World War and the subsequent cold war are stereotypical. We are quite over them. We just see them in different light now. President Truman's two bit rebuff of Oppenheimer is as asinine as it can get. It's cartoonishly evil. Perhaps it serves as the explanation of why no one ever committed suicide for being part of the decision to drop those bombs. Instead everyone just kept bickering over bruised egos for not being amply credited for the wonderful devastation which brought an end to the war.Also it feels like Nolan is showing off by bringing on-board every brilliant actor out there for minor roles and cameos. Additionally, it could be a nerd's wet dream to see the glimpse of every founding genius of particle physics being name called and paraded as part of the plot but as a student of physics myself, I'm cringing.Furthermore, the use of Bhagwat Gita reference was not given justice. The reason why Oppenheimer quoted those famous lines about becoming "destroyer of worlds" could have been treated better and not in a clichéd scene which could just be dismissed as some orientalist's curiosity with foreign religion. The movie didn't soak in the actual philosophy of which Oppenheimer was a keen student in real life.The idea of a scientist who created the ultimate weapon of mass destruction growing a conscience and getting punished for that is a bit of a routine drag. I think this is where Oppenheimer contrasts with Heisenberg. While Oppenheimer set aside all his personal doubts to create the atom bomb for US government knowing well that he won't have any say in its use (In-fact he was highly enthusiastic about it initially) Heisenberg and his team of scientists working on the same project for the Nazis did not show that same motivation. I believe that's where Heisenberg's character far exceeds Oppenheimer's. Let's not delve in assessing such historical giants with our current worldview.You can watch a movie called 'The Catcher was a Spy' on how USA deployed a baseball star to spy on Heisenberg to know if he's close to creating the atom bomb and if so, assassinate him. Critics didn't like the movie much. However I like it better than this.Comparing with the body of work of Nolan, Oppenheimer does not feel like his best. It's an over emphasized effort to dazzle the world with the scale of production. We are sitting on the verge of a world war III with very real threat of a nuclear annihilation and we still don't care if the world will come to an end.

With so many high ratings, I figured this would be a really good movie, but I was disappointed. Many of the scenes are long and drawn out way beyond what they should be, and much of the movie is quite boring overall. The movie did have parts that were interesting and other scenes with a lot of tension, but they were a minority. This is a 3 hour movie, and I honestly think they could have trimmed this down to half that and made it 90 minutes and none of the story would be missed.The movie was also quite scattered, continually jumping around to different time periods which got annoying and made it a little hard to follow sometimes.I think this movie was over-hyped just because Christopher Nolan directed it. I can imagine a social experiment where this movie was released with Christopher Nolan's name concealed and instead an unknown director is listed. I'll bet in that case there wouldn't be anywhere close to the turnout this movie received and the rating would be something like a 6.Overall, it wasn't a terrible movie, but it certainly wasn't good either and I wouldn't recommend it.

Oppenheimer (2023) is an extraordinary film that captivated my senses from start to finish. This historical drama, directed by the brilliant Christopher Nolan, weaves a mesmerizing narrative that delves deep into the life of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the brilliant physicist whose work changed the course of history during World War II.From the moment the film begins, the audience is transported back in time to the tumultuous era of the 1940s, and Nolan's impeccable attention to detail immerses us into the historical setting effortlessly. The cinematography is awe-inspiring, and the breathtaking landscapes blend seamlessly with the authentic period settings, bringing Oppenheimer's world to life.The casting is nothing short of perfection. Cillian Murphy delivers an Oscar-worthy performance as J. Robert Oppenheimer, capturing the complexity and inner struggles of the enigmatic physicist with unparalleled depth. His portrayal is nuanced and compelling, allowing us to empathize with Oppenheimer's moral dilemmas and the burden he carries as the father of the atomic bomb.The supporting cast, including talented actors like Jessica Chastain, Michael Caine, and Tom Hardy, further enriches the movie, elevating it to cinematic greatness. Each character is beautifully crafted and contributes significantly to the story's emotional weight.One of the most impressive aspects of Oppenheimer is its intelligent and thought-provoking script. Kudos to the screenwriters for expertly exploring the ethical questions surrounding scientific discoveries during wartime, the moral responsibilities of scientists, and the consequences of unleashing such powerful weaponry on the world.The film's score, composed by the incomparable Hans Zimmer, is nothing short of a symphonic masterpiece. It amplifies the emotional impact of every scene, pulling at our heartstrings and enhancing the overall experience.Christopher Nolan's direction is, without a doubt, a work of art. His ability to interweave historical events with human emotions and philosophical musings is nothing short of genius. He masterfully guides the audience through a rollercoaster of emotions, leaving us contemplating the consequences of our actions long after the credits roll.Oppenheimer is not merely a historical retelling; it's a powerful reflection on the frailty of humanity, the pursuit of knowledge, and the consequences of playing with forces beyond our comprehension. This film will undoubtedly leave a lasting impression on anyone fortunate enough to witness it on the big screen.In conclusion, Oppenheimer is an unparalleled cinematic experience that deserves every single one of its five stars. Christopher Nolan's visionary direction, outstanding performances, breathtaking cinematography, and emotional depth make this film a true masterpiece. It is a must-watch for anyone who appreciates the power of storytelling and the impact of historical events on the course of human history.

You really need your wits about you to follow this film. There are frequent and often quite rapid cuts to different time periods, perhaps a little overdone at times. Nolan helps by filming all of the Lewis Strauss (played beautifully by Robert Downey Jnr) scenes in black and white.The pace is relentless yet I still felt the film was just a little bit too long - the first hour in particular was at times even a little boring. Once we get to the Trinity test, the film absolutely soars - although everyone knows what happened, the film becomes breath-taking and powerful. The subsequent scenes involving the witch-hunt against Oppenheimer and the senate hearings to confirm Strauss's cabinet position are impressive.The acting is uniformly good, especially RDJ. I thought Cillian Murphy's portrayal of Oppenheimer was good but just a little too quixotic - you're never quite sure exactly what he believes, especially in the first half. It was great to see Tom Conti again, although maybe a little miscast as Einstein. Florence Pugh was given a few rather gratuitously explicit sex scenes, which I thought were just a little too bizarre. And as usual there were very good performances from Emily Blunt and Matt Damon.Another major gripe is the soundtrack - appropriate in style but way too loud, detracting from the visual experience at times.All in all a powerful but imperfect movie, certainly worth seeing, but it will require your intense concentration to keep up with the chaos at times. Not quite a masterpiece in my book.

Oppenheimer was the manifestation of the type of story Nolan had been itching to tell all his career. But this is where the beauty of Oppenheimer lies. It perfectly captures the chaotic, emotionally draining, and painfully glorious life of the father of the atomic bomb.The epic scores added a new dimension to the film. Thanks to the genius composition of Ludwig Goransson, fans lived the movie through their screens. Much like Nolan promised, fans felt the explosion of the Trinity Test. The VFX and sound work done to include Oppenheimer's words "now I am become death, the destroyer of worlds" only added to its poetic nature.Oppenheimer might be no Inception or Interstellar, but the richness of the story, and the purity of his directing have ensured it's not only Nolan's richest masterpiece to date, but one of the finest movies of the 21st century as well.

Oppenheimer is a dialogue heavy film that covers the development of the atomic bomb and the devastating impact and threat it posed to the world at the time and even nowadays.In Oppenheimer, Nolan has shifted genres from his usual Sci-Fi to a Biopic/Drama. Instead of his usual mind bending topics, Oppenheimer is more focused on characters and their relationships with each other, which could be considered a more 'straightforward' film.The film is 3 hours long and involves many jumps in time. The beginning of the film is fairly slow paced, however speeds up by the middle and end.The technical aspects were great, with beautiful visuals accompanied by a very captivating musical score. However in some specific scenes, the background music becomes a distraction and muffles the speech.The entire cast were amazing with one of Cillian Murphy and RDJ's best performances.Overall, having seen the movie twice, I would recommend Oppenheimer. Some people may consider it 'boring' which is understandable due to the vast amount of information packed in. For Nolan lovers such as myself, Oppenheimer varies greatly from his other films but still worth a watch.

The most important film ever made. After each viewing - by now I have the third behind me - this opinion solidifies. The exceptional director Christopher Nolan once again succeeds in projecting onto the big screen, with incredible attention to detail, unprecedented narrative structure and groundbreaking audiovisual design, the themes that have accompanied mankind since time immemorial and that make us ourselves a projection screen: Betrayal, death, time, love, the thirst for knowledge and progress. If Christopher Nolan has always based his previous works on these themes latently and sometimes individually, in Oppenheimer he unfolds them in a bundled and cumulative manner, questioning them anew throughout the film and thereby constructing them anew. Oppenheimer is a film that revitalizes, even reanimates, the institution of cinema, which was believed to be dead. The scenes in which the atomic bomb is tested and its dropping on Hiroshima is "glorified" in a speech by Oppenheimer are among the best that cinematic art has ever produced. The final section leaves one stunned, thoughtful, and at times disturbed. And that is exactly the task and the unique selling point of a movie theater. A mixture of biopic, horror film, courtroom drama and thriller - tightly packed and intricately knotted as only a Christopher Nolan is capable of. Oppenheimer is a film that society needed. After countless superhero and other CGI-drenched films in recent years, Nolan's 'Opus Magnum' is both an aesthetic delight and an existential challenge for our gray brain cells. That's exactly where the important questions burn themselves in after the viewing: Why is man trying to extinguish himself? What is progress worth at the expense of human lives? And how the hell did the British director manage to translate such a brute production into picture and sound?

The story of J Robert Oppenheimer 'the father of the Atomic bomb' in the hands of Christopher Nolan is a somewhat over inflated dialogue heavy affair. The film flashes back and forwards in time, and is often engrossing, particularly during build up to the first A-Bomb test, but it also gets bogged down in talky scenes focused on political and scientific controversies both during and after WW2. I thought that perhaps a more economical approach could have made Oppenheimer truly gripping and great, and could have helped explore more effectively the post WW2 period when Oppenheimer fell foul of McCarthy era investigations. I also found the music score often unnecessarily intrusive and annoying, further highlighting a sense of the film being just a bit over done, however, there were still things to savour, not the least an uncannily vivid and convincing performance by Cillian Murphy as Oppenheimer, plus many other excellent performances, effectively making the acting the best thing about the film. I thought Oppenheimer was a largely coherent and informative though rambling portrait of the man, wonderfully performed, meticulously written and directed by Nolan, but just pretty good when just a bit more economy might have made it great.

I didn't even know who Julius Robert Oppenheimer was until the announcement of the movie was made (forgive me that I only focused on histories in my country), so I did a lil bit of research before watching the movie and learned all about the Manhattan Project, Navajo miners, the Trinity Test, the Oppenheimer security hearing, the Chevalier incident, and McCarthyism.I'm not a fan of biography or war films, so I was actually scared going in, thinking that I'd be bored to death, but nope, it's actually not boring at all. This is my first time watching a Christopher Nolan movie in a cinema, so I was so excited to experience it on the big screen, and as expected, I left the theatre satisfied.What I like most about the movie is the score, which is so chilling, powerful, and epic. It's not Han Zimmer, but still, Ludwig Göransson has a strong discography. I also like how some shots in the movie are interchanging with particles and explosions, as it gives a more intense feeling. I love that one scene everyone is talking about and how eerie it is with the screaming noises and bombing parallel.I was hoping to see more on the effect of radiation on the uranium miners and how they were being treated, but it's not included in the movie, which is understandable considering the lengthy runtime. I'm slightly disappointed that the movie didn't explore more of the "spy" character. The reveal is underwhelming because I didn't even realize who he was until he was mentioned towards the end.All of the cast did an amazing job, but (don't attack me) Matt Damon's delivery of the lieutenant general's lines sounds goofy in that one scene from the trailer. I got emotional watching Emily Blunt's performance as Oppenheimer's wife, Kitty. Cillian Murphy's role as the "father of the atomic bomb" is outstanding. He might finally win an Oscar. You can clearly see his conscience and wonder whether Oppenheimer was a brilliant physicist who fell victim to McCarthyism or if he was only a hypocrite trying to cover his inner communism. "Now I am become Death, the destroyer of worlds."I will never rate a movie a 10/10, so I gave it an 8 because there are parts that confused me, especially with the names of the characters considering its massive lineup, the time jumps, and the whole communism thingy, despite the movie differentiating the scenes with a B&W filter.It's ironic that I decided to watch Oppenheimer entirely because of the Barbenheimer trend since I originally planned to only watch Barbie, but somehow I like Oppenheimer more 🤣 P/s: I was looking forward to seeing Devon Bostick the most because RODRICK RULES 🤣🤘

We will certainly see him holding the Best Actor soon.Definitely recommend and look forward to watching again.

Absolutely stunned by this film, it's a cinema lovers MUST. I was drawn within the opening scene and left speechless by the last, Cillian gives one of the best leading performances I've ever seen and the cast backing him are incredible. A Nolan masterpiece my favourite of his so far! If you are second guessing because of the run time just go with the flow and indulge in this experience and I doubt you will regret it.I loved how Nolan came up with the idea of having this film in the first person giving the lead a proper spotlight and shine on what a incredibly intelligent and also trouble man that Oppenheimer was and also I loved how the 2nd person shots were black and white which really helped divide the story, it gave it a different dynamic and point of view for thr audience.

If you look somewhere else for a brief second you will miss a key detail or a line and it really ruins your day , for a three hour movie it really is hard to focus and understand but if you manage to stand still it really makes you think about perspectives and peoples point of view ,other than that it really is a masterpiece. You really feel the view of Oppenheimer and it makes you think about how unsecure people believe the whole world shapes around them. At the end though i dont have any think to say really, for a Nolan movie you probably can not leave the movie theater more satisfied and relieved.

"Oppenheimer" is an extraordinary cinematic achievement that delves into the life of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the brilliant physicist and leader of the Manhattan Project. The film skillfully weaves together historical accuracy with captivating storytelling, offering viewers a deep insight into the complexities of his character and the moral dilemmas faced during the creation of the atomic bomb. With outstanding performances and breathtaking cinematography, "Oppenheimer" keeps audiences engaged from start to finish. A must-watch for history enthusiasts and anyone seeking a thought-provoking cinematic experience.

The way that Nolan show the things sometimes objective sometime subjective made the film to understand the way it goes to. I thought only before bomb scenes were there and I really thought that film is finished when the bomb drop down to Hiroshima. In the interrogation scenes the way turnover is like WOW. And while you watch the film you are into it you feel every emotion. Of course I don't need to say actors were really perfect. Casting was really fitted their character. I liked the Nolan showed politics not straight. (eg: He didn't mention Nazis at all) I mean that we are just watching oppenheimer not World War 2.

This movie has three distinct thirds, two of which I believe are extremely bloated and poorly executed. Don't get me wrong this movie is incredibly well made, well acted, and beautiful to look at, but it's also flawed.Backstory and slow moving plots are perfectly fine, but it still needs to be engaging. The first third of the movie moves at a snails pace, and it not engaging in the slightest. I love slow moving dramas, but the characters need to be interconnected and the plot needs to move, here it does not.The second third is pretty great, having a slow build up to a powerful climax. Not much to say here, it's a good hour.The final third of the movie is stronger than the first but still lacks engagement. Straus's? Moves against Robert come across un-impactful and thus the entire third act just isn't overly fun to watch.Many have said it, but 3 hours is simply not needed for this film. I would take 30 minutes off of the first third, 40 off of the last, and add 20 to the middle to add more time in the best part of the film.Overall, it's a well made movie, most likely a good movie; But it's also not an engaging or entertaining movie.

I personally did not like the non-linear structure of the film. The way that Nolan tried to spin Strauss's betrayal as suspense was lackluster and off-putting . Firstly, the structure really just made the trial lack build-up. Practically, the last ten minutes or so is where things unfold haphazardly. Almost trying to piece together a cop-out climactic surprise villain ending. Then 'thematic' suspense is just off-putting for what it was trying to do, create a complex view of Oppenheimer. By the end, he was just doing Spielberg's school of Heroes vs Villain. Strauss, very bad man. Oppenheimer, complex but mostly good. Its too simplified for comfort. The use of time could have been more effective in showing the change that the film aims to show with Oppenheimer's view of the bomb to be honest.It had more success in telling the pre-trial Oppenheimer. I think its much more successful in creating the enigma of Oppenheimer. You could see him weak, uncompromising, a bit psychotic, and just a tad bit hypocritical. I felt that some portion can be edited down clearly, especially the Communist period or the pre-Alamo days, which was while important in the trial, does not really hold any weight once told verbally. It is what it is, people he had knew. The relationship between his wife and him could have been the better choice to focus on. The three hours is not entirely necessary for the film to be honest.Otherwise, the film is marvelous and well-crafted. I think Cillian, Emily Blunt, Matt Damon and Safdie were noteworthy in the film. The story could definitely had be tweaked. 3/5.

Oppenheimer is one of those films that manages to continue catching you despite reaching its ecstatic point (When the trinity test ends) and that manages to link a story from which there are so many points of view. The characters are excellently portrayed, a special mention to Cillian Murohy and Robert Downey Jr, they must be at the Oscars. The music is not far behind, it accompanies the scenes very well and manages to create that drama. One of my favorite scenes is when Oppenheimer gives his speech in front of the participants of the Manhattan experiment in Los Alamos after breaking the news of the "success" of the Atomic Bomb, it is here where we see the change of thought and behavior of a man who, trying to save the world, started a war worse than he expected. A movie is good and unique when it lasts 3 hours and during the 3 hours you are attentive to what happens in the plot, Oppenheimer manages to do that and keep viewers on edge throughout the movie.

This movie is probably one of the best movies I have seen in recent times and is going up there with movies im going to rewatch the rest of my life.First of all the life of an amazingly complicated man is super hard to portray in 1 or even 2 hours. If you look at the 3 hours as long before watching this movie, dont worry. I thought the same thing, I figured it would be a slow paced movie like an in-depth character study. But this movie caught me off guard. Christopher Nolan has paced this movie expertly, it is suprisingly fast paced at times, but it still takes it time to explore Oppenheimer's mind.Cillian Murphy was born to play this role, he expresses so much with just one look alone. All the actors in this just feel perfect and they all shine when on screen. There is not a singel person who feels "out of place": Nolan even took some chances with some lesser known actors like Norwigain actor Trond Fausa who plays a Ukrainian explosians expert. This is truly an Oscar-worthy preformance by the whole cast and from Nolan.What really sealed the deal on this movie was the soundtrack by Ludwig Göransson. He shined when making music for Disney for shows like The Book of Boba Fett and The Mandalorian. The score for openheimer is truly his lifes work. The score "Can you hear the music" gave me goosebumps every time it plays.This is a breathtaking movie, but I would recommend doing some degree of research before watching. There is a lot of talking and if you go inn blank on who Oppenheimer is you might get lost at some point.Lastly I want to mention the one thing keeping this from a 10/10. The mixing of the music and dialouge is awkward at times. I watched this with my father and he asked me multiple times throughout the movie what was said. It can be hard to hear what they say at times. But this is merely a technical issue and the cinematography and music and acting makes up for it easily.

This is just a cinematic masterpiece, but, the minutes leading to the bomb test moment and reaching that climax... the entire room just suddenly became absolutely silent. You couldn't even hear people breathing, it would literally be possible to hear a fly... what a moment that was. From that moment on until the end of the movie every body was apprehensive. I think is the best way to put it.The visuals, the sound, the storytelling, the performances, what an actual masterpiece. In my opinion this is the 2 best C. Noland movie (only toped by interstellar).If you can please watch it in IMax, it is worth it.

Nolan is back again in the game. Always using great shots, good actors, nagnificent performances and scenarios, making it ideal. The trama is good, it keeps you in the edge of your seat, nail bitting conversations, and helping with the memory on flashbacks to the characters with a lot of lastnames and not too many background for each (except Einstein), to improve the experience of the mlvie. Even with 3 hours long, it never felt like more than a 2 hour film, because it was so intense and you are so deep in the trama, that you dont see the time flow. Romantic scenes are short and precise, so it is a great overal movie to watch. Band reminds you to interstellar and Batman, so it is a great gesture. Psycho is intense with mind blowing scenes that leave you thinking on what could happen.Nolan, you are GREAT once more.

Masterpiece from a master.Title: "A Journey Through Time: Unraveling the Past"Rating: (5/5)I recently had the pleasure of watching the documentary film "A Journey Through Time: Unraveling the Past," and I must say, it was an awe-inspiring and thought-provoking cinematic experience. Directed with impeccable finesse and an evident passion for storytelling, this documentary transcends the boundaries of traditional filmmaking and takes its viewers on a captivating expedition through history, culture, and the essence of the human experience.From the opening scenes, the film immediately grabs your attention with breathtaking visuals and a stirring soundtrack that beautifully complements the narrative. The cinematography is nothing short of stunning, blending archival footage, striking landscapes, and intimate interviews to create a vivid and immersive atmosphere. Each frame feels like a carefully crafted piece of art, perfectly capturing the essence of the locations and historical events being portrayed.What truly sets "A Journey Through Time" apart is its meticulously researched and well-structured storytelling. The narrative flows seamlessly, guiding us through various epochs and cultures, connecting seemingly disparate events, and revealing the hidden threads that bind humanity together. The director's ability to seamlessly interweave personal accounts with historical facts is a testament to their storytelling prowess.The heart of the documentary lies in its profound exploration of human resilience, the triumph of the human spirit, and the interconnectedness of civilizations across time and space. As the film delves into significant historical events and cultural milestones, it provokes deep reflection on our collective past and the impact it has on our present and future.Equally commendable is the documentary's balanced approach to storytelling. It avoids glorifying or vilifying any particular historical figures or cultures, instead presenting a nuanced and comprehensive perspective on complex historical events. This commitment to accuracy and fairness enhances the film's credibility and makes it an even more valuable educational resource.Moreover, the narration and interviews are skillfully conducted, featuring insights from eminent historians, scholars, and eyewitnesses. The personal stories shared by individuals who lived through pivotal moments in history add an intimate and emotional layer to the film, making it all the more captivating and relatable.The runtime of the documentary might seem substantial, but the sheer depth of content ensures that every minute is well spent. It never feels tedious or overwhelming, and the pacing keeps the audience thoroughly engaged from start to finish.In conclusion, "A Journey Through Time: Unraveling the Past" is a documentary masterpiece that should not be missed. It enlightens, educates, and entertains in equal measure, leaving a lasting impression on its audience. It serves as a powerful reminder of the importance of understanding our past to shape a better future. Whether you're a history enthusiast or simply someone seeking a captivating and enriching cinematic experience, this documentary is an absolute must-watch.

The story is adapted from "The American Prometheus" by Kai Bird and M. J. Sherwin, a Pulitzer price winner book. Nolan being an exemplary director, depicts why J. Robert Oppenheimer should be or shouldn't why he wasn't America's Prometheus (a Greek Titan who stole fire from gods and gave them to mortals and was chained to eternity for this act). The movie covers every aspect of his life, his highs and his lows, his selflessness and his pride and strives to achieve an accurate depiction of an character as complex as "The father of Atom Bomb". But it's not just Nolan that shines in this film, almost everyone on the screen is at their best. Cillian's portrayal of Oppenheimer must be his best job till date and that isn't an simple statement considering the actor of his caliber, so do Matt Damon, Emily Blunt, Florence Pugh and Robert Downey Jr. In their roles. Camerawork and Sound is another thing, Christopher Nolan has mastered, and like his most other movies, Oppenheimer is no different when it comes to
Cinematography and Sound design. I haven't seen it in 2D yet, but the movie seems to be explicitly tailor made for IMAX, so it comes as no surprise that movies seems even better in it.The film however sometimes becomes a bit too fast paced, with some scenes spontaneously cutting black and transiting between Oppenheimer's past and present, lose focus for a moment and you might be confused for a moment. It does not hinder the storyline though, sometimes it works in story's favour sometimes it doesn't.I don't get why leading critics are accusing the movie to be an "History TV Movie" when it's much more than that.

"Raindrops like minute explosions. Human, enslaved with an godly unbearable burden"Oppenheimer is a manifestation of both immense and incomprehensible switch in a military dynamic of the previous epoch, giving birth to a new one, one we live in. Intense, suppressed, vague one. Masterfully played out by Nolan a quintessence of fear and ash-like bloodshed prospects, all in one man pushing the button.Introducing characters was an intense marathon, indeed, and yet it was motivated by a necessity of keeping the atomic tempo, the one that J. R. Oppenheimer was in. Every character has put a piece of him-/herself into Robert creating a complicated, almost fathomless conflict inside a man that can be barely grasped. And every character was sophisticatedly comprehended and analyzed by Nolan, making them appear so real on-screen. Not to mention how superb the Oppenheimer-Strauss dynamic was played out.In the end a viewer can see Robert in an abyssal regret, a question carved deep into his mind that is so hard to be answered, neither by him nor by the rest of humanity. At this moment the viewer is imbued with inner desolation.In technical aspect there is no arguing in an absolute proficient Nolan's approach to befitting depiction of a story; the music rushing through your ears down to your heart, skipping even the brain sometimes, to be properly perceived. And the whole importance for filmmaking not to forget what it was born for.Without any doubts this artwork will become a crucial memo, venerated by future generations of filmmakers and filmgoers. And rightly so.

SYNOPSIS
"Oppenheimer" is a gripping historical drama directed by Christopher Nolan, delving into the life of renowned scientist J. Robert Oppenheimer, who led the development of the atomic bomb during World War II. The film portrays Oppenheimer's moral dilemmas, political struggles, and the profound impact of his creation on humanity. Cillian Murphy delivers a mesmerizing performance as Oppenheimer, supported by a stellar ensemble cast including Robert Downey Jr, Emily Blunt, Matt Damon, and Florence Pugh. The film presents a compelling narrative intertwined with Nolan's signature non-linear storytelling.SOUND DESIGN
The sound design in "Oppenheimer" is nothing short of exceptional. From the grandiose background score to the meticulously crafted sound effects, it intensifies the emotional impact of the film. The gradual crescendo of the music heightens the tension, while the explosion sequences are brought to life with incredible authenticity. The sound editing skillfully complements the visuals, enhancing the overall cinematic experience.CINEMAOTGRAPHY
The cinematography by Hoyte van Hoytema is breathtaking, capturing the vastness of the New Mexico desert and the solitude of Oppenheimer's journey. The use of 65mm film projected in 70mm format adds a sense of grandeur to the scenes. Nolan's expert blending of black and white and colour visuals effectively accentuates the shifts in Oppenheimer's life and emotions, creating a visually stunning and immersive atmosphere.SCREENPLAY AND DIRECTION
Nolan's directorial brilliance shines through in "Oppenheimer," as he adeptly balances historical facts with human emotions. The screenplay is a testament to Nolan's storytelling prowess, captivating the audience with its powerful dialogue and intellectual depth. By artfully weaving together Oppenheimer's personal conflicts with historical events, Nolan creates a compelling narrative that keeps viewers on the edge of their seats. The director's non-linear approach adds layers of intrigue, seamlessly immersing the audience in Oppenheimer's world and struggles. Nolan's meticulous attention to detail and precise execution of complex scenes, notably the Trinity test, showcase his unparalleled talent as a director, ensuring the film remains unforgettable.CAST ACTING
Cillian Murphy's performance as J. Robert Oppenheimer is nothing short of mesmerizing. With a profound portrayal of the character's inner turmoil and moral dilemmas, Murphy captivates the audience throughout the film. The supporting cast, including Robert Downey Jr, Emily Blunt, Matt Damon, and all other actors, deliver equally powerful performances, complementing Murphy's portrayal and elevating the film to new heights. The chemistry among the actors adds authenticity to the characters' relationships, making the emotional journey all the more impactful. The Oscars are confirmed by me to cillian murphy and Nolan, they definitely deserve it.CLOSURE
"Oppenheimer" is a cinematic masterpiece that seamlessly combines history and human drama, leaving a lasting impression on its audience. With exceptional sound design, breathtaking cinematography, and Nolan's masterful direction, the film stands out as a remarkable addition to the biopic/drama genre. Cillian Murphy's mesmerizing performance as Oppenheimer and the ensemble cast's brilliant acting make this film an unforgettable cinematic experience. As viewers reflect on the consequences of scientific discovery and humanity's complexities, "Oppenheimer" stands as a poignant reminder of the power and responsibility that accompanies groundbreaking innovations. It is a film that only can be watched in a Cinema and experience it.

Like many people I admire Nolan as a filmmaker, I think he's the closes thing we have to a Kubrick in the modern day, not so much for his style or sensibilities but merely for the fact that each film he makes has ambition, often tackles different genres, they're high-budget films but also intelligent and artistically accomplished. Also his name is well known enough that each new film he makes is an event. Personally my favorites of his are Memento, Interstellar, The Prestige, Insomnia, I also admire Inception though it has some flaws imo. Don't care much for his Batman films, to me they are not entertaining enough and don't really capture the spirit of Batman from the comics (Tim Burton did a better job with that).However I often find his storytelling style a bit muddled and convoluted. I often find myself confused as to why characters are doing things, there is a lack of clarity for me in his films, and the frequent time jumps don't help either. I didn't care for his last two films, Dunkirk and Tenet, at all. Oppenheimer is a step up from those but not by a lot.The basic problem for me is a lack of tension and suspense in the film. Maybe it's because I know nothing bad happens to Oppenheimer, ok he gets removed from the program but it's not like he goes to jail or something. The supporting characters are all pretty interchangeable, the movie just didn't really grab me. We never get an idea of why Oppenheimer out of all people ended up being the person in charge of this Manhattan program.The details of how they got to the conclusion that he did have communist sympathies just wasn't compelling enough to me. Basically, nothing really bad happens to anyone in the film. You just learn a bit more details about how things went down surrounding this historic event but it's not gripping stuff at all.I give it a 7 out of respect for Nolan, Murphy's performance, the Trinity test sequence, and for me Tom Conti's portrayal of Einstein pretty much steals the movie, should have had much more screentime.

Oppenheimer is a story of a flawed protagonist that undergos no redemption arch. He is portrayed as 'above' regular human morality and at no stage shows any remorse for his many horrid acts that span decades of his life.There are no character throughout the film in which you root for nor empathise with. And some of the direction in this regard is questionable.Being a biopic it is to be commended that very little has been altered however this doesn't make the movie any more engaging and the few changes that have been made are bizarre choices in my opinion.Epicly acted and beautifully shot. RDJ is a particular stand out and Damon is as good as ever. As with every Nolan film there is enough art and audio to keep true cinefiles engaged.But this is the first cinema experience I've had in over a decade where multiple parties walked out. And I also witnessed people sleeping in the last hour.Somehow even the A-Bomb test is underwhelming. Although the tension in the build up is masterful.But Oppenheimers biggest crime is feeling so arrogant in its own awesomeness that to dislike it feels as though it's a problem with and that you're wrong. It is pompous. And extremely boring.I felt every minute of its 3 hour run time.Oppenheimer would serve as a great mini series or a factual documentary with dramatisation throughout.But as a standalone film I was far from blown away.I would give it 1 star except for that being disrespectful to the amazing acting and technological feats throughout.

As expected nothing less from the legendary director, the movie doesn't fail to meet up your expectations in fact it exceeds your expectations through the roof.It may seem that with respect to the plot or the general storyline it would be enjoyable to people who are more into .. science but I assure this movie has the essence that just drags anyone's attention to it, to an extent that you wont even know when the 3 hours passed.One other good point about the movie is that it didn't just portray just the science genre into it, it contained other subject matter into like politics, history, moral and ethical perspectives which made the movie much more interesting as it managed to effectively utilize these themes.Now besides plot and everything else, the core and essential factor of the movie which actually gives you the sensation of hype is the pure art of cinematography, acting and sound design. The way the scenes transition from past to present throughout the movie makes it unique and interesting to the viewers and ensures to capture the viewer's attention. The color scheme used too is quite interesting as it uses B/W for the events happening whereas colored events to describe Oppenheimer's story. Coming to the main point the sound design, its immaculate. The essence of sound and where, when and how it was used completely gave you goosebumps and the sensation of hype. Sound really played a vital role in ensuring your movie experience as a rollercoaster ride. The acting was perfectly executed as well, as throughout the movie it really makes you feel that rather than just acting it was from the heart, it had a very natural flow and felt very real.It might seem that the movie would just end after all the scientific "story" is done but the politics and drama used after made it just more interesting. You may not understand the complete political and drama part at one go but that's just the essence of the movie which makes you wanna watch it again and understand it better. This point automatically just says how good the movie is. It just wants to make you come back to it again.It would be a crime if i didn't mention CGI wasn't used. Hearing that at first it piqued my interest. When I watched the movie and saw how those explosions were made it really blew my mind. The details and the exaggeration on the explosion made it better than CGI. This is another fact why people are interested or hyped about the movie and it didn't fail to surprise them.In conclusion, this movie truly is a piece of art and the best 3 hours you would ever spend. The plot is immersive and the mastery of cinematography, sound design and application makes the movie a literal black hole that sucks all your attention, and the best thing is you couldn't get tired of it. So, overall the movie is a perfect experience and is guranteed to make you come back for more.

I get the movie and length may not be to everyone's taste, but good lord did this film have me hooked for the entire runtime. During the trinity test sequence, I was biting my fingernails and could feel my heartbeat in my chest. I can't remember the last time I was at the cinema and a movie had me feeling like that. Murphy, Downey Jr and Blunt were outstanding in their roles, and everyone else was great too. The score and sound design were incredible too. The scene in the gymnasium was genuinely terrifying and will stick with me, I thought it was handled perfectly. I would highly recommend watching this at the cinema if you could!

"Now I have Become Death, the Destroyer of the Worlds"The calm view of a tiny drop of rain water hitting a puddle and producing large waves of various wavelengths and the frightening view of a tiny atomic bomb, falling towards mother earth and wreaking havoc, producing astounding shock waves! Both are the inevitable forces of nature and attract the attention of a scientific mind. And amidst the extra-ordinary analogy of these two spectacular powers of nature, master filmmaker Christopher Nolan tries to explore the differences. The falling rain drop hits the puddle hard but doesn't cause any harm to any living beings; it's fundamental. Whereas, the nuclear forces extracted out of a splitting atom on purpose is a force of nature summoned by the Man. And who will take the responsibility and it's inevitable consequences?"Oppenheimer" is a horror story told in the truest and most delicate form of humanism. It can also be viewed as the character study of a complex Physicist and his inner conflicts juxtaposed by how the top persons in power look at them with wrong perspective. Was very fortunate to see first day first show of this masterpiece.There are four detonation sequences in the film literally and allegorically. First one was the celebrated Trinity Test of July 16, 1945 in Los Alamos. In order to know, what are the rest of the three, you have to experience this film. As as per as visual depiction is concerned, these are NOT the portrayal of bombing events of Hiroshima and Nagasaki which were ofcourse, the inevitable inhuman consequence of the "detonation". It's deeply philosophical, emotional and concerning; the sensibility what Nolan has mastered over the years. It will chill down your spine.For cine-lovers, the cross cutting of the scenes and their juxtapositions with picture perfect background score by Ludwig Göransson takes the emotion, tension and further characterisation to a new height. The bombing scene, the use of flash and fire, the words (of consciousness, "I am the death, the destroyer of the world" in the real Oppenheimer's voice) and the sound and shock are something what you have never experienced before. The performances are amazing and no words are sufficient to describe Cilian Murphy (his eyes), Robert Downey Jr and Emily Blunt. Performance of the later one is highly underrated (as I am seeing the reviews) but she did a tremendous job as a person witnessing the nasty politics as an independent individual. The lesser screen time doesn't make the performance no way thinner or lesser.Rest, there are many great films on Science Fiction but this one can be depicted as a great work on "Scientific Consciousness" , the consciousness what in spite of all the accomplishment tell us to introspect our choice and fate. It will be celebrated in years to come.

From the moment I say the first trailer, I knew I had to see this movie in the cinema's. Luckily, I was able to see the movie in a IMAX cinema yesterday and boy oh boy. This film ticks all the boxes. With ease it joins the ranks into my top 20 movies of all time. And that for a movie enthusiast that has seen a lot of excellent movies (top 100 idmb e.g.).ON: Everything is in place: actors, music, pacing, visuals. There is absolutely nothing what is not correct. Besides the great visuals and music, the 3 hours fly by, because Nolan knows how to keep the audience attention without effort for the viewer. The moment where you come for, the explosion, breathtaking..Also and in my opinion, Nolan is so strong in setting up a normal dialogue between people. It just feels as if you are -in- the conversation, the emotion in the face right at the moment when you would search for it if you were in that conversation. All those subtle, but essential details in directing that makes a 3 hour sit not feel like a long sit. The only thing you notice at the end is a soar back ha-ha.Besides the great directing and visuals, the (oscar-worthy) acting performance of Robert Downey Jr. And Cilian are also out of this world. Ever since "The Judge" and "The Peeky Blinders", I knew that these two would carry the film to new heights.Altogether, you HAVE to see this movie in cinema, because I think it is an insult to see it at home. A 10 out of 10 from me.

It is a wonderful movie and I enjoyed watching it. The movie contains the wonderful drama that we miss in our time, and it also contains many beautiful dialogues that make you live every second in the movie and also the characters in the movie who played their role in an impressive way such as Cillian Murphy who quoted the character and also Robert Downey Jr. And all the actors with sound effects and the good thing is that you did not use visual effects and that makes you live the reality and live that era in time (Now I am become Death, the destroyer of worlds) It's really cool, great work, Nolan.

The acting and directing are amazing. The lines hidden within every series of act will stuck with you. Very precise storytelling, it make you feel what exactly how you have to feel with every minute of it. The plots are complex but not confusing. All the conversations put together can be a little overwhelming, but overall, it draws back to the point every once in a while. Cillian Murphy is killing it, an awesome acted piece, same, makes you feel exactly how you need to feel with Oppenheimer. You can easily cry hard just watching the takes of his big close ups. The whole cast wonderfully acted as well. The soundtrack, the editing, it's a film with all fine arts putting together.

It is filmmaking at its best. This is CLASS A. It is in my Nolan top 4 for sure. Not ahead of Inception or Tenet, but somewhere near Dunkirk.The atmosphere of it intoxicates you. It gets under your skin and never leaves. This is how biopics about such historical figures should be made. This is Nolan's "12 Angry Men" meets "Memento". Brutally 9.5/10 for me.The decision of making it from the POV of Oppenheimer is extraterrestrial intelligence. The treatment of how to show the world the way he saw it is an amazing choice.Cinematography is revolutionary. Nolan, Hoyte, and Imax films are the Trinity of modern filmmaking. It makes me feel like if I was living in 1968 and watching Kubrick's 2001 for the first time. Rebellious filmmaking. Extreme to the core.The haunting experimental score of Ludwig Görannson is traumatizing. It captures the weird combination of history, science, science fiction, philosophy, horror, nervousness, self doubt, triumph, and tragedy.The acting in general is phenomenal. Cillian Murphy lost himself in the magic of the role, and Robert Downey Jr is Oscar contender. These performances will be remembered for a long long time. The small parts are also amazing. Bennie Safdie, Casey Affleck, and Matthias Schweigoffer are mesmerizing.The custom design, production design, and the whole decorations are capturing the spirit of the terrifying, yet astonishing 1940s.What really captured me is the work on clothes and make ups. The characterizations are so accurate and yet creative.The pace, scenery, dynamics, and themes are all showcases of Nolan's abilities as a world designer.So terrifying and satisfying. One of the most important films in the history of filmmaking.

I have a mix feeling about the movie.The 1st half of the movie feels like collection of tiktok/IG reels.With jumps going so fast, it was harder to focus on any one character or character development or story flow.It felt like the movie was going for punch line to punch lines like "the world with end with this bomb" and so on.They built the Los Alamos, but if you have no idea why Los Alamos was built, the security, the secrecy, the bare bone structure of the city, the long and hard working hours of the scientist there, then from those jumping scenes, it was hard to understand the importance of Los Alamos.Same way Niels Bohr flew from Germany, but the actor had a big smile on his face and he was asking can you make a bigger bomb. I mean, what was the reason behind him asking if the bomb is big enough. Why was Niels Bohr character even there, and why was he smiling.Also, from jumping of scenes, it was also hard to grasp that it took them 2-3 yrs of long working days to finish the gadget. There was no sense of time how much they spent time in Los Alamos.Like always Nolan's movie has of late got a real high music to the end that it has become difficult to hear the dialogues. If you don't have clear understanding of what happened from other sources, then the 1st half of the movie just felt like giving you an overview of the history but with a lot of jumps back and forth.The 2nd half of the movie after the test gets better. They take time in scenes to develop a narrative enough before jumping to next scene.I will definitely recommend watching season 1 of "Manhattan" tv show before watching the movie.

We have talking, more talking, again talking, then a bomb and then again talking talking talking.Plus confusing time zone mix-ups, women characters who are next to nothing (kind of a trademark of CN),
a soundtrack which is waaaay to much for this kind of biopic, a try to take all of his live into the movie and delivering next to nothing at all, a character study which isn't really one (since you don't know nothing about Oppenheimer by the end and what it did to him on a personal level) and you need to be prepared with his live before the movie otherwise you are missing to much.So in short: Not his best, not the masterpiece everyone wants it to be and the hype suggest. But please go and see it for yourself.

This is Nolan's best film by far and Kilian Murphy's work is amazing. He played very inspiring, if not for Killian I think Oppenheimer would not be so interesting. I really liked the fact that this film, although about science, managed to combine love, humor, and much more, and the viewer does not get bored watching the film. Every minute is interesting as Nolan himself stated. I'm still collecting my thoughts after experiencing this film, Cillian Murphy might as well start clearing a space on his mantle for the Best Actor Oscar. This film is a masterclass in weaving narratives and different time periods while exploring the profound depths of a man whose actions altered the world's trajectory forever, for better or worse. Nolan brings us into the complexities of Oppenheimer, and all the moral conflicts stirring within him. Murphy's portrayal is so riveting that the long run-time became an afterthought. Robert Downey Jr also offers a great performance and Nolan's push and pull with how he uses sound design throughout is the cherry on top. Some viewers might need a brief refresher on WWII and Cold War history, but any film lover should be happy to willingly lose themselves in this film for hours on end.
