Known for his science fiction, Christopher Nolan has always bent the boundaries when it comes to cinema. However, the way he managed to balance everything together was nothing short of almost perfect. There is no CGI in this movie, and the way he was able to capture a miniaturized explosion with that level of visual is just captivating. He's always been able to manage balancing innovative visual ideas and constantly manages to keep the story interesting while managing to respect the viewers themselves. When they test the bomb in the movie, I told my girlfriend to get ready and I had my feet braced like I was there for the test. What came next was silence and then pure power! The score to this film is beyond anything I've hear either. I was extremely interested when he chose to not to use Zimer as usual for his scoring of the film. However, Ludwig Goransson's music will have you melting in your seats. I've don't have the words to describe it. My head followed the camera. My ears were constantly on alert. The scenery was almost to good to be true. I really thought what he did with Dunkirk and stepping out of the sci-fi realm was his best work, but I can't wait to watch this again. 10/10.

Hamilton (the musical) is special for many reasons: amazing sung, racially diverse, phenomenally written. But most of all, because it provided our current generations a modern connection to and humanization of the founding of our nation. Though it is about their primary author, the musical is as much a subtle honorific of the Federalist Papers and their philosophy, which in turn shaped the Constitution and our whole way of governance.Oppenheimer is poised to play a strikingly similar connection and humanization of the US' great international turning point, it's rise as a superpower due to the advent of the atomic age.Nolan crafts a powerful dramatic documentary of Oppenheimer's adult life. It is beautifully shot; fantastically acted; perfectly written and paced. The music is spectacular.The plot humanizes the creation of the most inhumane device every created by our species. It did not glorify, yet it also did not expressly vilify, being more content to tell the story of the man who would become known as the father of the atomic bomb, not just the story of the bomb itself. There is the trappings of McCarthyism and anti-communism. There are the mundane flaws of the man and those around him. But Nolan crafts the story and its telling to make these the conduit. Oppenheimer is never actually about the power of communism, or of love, or lust; it's about the power of the atom, and you feel that pull throughout.When taken in as a whole, Oppenheimer immerses you in the moments when our nation truly entered the stage as a terrifying force of power, and perhaps peace. I left with a sense of awe; amazement; perhaps a dash of fear, at the retelling of that piece of our history.There is still more to unpack with Oppenheimer- the cinematics, the sound, the production. How the reservations of the scientists ring hauntingly similar to the concerns raised by AI researchers and climate activists. Such a multi-faceted film, that this humble review on IMDB will leave for another time.Brilliant, brilliant, brilliant.

Saw it in IMAX 70mm film and it's staggering in that format. Truly one of the most incredible movie experiences I've ever had. Visually it's beautiful, and the audio in an IMAX theater has to be heard (and felt) to be believed.It's one of the most interesting movies you'll ever see, even apart from the spectacle of it. It was a 3 hour movie that didn't feel anywhere near 3 hours, to me. The performances were outstanding. Honestly, I know Cillian Murphy is supposed to get the lion's share of the plaudits (and for good reason), but Robert Downey Jr. Was equally as good, I thought.However...Florence Pugh's character, although acted well, serves absolutely no purpose whatsoever other than to have another female and someone to perform in a sex scene. The sex scenes do nothing other than fill Hollywood's quota for nudity, and they felt so out of place in this film. It seemed like Nolan went "Alright, we've ticked the 'sex' and 'nudity' boxes, now we can kill her off".I also wasn't wild about Gary Oldman as Truman. He's a great actor who just seemed like a poor choice for that role.Predictably, the military personnel and politicians are all portrayed as unfeeling, pushy, and manipulative. There's obviously some truth to that, but I would like to have seen them given a bit more nuance and their predicament more consideration. And McCarthyism is an old trope for anything set in this era. Another subject I'd like to see given more nuance than the almost cliche way it's always treated.But having said all that and those complaints aside, it's a spectacular movie that I'll definitely be watching again. I hope Christopher Nolan continues making them for a long time, because he's the best there is right now.

Quite a frustrating watch to be honest. Being a big fan of biopics, history, war, science, and Nolan, this film was going to be one to remember fondly. But it is not the case. As the film ends, I'm only thinking how it leaves much more to be desired.Oppenheimer - a character study interspersed with events surrounding the Manhattan Project which feels more like a minor secondary plot. Unemotional and rather jarring to the point where one might be tempted to use the word boring were the political and courtroom plots. By trying to blend in two stories, one being the Manhattan Project and the other being the political/courtroom drama, it fails to deliver on both sides. Can't help but think it would do much much better just focusing on one or the other. Deliver 100% on one story rather than 50% on two mushed in ones. Personally, I feel much more excited whenever the story progresses on the Manhattan Project-side - the building of the bomb, the work differences of the scientists/military/politicians, the morals, the ethical dilemmas, the politics of the project. The film builds on those aspects then, deflates into the courtroom-like scenes, taking steam off any real weight, emotions, and connections.However, it's not all bad. Nolan delivers on the technical filmmaking and the cast delivers on the acting. Film and filmmaking lovers will have much to enjoy and awards are almost guaranteed I dare say. The acting was the best part of the whole film. Needless to say, Cillian Murphy delivers as Oppenheimer himself and as many, many others mentioned, Robert Downey Jr. Also stands out.All in all, it still is a Christopher Nolan film and it shows. Though, it leaves much to be desired for as it aspired to be much more but can't. Just like my life.

Furthermore, there was several scenes of a poor child suffering and crying, and in one scene the poor child's face was so red and swollen from constant crying that I was shocked and disheartened that the director would exploit this child to capture this unimportant scene. It really alarms me at how people are willing to degrade and harm other humans for their own selfish ego and gain.The third issue was the excessively loud bursts of background noise, that were randomly issued throughout. "Prometheus stole fire from the gods and gave it to mankind. For this he was chained to a rock and tortured for eternity."
What a way to start this rollercoaster. Christopher Nolan has more than succeeded in giving his audience what they expected with the epic biopic Oppenheimer, in which he revisits World War II after Dunkirk. As with all of Nolan's films, with the exception of a few glaring points, this is undoubtedly one of the best blockbusters to come out in recent years. While expecting a more understandable and plain editing compared to Nolan's other films since this being a history film, Oppenheimer was perhaps one of his most difficult films to follow. Nolan, who persistently refuses to make a movie in chronological order, avoided writing a linear screenplay for this movie as well.As he himself stated, Nolan, who wrote parts of the script in first person, conveys the film to the audience by intersecting many plot points from different time periods, including scenes with color that we see from Oppenheimer's subjective point of view, and black and white scenes where historical events are conveyed more objectively. Similar storytelling with his first big hit Memento but unlike that film this time it causes problems with the pacing of the intense three-hour story, with the inclusion of dozens of key characters and heavy dialogue. The film contains numerous side characters and putting all of their side stories on top of each other in the narrative is overwhelming from time to time. In this chosen narrative, which already is very deep and complex, missing a few small details causes the audience to not grasp the integrity of the story. From Oppenheimer's youth to the construction of Los Alamos, the pacing of the film was occasionally erratic. Some scenes felt like an endless trailer or like a documentary. Continuous and overwhelming dialogues made it difficult to acknowledge the whole plot of the story with the inconsistent pacing but in general, I would say that the film successfully fits this much material in 3 hours.The nudity used in Nolan's first R-rated movie since Insomnia in nearly 20 years seemed a little unnecessary. I find it ridiculous to use a section from Oppenheimer's famous monologue in one of these scenes. They've used the same famous quotes in the Trinity Test scene yet both times it failed to impress me. Oppenheimer's sex scene in the security hearing was also an odd choice that I didn't quite enjoy. I found it strange that Florence Pugh was used almost exclusively for nudity in this film, where I think we didn't had a chance to see her talent deservedly.Following the successful score on Tenet, Ludwig Göransson, whom Nolan trusted again, once again did an outstanding job. It is a masterpiece in itself, from Oppenheimer's soft and fascinating light theme starting from his youth, to dense violin sequences that intensify as we approach the Trinity Test. Göransson, who perfectly captured the core of the characters and the story from the beginning to the end of the film, takes the film to the next level with yet another unforgettable piece of art that allows us to integrate with the film on top of the already masterful, mind blowing sound mixing.As usual, most characters lack depth but as for the acting, in the rich casting of the movie, everyone was top-notch. With the exception of Florence Pugh not having enough screen time, Cillian Murphy, Robert Downey Jr. And Emily Blunt, who are among the biggest nominees for the Oscars this year, alongside Matt Damon, Benny Safdie, Rami Malek, Josh Hartnett, Jason Clarke, Alden Ehrenreich and Gary Oldman deserve individual praise for their tremendous performances. As an president once again, Gary Oldman had one of the most impressive roles despite having 2-3 minutes of screen time. And Jason Clarke just stole the spotlight troughout the entire film.For years Nolan received many criticisms for the lack of depth in general but especially for the female characters he wrote in his previous films but this time, Kitty Oppenheimer may be the most well-written female character in his filmography where it felt like she really had a voice.Working with Nolan for the fourth time, Hoyte van Hoytema's magnificent cinematography has some of the best set pieces I've ever seen. The climax of the movie, maybe the most impressive sequence I've ever experienced in the cinema, the Trinity Test scene, which I followed with my heart pounding with unbelievable tension despite all knowing what's going to happen. After that, the film runs flawlessly for me. Some people didn't like the fact that a new side story started right after the climax scene of the movie and it took about an hour to conclude that but I was very interested in the story where Lewis Strauss came to the action. It reminded me of the relationship between Mozart and Salieri in Amadeus which I
thoroughly enjoyed.The film manages to show Oppenheimer's narcissistic character, his political conflicts, his relationships with people and the change he went through after the bombing, his psychological state that changed with intense emotions, his nature as a human being as well as his regret.Concluding his biopic by putting the best possible end to this epic historical event with the powerful dialogues between Einstein and Oppenheimer as he stares at the rain drops "causing chain reactions" just like the opening scene, taking his complex storytelling to the next level and combining it with his best screenplay, Nolan is making his great return to the movies.

Oppenheimer, directed by Christopher Nolan is a story based solely around J. Robert Oppenheimer, a Quantum Physicist who played a large role in the development of the atomic bomb. The film explores his life, his work and it is all presented through his eyes.

It is safe to say that this film is exceptional in every aspect: acclaimed director Christopher Nolan does not disappoint and brings to the big screen not only a film with a good historical narrative, but also a superb cast and, of course, a mind-blowing visual experience. However, it is important to keep in mind two aspects that for many could be negative and that I will discuss in this review after commenting on the positive aspects.The cast of the film is composed of exceptional actors and actresses such as Cillian Murphy, Matt Damon, Emily Blunt, Florence Pugh, Robert Downey Jr and more. Along with that, the film is directed by Christopher Nolan, author of great movies such as Interestellar, The Prestige, Memento, TENET... The entire team enhances the quality and credibility of the film through exceptional performances and an unparalleled visual and audio experience.The film's narrative is perfect, showing the reality of the historical events that took place in a detailed, dark and credible way, plus the perfect use of time by means of different chronological entry points. To bring this narrative to the big screen, Christopher Nolan once again surprises on a visual level without the use of CGI, reinterpreting on a smaller scale what happened in history thanks to his superb direction.Going into what could be negative aspects, even though the plot is superb, the pacing may not be perfect for many, as the film has a long running time, and is somewhat complex in its implementation of many characters and subplots. Moreover, especially for fans of the director, the film does not take the same approach as his previous films, but is different in that it deals with a detailed historical perspective rather than delving into fiction and final plot twists (there is something similar to this kind of plot twist, but in a different way).Having said all that, the film is a masterpiece that everyone should see and definitely will enjoy.

Oppenheimer's depth and unique suffering is elegantly portrayed by Murphy in this Oscar-worth performance. This movie is not one for the plot, it is for the small details in how each scene is laid out, and how Oppenheimer reacts/develops in regard to these things. Nolan shows his skill in both these fields throughout the movie.Nevertheless, the only thing separating this movie from a 10 is strange plot pacing in the beginning. Not so poor that it ruins the film, but poor enough to keep the movie from receiving a 10.

Christopher Nolan's Oppenheimer is a sweeping, epic biopic that tells the story of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the theoretical physicist who led the Manhattan Project to develop the atomic bomb. The film is a visual and intellectual tour-de-force, with Cillian Murphy giving a tour-de-force performance as Oppenheimer.The film begins with Oppenheimer as a young man, studying physics at Harvard. We see his early brilliance, his love of science, and his idealistic commitment to using his knowledge to make the world a better place. As the war progresses, Oppenheimer is recruited to lead the Manhattan Project, a top-secret effort to develop an atomic bomb. The film follows Oppenheimer as he leads this team of scientists, working day and night to create a weapon that could change the course of history.The film is not afraid to show the dark side of Oppenheimer's work. We see the moral and ethical dilemmas that he faces, as he grapples with the implications of creating a weapon of such destructive power. We also see the toll that this work takes on him, both physically and mentally.Oppenheimer is a complex and challenging film, but it is also a deeply rewarding one. It is a film that asks big questions about the nature of power, the responsibility of scientists, and the dangers of nuclear weapons. It is a film that will stay with you long after you have seen it.**10/10****Pros:*** Cillian Murphy's tour-de-force performance
* Stunning visuals
* Thought-provoking story
* Powerful performances from the supporting cast
* Christopher Nolan's masterful direction**Cons:*** The film is long (nearly three hours)
* Some of the scientific jargon may be difficult to follow**Overall:**Oppenheimer is a must-see for fans of Christopher Nolan, Cillian Murphy, and historical dramas. It is a film that will stay with you long after you have seen it.**Here are some additional thoughts on the film:*** The film's visuals are stunning. Nolan uses his trademark IMAX format to great effect, creating images that are both visually arresting and emotionally powerful.* The film's story is thought-provoking and challenging. It asks big questions about the nature of power, the responsibility of scientists, and the dangers of nuclear weapons.* The performances from the supporting cast are also excellent. Emily Blunt, Matt Damon, Robert Downey Jr., and Florence Pugh all give memorable performances.* Nolan's direction is masterful. He creates a film that is both visually stunning and emotionally powerful.Overall, Oppenheimer is a must-see for fans of Christopher Nolan, Cillian Murphy, and historical dramas. It is a film that will stay with you long after you have seen it.

In "Oppenheimer", Christopher Nolan brings to life a very deep and complex character. Unlike Nolan's usual style, this film has a lot of dialogues. It deals with many big issues like guilt, logical thinking, patriotism, and the effects of creating a nuclear bomb. The film also highlights the dark side of peace, hypocrisy, and double standards in morality."Oppenheimer" is a balanced film about a controversial figure. The movie's quality lies not just in the accurate storytelling and fair representation of events, but also in the quality of its scriptwriting.The story in "Oppenheimer" is not easy to follow because it jumps between different times. We get to see the process of making the bomb, the years after it was used, and how these events affected Oppenheimer's life, especially his mental state. The film focuses on Robert Oppenheimer's personal struggle and the heavy responsibility he carried.The film is very complete, whether you look at it as a historical movie or as a well-done adaptation. Nolan once again shows his skill in getting the best out of his actors.The last part of the film is a true artistic masterpiece, with smooth transitions between scenes and a great soundtrack. While the music isn't the best in Nolan's films, the sound effects are definitely top-notch. The film is also visually pleasing, with real explosions instead of CGI, which adds more artistic value.To wrap up, after less successful films like "Dunkirk" and "Tenet", Nolan took a big risk with "Oppenheimer". His bravery paid off and he proved that he still has more to offer in his films.8/10.

"Oppenheimer" (2023) is a biographical thriller, drawing inspiration from the 2005 biography "American Prometheus." The film intricately explores the life of J. Robert Oppenheimer, an intellectual and charismatic physicist entrusted with leading the Manhattan Project in Los Alamos, N. M., during World War II to develop the atomic bomb. The narrative centers on Oppenheimer's academic pursuits, his pivotal role in the Manhattan Project, and his eventual demise consequent to a 1954 security hearing. The director adeptly portrays Oppenheimer as a pivotal historical figure, yet poignantly naive, highlighting the profound gravity of the project and its profound repercussions on humanity.Cinematography and direction:
The cinematography of the film possesses a haunting quality, reminiscent of Christopher Nolan's distinctive style, imbuing it with an ominous atmosphere. Its non-linear storyline, coupled with a swift tempo and skillfully crafted narrative, effectively captivates the audience's attention. Nolan demonstrates his mastery by artfully interweaving revealing segments in lush colors and high-contrast black and white, forming a structure resembling the strands of a DNA double helix.Employing the terms "fission" and "fusion," he skillfully accentuates the film's themes and introduces an element of complexity through chronological manipulation. Vivid scenes from various periods draw the audience deeply into Oppenheimer's tumultuous life, establishing this movie as unquestionably Nolan's Magnum Opus, showcasing his exceptional vision, meticulous attention to detail, and storytelling finesse. The adept pacing enables both action-packed moments and character-driven scenes to shine brightly throughout the film.The cast:
The film impresses with remarkable performances from its highly skilled ensemble cast. Cillian Murphy's portrayal of the conflicted hero, grappling with duty and personal challenges, is truly captivating. The supporting cast, including Robert Downey Jr., Emily Blunt, Matt Damon, and other accomplished actors, deliver standout performances that infuse the narrative with depth and authenticity. The palpable chemistry among the cast members brings the characters vividly to life. Notably, even the extras are prominent figures, adding to the film's overall quality.Fantastic Audio Experience:
Ludwig Göransson's symphonic score enhances the film significantly by skillfully harmonizing with the on-screen action and intensifying emotional scenes. The expertly crafted sound effects create a captivating auditory experience, immersing the audience in the movie's world. The eerie and dreamlike tone establishes a tense atmosphere, enveloping viewers in the film's narrative. The exceptional score demands a full theatrical IMAX experience, providing an auditory delight that amplifies the film's overall impact.It pays tribute to the complex life of Oppenheimer and the profound impact of the Manhattan Project. Christopher Nolan's remarkable direction, combined with the stellar cast performances and the enchanting score, results in a film that leaves a lasting impression on its audience.

My favourite movie of all time is Christopher Nolan's 2008 Batman Dark Night. He did it again, delivering historical magic to the Imax cinematic world, and also changed our modern filmmaking method. Astonishing performance from Cillian, with beautiful cinematography capturing the magnificence of an atomic explosion. A refreshing and innovative film highlighting the challenges Oppenheimer faced as the person controlling the life and death of people through his invention, his struggles due to his background and his jealousy of his peers.I particularly love the usage of the B&W 70mm film describing the time frame of events, separating the present and the past, more importantly colouring the dynamic of people. B&W film separates characters from the background, drawing the focus to the facial expressions and movements of the actors. We see how Lewis's extraordinary performance on how his jealousy and delusion drove his anger towards Oppenheimer, how people are easily blinded by fame. Using handheld camera movement for most of the scene builds up the tension, in short truly immersive.Oppenheimer is known to be the father of the atomic bomb. In his previous interviews, he had expressed his concerns about the usage of these bombs and how his invention conflicted with his view on morality. He used his talent to invent such a bomb but everything comes with consequences. Likewise, a bomb can destroy or create destructions and contains greatness in good use but with massive consequences. Oppenheimer was aware of this fact, and the introduction visuals and after-effects complimented this conflicted feeling.The most breathtaking scene has to be the last scene. A close-up of Oppenheimer following an image of the world where it was covered with atomic bombs, end of the world. The fear lived within Oppenheimer. Another remarkable scene would be the explosion of the first successful atomic bomb. The scene started with clouds of dark gas, swallowing the sky, everything was silent, observing the power of it. Then soon later, a loud noise followed. Excellent method of immersing everyone to witness history, and the mightiness of the bomb alongside incredible soundtracks, creating an effect that could only be achieved in cinema.Yet this movie is not all about the process of how the atomic bomb was invented, it is a biography about Oppenheimer. The storyline includes his love affairs, marriage, family and politics. Oppenheimer had been accused of having a connection with the Russian communist party during the second world war. The majority of the movie was about his security clearance. Colleges of his were introduced one by one, some betrayed him, some told half-truths. A mentally draining trial for Oppenheimer but was important to the overall story as in the end cleared his name and his loyalty to the country.A great movie needs to provide a sense of connection with the audience, a reflection that the audience can carry even outside of the cinema. Oppenheimer is a must-watch movie though it is quite lengthy, a total of 3 hours. It gives you a glimpse of what it meant to be "with great power comes with great responsibility". The struggles behind the most magnificent invention of the century. Everything comes with a price, a price that Oppenheimer has to pay was his time with his children and family, and the betrayal of people he trusted. A phenomenal cast of actors, and I have nothing to critic about their delivery.

MISSION: BARBENHEIMER PART 2 OF 3!In my review for Barbie, I mentioned that there was a standout winner this weekend and that winner is undeniably Oppenheimer - a bonafide masterpiece.This film impressed me on multiple levels, as it showcased exceptional production quality, outstanding performances, brilliant scoring, and impeccable cinematography.Hoyte van Hoytema, the cinematographer, has now secured a place among my favourites, given the way he expertly captured each scene.Ludwig Goransson's score was both breathtaking and cathartic, a stark contrast to his previous work which failed to impress me, particularly in Tenet where I disliked the score and sound design. However, in Oppenheimer, the execution of the score was flawless, with only two minor moments where the sound felt unnecessarily loud, although it didn't detract from the significance of those scenes. Despite this, I must admit that my ears felt numb and I experienced discomfort after the movie due to the volume.As for the direction, Christopher Nolan once again showcased his talent, delivering amazing work. While Oppenheimer may be considered his best film by some, my personal favorite will always be Interstellar.The film lived up to my expectations in terms of drama, blending court room drama with elements of science, politics, and relationships. The writing was exceptional, dispelling the notion that Nolan struggles with female characters. Although females aren't the central focus of the story, had they been, I have no doubt that he would have written them well.Among my favourite moments were the captivating discussions on science and the stunning quantum visuals with roaring sound design as particles interacted. These scenes were simply incredible and left a lasting impression.One of the most beautiful shots in the entire film was the black and white scene where Oppenheimer met Einstein, evoking a raw and real-life atmosphere reminiscent of shots from films like Andrei Rublev.The acting was simply outstanding. Cillian Murphy, whom I previously considered somewhat overrated, surprised me with his depth and ability to convey emotions through his eyes. Emily Blunt was fantastic, and Robert Downey Jr. Delivered his best performance to date. Any claims of overacting made by some movie critics, including those who supposedly attended film school, are simply ludicrous. Robert Downey Jr.'s performance was truly phenomenal, and there's no denying this fact.I can't stress enough how much I enjoyed Oppenheimer, which instantly became my favourite movie of 2023 so far. It was a fantastic experience, and while it had a few flaws, such as unnecessary nudity and sex scenes, these did not overshadow its many other outstanding qualities.To sum up, Oppenheimer is an impressive film that deserves the highest praise. It has set itself apart as the clear and decisive winner when compared to other movies, even overshadowing my previous anticipation for Barbie. This cinematic experience left me incredibly satisfied and thrilled, and I can't wait to see how it continues to resonate with audiences.

Good movie, glad I saw it.I did not think it was quite as great as perhaps I had expected, though. As someone who has studied some physics, I would have liked to see a lot more of it. I did like the casting of all the famous physicists whose names I know well, but that too could have been milked a little more. And there were many things at Los Alamos that would have added nice context (like the "demon core" and its victims. And a clearer explanation of the fact that they only tested the plutonium bomb that was dropped on Nagasaki; the Uranium bomb needed no testing; they knew it would work, and it did - on Hiroshima).And three hours is long: the story about the loss of his security clearance took, I think, much longer than would have been needed. I thought "OK yes, he's being screwed; he'll lose the clearance" - and then it took another hour to ever so slowly get to that point.And the constant going back and forth in time was also sometimes frustratingly confusing.

Background:
"Oppenheimer," directed by the visionary Christopher Nolan, is a historical biopic that delves into the fascinating life of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the renowned physicist known as the father of the atomic bomb. Set against the backdrop of World War II and the race to harness the power of nuclear fission, the film takes the audience on a riveting journey through Oppenheimer's personal struggles, scientific genius, and the profound moral implications of his groundbreaking work.The Great Things:Compelling Storytelling: Nolan's masterful storytelling weaves together three timelines, providing an in-depth look at Oppenheimer's life, from his formative years as a student to his role as the head of the Manhattan Project. The non-linear narrative adds depth to the character and keeps the audience engrossed.Outstanding Performances: The film boasts an ensemble cast, with Cillian Murphy delivering a career-defining performance as Oppenheimer. His portrayal captures the complexities of the man torn between his scientific curiosity and the moral dilemmas posed by his creations. Robert Downey Jr. And Matt Damon also shine in their respective roles, adding depth and nuance to the narrative.Thought-Provoking Themes: "Oppenheimer" is not just a historical account of a scientific endeavor; it explores profound themes of power, responsibility, and the consequences of scientific advancement. It forces the audience to ponder the ethical implications of groundbreaking discoveries and the toll they take on individuals and the world.The Moderate Things:Lengthy Duration: Clocking in at three hours, "Oppenheimer" is a demanding watch. While the film's intricate plot necessitates a lengthy runtime, some viewers may find it challenging to stay fully engaged throughout.The Flop Things:Confusing Chronology: The film's non-linear storytelling, while engrossing, can be confusing at times, especially for viewers unfamiliar with the historical events and characters. Some may find it challenging to follow the complex web of timelines.Review from Various Aspects:Plot: "Oppenheimer" presents a gripping and insightful narrative, but the complex structure might overwhelm casual viewers. Nevertheless, the compelling exploration of Oppenheimer's life and the political context surrounding the development of the atomic bomb is commendable.Acting: The performances in "Oppenheimer" are nothing short of exceptional. Cillian Murphy portrayal of Oppenheimer is a career-defining triumph, with other characters also delivering standout performances.Duration: The movie's extended runtime might test the patience of some audience members, but it is necessary to explore the complexities of Oppenheimer's life fully.Special Effects: As expected from a Nolan film, the special effects in "Oppenheimer" are top-notch. The recreation of the Trinity test and other pivotal moments in the atomic bomb's development is visually stunning.Music: Ludwig Göransson's haunting and immersive soundtrack complements the film's tense and emotional moments, elevating the overall cinematic experience.Great Ending:
In conclusion, "Oppenheimer" is a thought-provoking masterpiece that showcases Christopher Nolan's unparalleled filmmaking prowess. While its ambitious storytelling and lengthy duration may not be for everyone, the film offers a mesmerizing journey into the life of a scientific giant and the consequences of his discoveries. Cillian Murphy's powerful performance and Nolan's directorial brilliance make "Oppenheimer" a cinematic achievement worthy of acclaim. This film serves as a stark reminder of the complexities of human nature, the pursuit of knowledge, and the moral quandaries faced by those who hold the power to change the course of history. "Oppenheimer" stands as a landmark in biographical cinema, leaving a lasting impact on its audience and sparking deep contemplation long after the credits roll.

Oppenheimer, almost feels like he was made for Christopher Nolan. For once in a Nolan film, he doesn't have to come up with a larger than life idea, with a complicated man at the helm of it. Because that kind of story, the kind Nolan seems to be so interested in, was Oppenheimer's life.There's a level of technical prowess to this film that's impressive even for Nolan. People have gotten so used to Nolan's technical ability, they almost ignore it, but this film doesn't allow you to, it is on another level. Without even commenting too much on the obvious 70mm IMAX film (I sadly was unable to see it), which is such an achievement for filmmaking going forward. The faced paced editing, breathtaking cinematography and practical effects so good you forget it's a movie. This movie is a technical masterpiece and that's clear as day even on a first viewing.And it goes without saying the acting will go down in history. Too many amazing supporting roles to even nominate all of them, and a lead so unbelievably good, it will redefine who people think of when they think of Oppenheimer. Cillian Murphy shows up almost immediately as the film starts, and he doesn't leave your mind for the week after it finishes.The SOUND, THE GODDAMN SOUND. Wether it's the sound design or the score itself. A score that rivals Zimmer's work with Nolan is score to die for, filling the room with anxiety when it needs to, and a feeling of grandiose when it needs to. The theater shakes and rumbles, the sound of a bomb, the sound of a hand on the shoulder, or the sound of a gust of wind, you can feel all of it. It's sad to say it but outside of the theater this movie will be a bastardized version of itself, and that's mostly because the sounds of an IMAX screening, make this one of the most riveting movies ever made.All of that is impressive, all of that can make a masterpiece, but at the end of the day, this is Oppenheimer. The story is what makes it all mean something, and what makes it so compelling. A beautifully dramatized version of history, with the truth still intact. Told in classic Nolan fashion, non-linear and labyrinthine. Told at a break-neck speed, through multiples lenses, keeping you guessing, which is nearly unheard of in a biopic. I said it's almost like Oppenheimer was made for Nolan. But in truth, it's stories like Oppenheimer's that make people like Nolan do what he does. I feel as if I've witnessed a classic at it's birth. Which is the first time I can say that in my young life. I went to the theaters and saw something come to fruition, Oppenheimer, a film we will definitely remember.

Christopher Nolan's first biopic keeps very true to its inspiration, American Prometheus. The casting was superb with what is Cillian Murphy's best performance on the big screen so far, and additional stellar performances from Robert Downey Jr and the remainder of the cast.The pace of the movie mirrors perfectly what J. R. Oppenheimer and the rest of the Manhattan Project must have felt racing to create this weapon of mass destruction first. The continuous shift through scenes, the fast dialogue, and the changing sceneries between Oppenheimer's life before and during the Manhattan Project (filmed in colour) and the security hearing (filmed in B/W) keeps the audience gripped to their seats, much like how the savants were gripped to their pads and blackboards trying to develop this weapon.For a historically accurate biopic, I must say it is ridden with a plethora of small and large metaphors: the security hearing being filmed in B/W showing a more basic right or wrong (loyal or communist) perspective of Oppenheimer; the constant imagery of rain droplets, almost signifying the thousands of ICBMs carrying nuclear warhead, pummelling the earth; etc.My only slight disapproval with the movie is that for such a long feature (3 hours) it leaves very little breathing room for the audience to digest the information given, so you must come prepared to dedicate 3 hours of undivided attention to this film in order to honestly appreciate and enjoy it.J. R. Oppenheimer truly is a modern day Prometheus and Nolan has masterfully managed to not indulge either side; misunderstood scientist and hero, or a man with blood on his hands and no remorse. Personally I like one of the ending scenes when Nolan finally reveals what Oppenheimer told Einstein: they did set off a never-ending chain reaction, just not in the molecular form they expected but by the means of mass proliferation of nuclear weapons.

Every actor is in their prime. Absolute masterclass of sound, cinematography, editing, acting, and directing.There were moments where my theater laughed, and times when I saw people jump from fright. When the credits rolled, it really wasn't a time for applause, or a time to breathe a sigh of relief that the film had ended. It was a collection of souls, lost, after having watched humanity's most horrifying turning point portrayed with such realistic horror.

In a world where legendary filmmakers clash, Christopher Nolan once again emerges as the victor, maintaining an undefeated streak with his latest masterpiece-a biopic that delves deeply into the psyche of an extraordinary character. Nolan's brilliance shines through flawlessly executed editing, captivating sound mixing and the enthralling interplay among complex characters.This high budget production spares no expense, meticulously crafting each scene to transport the audience back in time with its vibrant musicality. The result is an incredibly immersive experience that makes us feel like mere witnesses to the unfolding tides of history.However, what truly sets this film apart from others is Nolan's refusal to rely on the easy allure of CGI. Instead, he harnesses the awe-inspiring potential of practical effects to bring to life epic historical events that resonated throughout humanity's journey.The ensemble cast comprised of A listers is nothing short of extraordinary, even in their limited screen time. Nolan skillfully weaves their presence into the fabric of the story, leaving an indelible mark on both the narrative and actual historical events themselves. Cillian Murphy delivers a career defining performance as the heart and soul of this film, while Robert Downey and Emily Blunt deserve well deserved Oscar nominations for their outstanding supporting roles that add another layer of brilliance to an already stellar ensemble. I really loved Emily Blunt's last interview, it was one of the standout moments in the entire movie.In the third act, the film takes an exhilarating turn, almost feeling like a sequel within itself. This segment becomes the catalyst for exploring the depths of each character, peeling back their layers and revealing the complexities of their personas. The interplays between the characters are not only captivating but also socially and politically driven, reflecting the selfish tendencies that reside within every human psyche.At the center of this captivating character study is Oppenheimer, brilliantly portrayed by Cillian Murphy. Here, Nolan expertly captures the internal struggle of Oppenheimer, torn between his unwavering desire to see his country emerge victorious in the war and the haunting realization that his work has led to the deaths of thousands of people. This internal conflict adds an extra dimension to the narrative, making the movie truly exceptional.This portrayal of Oppenheimer as a multi-faceted individual, both hero and potential villain in the course of history, sets the stage for a riveting debate among movie lovers and the public alike. Audiences will be left grappling with the moral implications of his actions and the choices he made during this critical juncture of humanity's past.The film's third act not only ties together the plot's loose ends but also provides a deep psychological exploration of the characters, making it a thought-provoking cinematic experience. It showcases Nolan's mastery in crafting characters with profound internal conflicts and motivations, sparking discussions that will resonate long after leaving the theater.In this climactic act, the story reaches its pinnacle, leaving audiences with a mix of emotions and a desire for introspection. The film transcends its historical roots, becoming a timeless meditation on the duality of human nature and the profound impact of one person's choices on the course of history. It is this rich exploration of human complexity that sets this biopic apart and makes it a cinematic triumph.Nolan's artistry transcends cinematic boundaries, transforming this biopic into a mesmerizing opus, a symphony of emotions, ideas, and reflections on the human condition. Beyond a mere chronicle of a bomb, the film probes into the intricacies of the human psyche, navigating the labyrinth of politics on both national and personal scales. It deftly embraces the themes of science, power, and the harrowing specter of world destruction. As the credits roll, we find ourselves contemplating the profound impact of this film, forever imprinted in our hearts and minds. It is a magnum opus that will resonate through the ages, cementing Nolan's status as a true cinematic visionary.

Oppenheimer is not a typical Nolan films like Inception or Interstellar. It is a three hour long biographical thriller film which was running like a fast moving car. As an IR student i've found it very relatable but thats not the case with most of the Indian audience. This movie has lot of characters like Strauss, J Hoover, Roosevelt, Kennedy and many more American scientists. You should have fair idea about their role in American history then only you could relate it better. First half was very much setting up the plot of the film which revolves around Oppenheimer's Journey. But the second half right from the "Trinity test" to the mystery of the end was an absolute amazing. The background score was tense and will held you till the end of the movie. Cillian Murphy and Robert Downey have given their career best performance. Eventually, all i can say it is more of "Dunkirk" kind of film rather than Dark Knight or Interstellar. If you love watching serious cinema then it is a must watch movie, you will surely enjoy it.

Not a fan of the timing, i think the film was a bit long some scenes seemed unnecessary, the music and overall sound design was great though saved some scenes that were a bit long for certain, the framing of shots is a bit repetitive at times but the overall filming is as good as expected, the storytelling was great although a bit less clear near the end but it might just be an impression due to the length. Christopher Nolan proves once again why he has become such a well renown and respected director in such a competitive industry. The hype for this movie was real and as much a product of Nolan's incredibly reputation as it was the subject matter and man the film was based on. The movie is a slow burn and harkens back to an older style of film that Nolan has become so beloved for in an era of CGI bloated blockbusters. Void of CGI and overblown set pieces Oppenheimer is akin to an older film simply because it is carried by its drama, themes, and outstanding cast performances more than it is by spectacle. The cinematography is second to none , using both visual and audio cues to tie into the films deeper themes. The one that comes to mind is the stomping that Oppenheimer hears in his head throughout the movie that grow louder and louder almost like an oncoming train , the source of the sound that tortures him for most of the movie is revealed closer to the end. He is also haunted by quick cuts and flashes of the bomb exploding and fire expanding etc etc. Before the trinity test scene even happens. The way the trinity test was presented was tasteful. Going on premiere night in a sold out theater, you could hear a pin drop in the room during that scene. The movie tackles heavy subjects as Oppenheimer wrestles with moral qualms and guilt over what he helped create. While powerful I do believe that the latter half of the movie involving a hearing for Dr. Oppenheimer with regards to his ongoing security clearance for the U. S. and it's nuclear program could have been condensed a bit. While I do believe that the tail end of the movie used it's time effectively to bring some weight to the movie after the trinity test and tie together some strong themes that become clear by the end. I do believe that these hearing scenes could come off as long winded at times. At best the latter half of this movie and thus it's run time is appreciated by those not bothered by long run times , who likely enjoy other long dramas in vein with Oppenheimer like The Godfather, Scarface, and more. Even those not normally used to sitting in the theater watching a movie for so long might find the film and the superb performances to be engaging enough to justify its runtime. At worst Oppenheimer suffers from an ending that feels drawn out and caused the pacing of the film to suffer. Some modern audiences who do not understand or appreciate much of the important historical context to this movie as well , might find themselves bored sitting through what feels like a court hearing towards the end of the movie. For those type of moviegoers , they probably came to see the spectacle of the trinity test scene, likely thinking it would be a finale of sorts. But on the contrary the trinity test scene merely serves as catalyst to move into the second half of the movie (thematically) speaking. I suppose the latter type of audience is not who Oppenheimer was intended for exactly. If you are a fan of film, if your a history buff, If you don't mind a slow burn and enjoy a good character piece with some good drama and themes, then Oppenheimer is a great movie for you. If you are someone who didn't know who Oppenheimer was before they announced this movie, if you don't care much for history , If your a casual movie goer whose looking for an action packed thrill ride or just decided to check it out to see what the hype was all about... then you might get mixed results. Best advice is to tailor your expectations accordingly. For me this movie was not perfect but it came pretty damn close. It's cinematography, themes , character studies, historical significance, actor performances, audio work, and of course Nolan's signature dedication to practical effects combine to deliver a film that weights up to the reputation of a man who for better or for worse changed the world as we know it. This movie solidified Nolan's place amongst names like Martin Scorsese, Stanley Kubrick and more... in other words the best of the best Hollywood has to offer! Nolan is one of if not the last of a dying breed of director. His contributions and dedication to his art help keep the original spirit of filmmaking alive at a time when the majority of what we see in theaters encompasses very little of what made the roots of the art form so compelling and special.

Oppenheimer is a 3-hour movie that, in contrast to Nolan's more recent sci-fi movies, demonstrates his mastery of the Biopic/Drama genre. The movie moves quickly while tackling significant themes and giving a thorough character analysis of our culture. It was one of the most frightening scenes in recent memory, making theatergoers uneasy and serving as a reminder of the full power of the film experience. With a remarkable cinematic achievement and a poignant reminder that cinema is still alive, Oppenheimer is a winner on all counts. I have already seen the movie once and intend to go back to the theater at least a few more times in the near future. It is highly recommended for everyone.

This movie is a masterpiece; a cliché, but it is what it is. It is a very successful take on the life of Oppenheimer, who had an otherwise dramatic life given his complex nature and self contradictory actions. As with Nolan's other films, Oppenheimer assumes that the viewer has a certain level of history awareness and basic science, which is something I really admire.The direction is simply extraordinary, which is complimented by Nolan's trademark non-linear storytelling structure. The film has a lot of events going on at a pretty fast pace, which at some point really expresses the need to have the bomb completed in time. Add to the mix the incredible acting by the cast, particularly Cillian and RDJ. Outstanding performance by the duo; at the very least an Oscar nod for both the actors in their respective categories if not a win.The screenplay is really well written and a unique one. It is not written in the typical third person perspective. It is written in first person perspective which is really a very interesting approach. Hoyte van Hoytema's genius can be seen in the cinematography and the remarkable visuals the film portrays. The soundtrack in the entire film by Ludwig Göransson is unparalleled. The very first time I heard it gave me chills down my spine. The soundtrack captures the emotions of the scene and makes it even better.The only drawback I could see is the poor writing of the character Jean Tatlock. I feel the character should have had more screen time and the arc better portrayed. It felt like she came and gone too soon. On the other hand the portrayal of Kitty Oppenheimer was well written and likewise portrayed. The 3 hours flies by and you are left wanting for more given that not all of Oppenheimer's history is showcased. If that were the case the film would have been 4-5 hours long easily.I strongly recommend watching the film in IMAX as it is how it is intended to be watched. It is unfortunate that there are no 70mm IMAX screenings anymore in India. Digital IMAX is just as fine but I wish there were 70mm screenings at least somewhere in India. Rest assured, this is one of the greatest biopics ever and arguably the best work of Nolan yet, technicality wise at least.

Jesus Christ, I thoroughly loved this movie from the very beginning to the last second. This movie had everything - incredible cinematography, all-around Oscar-worthy acting, amazing plot and storytelling and a heart wrenching score. This is what I call a perfect movie. I loved the way that the story was told.First the main points and other plot points were thrown at your face and you really couldn't make sense of it, at least if you weren't that well read on the subject.The second act kind of took the focus off the court hearing and the somewhat confusing plot points and focused more on the actual bomb.In the third act everything was tied together beautifully giving the audience clarity on what really just happened.The main role by Cillian Murphy was an all-time great performance and I have no doubt that he will score at least 1 Oscar.The supporting cast was stacked with starpower from different eras of film. Matt Damon was amazing as always and RDJ, after many years, finally made a comeback into making real films. Emily Blunt and Florence Pugh were also brilliant.The score in this film was so great and dramatic that at times it felt like I was having a heart-attack. It was truly beautiful and in my humble opinion easily the best work from Ludwig Göransson.These movies are rare nowadays and I recommend everybody to watch this movie in 70mm IMAX if possible10.

If you are a person who enjoys a slow burn, biopic, character study, this one is gonna be in your top 10.Every single actor nails it. RDJ commands every scene he is in. Murphy embodies Oppenheimer's guilt and brilliance. Pugh, Blunt, Damon, fox dammit everyone is just fantastic. Nolan has crafted another masterpiece and is immediately in my top 3 Nolan movies.The films moment, the bomb drop, is perfect. The tensions, suspense and the silence followed by the epic boom is a cinema experience I will never forget. Please go and watch this movie in IMAX. I already want to go see it again for this moment alone. The audio mixing is nailed.There is just not a single bad performance. Not a single wasted scene. The pacing is fantastic and 3 hrs will never go by quicker.Just go and watch the movie. It may be one of the most important pictures of the century.

Frankly I was incredibly disappointed. Nolan at his best captures his audience with incredible cinematography, sound and, most importantly, narrative. The actors did what they could, which I might say was a fantastic job, but Nolan simply couldn't keep focus on a few but compelling narratives, but instead shot off in all kinds of directions with multiple plots. Oppenheimer did it the other way around, except the entertaining part never actually arrived.

"Oppenheimer," the latest venture by auteur Christopher Nolan, is a cinematic tour de force that masterfully fuses historical gravitas with human drama. It delves into the paradoxical world of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the theoretical physicist known as the 'father of the atomic bomb,' giving us a potent exploration of one man's ambition, guilt, and the cataclysmic power of science.As with all Nolan's films, "Oppenheimer" showcases an impeccably tight narrative that transcends linear storytelling. Every scene is intricately woven, each a revelation of character and event, slowly building an intense crescendo that is both chilling and mesmerizing. The multi-layered plot cleverly navigates the dilemmas faced by Oppenheimer, skillfully juxtaposing the scientific thrill of discovery with the devastating human consequences of his creation.The visual effects are, quite simply, breathtaking. Nolan brings to life the mid-20th century world of theoretical physics and wartime America with an awe-inspiring sense of realism. The climax, featuring the detonation of the atomic bomb, is a cinematic spectacle unlike any other, a poignant reminder of the destructive force humanity has unlocked.The ensemble cast delivers exceptional performances. The portrayal of Oppenheimer is nothing short of riveting - a man torn between his duty, curiosity, and the moral implications of his groundbreaking work. The nuances in his character are effectively and heart-wrenchingly conveyed, anchoring the audience in his complex emotional journey.Hans Zimmer's score, a character in itself, perfectly complements the atmospheric tension of the film. His haunting melodies add another layer of complexity to the scenes, mirroring Oppenheimer's own crescendoing turmoil and the world-changing events he set into motion.In conclusion, "Oppenheimer" is a magnificent achievement. It's a film that successfully marries artistry with history, and personal introspection with global catastrophe. Nolan once again proves his ability to create intellectual, emotionally-resonant cinema that stays with viewers long after the end credits roll. This isn't just a film; it's an experience, a contemplation on the human condition, and a sobering reflection of our times.

This move was a show stopper! Starting off with a complicated begging on Robert J. Oppenheimer with him being judged by a council. The movie continues with his research and it is all out in extraordinary view. Oppenheimer makes an outstanding young physicist and you can see his growth as he goes from Cambridge to Germany. This sequence was put together so well as he met new characters and spent a minute or two introducing them to the audience so they may be of importance later in the story. He begins teaching and later the bomb is found to be a possibility. This is where the complication begins as you go from his future to the future with Louis Strauss and they talk about things not seen yet. As Groves come to him with an idea of the directing of the bomb his past begins to unveil with communism in every corner. It is in this phase when the movie gets extremely complicated. He begins collecting scientist and Los Almos is soon made. The complication begins to unveil just as in every Christopher Nolan movie. Oppenheimer's clearance is questioned and you see Strauss at his own council meeting. He begins making the bomb and it is here where Christopher Nolan builds tension to make the movie so much better. The tension between the scientist as he builds the bomb is outstanding and makes the movie so much more realistic. You can understand how important this is and how vital it is to get everything correct.the movie takes a very political turn here with Japan about to be attacked and the tension grows when they find the bomb could destroy the world. Finally, they are put to the test and the bomb is exploded. Here is when the movie starts unraveling just as all Christopher Nolan movies. You find Strauss is the master mine between the clearance problems and you understand the council meetings with both Robert and Strauss. The moment you understand the whole movie makes sense. In the end it is heartfelt with his past and get a moral dilemma combined with politics, and physics. I love how it is all complicated and emotional yet it all makes sense in the end.

I would give the movie an 8.5 if I could, but I'm rounding it up to a 9.When I walked out of the theater I was still kind of watching the movie in my head, processing what happened between all the politics, personal aspects of Oppy's life and the actual timeline of events. It took a bit before it all clicked, but when it did, it really dawned on me how brilliantly constructed this movie is.And any movie that makes me think about it afterwards solidifies itself as a great film.I loved the political aspect of it, though this seems to be a point of contention for a lot of people who watched it. To be fair, it's understandable, I'll admit I didn't go into the cinema expecting politics, I wanted science and numbers and explosions, and I bet most people came for the numbers and the science and the explosions; it most certainly delivered on that part.But the politics really serves to cement the movie as a part of history. It's messy, it's confusing, all over the place, and that's perfect. Yes, the messiness is a good thing, because politics isn't straight and narrow, politics is confusing! Good job to the writers and directors.Jean Tatlock is a character that I wish we could have seen more of - though many aspects of her story aren't really relevant to that of Oppenheimer, the movie did encourage me to read up about her and realize just how tragic her story is. She really deserves her own movie at some point.Good movie. Good plot, good pacing, it made me think a lot, and that is good.

A truly remarkable film that, as the poster boasts, will change the world forever.In our modern political environment fraught with corruption on both sides - while the world teeters towards another global war and the threat of nuclear deployment - I can think of no film more informational and more critical for the American public to watch in this moment, than Oppenheimer.Nolan delivers a phenomenal film - jam packing a truly foundational moment of American history into a remarkable 3 hour journey.Arguably dividing the film into two acts, Nolan provides a rare glimpse into the astonishing reality of how America battled through the nuclear program in World War II. Immaculately providing an amalgamation of physics, patriotism, and philosophy Nolan takes a rather scientific effort and transforms it into the astonishing moment of history that it was.Through the use of bewildering special effects, a star studded cast, and an inspiring score Nolan is able to build to the boom in such a way that keeps the audience wholly engaged and entertained - while Cillian Murphy delivers a performance of a lifetime bringing the emotion, education, and eccentricity of Dr. Oppenheimer to life in a character that will permanently be tied to Murphy.And yet, the true darkness of the film does not occur until the second act - after the detonation of the bomb. Focusing on the witch-hunt efforts of the jaded Lewis Strauss, Nolan's Act 2 skewers the underbelly of a darker and corrupter time in American politics. Nolan - with stunning accuracy and gripping reality retells the story of how American agencies - particularly our FBI - was weaponized against Dr. Oppenheimer so as to discredit and disengage him from the American public.But after the second half, I found myself pondering "How much of this has really changed? Have our agencies? Our leaders? Our FBI?" And when I reflect on where our politics and country stand today, I found myself thinking - no.This is perhaps the most stunning piece of Nolan's puzzle. That he is able to so artfully display American greatness and innovation against corruption and cruelty - without losing a beat.Much like a nuclear explosion, Oppenheimer blows the viewer away with this amazing storytelling - ignited by a perfected cast and cinematography - but also just as a nuke once it has gone off, it leaves those in its wake in a moment of silence.

Oppenheimer is a biographical drama film about J. Robert Oppenheimer, the scientist who led the Manhattan Project to develop the atomic bomb. The film explores Oppenheimer's moral dilemma as he grapples with the implications of his work and the potential for nuclear destruction.Review: Oppenheimer is a visually stunning and thought-provoking film that offers a complex and nuanced portrait of one of the most important figures in the history of science. Cillian Murphy gives a tour-de-force performance as Oppenheimer, bringing to life the scientist's brilliance, charisma, and inner turmoil. The supporting cast is also excellent, with Emily Blunt, Matt Damon, Robert Downey Jr., Rami Malek, and Kenneth Branagh all giving memorable performances.The film's direction by Christopher Nolan is masterful. Nolan uses his trademark visual style to create a film that is both visually arresting and emotionally resonant. The film's use of sound and music is also effective, helping to create a sense of tension and dread.Oppenheimer is not without its flaws. The film is long, and some viewers may find the pacing to be slow. Additionally, the film's depiction of the Bhagavad Gita has been met with criticism from some viewers.( In possitive ony one cannot miss the Bhagawat Gita and in negative way it's the inappropriate time to discuss on it it's would be better if presenting as per Karthik 2 when anupam kher explain about shree Krishna)
Overall, Oppenheimer is a powerful and important film that offers a unique and thought-provoking perspective on one of the most important events in human history. The film is beautifully made, and Cillian Murphy gives a tour-de-force performance. However, the film's length and the depiction of the Bhagavad Gita may be off-putting to some viewers.Recommendation: I would recommend Oppenheimer to viewers who are interested in science, history, or war films. The film is also a good choice for viewers who are looking for a thought-provoking and challenging film.

The acting in this film is fascinating and the cast is absolutely stellar. It's an interesting story and certainly would have deserved a 9 were it not for two major flaws that are common in movies these days but taken to absurd excess here. First, the sound. It was so muffled and echoey, and the music and sound effects were so overwhelming, that my friends and I missed at least a third of the dialog. Since the drama depended on the dialog, this was a serious error in judgment. At times, it was obvious something very humorous was occurring in the dialog, but the entire audience just sat in confused silence trying to figure out what was going on. And then there were the frequent changes in scene. Just as you are settling into a scene, suddenly the story jumps to a different city, with different people, in a different decade. Between the inaudible dialog and the frenetic changes in scene, the film was often difficult to follow. I look forward to watching this with subtitles to see what I missed.

Making quality historical biopics is hard. First, a director wants to be true to history. Second, a director wants to entertain a broad audience. So here, master director Chris Nolan took on the task of a biopic of Robert Oppenheimer - the "father of the atomic bomb". I am sure the movie will get an oscar nod or two. But for this reviewer, it fell short of that lofty mark. First major flaw was the length of the film. It ran THREE HOURS. Yikes. I would almost go so far as to say no movie should run that long. That may go too far, but as to this particular film, the key part of the Oppenheimer life story should have taken 2 hours. Second major flaw, at least in IMAX, was a loud "boomy" audio that made dialogue tough to follow. "Boomy" bass is fine for atomic test explosions and the like, but not for dialogue. With that said, the quality of acting by Cilian Murphy, Florence Pugh, Matt Damon, Emily Blunt and others was natural and convincing. I won't fault them.

Nolan focuses on particular stage in the life of Oppenheimer, were he led the team of scientist to creating, what would be later, regarded, the Destroyer of all worlds.With zero CGI, Nolan manages to create stunning visual effects and achieve almost-impossible challenges of recreating the Trinity bomb effects. The IMAX created a sense of emotional attachment with the main characters, by portraying true form emotions and effects, and that itself was a pure masterpiece of cinematography.The music, composed by Ludwig Goransson, was divided into two themes, one that is character-related and the other that is event-related, and it was immersive at every point of time due to the intensity and delicacy of those events.Nolan, a timeless director of the century, wanted this to be the movie of the century, and there is a very good reason why. Because, it is the reason we are living the way we are now, in this so called "World Order", the event that changed the course of history forever and defined our present and future geopolitical world for generations to come.That is why, Nolan took a bold decision in staying away from the story-like, interstellar-like, inception-like, narrative, and focused more on the politics, moral-rich dialogues, and character-rich involvement that diversified between the inner and outer circle of J. Robert Oppenheimer.In his masterpiece, Christopher Nolan, highlights the controversial character of Oppenheimer, who we saw from the beginning, mentally driven to develop and create the atom bomb that will help strengthen his theories.We see how imperialist-acting USA treats its scientists who defies their foreign policy, by demarginalizing them, defaming them and discrediting them. One scene really hits the core when Oppy is trying to convince his lab colleague to join him and say "They need us" who in return replies "Until they don't", and that is reflected specifically after Oppenheimer finished the trinity test, and starts feeling left out of major details of how things will go from there.The movie gives justice to portraying a murderous unapologetic apartheidic TRUMAN criminal, who sets the historical narrative of USA for generations to come "USA will always bomb hundreds of thousands of people, and collateral damages, to preserve world order and peace amongst the rest", this is the holy grail of the devil himself.The relationship between Strauss and Oppenheimer, is probably the most controversial and defining moments in the lives of both characters. Strauss sees a side of J. Robert Oppenheimer, that is true in many ways. The man knew what he was up to, and it wasn't a lab homework, he was building a bomb to be used, just like gunpowder (also referenced by Oppenheimer during his meeting with General Groves), which means that he believes in the pattern of events following a creation of , what could be, a deadly weapon. It is a point view to see Oppenheimer as a hypocrite, and it is actually a strong one. Despite being fought and framed by the AEC and the FBI and Strauss, it is still a valid point. Both are two sides of the same coin. DESTROYERS OF WORLDS.Oppenheimer might be finally Nolan's long awaited and anticipated Oscar win for best director and Cillian's performance is also to be topped at the Golden Awards.The movie of the Century indeed.

The 3 hour run-time was no issue even for somebody such as myself who tends to get bored when moves push longer than 2.5 hours. The movie almost feels like it's more around the 2 to 2 1/2 hour run-time due to how entrenched you become in the story and the overall characters. The movie can be very jarring with how technical some of the dialogue and nuanced discussions between scientists can be. Nolan doesn't try and dumb down the movie for the audience and really respects the intelligence of the viewer. A second viewing almost feels necessary to discern every character and minutiae the movie has to offer, but I wont be waiting long to indulge in that second viewing. Please go see this movie, even if you already have an idea of how some of the actual historical events took place. It's well worth your time and well.

I have never written a review on this site, nor had I planned to until I sat down and watched Oppenheimer. I was floored by its effortless genius and masterful writing. The movie takes the viewer on a turbulent, frankly disturbing ride, that leaves you jostled, depressed, and stunned. A cinematic experience that goes unmatched. A cinematic experience that I hope is not overlooked by the often ignorant Oscars. The film easily cements itself as Christopher Nolan's Magnum Opus. The directors usual tricks that often make his films at times fall flat, work wonders here. From the entirely practical effects to dialogue overload that in his other films feel hollow only fuel the fire that is Oppenheimer. Techniques that make me overjoyed that Nolan was the director to make this movie and not someone else. If you have not seen it, I urge you. Yes, it is long, and yes, it is not an action filled blockbuster, but it is something better. A movie that tells a story that changes the way the viewer perceives the world we live in. Because isn't that what art is supposed to do.

First of all, I must say that I personally loved the movie. It was very well made and historically accurate. But I also have to point out that I'm a history nerd and I have read everything about the history of physics and the development of nuclear weapons and nuclear energy because these things fascinate me. If you're not like me, I bet this movie might feel boring.What this movie doesn't have is emotional investment like previous Nolan masterpieces such as Inception and Interstellar. Oppenheimer's love life and trust with Jean Tatlock serves little purpose for the plot compared to Cobb's love story in Inception and Cooper's feelings for his children in Interstellar. In this regard, it feels like Nolan has already made his best and most complete movies and may never reach that same level again.I also understand the criticism conerning the score. While not bad, the score here is nowhere near as good as Hans Zimmer's scores for The Dark Knight, Inception and Interstellar. As with the emotional investment, this, too, is a thing that may never reach the same level of greatness as previous Nolan pieces.The reason why I'm saying that Nolan might never reach the same level again is that these are also the things that were lacking in his previous movie Tenet. Oppenheimer was definitely better than Tenet, and I like both movies, but honestly both lack emotional investment and a memorable score. There was also at least one scene in Oppenheimer with jump dialogue, which was a thing I hated in Tenet.Lastly, I have to point out that even though I love the history of physics and nuclear weapons, they also had a too small role in the movie. Sure, there were many theories and names thrown around, but I bet the uninformed viewer will miss at least half of them. If you compare this movie to the TV series Chernobyl, things are not explained nearly as well. This movie also lacks the excitement and thriller aspect of similar productions such as Chernobyl (about nuclear physics) and The Imitation Game (about a secret World War 2 facility).So, all in all we're left with a historical movie, most of which deals with politics. I still liked it, but I'm not surprised if many people find it a tad boring. At the same time as I was enjoying watching the movie, I was afraid that my date was bored because she doesn't like history, politics or nuclear physics.

Oppenheimer takes on a very difficult job, to accurately illustrate a complex man who must reconcile his love for theoretical physics and scientific discovery with his fear of being the American Prometheus, capable of giving the country he loves the power to destroy itself.Nolan takes a cubist approach to formulate a depiction of Oppenheimer with many sides and many faces. For the majority of the movie, we observe the world subjectively through his eyes. However, at times we also observe the world from the point of view of his bitter rival, Lewis Strauss (Robert Downey Jr.).At a critical moment in the movie, Strauss gives a fiery monologue about the man he sees Oppenheimer to be, and we are left wondering what to believe about who the man truly was. Nolan commonly uses this tool of unanswerable, ambiguous, cliffhanging questions to invite discussion amongst his audiences.There is merit to the historical accuracy of Nolan portraying Oppenheimer as Pablo Picasso portrays The Old Guitarist or as William Faulker portrays Thomas Sutpen in Absalom! Absalom! In a work published in 1973 by Hayden White titled Metahistory: The Historical Imagination in Nineteenth-century Europe, White argues that the way a historical event is told is more valuable to any given culture or society than its truthfulness and accuracy. The stories that prevail are the ones that are interesting. Historiography is also inherently reductive, he writes, because it charges historians with creating simple cause and effect relationships that explain history in an understandable way.In Oppenheimer, Nolan's account of history includes a full breadth of points of view, indescribable emotions and ambiguity. He offers both objective facts of history and subjective character viewpoints, leaving us with inconclusive ideas of who J. Robert Oppenheimer really was. We are tasked with making our own decisions as to who he was because, as Nolan highlights, nobody can really say for sure.

Yes, we all expected this to be visually stunning, with a cast laden with the best in the business giving stellar performances all round. And of course, it delivers in spades.Sergio Leone's westerns were described as operas where the arias are stared rather than sung, and in Nolan's film the camera examines the characters' features in soul-stripping close up, searching for the inner thoughts of the men and women who gave birth to the atomic bomb. These are human beings, flawed and complex, and the film constantly asks who was right and who was wrong, and at the end of it all, does anyone have the moral high ground?At the heart of the film is a tale of a run-of-the-mill functionary with a jealous hatred of a far greater contemporary. The character dynamic of Oppenheimer is so reminiscent of that of Mozart v. Salieri, and the unfolding of the story is just as gripping.

I am biased towards historical period pieces as history often tells the most human stories and movies exaggerate these stories for dramatic effect. Nolan understands how to to paint a memoir of Oppenheimer without rose tinged glasses. You won't find the conventional action in this but the words spoken carry a much more compelling conflict than any car chase or battle. This is more about my love for the genre but Nolan made a great historical time piece, and to be Honest, got a lot of help from the uniqueness, complexity, and significance of having one of the most interesting men, Oppenheimer, live during one of the most interesting time periods, the 1930-40s. However these traits are a double edge sword as a lesser team would have fumbled all the details onto the screen, making the audience unable to pick up the pieces of such a complex puzzle. One more thing to remember, THIS MOVIE IS ABOUT OPPENHEIMER, NOT THE ATOMIC BOMB so don't think the bomb is the focus of the movie, it's only one chapter of Oppenheimers life. That being said go out and watch Oppenheimer to support other historical movies as history tells the most compelling stories. Because in fiction characters are good and bad but in history, everyone believes themselves to be good.
