9.5/10. Let me establish some context before I present my review. I went to watch the movie without any expectations, without prior knowledge about Oppenheimer and without even watching the trailer. My love for Christopher Nolan's work and being a huge fan of majority of the film's cast incited me to watch the movie on the first day itself. If I were to give a review in one sentence, it would be "Either you will truly love this movie or greatly appreciate it but nobody will hate it". Everything about this movie is top-notch. The casting, cinematography, direction, background score (which will take your breath away) and pretty much everything else is phenomenal with great attention to detail, something which has become a standard for Nolan's work. Just half hour into the movie and I said to myself that I am witnessing something special. There were more than two times in the movie, when I was genuinely left with my mouth wide open and eyes mesmerising at the screen. If you are interested or have spare time at your arsenal, learning something about the life about the main character and World war 2 in general would be helpful, although not compulsory by any means. It will just help you better understand the nuances of the movie and better grasp it without getting overwhelmed with the introduction of different characters. At the end, I would finish the review by saying that this is truly a cinematic experience, which needs to be enjoyed in a movie theatre in order to properly appreciate the great effort that went behind this now critically acclaimed project.

I digress).It's a film that will stick with you. It's intelligent and demanding storytelling that I hope we'll get to see a lot more like it in the coming years. It's also a good idea to watch it in theaters. The 3 hours fly by.

"Oppenheimer" has left an lasting impression on me, a feat only a handful of movies have ever accomplished. Through Nolan's exceptional storytelling and artistic abilities, this film presented history and life from fresh perspectives, which captured my attention from the opening scene to the final credits. I just sat there while the credits rolled in the end, in silence feeling a sense of the horror Oppenheimer must have felt at his accomplishment. I foresee this film having a significant influence on audiences all over the world. Prior to watching this movie, I had little knowledge of Oppenheimer. However, it has given me a fascination and hunger to learn more about him and the stories told in the movie. Oppenheimer and his associates set into motion a series of irreversible events that have significantly shaped our world. His choices and their consequences remind us of the profound impact an individual's life can have on history.

If you don't like history movies, just don't watch history movies. I'm seeing most the negative reviews here being bored by the "history lesson". But this movie is about history, so what did you expect? The "boring" part I seriously cannot understand. This was one of the most anxiety inducing, suspenseful, engaging, compelling, and interesting films I've ever seen. I think the fact that it's three hours will rule out a lot of viewers because some people just simply don't have a long enough attention span.This movie isn't really a history lesson. It's an incredibly important story about humanity. What happens when we get our hands on something with unlimited power? And what happens when we pull the trigger? When it's all over, what happens next? The aftermath of the bombings are arguably the best part of the movie. Cillian Murphy's portrayal of regret brought me to tears multiple times.The cinematography was really something else. REALLY. Never have pure visuals alone made me cry, but within the first 15 minutes of this movie, the visuals were so insanely beautiful that I just started crying out of nowhere. I couldn't control it. This movie made me care about the important historical figure of Oppenheimer more than I thought I even could. The way Nolan tells a story in three cohesive storylines is so, well, Nolan-esc, and plain genius. He helps the audience understand this mind-blowing, shocking, and tragic story in an extremely engaging way. Especially for someone like me, who didn't know the personal story of Oppenheimer aside from the Manhatten Project and the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, this movie really opened my eyes and showed me such a tragically beautiful story I didn't realize would hit me in my heart so hard. At the credits, I couldn't speak, I just sat there with my mouth open, tear running down the side of my face, and all I could think was: "cinema."The MUSIC. My gosh, Ludwig Goransson! I'm the biggest Hans Zimmer fan. I am a firm believer he's the greatest composer to walk this earth. So, I walked into this movie thinking: "Man, Hans Zimmer isn't scoring a Nolan film? Screw that. I guess this movie just won't have good music."
Oh my gosh. I underestimated Ludwig Goransson so much to the point where I am on the verge of sending him a personal apology letter about how sorry I am for doubting him. The music in this film was another contribution to my uncontrollable crying. The reacurring tempo changes in this score make my heart race, I literally forgot to breathe multiple times. What a masterful, beautiful score. It seems to pull a lot of inspiration from Johnny Greenwood's score from There Will Be Blood, with long, violin screeches and horrific orchestral buildups. I loved that, considering Greenwood's score is one of my favorites of all time.The acting was otherworldly. I was nervous Robert Downey Jr. Would show up to this movie acting like Tony Stark, but he really showed me up! He did a really fantastic, unique performance from his usual acting. His character portrayal was phenomenal, wicked, professional, and menacing. But Cillain Murphy's performance I can't even praise with words. I wasn't watching Cillian Murphy. I was watching Oppenheimer.Overall, what a masterpiece. I really can't give all my thoughts in a review, I simply can't. I never will be able to. You can't do that with something THIS good. Instead, I think I'm going to lock myself in a dark room for 5 days to process this film.

"Oppenheimer" is about nebulous men struggling with identity. We're told that the problem is morality, but the finished film - the sum total of Christopher Nolan's vision, script, direction, and ego (so much ego) - has little to say about the catastrophic technology it supposedly chronicles. It barely registers as a biopic, and it certainly isn't a meditation on history or even the bomb. Instead, it's three hours of a director insisting that he has something important to say, but that you should be smart enough to understand what that is without him having to accomplish it.And that is a problem that no one seems to be mentioning in their rapturous reviews of "Oppenheimer". What exactly is it all about?The entire film is so monotone and self-serious that one often forgets why any of the talking heads are important. They all speak and act like the same character. And honestly, they aren't particularly important. Edited linearly, "Oppenheimer" would be a quite simple, drab film. The performances are great, the roles thankless. So much so that when the only characters that suggest real people are not on screen - Downey's frustrated Lewis Strauss and Damon's General Groves - we feel their absence. Murphy does admirable work, as does Krumholtz as Isador Rabi, but really, these are flat, rote characters that gain empathy through persistence, not necessarily precision. In fact, that's the game that "Oppenheimer" plays: it only ever manages to emphasize the grey areas of it's central ethical dilemma.To that end, the bomb really doesn't matter. The devastating after effects of the device are measured in terms of its function as science and as a scientific albatross around Oppie's neck. The human cost - and the cost on Oppenheimer himself - are given passing glances, leaving us to the real meat of the film, which is, in fact, conference rooms. "Oppenheimer" is about men talking. Make no mistake.This makes for a tortuously obtuse and often offensively glib first hour. With the intrusive, often silly Tangerine Dream-esque score highlighting every petty argument and special-effects-imagining-the-cosmos scene and the spot-the-celebrity platforming, the only sign of humanity we get is literally writhing human flesh. Female nudity is a plot point for "Oppenheimer", though as in most Nolan productions, women barely exist. Here are two of Nolan's three female types: tragic trollop and tragic nag. Really, these could be any two actresses. They don't matter. Make no mistake, this is a film about men talking.The second hour is genius. Cross cutting between the genesis of the bomb and the political machinations surrounding it, you get the sense that Nolan has really found a moment of true excitement. That sets up an incredibly disappointing third act which reveals exactly how weak Nolan's script is once it literally loses the power of nuclear annihilation. Everything, in fact, comes together over a very famous meeting that, historically, never happened. Poetic license? That's a problem when you waste 3 hours browbeating the audience with conference room minutiae and a script lifting from actual government documents."Oppenheimer" - in an ironic note that I've seen leveled against "Barbie" - is a film that wants to have it's cake and eat it too. We're told that the bomb is loathsome and dreadful and unethical pornography, and so Nolan knows that we have to see it. And we want it big and messy and full of ejaculate. Never mind that 300,000 human lives were what Oppie saw every time he closed his eyes - no - Nolan returns us again and again to the conference room, where petty insults manifest in conspiracies and smirking. Lots of smirking.So what has Nolan accomplished here? The same end that he arrives at in each of his films: stolid detachment, pseudo-intellectualism, and stunning cinematic craftsmanship. Unfortunately, the movie is only worth an 90 minutes of inspired filmmaking. The rest is simply pretentious fat. Or rather, the rest is Nolan's insistence that he has something so important to say, but never gets around to it in 3 hours. Oppenheimer may be an infinitely interesting human being, but as a film character, he's cardboard, no matter how hard Murphy works to give him wrinkles.Defenders of Nolan (and they are Legion) will explain to you that this is a great anti-war film, but it tells a lot more than it shows. It's not a satire and as a history lesson, it certainly omits large sections of the timeline that may have provided some drama, like say, the fates of Daghlin and Slotin. Frankly, this is the same tiresome walk and talk that weighs down the typical Aaron Sorkin history lesson, somehow rendering all of the characters and all of the audience to the same level of "look at how smart we are just for having experienced this."None of this matters if the film moves you emotionally. I felt nothing during these 180 minutes. Certainly, I didn't come away with a greater understanding of the scope of the bomb, nor did I learn much about Oppenheimer. I learned a lot, however, about how meticulously exhausting Nolan is when Downey Jr isn't on screen.

"Oppenheimer" is a biographical thriller film written and directed by Christopher Nolan ("The Dark Knight trilogy", "Inception",
"Interstellar", "Dunkirk"), based on the biography "American Prometheus" by Kai Bird and Martin J. Sherwin. Starring Cillian Murphy in the lead role, in addition to Matt Damon, Robert Downey Jr, Emily Blunt, and Florence Pugh, it subverts the usual biopic formula to create a brilliantly layered examination of a man throughout all of his incredible accomplishments and fundamental flaws.During the height of the Second World War, theoretical physicist
J. Robert Oppenheimer (Cillian Murphy) is recruited by the United States government to oversee the "Manhattan Project", a top secret operation intended to develop the world's first nuclear weapons. After becoming acquainted with the project's director Major General Leslie Groves (Matt Damon), Oppenheimer and the General come to an agreement that the best place to carry out such an undertaking is the vast desert of Los Alamos, New Mexico. As numerous other scientists and their families are brought in to this discreet location, Oppenheimer works tirelessly around the clock to build this weapon of mass destruction before the Nazis can devise their own. With the War raging and personal troubles mounting, Oppenheimer continues to push himself to his utmost limits, but soon suffers the consequences of his dedication.

"Oppenheimer" is a cinematic masterpiece that reaffirms Christopher Nolan's position as a visionary director. With meticulous attention to historical detail, he takes us on an enthralling journey into the life of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the brilliant physicist and key figure behind the development of the atomic bomb. The cast's performances are nothing short of exceptional, with each actor breathing life into their respective characters, making them relatable and engaging.Nolan's storytelling prowess shines throughout the film, as he weaves a complex narrative that delves into Oppenheimer's personal struggles, ethical dilemmas, and the moral weight he carried with his groundbreaking work. The portrayal of the scientist's internal conflicts adds depth and humanizes a historical figure often viewed through a one-dimensional lens.Undoubtedly, the soundtrack is one of the film's standout features. Ludwigs Göransson's mesmerizing compositions perfectly complement the unfolding drama, heightening the emotional impact of each scene. The music creates an immersive experience, amplifying the tension and adding layers of emotion to pivotal moments.Visually, "Oppenheimer" is a marvel to behold. Nolan's signature style of practical effects is on full display, resulting in breathtaking visuals that transport the audience to the World War II era. The attention to historical accuracy extends to the production design, costumes, and set pieces, which further immerse viewers in the period.The film's pacing keeps audiences engaged throughout its runtime, striking a fine balance between action-packed sequences and quieter character-driven moments. Nolan masterfully maintains suspense, making the historical events feel as gripping and relevant as ever.While "Oppenheimer" is undeniably a gripping and intellectually stimulating film, some may find it challenging to follow its intricate narrative, requiring focused attention to fully appreciate its nuances. However, this complexity ultimately rewards viewers with a thought-provoking experience that lingers long after the credits roll.In conclusion, "Oppenheimer" is a cinematic tour de force that leaves an indelible mark on the viewer. Christopher Nolan's brilliant direction, coupled with an outstanding cast and a mesmerizing soundtrack, elevates the biopic into a transcendent exploration of humanity, ethics, and the consequences of scientific advancements. This is a film that demands to be seen and discussed, solidifying its place among the greatest works of modern cinema.

Oppenheimer is a cinematic masterpiece that exemplifies Christopher Nolan's unparalleled directorial genius. The movie's gripping narrative, coupled with awe-inspiring sound engineering and music, makes it an unforgettable cinematic experience.Nolan's attention to detail is evident throughout the film, and the sound engineering plays a crucial role in enhancing the storytelling. The use of sound, or lack thereof, during the atom bomb explosion scene is a stroke of brilliance. As the bomb detonates, the absence of sound leaves the audience in a state of eerie silence, mirroring the overwhelming shock experienced by the characters. When the sound eventually emerges after the fireball has vanished, it brilliantly conveys the delayed chain reaction, adding to the intensity and realism of the moment.The music in Oppenheimer complements the visuals impeccably, heightening the emotional impact of each scene.The cinematography is mesmerizing, with each shot meticulously crafted to showcase the film's historical context and psychological depth. The unique angles and perspectives allow us to understand the characters on a deeper level, giving insight into their struggles, motivations, and emotions. The visuals alone are a testament to Nolan's mastery as a storyteller.The stellar cast, led by Cillian Murphy's exceptional performance as J. Robert Oppenheimer, elevates the film to new heights. Robert Downey Jr., Emily Blunt, Florence Pugh, and the entire ensemble deliver powerful and nuanced portrayals, breathing life into their respective characters. The chemistry among the cast is palpable, adding layers of authenticity to the relationships portrayed on screenIn conclusion, Oppenheimer is a cinematic triumph that showcases Christopher Nolan's brilliance as a director. The impeccable sound engineering and captivating music draw the audience deeper into the story, while the unique shots and mesmerizing visuals create an immersive experience. The lack of sound during the atom bomb explosion scene is a masterstroke, heightening the impact and intensity of the moment. The entire cast's remarkable performances, led by Cillian Murphy, make this film an extraordinary cinematic journey. Oppenheimer is an exceptional testament to Nolan's filmmaking prowess and is undoubtedly a must-watch for any cinephile.

Nolan's newest movie, which tells the story of the brilliant J Robert Oppenheimer, will satisfy his fandom with a full Nolan experience. Fast pacing, unsequenced scenes loaded with dialogue and played by a great cast will keep you on the edge of your seat. Both Cillian Murphy and Robert Downey Jr. Deliver their best performance to date.The movie tells two stories, the story of the atomic bomb and the story of Oppenheimer. Trying to do both in one movie is ambitious and results in a constant salvo of information which might not be everyones cup of tea.The story of the atomic bomb takes roughly two thirds of the film to create and is very fast paced. The pace is justified by the sense of urgency to work against the clock against the nazis. Matt Damon as Leslie Groves creates short moments of tranquility as one of the only layman characters surrounded by the intellectual brightest of their time. The culmination of this part, the explosion of the bomb, is done beautiful and created silence throughout the packed cinema.After the atomic bomb comes the nuclear fallout. Not only for the people in Japan, but also in Oppenheimers life. Not radiation poisioning, but opportunism by lesser men during McCarthyism plague Oppenheimers life. This part of the movie has flaws. It is not shown to the viewer why the security clearance of Oppenheimer is of such importance that it needs another hour of screenplay. The motives are clear, Robert Downey Jr is great as Strauss, but the deposition scenes feel unnecessary, Oppenheimers character development is limited and it takes the spotlight away from the moral questions surrounding using science for mass destruction. Nolan clearly signals to the viewer that the movie is a biography of Oppenheimer, rather than the atomic bomb.I'm unsure if the movie needed the villainization of the Strauss character when the real villain was the creation of Oppenheimer and his team.Anyway, Nolan did it again. You leave the cinema with questions about good, bad, lesser evil and the purpose of war. The Red Scare is purposefully portrayed as yet another time in history when dissenters were structurally humiliated and the Truman scene is a satirical wink to the Anglosphere. Einsteins scenes were thoughtful. Bohr's question is yet to be anwered, will the bomb end all wars, or will the bomb end civilization?

"Titan! To whose immortal eyes
The sufferings of mortality,
Seen in their sad reality,
Were not as things that gods despise;"In his poem Prometheus (1816), Lord Byron praised the revolutionary deeds of the legendary Greek character who stole fire from the Olympian gods and gave it to mankind to prosper technology, science, and civilisation more broadly. These words rightfully characterize the protagonist of the film Oppenheimer (2023), who rather invented a source of fire with the intention of attaining peace and ending war and devastation. Christopher Nolan's dubiously called magnum opus is vastly based on the 2005 biography American Prometheus by Kai Bird and Martin J. Sherwin. This biographical thriller delves into the intriguing life and dilemmatic psychology of Julius Robert Oppenheimer, the Father of Atom Bomb. Cillian Murphy stars as Dr Oppenheimer, with Emily Blunt as his wife, Katherine Oppenheimer, Matt Damon as General Leslie Groves, Oppenheimer's military handler, Robert Downey Jr. As Lewis Strauss, a senior member of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, and Florence Pugh as Jean Tatlock, a member of the Communist Party in the USA. Apart from the brilliant job done by the ensemble cast, the outstanding screenplay, groundbreaking background score and cinematic grandeur makes it a sublime marriage of far-reaching excellence.The movie begins with a colour close-up shot of Murphy as Oppenheimer labeled as "Fission" and the following scene features a similar shot of Downey Jr. As Strauss in monochrome titled as "Fusion." While the colour sequences represent the subjective elements and depict Oppenheimer's perspective, showing his moral struggle and personal relationships, the black-and-white sections present the objective historical perspective, focusing on the repercussions of the atomic bomb, particularly the hearings against Oppenheimer. Thus from the very beginning, Nolan epitomizes the theme of duality and sets the mood of ambivalence in the audience's minds. Scuffling with homesickness and anxiety while studying in Cambridge, the 22-year-old Oppenheimer leaves for his tutor Patrick Blackett a poisoned apple but undergoes a change of conscience and prevents Niels Bohr from eating it.Nolan adeptly employs a variety of allusions to develop Oppenheimer's personality and indicate his wide-ranging interest in many other areas. Murphy holds in his hand The Waste Land (1922) by T. S. Eliot, a classic work of modern literature that captures the disenchantment of the post-war generation. He also visits a museum and is struck by Pablo Picasso's Seated Woman with Arms Crossed (1937), which was painted during the Spanish Civil War the same year as Guernica. In addition to providing an early indication of Oppenheimer's kaleidoscopic and fragmented mind, this montage sequence, combined with Oppenheimer's observation of the Cubist paintings, the dazzling fire, and the smashing of wine glasses, approximates the nonlinear structure of the movie. Instead of digging into the details of fusion and fission, Nolan instead uses quick cuts to stunning visuals of particles, stars, and light to evoke the sublimity of these ideas while playing Ludwig Göransson's score at its loudest.The audience is then taken through the long process behind the Trinity Test. Oppenheimer has been recruited by U. S. Army General Leslie Groves (Matt Damon) to supervise the Manhattan Project and create an atomic bomb. Being Jewish, he is particularly driven by the possibility that the Nazis have a nuclear weapons program underway, under Heisenberg's direction. In Los Alamos, New Mexico, Oppenheimer assembles a group of scientists that includes Edward Teller, Isidor Isaac Rabi, and David Hill with the objective of secretly developing the weapon that, despite its possible worldwide repercussions will rescue the world. During the development, Bohr visits and Oppenheimer discusses with Albert Einstein the potential for such a bomb to set off a domino effect that might wipe out humanity. Eventually, the bomb is completed and the Trinity test goes off without a hitch. During the spine-chilling background score and the fast cut shots moments before the blast and the remaining silence afterwards, the audience cannot even blink for a second. William L. Laurence wrote, "The big boom came about 100 seconds after the Great Flash-the first cry of a newborn world. It brought the silent, motionless silhouettes to life, and gave them a voice. A loud cry filled the air."While everyone around him was experiencing unadulterated satisfaction, Oppenheimer briefly considered all the destructive potential of this weapon. He remembers verses from the Hindu scripture Bhagavad Gita as he observes the humongous mushroom cloud rising into the heavens above Point Zero- "We knew the world would not be the same. A few people laughed, and a few people cried. Most people were silent." He has dutifully carried out his tasks, much like Prince Arjuna, but their menacing results have turned him into an eradicating miscreant. He speaks the words of Lord Vishnu with revolting terror and insatiable guilt- "Now I am become death, the destroyer of worlds."In Robert Louis Stevenson's The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, Dr. Jekyll wrote to Utterson, "If I am the chief of sinners, I am the chief of sufferers also." When America drops the atomic bomb on Hiroshima and Nagasaki after the resounding success of the Trinity Test, Oppenheimer had a similar epiphany. We see a glimpse of the psychological outcomes of Oppenheimer's remarkable accomplishment-guilt, emotional suppression, and rational justifications. He realizes, "physics and the teaching of physics, which is my life, now seems irrelevant." Oppenheimer's oscillating psyche is affected by the incessant pounding of the triumphant Americans on the wooden floor. Oppenheimer opens his statement with the words "The world will remember this day," but his repeated pauses and downcast look give the impression that he is nothing but a puppet to the U. S. government."What was thy pity's recompense?A silent suffering, and intense; The rock, the vulture, and the chain, All that the proud can feel of pain."This elucidation from Byron's Prometheus can be distinguished in the flaming blue eyes of Cillian Murphy in which we see not sincerity but a kind of unaltered shock. The shaky background, glowing visuals and handheld close-up shots add to the horrifying consequences of the bombing. The constant psychological dilemma of Oppenheimer becomes evident as he walks out of the exhilarating crowd and steps on the scorched dead body almost turning into "a handful of dust.""Thy Godlike crime was to be kind" - writes Byron about Prometheus. Oppenheimer begs President Truman at their meeting to prevent the creation of more powerful weapons like the hydrogen bomb. Though he utters "I have blood on my hands," but Truman perceives his distress as cowardice. Truman is played by veteran actor Gary Oldman, who gives a brief but impactful performance. Finally, after various hearings in the courtroom, Oppenheimer's security clearance is revoked tarnishing his reputation and reducing his political influence. Later, at a Senate confirmation hearing David Hill reveals Lewis Strauss's personal reasons for orchestrating Oppenheimer's destruction. The audience may ponder the same question Oppenheimer posed at a party in Berkeley - "What happens to stars when they die?" The "star" of the nation who contributed to the victory in the war is shunned. However, Nolan's own assessment of Oppenheimer as "the most important person who ever lived," prompts us to consider another question - "Do the stars die?"The ending of the film calls back to an earlier moment of Oppenheimer and Albert Einstein (Tom Conti) speaking by a pond. We now examine the same situation from Oppenheimer's perspective in colour as compared to Strauss' initial, monochromatic perspective. Einstein, who has been shown as an avuncular figure throughout the film gently asks a few questions to Oppenheimer and makes a prognostication. "Now it's your turn to deal with the consequences of your achievement" - speaks Einstein who personally experienced the agonising effects of the scientific establishment. Oppenheimer will be awarded and salmon feasts will be hosted in his honour, he predicts and says, "They'll pat you on the back, tell you all is forgiven." While he talks, we see brief flashes forward of Oppenheimer as an elderly man receiving rewards from the President and being formally celebrated by former adversaries. "Just remember, it won't be for you. It will be for them," Einstein adds. The film's closing frames which mirror the opening scenes, serve as a sobering reminder of how interconnected everything is and how decisions made by one affect the rest of the world.The circular ripples in the pond that symbolizes the chain reaction of atoms recall the raindrops on a puddle at the beginning of the film, creating rings like the radius of an atomic bomb. When Isador Rabi uses a compass to mark the evident radius of the bomb on a map during a roundtable meeting, the circle metaphor may be seen in action once more. Nolan incorporates water in various parts of the film not only is a recurring antithesis to the diabolical catastrophe and serves as a symbol of serene and peace. Nolan has a reputation for mind-bending, twisty-turny movies that leave your brain in knots, right? Well, despite it's magnificence, "Oppenheimer" doesn't exactly fit that bill.Oppenheimer takes a different approach. It aims to give us a true portrayal of the protagonist, the man behind the atomic bomb. It's a more linear narrative than what we're used to.There's one little thing that caught me off guard - and not in a satisfactory way: the nudity scenes. Thy felt forced, graphic, and out of place.The other surprise was the intensity of the dialogue. It felt clunky and sometimes killed the momentum of the film. Nolan usually has this knack for sharp and memorable lines, but this time around, it fell a little flat.I found myself waiting for those powerful, mind-bending exchanges, but they were few and far between.On a positive note, the acting is absolutely stellar. Robert J. Oppenheimer (Cillian Murphy) and Edward Teller (Benny Safdie) were unbelievable and authentic performances the likes of which we have NEVER seen on screen.Visually, it's still a Nolan film, so you can expect some stunning cinematography and breathtaking shots. The attention to detail is, as always, on point, making the experience a treat for the eyes and ears.Without a doubt, the 70mm used to make this movie makes you feel like you're back in 1945.In the end, "Oppenheimer" might not be the Nolan mind-bender we've come to expect, but it does offer a sincere and more grounded look at the life of a historical figure who changed the f*cking world.If you're expecting twisty narratives and jaw-dropping moments (apart from a couple of scenes), you might leave the theater feeling a tad disappointed.Still, you cannot miss seeing this in the cinema. Even if it's not entirely up to his usual mind-blowing standards.Bravo again, Sir Christoper Nolan.

Oppenheimer is a one-of-a-kind film, a brilliant blend of a biography, a drama and a war film.The film is perfectly made, through the narration of Oppenheimer's prehistory, with the constant changes to the present, the epic music, which in any case fits perfectly with the story told. The highlight of the film, the Manhattan Project, is better executed than anything before, the moment when the atomic bomb explodes, the cinema hall is illuminated.And then nothing. Silence. Until the sound brings the explosion with it. The scenes in the courtroom when Oppenheimer is accused of being considered a communist. When he is defended by his wife and friends, and you keep seeing scenes from the past, with the perfectly acknowledged music. Just wow. The final scenes, when Oppenheimer talks to Einstein at the pond about the possible chain reaction, will be considered one of the best plots of all time. The visions he created shortly before the film ends and the cinema screen goes dark are incredibly well realized and stayed in my head for days afterwards.The cast was perfect, everyone embodied their role incredibly. A film that will stay in your memory forever!!!

I don't feel fully equipped to review Oppenheimer. I don't know if I was fully equipped to see it. Is seeing even the right term? I was snapped up by it, tossed about by it, brought to tears by it, left shaken by it.First some context: I drove 2.5 hrs to see it in IMAX 70mm today.The first minute or two made my jaw drop and moved me to tears. I wish more films would be made in start-to-finish analog IMAX because I've never in my life seen such beautiful imagery for a movie. (Shout out to our projectionist who assembled the 600lb print out of the five sections shipped to the theater). I saw Oppenheimer described as a film centered about the human face and that's an apt description. Every moment of IMAX footage is a visual joy, and the way it captures the face is splendid.Oppenheimer is long fast movie. It was a massive amount to take in, and honestly much of it after Trinity blurs together a bit in my memory, with a few exceptions. Every scene with Einstein stood out, as did the church/hall/gathering scene where Oppenheimer greets a crowd. Some of the pivotal hearing scenes stick out. The last scene of the movie was absolutely chilling. There's so much to digest, to return to. All of it was at least good, and a handful of scenes were the best bits of cinema I've ever seen. For these scenes and in expectation of a repeat viewing where I'll digest more of the '54 hearing scenes better, I venture to give Oppenheimer a full mark of 10/10.

"Oppenheimer" is an awe-inspiring cinematic triumph that surpasses all expectations. Clocking in at a remarkable three hours, it boldly claims the title of the longest IMAX film ever, and rightfully so.Christopher Nolan's directorial genius shines once more, elevating "Oppenheimer" above even his own acclaimed works like "Interstellar." This movie is undeniably a groundbreaking masterpiece in the history of cinema. It effortlessly weaves an enthralling narrative around the captivating true story it portrays.The film's unique subject matter delves into the life and legacy of J. Robert Oppenheimer, whose contributions to history continue to reverberate to this day. Nolan's impeccable storytelling, coupled with a stellar ensemble cast, breathes life into the characters and transports the audience to a different era.The breathtaking cinematography captures the grandeur of the Manhattan Project and the complexities of the human spirit. The use of IMAX technology elevates the visual experience to a whole new dimension, making "Oppenheimer" a visually mesmerizing spectacle.The narrative's depth and emotional resonance leave a lasting impact on viewers, sparking contemplation and awe. As the story unfolds, you'll find yourself drawn into a world of passion, intellect, and moral dilemmas that grip your heart and mind.With its seamless blend of historical accuracy and artistic vision, "Oppenheimer" becomes more than just a film; it becomes an immersive experience that stays with you long after the credits roll. Nolan's masterful direction and the cast's exceptional performances breathe life into the past, making history come alive on the silver screen.In conclusion, "Oppenheimer" is a rare gem in modern cinema, an unforgettable journey into the depths of history and human ambition. Christopher Nolan's unparalleled storytelling, combined with the innovative use of IMAX, cements this film as a landmark achievement. For anyone seeking a captivating, thought-provoking, and visually astounding experience, "Oppenheimer" is an absolute must-see. Prepare to be enthralled and enlightened in equal measure as you witness this cinematic magnum opus that will undoubtedly be remembered for generations to come.

Oppenheimer is a 2023 historical epic film directed by Christopher Nolan and written by Nolan and the late David Kajganich. The film stars Cillian Murphy as J. Robert Oppenheimer, the scientist who led the Manhattan Project to develop the atomic bomb during World War II. The film also stars Emily Blunt, Matt Damon, Robert Downey Jr., Florence Pugh, Benny Safdie, Rami Malek, and Kenneth Branagh.Oppenheimer is a sweeping and ambitious film that tells the story of one of the most consequential events in human history. Nolan's direction is masterful, and he brings the story to life with stunning visuals and an immersive soundscape. The performances are all top-notch, with Murphy giving a tour-de-force performance as Oppenheimer.The film is not without its flaws. The runtime is a bit long, and the pacing can be slow at times. However, these flaws are minor compared to the film's many strengths. Oppenheimer is a powerful and thought-provoking film that is sure to stay with you long after you've seen it.Here are some of the things that make Oppenheimer a 10 out of 10 film:The direction is masterful. Nolan creates a truly immersive experience that takes you inside the mind of Oppenheimer and the Manhattan Project.The performances are all top-notch. Murphy gives a tour-de-force performance as Oppenheimer, and the supporting cast is also excellent.The visuals are stunning. Nolan uses his trademark visual style to create some truly memorable images.The score is haunting and atmospheric. Ludwig Göransson's score perfectly complements the film's visuals and tone.The story is both complex and engaging. Oppenheimer is a challenging film, but it is also a rewarding one.If you are a fan of historical epics, science fiction, or Christopher Nolan, then you need to see Oppenheimer. It is a truly remarkable film that is sure to leave a lasting impression.Here are some of the specific things that I loved about the film:The way that Nolan uses visuals to tell the story. The film is full of stunning images that help to convey the scale and complexity of the Manhattan Project.The performances of the cast. Murphy is excellent as Oppenheimer, and the supporting cast is also very good.The score by Ludwig Göransson. The score is haunting and atmospheric, and it perfectly complements the film's visuals and tone.The way that the film explores the moral implications of the atomic bomb.Oppenheimer is a film that asks difficult questions, and it does so in a thoughtful and nuanced way.Overall, Oppenheimer is a masterpiece. It is a film that is both visually stunning and intellectually stimulating. I highly recommend it to anyone who is a fan of historical epics, science fiction, or Christopher Nolan.

Had always been a fan of Nolan's works, but Oppenheimer certainly is not one of them. Here are my reasons.First of all, the editing is a huge mess. Unnecessarily overcomplicated and rushed. The movie brushes through scenes like it's browsing on Tiktok, and jumps around different timelines like it has ADHD. What's worse is that a lot of these mini scenes are pretty much pointless fillers, serving no purpose whatsoever.Second, they throw in new characters every few minutes and fail to develop almost any of them. Despite the great acting, they still feel dull and abundant. By the end of the movie, I couldn't recognize half of the cast nor do I care much about them.Most importantly, does it have to be THIS LONG? The first half of the events are simply unnecessary and uninteresting. The length could have been cut down by an hour and nothing will be lost. I understand Nolan wants to include Oppenheimer's private life as well as events that impacted him prior/post the Manhattan project. However most of these are at very surface level, as the movie tries to run through so many different storylines and yet didn't really focus on and dive into any of them. It wasn't as thought provoking or emotion evoking as it tries to be, instead it becomes a tedious mess with so much happening but nothing much to take away from.I have to make it clear though, despite my rant, I don't think this is a bad movie. I think the scenes are well shot and directed. The cinematography and acting is undoubtedly top tier. I like the visuals and sound effects, and certainly enjoyed the second half way more than the first.That being said, this is still quite a let down as I had a lot of expectation for this one. Although this could be the type of movie that you'd enjoy more on a second watch (given more context), I 100% will not spend another 3hrs on this ever again.

Not sure the hype around Oppenheimer. I am a fan of Nolan but his storytelling is somewhat strange. Timeline never flows properly and the movie likes to jump all around.I like Dunkirk, I love Batman Dark Knight Trilogy, I thought Inception was thought provoking as well as Interstellar but his last film Tenet and this one was just utterly bad storytelling.There are many parts to like, the great music the odd and weird way we get to feel inside Oppenheimer's head but for the most part the movie was just too long and narrative was all over the place.There is story about his youth, story about his Manhattan project, story about his politics, story about his trial to remove his status and finally a story about a political rival ann maybe even a story about his lover. If you could of rearrange and stop jumping around this movie would of been better for me.

Christopher Nolan's latest addition to his already impressive repertoire, is a tale about a famous figure that is haunted by what the future might hold after having made crucial decisions that changed the world forever, and the movie isn't about events that took place at certain times, but it is about the man that was responsible for them; Julius Robert Oppenheimer, the father of the atomic bomb.The most impressive thing about Oppenheimer is that it has all the makings of a boring movie, and a lesser experienced director might have deviated from the core of the movie. For instance, the movie is three hours long, and it's mostly shot in rooms where people are having discussions; in many ways the explosives were in the back seat for the whole movie, and one might argue that it's for the better.This movie is a cinematic experience that can only be described as a masterpiece, and we see the whole journey that Oppe had taken during world war 2.Cillian Murphy gave an Oscar winning performance and the performance of a lifetime for him, and we all think that it's been long overdue as he waited for a moment like this his whole career and finally got the best of the best.All in all, we need to be very focused and ready as the movie moves very fast in the first hour, and finally it's definitely a top three movie for Nolan.

The film could have focused more on the war and less about the communist associations of his earlier life. But the film still was incredibly well written, directed and choreographed.At the end of the day, I hope most people realize the frightening power of nuclear energy. No victor will and can be declared in nuclear warfare, the only victor is the dead.

From the very beginning to the absolute last moment of this masterpiece, you will be completely captivated in all facets of the word. The visual effects I saw on screen and the wicked audio that shook the ground below at times have been unmatched by anything else I have witnessed. Combine this with a story that will keep you on your heels through the entire three hour duration that this movie holds and it is absolutely worthwhile for anybody and everybody to see.I'd like to use this review to also point out the impeccable performances so many actors in this film put on and will almost certainly be used as defining moments in their careers: Cillian Murphy, Robert Downey Jr., Emily Blunt, Rami Malek, Josh Harnett, Gary Oldman, etc.,

Oppenheimer is an absolute triumph in the world of cinema, leaving a lasting impression with its powerful storytelling and exceptional performances. Cillian Murphy's portrayal of J. Robert Oppenheimer is nothing short of mesmerizing. He flawlessly captures the physicist's brilliance, inner conflicts, and transformation throughout the film. Robert Downey Jr., in a supporting role, delivers a compelling performance, showcasing his versatility as an actor.The film's musical score, composed by a maestro, complements the narrative beautifully. It weaves a tapestry of emotions, heightening the tension and drama of pivotal moments. The music becomes an integral part of the movie, guiding viewers through Oppenheimer's journey and adding layers of depth to the storytelling.Overall, Oppenheimer is a tour de force, tackling complex themes of ambition, ethics, and the human cost of scientific progress. The direction is masterful, deftly balancing the scientific discoveries with the personal struggles of its characters. The film's narrative arc keeps viewers engaged from start to finish, evoking a wide range of emotions.

Wow, just wow. Christopher Nolan came back to film with one of the greatest examples of storytelling ever. Even though Oppenheimer is a biopic, Nolan still manages to deliver a beautifully crafted story about a complex and morally gray genius. Though I believe this was a little too dense and could have been shortened up or made into two different movies, it still manages to keep your attention throughout your viewing. Nolans style is at its absolute peak and creatively intelligent. Along with beautiful writing, comes an expertly assembled cast. Cillian Murphy absolutely brought everything he had to this role and it shows. Robert Downey Jr. Finally gets to show his immense talent and range. Emily Blunt and Florence Pugh give convincing emotional performances and really embody their characters. Every actor is absolutely spectacular, and it enhances the movie so much. Cinematography has always been a key part of Nolans films, but this movie's visuals are utterly stunning. The camera work and practical effects leave you with a sense of dread and fear of what Oppenheimer created, but that's also thanks to the intense audio mixing. All in all, Nolan has made the film of the year. He has shown that a movie doesn't tell just a situation, but an actual story. Oscar worthy is an understatement.

I respect Nolan's craft but I am not a fan.I was left a bit bemused with the decisions that Nolan has taken as a director for this film. The entire first half the audience is made to invest emotionally in the making of the A-bomb. Because of the nature of the storytelling showing the film from the point of view of Oppenheimer, it is a natural way of making the audience root for the main character. Understood. Accepted.The second half goes in establishing that Oppenheimer was a true patriot. He is even decorated for his contribution.But what about the aftermath?Yes there are mentions here and there. But there is no visible remorse. Nor in his actions it is clear. It is as if there is no accountability in the man. That is what baffled me the most. Was it the plan to hang it in the middle and allow the audience to choose how they see it fit? If yes then why tell the story from Oppenheimer's pov? Why make the audience connect with the man? The emotional investment in the main character only to be left wondering in the end as to why Nolan chose to leave it this way?This may have worked for every other person but sadly it has not worked for me.There is nothing great that we have not already seen in a Nolan film. The acting overall is good. Clearly the studio backed Nolan very well, so well that the film has prominent actors even in short cameos.It's 5/10 for me as the movie, for me, fails at a human level. The film has no soul.

Nolan has done it again as he tells a tight and amazing story matched with great visuals, cinematography, and score while leaving you deeply connecting with the theme of the film. I left the theatre today not to claps or conversation but it was silent, and the reason I was silent is because diving into that story and the mind of Oppenheimer it really shows how complex of a time it was and leaves you in a grey area, up to your interpretation. I've always view nuclear bombs as the destroyer of worlds as Oppenheimer puts it, yet it has led to the longest relative peace time that we have seen.Along side with the free existential crisis, Oppenheimer also delivered with amazing performances from Murphy, Downey Jr. And blunt. Watching these three well known actors I didn't even notice them, I was totally lost in 1940 with them being able to feel everything they felt truly great performances.These are the type of films I miss from Hollywood, something that challenges the viewer something that was made with a clear vision that was done how it was meant to be done, a director and it's cast with no big wig effecting the production.

The most important part of this film, in my opinion, is the parallel between Oppenheimer and the myth of Prometheus and his sins, the missing part of this mythical story is the liberation of Prometheus by a titan who, seeing his innocence in his attempt to deliver fire and revelation to mankind, unlocks his chains.Oppenheimer receives no such redemption, for when he seeks it he is treated as a coward, a crybaby and a weakling, and is even accused of his sentences. The only thing he received is public oblivion, that his deeds are not forgiven, but are demeaned of severity and damage, as Einstein tells him in one of his final conversations, all applauding and commemorating him, regardless of his obvious sins.

Before I watched the film I was exposed to a few not-so-positive reviews, and my high hopes got replaced by a small preparation of being let down. OppenheimerIt's interesting that now, a time fully surrounded by political rhetoric and opposing sides on seemingly everything, there is a remembrance that it's actually been this way for a very long time.At its core (pun intended) "Oppenheimer" is knee-deep in a reflection about Mccarthyism. Probably something most have forgotten from their brief studies into US political history that one sophomore afternoon in High School. Beyond that, nothing."Oppenheimer" is also about what can happen when the collective is all pulling in the same direction. In this case the collective science and knowledge from most of the brightest people of the last 120 years; brought together for one single purpose.Lastly, of course "Oppenheimer" visits world history as it reflects on the unknown, war, and the atomic (now nuclear) age.The move reveals itself in layers, swirling between the past and present, with distinctly different topics all finding themselves interwoven.As the goal was ending WWII, in many ways the fears they had of possibly ending the world instead STILL transcend upon us in fear today. They call it mutually assured destruction, one which was certain envisioned and predicted 7+ decades ago.It's odd to say that "Oppenheimer" the movie is a slow-burn as it is a VERY slow burn indeed. Especially when you overlay the fast burn, the explosion, the devastation that occurs at an instant when viewing the film as only about a bomb. It is... however it really isn't at all.With an evening to digest the movie prior to this review, there was a lot of interesting cinematography, history-telling of multiple stories, and facts just touched upon that made for an interesting... but not a fantastic... movie.All in all, it was nice to see the crowds at the AMC theater with Barbie and MI playing too. Oppenheimer was a B- from me, a C from her.

Nolan has a reputation for creating thought-provoking and visually stunning films, and "Oppenheimer" promises to be no exception. With a talented cast, a compelling story, and Nolan's signature cinematic style, this film is sure to be a cinematic event that will be talked about for years to come.One of the most exciting aspects of "Oppenheimer" is the cast. The film will star Cillian Murphy in the lead role as J. Robert Oppenheimer, and he is joined by a talented ensemble cast that includes Emily Blunt, Matt Damon, and Robert Downey Jr. With such an impressive cast, it's clear that Nolan is committed to bringing the story of Oppenheimer to life in a powerful and engaging way.But what really sets "Oppenheimer" apart is the story itself. The Manhattan Project was one of the most significant and controversial events in modern history, and Nolan has the opportunity to explore the complex ethical, moral, and political issues that surrounded its development. The film promises to explore not just the scientific and technical aspects of the project, but also the human drama and personal struggles of the people involved.Of course, no Christopher Nolan film would be complete without stunning visuals and mind-bending concepts, and "Oppenheimer" is sure to deliver on that front as well. Nolan has a reputation for pushing the boundaries of what's possible in filmmaking, and "Oppenheimer" promises to be his most ambitious project yet.Overall, "Oppenheimer" is shaping up to be an epic and thought-provoking film that will showcase Nolan's unparalleled talent for storytelling, visual spectacle, and complex themes. With an impressive cast, a compelling story, and Nolan's visionary direction, "Oppenheimer" promises to be a cinematic experience that will stay with audiences long after the credits roll.

After letting the movie marinate in my head for some time, i am dissapointed with it. Plain and simple. I am the biggest Nolan fan (Inception, Interstellar and TDK are in my top 5 all time), and this, plus the fact that almost everyone seems to be putting this movie through the roof, made me go in with more hype than i've had in a long time. Unfortunately, the movie is not what i expected. Not by a long shot. As a big fan of history, plus anything to do with atomic bombs/nuclear power, and everything the trailers led us to believe, i thought Nolan would create a fast paced, time distorted story around some of my favorite topics. Instead, time distorting is what i felt in the last hour of the movie, as it felt as though time was standing still and the movie dragged on until the end. The reason for this is that Nolan focuses 90% of this 3 hour movie on the events outside the creation of the bomb, with long drawn out court/interrogation scenes, making this feel more like a Strauss vs Oppenheimer than about the story of the father of the atomic bomb. For context, i love great dialogue in movies/TV. But this was too much and not interesting enough. The black and white honestly didnt land either. Also, after hearing for months about the explosion scene that Nolan created with no CGI, hearing him say this needed to be seen in Imax, hearing how this movie was gonna be a mindblowing display of sound/visuals, left me all the more dissapointed when the explosion scene lasted no more than 10 minutes. At first when it ended i thought, surely we will see more of it with the bombings of Japan, but no. That was it. Was the point of seeing it in Imax, only for those 10 (albeit great) minutes of the explosion scene? There is no need for Imax for 3 hours of dialogue. I also heard several people in th early screenings talk about a "horror" theme to this movie. Maybe those people had just finished watching Barbie and were not being objective. This movie did not have horror themes at all. It barely explores Oppenheimer's feelings after the bombs are released. Instead we see the final hour with more of Strauss vs Oppie. Let me also give some credit where its due. The cinematography, the sound, and the acting were great. Its what we expect of Nolan. But when you strip away all those things and look at only the story, its not great, instead its quite boring. Looking only at the story, i could have been fooled into thinking this was a documentary movie on netflix. Perhaps its on me, for going in with such high expectations for a Nolan movie. If you haven't seen it yet, lower your expectations.

Probably the only director of our times whose name is enough to pull the crowd to theaters. His best quality is that he thinks that the audience is smart enough to understand and doesn't spoon feed everything.Oppenheimer is a biographical thriller which makes Nolan sit in another league of filmmakers. His Nolan ness is stamped in every scene. Caution - don't expect action or masala entertainment here, it's a very serious study of the character of the father of the atomic bomb.Every time I see a biopic I want to go into the psyche of the protagonist but only a handful of movies were successful in doing that, and this is one of them. From the first frame till the last one you are with Oppenheimer, Nolan grabs you by neck and puts it into the mind of the character. His struggles, his inner turmoil, his guilt you feel it in every frame. This was also possible because of Cillian Murphy, It will be his career defining role. He has just become Oppenheimer. In some of the scenes his acting chops are just masterclass.Casting is done so perfectly that you cannot imagine any other actor in that role. RDJ makes worthy as a opponent to Cillian Murphys character. His brilliance overshadows his persona. Mat Damon, Emily Blunt, Cassey Affleck, Gary Oldman every one is brilliant in their portrayal. This is Nolan's legacy that great actor's have agreed to appear for one or two scenes just to be associated with Nolan and trust on his filmaking. Everyone has given their best.Music by Ludwig Göransson is special, it perfectly fits the scenes and makes the movie more immersive. Although I felt the Hans Zimmer mark on it. Cinematography, editing, production design, writing you name it every department has given their best to this project. Highlights are 2 sequences the detonation of the bomb and the gym speech sequence. This is the most refined film making you will get. Hats of to his vision and guts to not to use CGI. But still managing to get emotions out of you.We in India had something similar to this, the story of Nambi Narayanan. R Madhavan tried his best to make his directorial debut from this story but it felt short on a lot of levels. If you really want to compare, then compare The Nambi effect with Oppenheimer, you will know how much behind we are than Hollywood.For me by far this is Nolan's best as pure film making point of view. It's 3 hours long, dialogue and conversation heavy but the way it is paced you won't feel the length. But it doesn't have the same re-watchable quality like his other movies. It's not for everyone, normal film audience will be bored. But it's a feast for cinephiles like me. It stunns you with his craft. More power to Nolan. It's an Oscar studded movie, by far the best film of the year. Thank you for this and as always eagerly waiting for your next.#Oppenheimer #oppenheimermovie #moviereview #Oppenheimerreview.

Oppenheimer is a very good movie, starring Cillian Murphy as Robert J. Oppenheimer, the father of the atomic bomb. The film is rated R for nudity and sexual themes, so many women are walking out of the theater for what they perceive to be patriarchal oppression. Though that part didn't personally bother me, Christopher Nolan could've deleted those scenes to get a PG-13 rating so the film could've grossed more money. Anyway, Oppenheimer's runtime is 3 hours 15 minutes.Now I really think Oppenheimer would be difficult for non-American audiences to fully appreciate and non-native English-speaking audiences to catch all the dialogue. The film is very dialogue heavy and the beat in the background is loud enough that you'll have to strain your ears. The film in general is difficult to fully grasp because of the huge cast of characters and the fractured narrative of the script. Lots of times, the film is in black and white. Nolan is also fixated on the historicity of the script such as when a general said, "I don't want to drop the bomb on Kyoto because of its huge cultural significance and because my wife and I honeymooned there." Or when Oppenheimer said, "Now that we've finished our work at Los Alamos, I plan to give the land back to the Indians." Anyone not familiar with the history of the Manhattan Project would probably miss those lines of real-life lore.What really impressed me was how the film was basically broken up into three parts. The first part was about Oppenheimer's personal and academic life and how he theorized the atom bomb thanks to Albert Einstein's work in the field. The second part was when the general (Matt Damon) built a town in the New Mexico desert at Los Alamos so Oppenheimer could make and test the bomb. The third part was about the government interrogation of Oppenheimer's ties to communism and the bad guy named Strauss (Robert Downey Jr.) who wanted to be appointed to a presidential cabinet position and gain bureaucratic powers setting Oppenheimer up for failure. Thus the movie's themes and subplots wove together like an elegant tapestry. My only problem is that the film is so dialogue heavy, you can't lose focus for a single scene. Cillian Murphy who I enjoyed as Thomas Shelby from Peaky Blinders stole the show.

I know with Christopher Nolan's Dunkirk, that clicked on a second watch, so maybe Oppenheimer will need one too. That being said, I don't feel the need to rush out and see it again too soon, because it was a long and exhausting film.But in many ways, I can't deny it was an exceptionally well made one. It looks and sounds as amazing as you'd expect, feeling as though it accurately captures the time period it's set in, and containing amazing sound design and one of the year's best scores so far. Every performance is good to great, but the film belongs to Cillian Murphy, and I feel like he's the lead actor to beat at this stage, if we're talking (early) awards consideration.The film's at its best when it focuses on being a psychological thriller featuring a famous historical figure, and at one point, it even turns into a psychological horror film. There's one sequence in here involving a speech that's particularly terrifying. It also manages to have some very suspenseful moments, even though its story is commonly known history at this point.I did really feel the length in the final hour, though, and maybe I wish that final act had been more of an extended epilogue, rather than a whole third of the movie. I currently feel as though I would've loved Oppenheimer more had it been 2.5 hours instead of 3, but nothing about it was bad by any means; just a little patience testing (this is very subjective - I remember feeling like the similarly long Babylon totally justified its runtime, though others didn't feel that way).I'm left feeling like I watched a film that wasn't a slam dunk, but was incredible for more of its runtime than it wasn't. And that's still worth celebrating, and makes Oppenheimer worth seeing in cinemas for sure.

I watched Oppenheimer on IMAX 1570 film at the only theatre showing this format in the Southern Hemisphere, the Melbourne IMAX.Overall, I think the movie is interesting, but it fails my expectations.First, I have read before viewing that the screen will be filled in some scenes. I assumed that those scenes would be the dramatic scenes. However, the aspect ratio keeps changing, even the middle of a scene, for no obvious reason. Take the example of the scene where Oppenheimer rode horses with his wife: it is not a dramatic scene. The changes are often quite jarring.Second, some of the bomb / explosion footage interspersed in the early parts of the film, for lack of a better analogy, look like Windows screensavers. Some of the footages are highly effective, such as the Trinity testing scene, but most of the time those scenes appear to be embellishments that don't gels particularly well with the narrative.I think the character writing is also quite weak given that the film has a three hours runtime. The motivations of Oppenheimer are not fleshed out well. The women characters, as you expect from a Nolan film, lack dimension. The suicide lacked enough context to make sense.

This movie has a great staff of actors who all did a great job, especially Emily Blunt who really shows her chops in her limited role in the film. All of this should make for a great film.Unfortunately, the movie is full of video and sound gimmicks and doesn't deliver on the true story due to extreme political overtones. After 3 hours of viewing, I'm thinking what did I get from this movie? Pretty much nothing, it truly was a bomb!So why is this movie so popular?

Oppenheimer. A historical feature film that tells us the course of events in one of the most crucial moments of World War II and shows in a raw and controversial way, how far one is capable of going to achieve victory.I found the plot itself too dense, although it is understandable since it deals with such a complex subject matter. Still, I think it could have been handled in a more digestible way for the viewer.The script tells the story, alternating between different timelines, a methodology that has become the celebrated director's personal signature.In this film, Nolan offers us a narrative formed by dialogues full of information that, at times, are released at a somewhat accelerated pace, a fact that at times can generate confusion and make you see yourself in the situation of reorganizing the ideas in your head, to finish understanding what you are being told.Audiovisually speaking, it is a work of art, like all of the director's creations.The sound representation is a fundamental part that makes the cinematographic experience exciting.As is the image, which envelops you and makes you forget where you are with its constant, back and forth black and white shots.Even so, there were moments when I expected more, as in the moment of the explosion, where I had the expectation of experiencing a more shocking visual terror, because that was what we were promised, but far from being so, the scene has the same impact, managing to convey the anguish and uncertainty of the characters.However, for me, the jewel in the crown were the masterful performances of the cast. An exceptional cast, led by the brilliant Cillian Murphy, who delivers a Robert Oppenheimer performance, practically unbeatable and worthy, without a doubt, of an Oscar nomination.This is not a war movie, not even a biopic, it goes beyond that. It is a cinematic puzzle of a historical, political, scientific and even philosophical nature. A portrait of guilt, caused by the greedy search for recognition and power.It is a story with a morally complex undertone and with a final reflection so existentialist that, at the end, it leaves you wondering what would you have done?So I can't say if this is Christopher Nolan's best creation, what I do know is that, if you're up to it, this is an experience worth seeing and enjoying on the big screen.

Christopher Nolan's much-anticipated film, "Oppenheimer," is a visually stunning and thought-provoking cinematic experience that delves into the tumultuous life of the brilliant physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer. As expected from a Nolan film, it delivers on its promise of grandeur and spectacle, offering audiences a captivating exploration of history, science, and the human condition.Set against the backdrop of World War II, "Oppenheimer" artfully captures the tension and urgency of the Manhattan Project, where Oppenheimer and his team raced against time to develop the first atomic bomb. Nolan's mastery of visual storytelling is on full display as he recreates the era with impeccable attention to detail, immersing the audience in the atmosphere of the 1940s.At the heart of the film is Cillian Murphy's mesmerizing portrayal of J. Robert Oppenheimer. Murphy's performance is both commanding and vulnerable, bringing to life the complexity of the man behind the scientist. He deftly conveys Oppenheimer's brilliance, ambition, and internal conflicts, leaving the audience torn between admiration and empathy for this enigmatic figure.The film explores not only Oppenheimer's scientific achievements but also delves into the moral dilemmas faced by him and his team. Nolan masterfully weaves in ethical questions about the development and use of the atomic bomb, forcing the audience to confront the complexities of scientific progress and its potential consequences.As with many Nolan films, "Oppenheimer" employs a non-linear narrative, which, while intellectually stimulating, might prove challenging for some viewers to follow. The film jumps back and forth in time, showcasing various key moments in Oppenheimer's life, often leaving audiences to piece together the chronology. While this approach adds depth to the storytelling, it may require multiple viewings to fully grasp the intricate nuances of the plot.Another highlight of the film is its spectacular cinematography and visual effects. Nolan's signature cinematic flair elevates pivotal moments, particularly during the tense scientific experiments and the dramatic conclusion of the Manhattan Project. The use of practical effects and meticulously crafted sets heightens the film's authenticity, transporting the audience back to a pivotal point in history.Where "Oppenheimer" slightly falters is in its pacing. At times, the film lingers on certain scenes, delving into intricate scientific discussions that might lose the attention of casual viewers. Additionally, some character arcs, including those of supporting cast members, feel underdeveloped, leaving certain relationships and motivations less fleshed out than desired.In conclusion, "Oppenheimer" is a visually arresting and intellectually stimulating cinematic endeavor that offers a captivating glimpse into one of history's most influential figures. Christopher Nolan's direction, combined with Cillian Murphy's exceptional performance, elevates the film to great heights. However, the complexity of the narrative and occasional pacing issues might be a minor drawback for some viewers. Nevertheless, "Oppenheimer" remains a must-see for those who appreciate historical dramas that challenge the boundaries of storytelling and provoke contemplation on the human impact of scientific advancements.

An American-British biopic thriller; A story about physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer, appointed to develop and design the atomic bomb. After his scientific team's work comes to fruition he faced the consequences of speaking truth to power. This is an ambitious character study epic with big scope and spectacle. It relies on a tour de force from Cillian Murphy who harnesses the anguish, guilt, gloom, and haughtiness of the title character in a layered performance. The optics captivate, which it must, and it haunts, as it should, given the enormity of real-life events and it is brilliant in showing how ambition and morality can end up in silos. Despite its meticulous, fact-based psychodrama it is a broad story with strong visuals and sound design. Exposition was critical for the plot so great minds of the age who had varied involvement in the arms race were introduced. But the first 45 minutes played out like a long film trailer with biographical detail that was often clunky. Eventually a hiatus in the musical score led the way for suspense to build to a gripping centrepiece sequence whereon the director's expertise in choreography was evident. Films which are dialogue-heavy can assuage the feeling of being overwrought by using montages which help with the viewing experience. The absence of this at times worked to the film's detriment. Long feature films need to earn emotional engagement too. The male-female narrative seemed curtailed and the third hour's pacing was at times enervating with its long legal meetings and political scrapping. Overall, a bold, fascinating film about a complicated legacy with many strong supporting performances, but it was dizzy and occasionally clotted in delivery.

Oppenheimer while a solid film is not what I expected.I'll start with the great. The performances especially Robert Downey Jr are off the chart. Emily Blunt has an absolute masterful scene. Cillian Murphy is very good as Oppie.The good. It's an interesting film that FEELS important. It's shot well of course. Many of the scenes hold your interest.The rest: it's too long... and for no reason. It's 3 separate films poorly edited into a mismatched formal outfit. Additionally, the sound mix fails miserably. The big moments are big; however, the dialogue is often missed at crucial moments of the film making the through line difficult to follow.It feels like a film that wants to be Oliver Stone's JFK; but, fails to have an underlying story interesting enough to justify the black and white and odd cut backs. The atom bomb is a sideline to the story unlike every ad campaign which makes it the primary focus. By the time we TEST the bomb (considering we don't see anything of Hiroshima or Nagasaki) we are left with another hour of the same beat over and over and over in a claustrophobic coat closet of a conference room with 2 dimensional characters including Oppenheimer himself for every single scene in the room or similar 2 dimensional congressional hearing members droning on about whether Downey (who is brilliant) should be confirmed for a cabinet position.I wanted to love this film but it's just another big budget effort that fails to meet expectations.

Oppenheimer has everything to be the film of the year. One of the few films recorded in Imax, surreal, certainly adds to the experience.About the film, it is the consecration of Chris Nolan's directing style. The execution of the work with his signature this time was perfect, no narrative slips, nothing exaggerated and nothing omitted, the film uses the techniques in the right measure.The filmmaker's best film so far brings back the puzzle narrative, in a more spiral format, especially at the beginning of the film. This type of narrative is one that makes you think, build the film along with the execution of it. The beginning of the film demands a lot of attention. Many timelines in quick scene cuts, many new persons introduced, many situations presented out of order: it is the perfect experience for those who enjoy this type of film. Like a puzzle, you're given several pieces that are unlocked for you to piece together the story. If you lose your attention in those first 30-45 minutes of plot and can't put together the narrative, it will be difficult to understand from there. When the pieces fall into place and you understand the timelines (which are few here, when it comes to Nolan), enjoying the art of the film in the next 2:30 hours of film is a great experience!Oppenheimer brings a new way to watch a biopic unlike anything you've watched before in this genre. The three hours of film pass as if they were one, the pace of the film is electrifying, quick cuts, quick takes, most scenes last a few seconds, before moving on to another point in the story. Very few scenes drag on for more than 30 seconds.The casting is immense, there are many characters, many actors, many names (which may sound confusing at some point), that the film does not prioritize presenting the trajectory of each one in detail - and it would never have been able to, such a large number of actors -, the performances are of a high level, and the puzzle narrative diminishes in the middle of the film, helping to understand the narrative thread in this large number of actors. Cillian Murphy's performance is extraordinary, by far the best developed character in all of Nolan's filmography, it gave him space to shine and he delivers a lot. Robert Downey Jr also delivers a great performance, in fact the best or one of the best of his career. Emily Blunt manages to dominate the dramatic scenes throughout the film. In my opinion, a cohesive script, with the perfect screen time for each character, given the relevance of each one in the story.Cinematography, visual effects (no cgi), editing, original score and sound editing are categories with a high probability of awards. The original score and editing of this film, in particular, caught my attention too much, quick cuts, great editing, non-linear at times, and when linear, with short scenes, in addition to the original score that holds you in your chair and gives a frantic pace to the film are exceptional.In summary, this film has Nolan at his best (debuting in a new studio, Universal), in his best film, managing to overcome all the negative nuances that hovered over his other works (little tenacity with the characters and exaggeration in his non-linear narrative vices). Far surpassing his last work, Tenet, which is his worst film.Oppenheimer is finished, mature, and Nolan's best yet. It has a chance in virtually all award categorias o Oscars. 10/10.

In ways that only Christopher Nolan can do, Oppenheimer is a layered, critical thinking film with A-list surprises, brilliant cinematography, and a hell of a sound mixing team. There's history, there's science, there's humanity- it's all there for the viewer to interpret as deeply (or superficially) as they like. I love Christopher Nolan because I feel I can trust his work; sure there's some suspension of belief (it is Hollywood after all), but you know you'll walk away from the movie lingering on subtle scenes, powerful dialogue, challenging morals, etc. There's always always something to think about and relish, and Oppenheimer does not disappoint!

Actors did a great job, visuals were great and it was about important subject matter. I did NOT like the disjointed storyline and it felt like they left out so much of Oppenheimer's actual story. We see him at college and then at his great Atomic bomb building level. Story alludes to his greatness but not why. Also left out his wife's bio completely and in real life he got grief for that. Timelines were wonky too... made story hard to follow. Oh and they completely left out pearl harbor and the pivot to bombing Japan vs the original idea to use it on Hitler. Was also very long....they had ample time to tell the story but it was shown as more of a collage of times and events. Was it worth a watch? I think so.
