Wasn't a fan, American military propaganda at it's finest. The struggle between ego and morality wasn't developed enough & the human impact of nuclear warfare was told in in the most egotisical way.The acting was good but I was not invested in the characters. The Oppenheimer characterisation feels one dimensional compared to what I imagine the real one would be like but the acting of this character I can't fault.Cinematography, dialogue & atmosphere was good but I didn't find it emotionally riveting as it felt too much like propaganda. The glorification of the military industrial complex. Apart from the occasional jarring sounds I liked the cuts between scenes and the use of black and white as it helped with the storytelling.The internal psychological struggle of Oppenheimer in evaluating the implications of his work and the realisation of the impact of his creation would have been much more interesting to explore rather than the way he was backstabbed. I wanted to be inside Oppenheimers brilliant but conflicted & devastated mind more. What it's like to have three centuries of scientific innovation become a tool for global warfare? What's the psychological impact of realising your contribution towards that?They forwent the true tragedy of the human impact that nuclear warfare has. They mentioned the death tolls in Japan and there was the skin melting off from the American audience but it felt like it was trying to tell a good story rather than be a deep psychological insight in to the mind of Oppenheimer. Little empathy for the Japanese experience.What I was hoping for was a deeper psychological exploration into how one of the most brilliant minds of our times, well aware of the devastating impact that nuclear weapons can have on the world, intellectually and morally justifies his involvement & then their inevitable development. It didn't delve deep enough on this but chose to focus the last third of the movie on the faux hearing, political backstabbing and how he was treated.With any high technology it can be a double edged sword, used to empower or enslave. Perhaps Oppenheimer believed in the development of nuclear fission as a fossil free, clean energy source. It is doubtful that the only application he could think of was an atomic bomb, but then again he was well aware of who he was commissioned by. Instead we get a one dimensional story.To me it didn't live up to its potential & I was counting down the time. Technically decent I just wasn't moved. If you like war movies then you might like it. If you want a deep philosophical, psychological thriller, a deep insight in to the human condition, this isn't it. Maybe I should have watched Barbie instead.

This is an attempt to condense what occurred in a reverent teenage mind, over the course of 180 minutes sat in a cinema theatre (with no seat left empty) witnessing Oppenheimer. I doubt it shall do any justice to the emotions elicited in my own viewing, and I encourage those who read, to see for oneself independent of my own perspectives.ART
Nolan's choice of dividing the movie, splitting it, into scenes of colour and black and white did appear to me, prior to viewing, as an attempt to raise this film to an artistic standard it would not hold upon viewing. I must admit to being incorrect in my predisposition. This choice to divide the colour in the film between monochrome and technicolour is perhaps as useful as it is impressionistic. Not only does it enable the viewer to chronicle the timeline of the film simply, but also present a different theatre, a more complex theatre, to the one the first two parts of the film present. It serves as a useful distinction to the eye, as well as the mind. Where Oppenheimer deals initially with the theatre of science, of creation, of morals, the closing black-and-white post-climax of the film serves to deliver the sickening witch-hunt in the theatre of politics, of immovable institutions, of what shall be called for the rest of this review, the American Justification.AMERICA
I will try to define this term now: and I am sure it will be insufficient to portray what I truly believe it to be, in simply, insufficient words. I believe the American Justification is, put in a pretty, concise words, the ability of 'America' to perpetuate not only its physical existence, but also its image and symbolism by means of justifying itself on the basis of its simple existence and continuation of the 'American way'. Nolan expresses this most beautifully - via his presentation of the aged, the suited, the decrepit, the congruous, the white (ethnically, yes), and their assault on any form of progress that does not follow the route of the American Justification. This path, based purely on opinion and my own personal viewership, is that of winning. And I think winning is different to victory. Victory is a discriminate end goal, while winning is the process, as well as the end goal, if it is ever reached. The story of Oppenheimer is the epitome of the American desire to win, and to never stop winning. Oppenheimer is ultimately persecuted for his delays to American winning. His doubts over the moral credibility of the development of an H-bomb does not coalesce with the American ideal of always winning, of always being ahead.However, trying to root myself from disappearing into ideals and politics, and whichever way the our world's current political climate turns, I should return to what is upon the screen, what is evident. I shall begin with perhaps the most appalling scene in the film, for me at least, marking one of the six times I moved to tears during the film, and one of the seven times I was moved to tears over the duration of the whole experience of my evening. This scene, to place in context, is after the two A-bombs produced in Los Alamos have been detonated over Hiroshima and Nagasaki to end World War II. We see Cillian Murphy troubled, his name, endearingly shortened to 'Oppy' being chanted by the residents of Los Alamos, calling for his speech in celebration. Perhaps this is pinnacle of the film, to me at least. He walks through his neighbours, haunted by the train-like chugging of their stamping on the wooden boards they are seated upon. If one has watched David Lynch's 'Mulholland Drive' they will pick up on the lighting in this scene. It is shadowy, dark. The wood of the hall is rich, blooming, wet. The faces of those cheering are dark, almost zombified. 'Oppy' stands before his congregation and delivers Americanized sentiments that he does not believe, receiving uproar in applause and cheer and laughter. Here, Nolan cleverly paints Oppenheimer's own fission, his division of his ideals. In this haunting scene we witness the devouring of guilt, airbrushed over by victory, by the cessation of WWII. The zombified Americans feed off the decay of 110,000 dead (initially, 250,000 in the weeks continuing) in the two Japanese cities to fuel their arms to wave small American flags, and to fill their lungs for whoops and cheers. This scene is haunting even before Oppy's visions, where everything becomes muted, and he finds himself stepping through the heart of a burnt husk of one of his bomb's victims. Everything is engulfed in light, everything is swallowed by American victory, the idea of which is on par with divinity. Oppy exits, witnessing some crying, some embracing, all joyous, as well as a couple kissing under the seats, and one of his physicists throwing up outside of the hut. He witnesses all the putridity of America's pulp culture. Americanization devours the intellectual achievement of the creation of such a device, commercialising and lowering it to the level of beer-sodden, vomit-inducing, homecoming partying and cheer. Mass violence is Americanly justified under the guise of winning. Cruelty, gruesomeness, guilt is all admonished by the positive result of victory.CHARACTERS
I feel that now is an opportune moment to depart from the greater ideals that are tackled in the film, and to address the minutiae, of each of the roles tackled by Nolan's stellar cast. Damon plays an intimidating chalk to Oppenheimer's cheese, a shouty, but informed and sympathetic, army general overseeing Los Alamos. The only time his allyship to Oppy, to the audience, is questioned, is in the confined cabinet prosecution room. Blunt plays all but a blunt character, pardoning the pun. Kitty, Oppenheimer's wife, serves a tasteful discord to Oppenheimer's arrogance. To all that he is blind, Kitty is witness to. Blunt's delicate portrayal of Kitty is equally able to be hated and admired by the audience. Her testimony within the cabinet room is a moment of the film where the audience can truly smile. Oppy's science team are perfectly measured, credit to the actors or script writing I do not know, but they do not intrude on the storyline too much and are equally not sidelined. Each is characterised in seconds, and playfully too. They always add the scene, each additional detail is always welcome and never overplayed. I ultimately believe that no word, no moment, is acted incorrectly. There are no times that the acting falls short or feels artificial. You receive an overwhelming sense that each actor enjoys the character that they well and truly live within, unflinchingly. Downey Jr plays a deceptively hurtful role, a political animal. His rupture from his initial portrayal is a betrayal to the audience. We feel deceived, we feel hurt. We feel that we were misfed a character who was simply a fake, and phony, concealing a vain, power-hungry man who aims to succeed and hold control. Cillian Murphy must be mentioned for his role. His depiction of Oppenheimer is not only deeply nuanced, paired with the nuanced characterisation of him by narrative voice throughout the film, he balances Oppy's genius, brilliance and intelligence with his blue-eyed blindness, his naivety. He is flawed, and truly lovable, truly admirable. His impression on the audience is always poignant and touching. His ability to act in silence is as incredible as his ability to deliver lines. He could walk back into the second world war and play Oppenheimer himself.A BIOPIC? A 'PEOPLE' FILM
A striking feature of the film that dawned on me during the cinema walk-home, is how the film is focused. Oppenheimer is a departure from modern filmmaking style: it did help that I watched a 35mm millimetre screening, which removed some HD nature to the viewing, but instilled in it an artistic imperfectness. Nolan chooses not to focus on CGI, on visual spectacle, and while he does not shy away from it completely, his lens it focused on the human, on the being. More shots focus on the eyes, the faces, the bodies, the physicality, the voices, the clothes, the gazes and the actions of those in Oppenheimer than the A-bomb. It is ultimately a film of people, not of explosions, which gives it a great emotional touch. Nolan examines the value of exploring the effect upon the psyche, upon the emotions, upon the relations of people, rather than pure destruction. In fact, Nolan chooses to end upon creation rather than destruction. Avoiding straying into biblical allusions, of which there are many in the 180 minutes, Nolan chooses to instead focus on beginning, rather than ending. WWII is not ended by the A-bomb, instead, the atomic era, the H-bomb race, the age democratic hostility is begun.CONCLUSION
The film is ultimately about fission. Ha-Ha, funny joke, he's trying to be a fancy artistic reviewer. I encourage you to watch, and you shall see, how each ideal, each person, each story explored in this masterpiece is ripped apart, atomised, before the audience. Oppy's communist ideals dissolve and split, ultimately his allegiances to humanity remain, but are smothered by American capitalism and reverent fear of all things Left. Our physicists' relationships with one another are pulled to pieces, and rejoined momentarily by phony formality of a handshake, between Oppenheimer and Teller.America is split apart. We see an admirable, heroic hunger for academic progression, reduced to greed, and its lust for success and power. I wait for what Nolan has for us next but doubt it will ever be able to succeed his statement that is Oppenheimer. He tackles not only a biopic of such a complex character, but a timeless reincarnation of a time of politics and tension, delivering it all within a three-hour film that will leave you speechless. I encourage you, I implore you, to book your tickets for your local cinema, to experience what shall become a hallmark in cinematic history, to witness Oppenheimer.

Oppenheimer is a delight as good cinema. From the performances of Murphy and Downey Jr., Damon and Malik, to the staging, they give the film a pace that doesn't slow down in its 3 hours, at times conveying the feeling of being overwhelmed by their characters. Nolan proves to be very solid in the biographical genre, showing in great detail one of the most iconic and thorny moments of the entire 20th century. Definitely an important historical document; a film to show in schools and reflect on how the start of this arms race marks a before and after in geopolitics and how our actions, however altruistic, sometimes have unsuspected consequences.

Sure, this was an interesting movie. It is about a significant, historical character who was instrumental in changing the world. His story is important and should be told. The all-star cast showed up, performing to their expected levels. I particularly enjoyed Matt Damon's character, Lt. Gen. Leslie Groves Jr. He was a hard-nosed, witty, no nonsense, Pattonesque general. I learned some things about the development of the atom bomb that I didn't know previously. The cinematography and the movie period atmosphere were authentic enough, however, I was not as blown away by the film as I expected to be. There were many characters, names, story lines that were a bit befuddling at times, taking awhile to learn them all. The way the movie went back and forth in at least three different periods of Oppenheimer's atomic bomb development endeavor, which involved sections of black and white filming, then going back to another period in color, was at times, somewhat discombobulating. The movie was also 1/2 - 1 hour too long. I think the same story could've been told in a shorter period of time. Don't get me wrong, I really enjoyed the movie, but it did not strike emotion in me as some of my favorites have. I'm sure the academy will love it. I'm just not ready to give it Best Picture - yet.

The problem with Christopher Nolan movies is, that no matter the premise, people will always enter the theatre with incredibly (and sometimes unrealistically) high expectations. I don´t think, many people would get overly excited about watching a 3 hour biopic about Robert Oppenheimer, but put Christopher Nolans name on it and it becomes one of the biggest blockbusters of the year. I am a huge Nolan fan as well but tried to limit my excitement as much as possible, remembering very well that in 2020, I left Tenet kind of disappointed because of my unrealitstically high expectations - even though it was overall a very good movie (after the second viewing that is). For Oppenheimer, it didn´t make it easier, that movie theatres were immediately sold out for days and initial critics (even the ones that were not generated by Chat GPT) were showering it with praise. I finally managed to get a seat in a rather small theatre tonight and have to say: Even with neutral expectations, this movie was a disappointment.Don´t get me wrong, with a 100 Million dollar budget, it will obviously still provide you with incredible imagery, flawless acting, a great soundtrack (there is a BUT! Though) and an original story that still manages to give you a blockbuster feeling, something that has become very rare in Hollywood these days. But I will still not watch it again. Here´s why:Christopher Nolan movies have often stood out from the crowd, due to 1. Big spectacle, that was held together by 2. An emotional story at its core, with 3. Some kind of twist considering the narrative structure. Oppenheimer completely neglects the emotional part and tries but fails to deliver on both the spectacle (with one obvious exception) and the narrative complexity. The narrative device of telling the story over three different timelines delivers one (maybe two) exciting twists at the very end but otherwise almost feels like Christopher Nolan just HAD to use different time periods because...that´s his thing. Telling the story through retrospective court hearings is not new and most of the scenes do not really add anything. The Social Network for example did a much better job of incorporating this narrative device. If you are expecting big spectacle, you have to be aware that 95% of this movie is pure dialogue. There´s nothing wrong with that per se, but Nolan has never been famous for his great dialogue writing skills (except for some memeable Joker quotes I guess) and this movie is no exception in that regard. There are like 5 witty one-liners (most of which already given away in the trailer), the rest is basically characters explaining the different plot points to each other (minor exceptions apply). The spectacle is provided by the Nuclear bomb explosion scene and I am not gonna lie, this scene is spectacular and very satisfying to watch, amplified by the fact that the almost 120 minutes leading up to it have been very underwhelming (more about that in a second). Nolan reportedly was very proud of this scene, being shot completely without CGI, which is undeniably an incredible cinematic achievement, but if you are expecting to be blown away (pun intended) by a 150 minutes visual, action-packed extravaganza ala Inception, the dark knight, or Tenet, be aware that this is a completely different movie. The emotional component is completely absent, the relationship between Oppenheimer and his wife is reduced to maybe 10 minutes of shared screentime, with Kitty Oppenheimer being a voice of reason and concern about Mr. Oppenheimers scientific, political and romantic endeavours, and him barely reacting to it. Oppenheimers affair and the rather unfortunate ending to it is also not given enough screen time to have any emotional impact on the viewer. All of the other characters (except Lewis Strauss) are mainly reduced to Cameos anyway, without any insight into their emotional site whatsoever. Which brings me to the main point, why this movie fails:For the first 120 minutes, up until the nuclear explosion, the movie has NO ACTUAL SCENES. I´m sure I´m not the only one, who occasionally gets stuck on youtube, browsing multiple, 3-4 minutes long clipped out scenes of my favorite movies. I dare you to try clipping out memorable scenes of the first two hours of Oppenheimer. It is an impossible task. No scene can actually breathe, it is a just constant cutaway of Oppenheimer meeting a certain character, sharing 10 seconds of dialogue, moving on to the next location, the next character, the next scenery, the next "plotpoint", with dramatic music CONSTANTLY playing in the background, trying to create an artificial sense of urgency. In the beginning, I thought this would be just to get through the first stations of Oppenheimers life quickly before the actual plot can kick off, until it dawned on me, that the whole movie is cut that way. What doesn´t help is the neverending CAMEO parade of A-list Hollywood actors, that makes you wonder "oh wow, what are they going to do with this character?", before you realize that you will most likely never see him again. In that sense, the atomic bomb explosion scene is a huge relief, because the movie finally STOPS. Takes its time to develop a scene. Shows characters emotions. When the music stops for these couple of seconds, I even breathed out a sigh of relief. And after this scene, the movie actually takes a turn for the better. The scene of Oppenheimer mentally checking out in front of a cheering crowd is great. The meeting with Truman scene is great. Even the final congressional hearing scenes and a few of the final court testimonies are great. Because Nolan finally takes some time to develop some actual character interactions, instead of just rushing over them. The ending scene is great. But if the first two hours of the movie are rushed, a good (but also not perfect) last hour can´t really save it. At least not for me. For me, this is by far Nolans most disappointing film, but even if it had been done by a different director, I still would not consider it to be a good film. So if you are craving a blockbuster, that does not contain superheroes, video game characters or toys, jump onto the hypetrain and watch it, but if someone asked me for a list of 200 movie reccommendations, Oppenheimer would probably not be on it. 5/10.

It's a partial biopic of J. Robert Oppenheimer, who helped with the theoretical research for the atomic bomb and led the Manhattan Project at Los Alamos, New Mexico. It's set from the mid-1920s to 1958 in many places, with the most significant time in Los Alamos.J. Robert Oppenheimer (Cillian Murphy) is portrayed in a jumbled timeline that touches on his early scientific education, his political interests and relationships, the influential women in his life, his interactions with a vast array of scientists in the development of the atomic bomb, the post-war controversy aroused by his political sympathies and family relationships, and his reflections on the implications of the nuclear bomb for humanity.The most important figures who relate to Oppenheimer in the film include Jean Tatlock (Florence Pugh), Kitty Puening Oppenheimer (Emily Blunt), General Leslie Groves (Matt Damon) of the Manhattan Project, Commissioner Lewis Strauss (Robert Downey, Jr.) of the Atomic Energy Commission, and Edward Teller (Benny Safdie). Other prominent historical figures like Albert Einstein (Tom Conti) and Harry Truman (Gary Oldman) make cameo appearances, as do many scientists."Oppenheimer" is a compelling movie. My favorite scenes were Kitty Oppenheimer refusing to shake Edward Teller's hand late in the film and Harry Truman's brusque treatment of Oppenheimer and his demand that they "don't let that crybaby in the door again" after Oppenheimer raised concerns. The film brilliantly portrays Oppenheimer's complex personality. Unfortunately, almost everyone else is an incomplete character. The movie is overproduced with a few valuable gimmicks and too many that are simply distracting. The time lapse between the flash of the first test explosion and the sound reaching the scientists a short distance away was silly. And I doubt Oppenheimer climbed to a high platform to examine the bomb in a suit and tie.Some characters seem exaggerated, as is wont to happen in such biopics. Lewis Strauss's villainy seems overdrawn, especially since his failure to get a cabinet seat occurred years after the conflict with Oppenheimer. John F. Kennedy's vote as a senator against Strauss joined 56 other Democrats.Still, "Oppenheimer" is well worth seeing. It raises good questions about nuclear weapons and the meaning of international arms races. Oppenheimer's final words are not optimistic.

Oppenheimer is a sweeping and ambitious film that tells the story of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the scientist who led the Manhattan Project to develop the atomic bomb. The film is directed by Christopher Nolan, who brings his signature visual style to the project. The film is also notable for its large ensemble cast, which includes Cillian Murphy, Emily Blunt, Matt Damon, Robert Downey Jr., and Rami Malek.Oppenheimer is a challenging film, but it is also a rewarding one. The film is not afraid to tackle complex and controversial subjects, and it does so in a way that is both thought-provoking and suspenseful. The film is also beautifully shot and features some of the most impressive special effects of the year.Cillian Murphy gives a tour-de-force performance as Oppenheimer. Murphy captures the scientist's brilliance, his charisma, and his inner turmoil. The supporting cast is also excellent, with standout performances from Emily Blunt, Matt Damon, and Robert Downey Jr.Oppenheimer is a film that will stay with you long after you have seen it. It is a film that is both challenging and rewarding, and it is a film that will make you think about the nature of science, the power of technology, and the responsibility of scientists.Overall, Oppenheimer is a masterpiece. It is a film that is both challenging and rewarding, and it is a film that will stay with you long after you have seen it. I highly recommend it.

This is a film to be watched many times. So many layers intertwined to majestically compose a perfect description of Oppenheimer's life,inside out. The guilt. The genius. The lover. The rational. All of this about one of the most important moments in human history. How can you combine all these in a single film? There are movies that transcend mere entertainment, and "Oppenheimer" is undoubtedly one of them. Directed by the brilliant Christopher Nolan, this three-hour masterpiece is a breathtaking display of pure art, paying a splendid modern tribute to the grandeur of Hollywood's golden era. Nolan's craftsmanship is at its pinnacle, complemented by a 5-star cast featuring Cillian Murphy, Robert Downey Jr., and Emily Blunt.Cillian Murphy's portrayal of the troubled and complex character, Robert Oppenheimer, is an exceptional achievement and his best performance to date. With ease, Murphy makes Oppenheimer remarkably relatable to the audience, tracing his journey from a young, uncertain man to an accomplished scientist who would reshape the course of history.Special mention to the performances of Robert Downey Jr as Lewis Strauss and Matt Damon as General Groves, both of whom add depth and intensity to the narrative.I'd also like to salute Nolan's commitment to historical accuracy, purposefully avoiding CGI to render the experience as realistic as possible, despite minor blemishes (like the appearance of a incorrect American flag.)Ludwig Göransson's work on the film's soundtrack is a standout aspect, adding an emotional dimension to the film and making the experience truly unforgettable.Overall, "Oppenheimer" is another cinematic masterpiece by Nolan that deserves every accolade and recognition it receives. This film is a testament to the power of cinema, and is already solidifying its place among the all-time greats in the history of cinema.

Oppenheimer (the film not the guy) communicates some very complicated scientific ideas simply to allow them to be surrounded in the main message of the film, questioning the morality of the entire project and the persons involved. It is written extremely well.The editing of Oppenheimer may be my favourite part, Jennifer Lame chose to make frequent cuts to abstract snippets of the future to convey the noise in Oppenheimer's head. This is followed by the understanding of the confusion later on the film - as the story slowly unravells - creating a very satisfying viewing experience, one of constantly learning the reasons behind his actions and getting a better understanding of the man the films centers around.The film does have occasional slow and potentially confusing moments, however like some of the best films, everything is made clear, previous secrets giving the viewer an almost complete understanding by the end of the film.If you like science I would definitely recommend it.Overall, the film is extremely high quality in every aspect, not afraid to make more outlandish artistic decisions like shooting large segments of the film in black and white.

I rarely talk or write reviews on movies, but I can't stress how much I love this movie.The way it manipulated emotions within me, I could feel it, I could feel and understand what Oppenheimer feels, even though I was not him, I felt that I myself was merely him in the way he was narrated in major moments of the movie. What my eyes saw was absorbed all the way inside to creat a gleam within my mind, and that gleam illuminated back through my eyes, This is what I love this movie.It was a very well written biography in the first place, but Nolan took it to the next level. The emphasis on what it means to be prometheus. Although Nolan only mentioned the story of Prometheus only once in the first minute of the movie, you could see the embodiment of the character in Oppenheimer; the moment where he was horrified to see the power he brought to humanity, while people around him celebrated the moment, he knew it could've been put in a better use, but he also knew it is a human nature to strive in using power in exchange to become evil. Oppenheimer only acted upon what humans requested, even though he had a will, he carried a dream, but he would've never make his dreams come true so he proved it through benefiting people's desires, exchangeable benefits in a way. Until you see Prometheus, until he feels abandoned after he gave humans what they needed from him, Cillian Murphy's acting skills were out of this world, he made sure all his emotions were vividly felt, how was he alienated right after he accomplished his mission, he the power he created was taken away and put to use right when it was proven to be as evil as it was promised. Even when he was celebrated in the crowd, and when he was asked to give a speech, he knew he could never say that never wanted this, he could only flatter about it about it and say what the crowd wanted to hear, I could see the embodiment of Prometheus vividly in that moment which was very amusing to see especially as a literature lover.The entirety of the movie was an experience to be put in a humans own biography. It is an experience that makes a human discover places he never touched in his emotions, a different type of emotions that we as human have forever thought we knew and understood perfectly, until this movie came and shattered all of that. As it promised to do.

Nolan delivers a gadget of profound intellectually provocative weight, slaps it upon the minds of the audience and compels them to implode their moral preconceptions upon the nature of power, love and humanity. A true biographical film which latches upon the eyes of J. Robert Oppenheimer; revealing the troubles that come with "vison beyond this world." In my personal view, Julius Robert Oppenheimer is a flawed individual: conceited, arrogant, stubborn in his vast intellect, to the extent that his devotion to science and advancement of scientific theory clouds his intrinsic morals. The protagonist is portrayed as logical, with ample ability for reasonable foresight in matters of the political and philosophical impact of his actions, but continues to deceive himself of the moral implications of his "gadget." This man knew in his heart of hearts the results of his theory,
fully aware of the eventual display of power and threat of mutually assured destruction in the future. Nolan humanizes a genius of universal proportions, revealing that in-depth understanding of quantum phenomena (or any physical science) does not equate to emotional intelligence, nor basic human empathy.

I went to see this movie in the theatre, knowing about the Manhattan project loosely with little knowledge. It is well done, and once you sit through the first 20 minutes, the movie's ADHD back and forth makes sense. To avoid spoilers, I will mention the cinematography. There are 2 scenes that blew me away. One is the Trinity test, which faithfully and almost meticulously recreates actual filmed parts of the test and preparations for it, is bone chilling. The other scene at the end, with another person, makes a great ending, and the accompanying soundtrack almost makes you feel obligated to feel the emotions they are talking about. If possible, I would recommend seeing it in IMAX because it is actually designed for it, and I REALLY want to see it in IMAX now, even though I saw it yesterday. The only downside was the sometimes confusing story, but the overall story is understandable.

Nolan is an excellent filmmaker and the hype surrounding this film might be why I wasn't overly impressed. The fact that it was filmed on 70mm film was a major marketing point, however the film is 99% talking, which doesn't need 70mm.The good: Acting is phenomenal by Murphy, Pugh, Blunt, and Downing. The soundtrack in itself is great. The cinematography is top tier. Even though it's 3 hours it never feels like it's dragging.The bad: The soundtrack was constantly playing over the dialogue making it hard to hear what was happening at times. The flow of the story is hard to follow because it is told non-linearly and there are several threads happening. The use of black and white film in some scenes was also a marketing point but it seemed to be used almost arbitrarily. At some points it's future events sometimes past events. Despite the runtime being 3 hours there is little growth between characters.If there had been one anchor point timeline and the rest told linearly and the score scaled back this would be one of the best movies ever made. Definitely still worth watching I just think it may have been oversold.

The good: excellent performances by Murphy, Damon and especially Downey. A couple of powerful scenes, especially of the first test of the atom bomb - literally mind blowing .The bad: disjointed and confusing storytelling. Characters are plopped in and we have no idea who they are or their significance. Bombastic score that never lets up. At 3 hours way overlong.I was so looking forward to seeing this film, especially after the critical huzzahs for it and I'm a fan of all the talent involved. Well, folks, we've been misled by the critics yet again. Quite a few walkouts at the screening that I attended.

This film is definitely worth watching. The cinematic experience is out of this world and makes you leave the theatre almost in the state of shock. The cast, the story and simply every aspect of this film is a masterpiece. Even though film is generally considered an art form, I have yet to encounter a film more worthy of the title of art than Oppenheimer. As I saw critics and media portraying this film at the top of the industry, I had more than high expectations and they were all met. As I was running a bit late to the cinema I didn't have enough time to buy popcorn or any snacks, which was honestly a save of money since all my focus was immediately captured when Oppenheimer showed up on the screen so I am not sure I would even be able to eat it.

What does the film represent? A story about the manhattan project and the making of the atomic bomb, but also a detailed view into a mind which saw things not many could see. Oppenheimer shows that all along, he knew exactly what he was doing, they all knew they were building a bomb with huge destructive capabilities, yet went with it anyway. These people on the project were scientists and the film really shows that there was a fine line of morality that each one was crossing when pushing for innovation, which ultimately led to destruction. In the end, Oppenheimer never regretted what he did, he may have felt remorseful about the deaths, but Nolan captures that really he knew he was the most important man on the planet at the time and people would listen to whatever he had to say. A gentle soul, yet strong egotistical and somewhat political view on the world.

#Oppenheimer
It's not cyclical, it's spiral. It looks like a cycle (circle) since we are accustomed to look from the top (from the position of moral superiority as it is convenient). But from the top even mushroom cloud will appeared to be a circle (if you ever survive to tell the shape of it) .It begins with Oppenheimer looking from the top at ripples of water and and it ends at the look itself. You can't hold your tear at the beauty which is quintessentially spiral in so many ways - Temporal Unity, Narrative Unity of storytelling, Philosophical Unity of observer and observed, Existential Unity of Subject and Art form and yet many more to discover.Narrative Nolan is a sage who has been endlessly penancing to harness the spirit of time. Many a times he showed the world of his own imagination in which he twisted arm of time to get whatever he wanted. He seemed to have been artist of time in his artificial world and as such it has been a question in my mind whether he can sculpt the real time, time of our shared world, time of objectivity.In true sense there has been only one sculptor of time and his name was Andrei Tarkovsky who could metamorphosis the real time into marvel block and then sculpt out the useless and gave us cinema.While looking at the IMAX screen, I was wondering how would Tarkovsky have incepted the idea in Nolan's dream that a magician of imagination was turned into a wizard of real world.Nolan is an artist for whom existential Unity comes naturally. When he picks up magic as his subject, he lays bear the structure of magic. He shows something ordinary (The pledge), then make it disappears (The turn) and then make it reappear (The prestige). And this is how he woven the very structure of magic in the storytelling : The pledge, the turn and the prestige. An onion layer is enveloped by an onion layer and which in turn enveloped by another layer. So if he one day makes a film about onions be ready to get enveloped. This is existential unity of art in my view and Nolan's soul is a platform which provide existential unity to subject and art, a platform on which Subject dances with its true art form. Oppenheimer is a paradoxical character whose existential and existence crisis both are due to the existence of something which he himself made to exist. A-bomb is the fulcrum and on the both end subjectivity of Oppenheimer and objective reality plays see-saw. Awe!! How one can not be stunned by the awe of such an existential unity.Nolan! I bow before you master.

This is such a great and thorough telling of the history of the atomic bomb and the Manhattan project, but unlike the cold emotionless pages of a history book, it has been brought to life.We do not choose to exist, but we have an obligation to do so, I hope humanity can find the candor and courage to learn from our mistakes, not take life for granted, and strive to leave the world in a better place than we entered it."All humanity could share a common insanity and be immersed in a common illusion while living in a common chaos. That can't be disproved, but we have no choice but to follow our senses."

It's not a bad film at all, but when you've got a director of Nolan's calibre at the helm, you expect more than what Oppenheimer has to offer.Many of the scenes felt way too rushed, like the actors were just trying to deliver their lines without thinking about what they were actually saying. There were also way too many scenes in general; it felt like a series of vignettes that oscillated between Oppenheimer's personal life and moral qualms, and the reverence/derision he received from those around him.The dialogue also hits you over the head a little too much, so much is made explicit through the characters' conversations that it's implausible anything resembling these interactions would've ever taken place.The acting is fantastic, Cillian Murphy absolutely nails the part, as does Emily Blunt, whose scything take-down of the interrogator towards the end is a real highlight of the film. Kenneth Branagh's performance as Niels Bohr was a head scratcher - I never knew Danes spoke with Afrikaner accents.All in all, yes it's a decent film but there's just too much going on.

Excruciatingly long, slow and *gasp* dare I say it, boring. It's boring. The only good thing was the stacked cast of actors, it get to a point while I almost doze off, Casey affleck's voice woke me up and then yeah there he is, a surprise appearance by casey affleck yayyy. That's how bored I am.This is a passion project of Nolan, only it felt like he made it for himself and that's fine actually. Too bad I dont enjoy this movie, though another thing I do enjoy however was the score. It is mighty cinematic & beautiful, it also enhances some of the boring dialogue which otherwise would be rather bland. I've been a fan of Ludwig Goransson since Tenet & Wakanda forever.I think Nolan's name alone could made this a box office hits, however in this day where our attentions were divided upon so many things, it could prove to be detrimental for our enjoyment of the movie, maybe I couldn't enjoy this movie because my brain was used to shorter & compact contents (Tiktok is a pandora box for me) BUT in my defense, comparing this movie to Nolan's previous works, I cannot say this was superior in any means. Inception, Interstellar, Batmans, Tenet were all feast for my eyes & brain. But I pushed through to the end and I pat myself in the shoulder as I walked out of cinema.Cinematography is sub par, strory's not really engaging, the back and forth in timeline feels messy, performances was nothing special, all the actors did their job okay, and also the much hyped no cgi for the bomb sequences felt underwhelming. I agree that they dont need CGI because this is not an action movie, it's a historical biography movie whom also focuses a lot on political tension during wartime. And it wont matter much anyway, the bomb scene was just a short scene. So I guess the much hyped marketing tactic which spread around saying all of the effects was practical was actually inconsequential.Feel free to skip this one as I felt the regular nolan fans will be dissapointed. Its a historical biography drama but less emphasis on the drama.

Oppenheimer instantly enters the discussion for best film ever made, with impecable editing, scarring music and towering performances from a solid cast. Nolan's screenplay is incisive and detailed, with enough material to make the 3 hours feel like not enough time to devour this delicious work of art. Blending the thriller and the political courthouse drama, Christopher Nolan crafted an innovative cinematic experience that's both grand but shockingly sensitive and intimate. The tension, brought to its absolute limit in what may be the most tense countdown sequence ever made, is ultimately released in a shattering revelation that feels like a bucket of ice-cold water thrown at your body in the film's final moments. This masterclass in balance of an abundance of rich elements makes Oppenheimer a thoroughly engrossing victory that makes one feel as conflicted as the man behind its title: happy to have witnessed it but disheartened by its consequence.

Oppenheimer is a thought-provoking and emotionally charged cinematic experience. With its exceptional performances, especially from Cillian Murphy and Robert DJ, the film delves deep into the moral dilemmas of scientific progress and the burden of responsibility. Nolan's directorial prowess and storytelling mastery shine once again, making Oppenheimer a powerful and unforgettable cinematic experience.Movies like Oppenheimer challenge us to grapple with the complexities of history, science, and the human condition. They remind us of the power and responsibility we hold as individuals and as a society to use our knowledge and capabilities for the greater good.On my way home after watching the film, I found myself experiencing a mix of emotions - sadness, admiration, and perhaps even a sense of existential contemplation.

Probably the most thought-provoking big-budget studio film in the last 20 years. While this was a fine film, the acting was utterly tremendous. Cillian Murphy, Robert Downy Junior, and Emily Blunt put on a true masterclass in acting, dwarfed only by the magnitude of Oppenheimer's life's work: the atomic bomb. Magnificent performances, and as far as big-budget studio films go, Oppenheimer may be second to none. The film had so many layers, and was truly one of the finest examples of the magnitude of life's everlasting consequences. It's silly to say a commercially successful movie will clean up at awards season, but it would be a travesty if the Cillian, RDJ, and Emily Blunt didn't all get a statue, as well as the sound team, and cinematography.

Vada Pav: The Iconic Mumbai Street FoodVada Pav, a beloved street food originating from the bustling streets of Mumbai, is a mouthwatering combination of flavors and textures that has captured the hearts of millions. Comprising of a spicy potato fritter (vada) encased in a soft bun (pav), this delectable snack is a testament to the fusion of Indian and Portuguese culinary influences.The vada pav recipe begins with the preparation of the vada mixture. Boiled and mashed potatoes are seasoned with an array of spices including mustard seeds, cumin seeds, turmeric, and chopped green chilies. This mixture is then sautéed with finely chopped onions and ginger-garlic paste, infusing it with layers of savory flavors.For the batter that coats the potato mixture, besan (gram flour) is mixed with water, creating a smooth consistency. A pinch of turmeric and red chili powder adds both color and a hint of heat to the batter. The potato mixture is carefully encased in this batter and then deep-fried to golden perfection. The resulting vadas are crisp on the outside, with a warm, spicy potato filling on the inside.The pav, or the bun, is another essential component of vada pav. These soft, slightly sweet buns are sliced horizontally and lightly toasted on a griddle with a touch of butter. This toasting imparts a delightful crunch to the exterior while keeping the interior soft and pillowy.To assemble the vada pav, a green chutney and a garlic chutney are spread generously on the inside of the pav. The green chutney, made from cilantro, mint, green chilies, and lemon juice, adds a refreshing and tangy kick. The garlic chutney, with its pungent and spicy notes, provides a contrasting depth of flavor.The fried vada is carefully placed between the chutney-slathered pav halves, creating a tantalizing blend of textures and tastes. The crispy vada complements the softness of the pav, while the chutneys add layers of zesty and aromatic dimensions.Vada pav is often served with a side of fried green chilies or mirchi, adding an extra level of spiciness for those who dare. Some variations of vada pav also include cheese, creating a fusion of Indian and Western flavors that has gained popularity in recent years.This beloved street food embodies the spirit of Mumbai: fast-paced, flavorful, and diverse. It has become a cultural icon, transcending boundaries and appealing to taste buds worldwide. Vada pav vendors can be found on almost every street corner in Mumbai, serving this satisfying snack to locals and tourists alike.In conclusion, the vada pav recipe is a harmonious blend of ingredients and techniques that results in a tantalizing street food experience. From the aromatic potato mixture to the tangy chutneys, and the soft pav to the crispy vada, every element plays a crucial role in creating this culinary masterpiece. Enjoyed by people of all ages, vada pav continues to be an emblem of Mumbai's vibrant food culture.

"Oppenheimer" is a mesmerizing cinematic masterpiece that delves into the riveting life of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the brilliant scientist behind the development of the atomic bomb during World War II. Directed by the visionary filmmaker, this biographical drama transcends the boundaries of a typical historical documentary, offering an intimate and thought-provoking exploration of Oppenheimer's complex character and his moral dilemmas.The film's cinematography is breathtaking, capturing both the haunting beauty of the nuclear tests and the somber depths of Oppenheimer's conscience. The narrative brilliantly weaves through his personal struggles, intellectual brilliance, and the grim reality of unleashing the ultimate weapon of destruction. The audience is transported into the era, immersing them in the atmosphere of tension and uncertainty.What sets "Oppenheimer" apart is the raw and authentic portrayal of its characters. The lead performance is a tour de force, as the actor masterfully conveys Oppenheimer's inner turmoil and the burden of his choices. The supporting cast, including fellow scientists and military personnel, add depth and authenticity to the narrative, breathing life into history.The film isn't merely a historical account; it raises profound ethical questions about the consequences of scientific discoveries and the responsibility of the scientists behind them. It prompts viewers to ponder the implications of progress and the human cost of such groundbreaking achievements.While the runtime may feel long for some, every moment is justified as it allows the audience to fully grasp the emotional journey of Oppenheimer. The dialogues are insightful and profound, adding layers of depth to the character dynamics.In summary, "Oppenheimer" is a captivating film that not only honors the legacy of one of history's most enigmatic figures but also challenges viewers to contemplate the weight of their own decisions. A cinematic triumph that deserves accolades for its storytelling, performances, and thought-provoking themes. This is a must-watch for both history enthusiasts and those who seek cinematic brilliance with substance.

This movie is such a departure from a standard Nolan film in that it is a true story. It is a story about how a group of people got together to change the world through science and maybe not for the better. The story that is told is very clear, there is a pre-Nuclear war world and a post-Nuclear war world. The US spent almost 3 billion in 1945 money on a single project that would shape the nature of warfare and it was done by some pretty awful people, most of all J Robert Oppenheimer.The movie itself is almost perfect. Incredible pacing and storytelling. Incredible acting from everyone. There are so many "Oh that's so and so" moments throughout the movie and it felt like every single performance was genuine. From the first frame, the visuals and the score really drive home this sense of impending doom and anxiety. That pace never lets up and by the time you hit the final act it doesn't at all feel like it's been 3 hours. Visually I just can't say enough about this movie. Hoyte Van Hoytema is going to walk away with his first Academy Award and if he doesn't it will be straight up robbery. After saying all of this I'm not sure this is a film that you are meant to enjoy. It's really heavy in subject matter and it's implications. I left the theater feeling like I had been through something. Great overall experience.

After 2 and a half hours, you realize that it all revolves around the conflict between Oppenheimer and Strauss, who originally hired him to create the Atom Bomb. Strauss later tried to undermine him simply because he didn't want to give Oppenheimer so much credit. Other topics such as competition with the Nazis, how the bomb was made, Oppenheimer's relationship with Eisenstein, and his love life are only briefly touched upon. There is a continuous musical score accompanied by overwhelming sound effects to alleviate the boredom. You are relieved when things become slightly clearer at the end what is the focus of the movie and especially that the film is finely over.

While the film showcased impressive visuals and cinematography, it couldn't compensate for its flaws. A five-star rating for technical prowess, but the execution fell flat, leaving me wanting more from this talented director. Hoping for a better show next time around.

I admire Christopher Nolan's audacious decision to place the bomb test in the middle of the film instead of concluding with a grand finale. By eschewing the typical 'big bang' approach, Nolan artfully unveils the subtle yet crucial nuances of Oppenheimer's eventual downfall from grace. This unconventional narrative structure allows us to delve deeply into the complex issues that Oppenheimer encountered during the later phases of his illustrious career.As the story unfolds, a profound appreciation dawns upon the viewer, showcasing the challenges Oppenheimer faced and the moral dilemmas he wrestled with. Nolan's deliberate choice not to culminate with the Trinity test serves a purpose beyond cinematic bravado. Instead, it crafts a deeper understanding of Oppenheimer's significance-a poignant reflection of the consequences that arise from refusing to resort to violence against our adversaries, as it blurs the lines between 'us' and 'them.'Had Nolan opted for a more predictable conclusion, the film's powerful message might have been lost. However, by threading Oppenheimer's narrative with finesse and offering an unorthodox perspective, he ensures that audiences are left with an indelible impression of historical significance and the enduring lessons to be learned from this remarkable chapter in human history.

Tbh., this has to win every Oscar there is... Cillian Murphy is a genius actor and one of our generation's finest. Pretty long film no doubt, But I had expectations because we were told by the cast and the director Christopher Nolan during the interviews, that the audience would be able to experience what destructive power an atomic bomb has just like what we can see for an explosion in Nuclear reactor visually in the show by HBO, Chernobyl.Disappointed, that nothing was shown visually, I couldn't connect with the guilt Oppenheimer had when he said, "he feels blood on his hand". I've had more fun having my teeth surgically removed and sucking on a lime straight after.This movie was so unbelievably dull, yes the the actors did a good job but the story was so stretched out it could have been compacted into a 30mins documentary.Don't get me wrong I will watch this again when its on the streaming sites as a means to be sent asleep.Not sure how it's rated so high.It was a flip of the coin to see this or Barbie and believe me that coin is no longer with us, at least Barbie would have maintained our attention to the big screen.I think the names of the people involved are what draws people to see this but they are not enough to save it.

Not to mention that the movie shows little about the actual building of the atomic bomb and more about the political drama.Some scenes and characters felt even unnecessary or irrelevant to the plot. But, I can't deny that it was still a really good movie. A real story of such significance can't go wrong after all.A hard 8/10 from me :)

Really well shot, written and directed. Great acting from ALL cast. Excellent sense of suspense which ultimately leads to a fantastic movie that will be one to watch for years to come. The movie is a 3hour long Wikipedia audio book of Oppenheimer life story. The book that this movie is based on is a great work of literature which even won the Pulitzer Prize in the biography category.Overall the movie is very factually correct and captures the main events in the life of Oppenheimer and the major events of world war 2.It also contains dozens of notable scientists of whom many are Nobel laureates.The main con of the movie is like how the neutrons bombard the atoms in a chain reaction Nolan choses to bombard us with too much information as part of the Q clearance trial. If your native language is not English even with subtitles you are going to have a major inconvenience following the plot.So overall narrative is not gripping and some trivial events have been given so much of importance which kinda makes the plot a bit silly and the rivalry very petty.

There's not a single moment without background score, except for the bomb explosion. It always bothers me when a film requires background music for everything, even quiet conversations, that nothing is good enough to survive without musical support. Also bleach bypassing IMAX seems a real waste - why use a lab process that increases grain and reduces contract ratio on the highest resolution film medium available? It all feels pretty one note, style over substance. Dry. Given Nolan's limitless resources it should be much more rounded. I didn't care about anyone, or even really get to know anyone, including Oppenheimer. Overall really disappointing and all the glowing reviews to me feel like everyone has drunk the Kool Aid. The emperor has no clothes. Not sure how much I'm influenced by having read the biography it's based on. Dr George Miller used to say that a film should feel like a great piece of music with highs, lows, quiet, crescendos, pacing. This feels like one very long chorus, and not a great one at that.

Disclaimer: To non-Dutch speaking audiences this may seem fussy or overly critical. But imagine there was a British-made docudrama on the life of John F. Kennedy, and the actor portraying Kennedy spoke with a strong British accent, would you be upset? And that's only an accent...Nolan got an entire language wrong, and all he had to do was check Once. I understand this isn't a documentary, but this was Quite the interruption from the movie; for the entire audience. I watched Oppenheimer in the Netherlands, so to the audience it was blatantly obvious that Oppenheimer wasn't speaking Dutch, instead he spoke German in the scene in Leiden. Mixing the 2 is no small mistake here, I don't need to explain why.During the movie and shortly thereafter I thought of this mistake as rather small yet quite annoying to those who noticed. However, after I took one look at what Wikipedia had to say about Oppenheimer I think Nolan made quite a big error.Oppenheimer was praised for giving lectures in Dutch while in Leiden. I think that's quite remarkable, and so did others. He was given the nickname "Opje" which later became "Oppie". This whole thing is one of the many pillars of Oppenheimer's character. And Nolan missed it, devaluing the work of Everyone involved.So, first I was annoyed with Nolan, now I think he should stick to fiction. The movie is worth a 6, it was nice, that's it.

There is no sugar coating it. The cast did a good job. Story was well paced. Directing was well done as expected. You have to focus and pay attention to really get lost in the movie and while it does those things moderately well.. but I still found this movie just a totally disrespectful for the human experience.

*Context:*
"Oppenheimer," directed by Christopher Nolan, promised a riveting biography of Robert Oppenheimer and the creation of the atomic bomb, but unfortunately, it veered off course and left viewers wanting more. The film focused primarily on discussions surrounding Oppenheimer's security clearance and Strauss' confirmation hearing, failing to deliver on its marketed premise.*Negative aspects:*
The negative aspects of "Oppenheimer" are quite pronounced. Running for nearly three hours, the film was heavily laden with discussions, ego clashes, and court room drama, rather than exploring the intriguing world of atomic bomb creation and the scientific brilliance that shaped history. Although the discussions and courtroom drama were needed but at the cost of A-bomb development process, was something not anticipated at all. The Trinity test bomb scene, while boasting great sound design, suffered from inefficient visuals that did not live up to expectations (as promised before release).Complexities & non linear narrative again:
Adding to the film's complexity, a non-linear storytelling approach left many viewers perplexed and struggling to grasp the sequence of events and the significance of certain conversations. The omission of pivotal moments, such as Oppenheimer's childhood years and the aftermath of World War II, hindered the film's ability to provide a holistic portrait of the brilliant scientist and visionary.*Few positive aspects:*
On a positive note, the film's sound design and soundtrack deserve acclaim for its flawless execution. Additionally, the performances of the cast were commendable, with RDJ delivering a noteworthy portrayal.*Conclusion:*
In conclusion, "Oppenheimer" embarked on a bold journey to depict one of the most significant periods in history, yet it ultimately fell short of achieving its full potential. The film's preoccupation with discussions and courtroom drama overshadowed the opportunity to delve deeper into the fascinating world of atomic science.*Final words:*
"Oppenheimer" falls short as a biopic, failing to showcase the crucial A-bomb development process and attacks. While the sound design is impressive, the film left me unsatisfied, yearning for a deeper exploration of historical events. A missed opportunity to deliver a compelling narrative on a pivotal figure in history. It was marketed a "biopic thriller" but ended up being "biopic courtroom drama thriller".

When the Oscars come round I don't think it will be Cillian Murphy that gets his shoulder tapped I think it could be Emily Blunt and Robert Downie Jr who plays Oppenheimer's would be nemesis, Lewis Strauss. Don't get me wrong, Murphy is good, just not truly great.And that about sums up this overlong movie, good just not truly great.The plot wriggles and writhes through timelines in such a way as to satisfy Nolan's trademark need for complexity and I have to confess to being confused for much of its three hours.Also, if I was watching this as a Japanese viewer I'd be gritting my teeth at the overall celebration of the outcome of Oppenheimer's technical success. It treads a fine line between glorification and condemnation of the A Bomb that was dropped on Nagasaki and Hiroshima killing over 200,000 Japanese civilians.And while Nolan coaxes a degree of remorse out of his central character I wasn't 100% convinced that he really did regret his actions. Sure he denounces them, to an extent, but he didn't go into this in wide eyed innocence, Oppenheimer absolutely knew his objective. The ethics are pretty muddled, like a lot of the plot in my view.Ach, it's a hard one to deconstruct. I'm a little surprised at the ratings this movie is attracting because it's a long hard slog with a LOT of dialogue and not a great deal of action.Perhaps the best scenes are the test sequences in the desert, the senatorial election drama at the end and the creepy but well handled rabble rousing reception Oppenheimer receives from his team on the news that Hiroshima has been obliterated. At least in this scene Nolan convinces us that it's not a celebration of the bombing, but an indictment.Oppenheimer's vilification as a possible Communist is a central theme of the movie and is key to Strauss's objections and the 1954 kangaroo court FBI security clearance meeting which anchors the plot. There seems little evidence that he was a Commie, but the McCarthy regime at that time seemed to put little store in hard evidence and he clearly fared badly in this terrible stitch up.Perhaps my favourite moment in the movie is the look of schadenfreude on the face of Strauss's advisor towards the end of the movie.It's a delicious moment in a banquet that sadly has more plain fare than delicacies.

What a drag! Jesus. Three hours, really? I almost fell asleep two times during its span, my partner shook me up. Long, long, long, just boring. Goodness me, just how boring it is. If it was cut by half, it wouldn't be short enough even then. I understand the need of character development, but this? A horrible waste of time by moaning, whimpering and regret forever. Those feelings were there for sure, you just shouldn't watch them for three hours as an entertainment. The story is sublime of course, but the screenplay is bad and so is the execution. The issue I have with Nolan films is I find them to be emotionally disengaging, I find Oppenheimer no different.There is no doubting the stunning cinematography, impressive sound design and strong performances, yet I find it difficult to connect to the characters and story, Nolan's clinical approach to storytelling leaves you feeling distant.The all too familiar non-linear narrative can at times leave the film feeling disjointed, I can't see a reason why in Biopic it is necessary, it adds little to the film in both narrative and artistically. Despite the 3-hour run it feels rushed towards the end, As the film moves its attention entirely to the post war setting, Nolan tries to cram as much as he can into the last half hour, leading to a feeling of information overload. The film tries to tell two stories. The story of the creation of the atom bomb reaches at satisfactory conclusion, however the post war maybe should've been a separate film in order to flesh the detail and give it some space to breath.Cillian Murphy is superb as always and the support cast was excellent, every scene there seemed to be recognisable face in minor role. I would have liked to have seen more of Emily Blunt, I felt she was underutilised and brought some much-needed emotional drive to the film.Overall, from a technical perspective It's a great film but it leaves me not feeling a whole lot of anything towards it, it certainly won't linger in my head and I doubt I'll be coming back for a second viewing.....7/10.

Do you know why Christopher Nolan has never won an Academy Award for Best Director, despite being nominated only once? It's because he is not a good director. I would have imagined Oppenheimer a bit different, not so 'british' as he is.It is not a bad movie, but rather a boring movie. It is also predictable, at least for me it was.Also, I am not a fan of black and white films, and I do not see the reason for doing it as such. Maybe if you are, you will understand it better. It all comes to personal taste in the end.

That's it. Throw in a lot of loud dramatic sound effects to attempt to make the visual aspect more interesting and there's your film. It was essentially 3 hours of blathering drivel and the first time I've considered leaving the cinema from boredom.

Despite the anticipation surrounding Christopher Nolan's latest work, the film might not meet all expectations. The grandiosity of the movie, driven partly by Nolan's stellar reputation and the extensive marketing, creates a halo effect that might be misleading.The casting of Cillian Murphy in the lead role under Nolan's direction is a welcome decision, and his remarkable performance rightly takes center stage. However, the inclusion of over 21 celebrity cameos appears as an unneeded distraction, drawing attention away from the central narrative and undermining Murphy's role.Concerns also arise around the film's pacing. From the beginning, it plunges into a frantic tempo that continues relentlessly throughout. While this pace might be fitting for certain plot elements-such as racing against the Germans/Russians-the unyielding speed becomes disorienting. Quick scene cuts and often inaudible dialogue further contribute to the confusion.This incessant pace, though potentially intentional, restricts the artistry's room to breathe. The audience is left with little chance to immerse themselves and "feel" the film. With an expansive budget and a three-hour runtime, the rush to include substantial footage feels more like an attempt to justify the spending rather than letting the narrative unfold organically.Nevertheless, the movie's merits are undeniable. The visual splendor, combined with a beautiful musical score and Murphy's compelling performance, enriches the film's artistic value. Still, these qualities, as exceptional as they may be, do not suffice to label the work as a masterpiece.The conclusion to be drawn from Nolan's latest creation is that, while there is much to admire, certain choices undermine its overall impact. It might not connect with everyone, especially those seeking a more cohesive and immersive cinematic journey. The film shines in parts but may disappoint viewers expecting more than a Hollywood spectacle.Reflecting further, the true core of the story seems lost in the spectacle surrounding it. Nolan's name, the Hollywood cameos, the dominant score, and the grand IMAX visuals all contribute to the narrative receding into the background. The film's indulgence in cinematic glamour, though visually and auditorily thrilling, risks losing storytelling's essence. The intricate weave of characters, emotions, and themes gets overshadowed, tilting the balance towards appearance over depth. The result is a dazzling yet soul-unsatisfying movie that comes across more as a Hollywood extravaganza than a poignant human drama.

Being a student of the history of nuclear weapons development, I was pleased that the film was surprisingly accurate in terms of Oppenheimer's role in the development of the atomic bomb. I was especially interested in the efforts made to destroy Oppenheimer's reputation after the war and applaud Robert Downey's Academy Award level performance. My reason for rating this film lower than I had hoped to rate it is the sound track. Three of us found it difficult to clearly hear the cast members because of either distortion in the recording or masking level ambient noise in the film. The use of "airy" voices that has become so prevalent in todays films is infuriating. It is as if the use of vocal cords in the uttering of speech is now forbidden. I kept wanting to shout out "SPEAK UP". SAY IT SO WE CAN HEAR YOU!" Finally, the use of extreme noise levels in this film was far, far overdone. For an atomic bomb explosion? OK. But the use of room jarring, earth shaking low frequency sound levels over and over again was both gratuitous and ridiculous. I would be very careful in recommending this movies to my friends and relatives.

Where do I even begin with this trainwreck of a movie? "Openheimer" was supposed to be a cinematic masterpiece, exploring the fascinating life of J. Robert Oppenheimer and the development of the atomic bomb. However, it turned out to be an utter disappointment, leaving me questioning why I wasted my precious time and money on this cinematic catastrophe.First and foremost, the screenplay was a complete mess. The story lacked coherence and failed to provide any meaningful insights into Oppenheimer's character or the historical events surrounding the atomic bomb project. It felt like the writers had no idea what they were doing and were merely patching together random scenes without any logical connection.The pacing of the film was torturous, to say the least. It dragged on for what seemed like an eternity, with scenes that were either excessively long and tedious or confusingly rushed. The lack of a clear narrative arc left me struggling to maintain interest throughout the movie.The casting choices were equally disastrous. While talented actors can sometimes elevate a mediocre script, that was not the case here. The lead actor's portrayal of Oppenheimer was bland and unconvincing, failing to capture the complexity and intensity of the renowned physicist. Supporting characters were poorly developed and often served as mere placeholders, with their talents wasted in this forgettable production.To make matters worse, the film's production value was abysmal. The shoddy cinematography and lackluster set designs made it difficult to immerse oneself in the period the movie was attempting to portray. The lack of attention to historical accuracy was jarring, and it felt like the filmmakers were indifferent to doing justice to the real-life events they were trying to depict.Perhaps the most insulting aspect of "Openheimer" was its treatment of the atomic bomb's moral implications. The movie barely scratched the surface of the ethical dilemmas surrounding the development and use of such a devastating weapon. It was a missed opportunity to explore the complex and profound impact that this momentous event had on humanity.Overall, "Openheimer" is an unmitigated disaster that fails on almost every level. Its lackluster script, poor pacing, subpar performances, and disregard for historical accuracy make it one of the worst cinematic experiences I have ever endured. Save yourself the agony and avoid this film at all costs.

As "Oppenheimer" (2023 release; 180 min.) opens, we are introduced to Robert Oppenheimer, generally known as the "father of the atomic bomb". Oppenheimer is being interrogated by some congressional subcommittee in 1954, at the peak of McCartyism, for his alleged links to communist people and causes. We then go to Cambridge, England where Oppenheimer is doing his graduate studies... At this point we are 10 minutes into the movie.Couple of comments: this is the latest oeuvre (don't call it just a film from writer-producer-director Christopher Nolan. Let me state upfront that I am a huge fan of his works, and that surely he is one of the leading filmmakers of this generation. I absolutely loved Tenet, Dunkirk and Inception, just to name those. As you can imagine, with all of the critical acclaim and box office success this movie has been getting, I came to the theater with pretty high expectations. What I saw on the big screen did not match my expectations, I'm sorry to say. I never felt truly engaged by the movie. I never felt emotionally invested in Oppenheimer the man. On top of that, the movie seemingly went on forever. This negates the fine leaf performance from Cillian Murphy, and several others. I had hoped to see this in XD (the biggest screen at Cinemark), but alas by this weekend (the 3rd weekend of its release), "Oppenheimer" was relegated to a regular screen, unfortunately. Bottom line: is Oppenheimer a 'bad' movie? Of course not. But I can only tell you that my high expectations were not met, and that this wasn't nearly as enjoyable as Nolan's other recent releases."Oppenheimer" was released several weeks ago on the same day as "Barbie", creating a "Barbenheimer" effect that benefitted both movies. "Oppenheimer" has received nearly universal critical acclaim and I expect that it will be in the running for many awards when the awards season rolls along. If you are a fan of Christopher Nolan's earlier works, I'd readily suggest you check this out, and draw your own conclusion.

I was eager to watch "Oppenheimer" with high hopes of experiencing an engaging and insightful depiction of one of the most critical scientific figures in history. However, I was left deeply disappointed by the film, which fell far short of my expectations.The movie fails to capture the essence and complexity of J. Robert Oppenheimer's life and contributions to the world. Rather than delving into the intriguing details of his scientific genius and the moral dilemmas surrounding the development of the atomic bomb, the film becomes an incoherent mess of disconnected scenes and poorly developed characters.One of the most glaring issues with "Oppenheimer" is the lackluster portrayal of the protagonist himself. The character development is superficial, and we are left with a one-dimensional portrayal of Oppenheimer that does no justice to his intellect, ambition, or internal struggles. The film misses a golden opportunity to showcase the man behind the science, leaving audiences unattached to the central figure and disengaged from the story.Furthermore, the pacing of the film is disjointed, making it challenging to follow the narrative coherently. It jumps from one event to another without proper context, leaving the audience perplexed and struggling to connect the dots. The lack of a well-structured timeline makes it difficult to grasp the significant historical events surrounding Oppenheimer and the Manhattan Project.While the cinematography is visually appealing, it is not enough to compensate for the film's numerous shortcomings. The director seems more focused on artistic aesthetics rather than delivering a compelling and meaningful narrative. As a result, the film feels more like a collection of visually pleasing shots than a coherent and captivating storytelling experience.Additionally, the supporting characters are underdeveloped and do not add any depth or substance to the overall plot. The interactions between characters lack authenticity and fail to evoke any emotional connection with the audience.In conclusion, "Oppenheimer" falls short of being a gripping historical drama, failing to bring life to the fascinating story of a brilliant scientist in the tumultuous times of World War II. The lack of character development, disjointed storytelling, and underutilized supporting cast render this film unimpressive and forgettable. Regrettably, I must give "Oppenheimer" a one-star rating for its inability to live up to its potential and engage its viewers.Save your time and seek out other well-crafted historical films that do justice to the subjects they portray. "Oppenheimer" fails to leave a lasting impression, making it an unfortunate disappointment for those seeking an enriching cinematic experience.

The most important and potent line is used so early and during an unnecessary scene. Nolan has surly lost the plot.In "Oppenheimer," directorial maestro Nolan sought to bring the life of one of history's most enigmatic figures, J. Robert Oppenheimer, to the silver screen. Unfortunately, this much-anticipated biopic fails to live up to the immense hype surrounding it. Despite the promise of exploring the tumultuous life of the brilliant physicist who played a pivotal role in the creation of the atomic bomb, the movie falls flat in execution, leaving audiences underwhelmed and disappointed.The film begins on a promising note, introducing us to a Oppenheimer, portrayed with remarkable dedication by a talented Murphy. The portrayal of Oppenheimer's early years and his academic pursuits shows some potential, but as the narrative progresses, it becomes evident that Johnson struggles to find a compelling and coherent direction for the movie.One of the film's primary downfalls is its meandering pace and lack of focus. Instead of delving deep into the complexities of Oppenheimer's character, the movie frequently sidetracks into irrelevant subplots and meager character developments. While the desire to humanize Oppenheimer is evident, the script often feels forced and clichéd, doing little to shed new light on the man behind the bomb.Furthermore, the film's supporting cast, despite notable actors, is woefully underused and fails to make a significant impact. Characters such as General Leslie Groves and Edward Teller are reduced to one-dimensional caricatures, robbing the movie of potential opportunities for conflict and intrigue.Perhaps the most egregious misstep of "Oppenheimer" lies in its portrayal of the scientific endeavor. One would expect a movie about the father of the atomic bomb to delve into the scientific process and the ethical dilemmas surrounding the creation of such a weapon. Regrettably, the film merely skims the surface, sacrificing substance for unfulfilling melodrama.The cinematography and production design are passable, providing a visually acceptable backdrop to the lackluster narrative. However, these technical achievements cannot save the film from its fundamental flaw: overhyping a movie that fails to live up to its grandiose promises.In conclusion, "Oppenheimer" falls prey to the dangers of overhype. While the premise had the potential to be a gripping exploration of the life of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the film fails to deliver on its lofty aspirations. A disjointed script, lackluster characterizations, and a failure to tackle the ethical and scientific complexities of the atomic bomb's creation prevent "Oppenheimer" from becoming the biopic masterpiece it aspired to be. Regrettably, it ends up being a mere fizzle in the realm of nuclear cinema.Could have been an excellent HBO mini series but Nolan pulled a D&D GOT style on us and thus it felt rushed.
