There have been numerous dramatizations about the building of the bomb. Certain movies were bombs themselves (Fat Man and Little Boy). I was expecting the movie to centralize around the work going into building the first atomic bomb. Instead, it is really only the backdrop for a biography about Oppenheimer. Nolan and the screenwriters spiced up his story, using a hearing with flashbacks as the narrative structure. That type of structure allows the film to jump around in time, following the impacts of a decision throughout his life. Jumping around is definitely Nolan's directing style. It keeps the pacing fast, and helps to parse out portions of the film that would have otherwise become static if told in linear fashion. This is the case of the hearing. It is conducted in a small and uninteresting room as a location. Same for the many many conversations about being engaged in politics.One review mentioned the directing style resembling Martin Scorcese. The "Goodfellas" director was the pioneer of the hyper-pacing when telling a story. Nolan perhaps might feel that Michael Bay syndrome of quick cutting to force the audience to keep watching by subjecting them to some new stimulus every few seconds. Nolan probably justifies the quick cutting knowing that this is meant to be a summer tentpole film, which needs to resemble a roller coaster ride. So you get a lot of big music cues, big scenes, a big group of side characters, and just a little tiny bit of humour. Adding the right amount of humour is extremely important for a script that wants be a serious drama. Too many yucks can decrease the amount of gravitas to the story. Too little humour keeps the audience in an emotional rut. They need to have a bit of levity once in a while, especially when the movie gets heavy handed. Matt Damon plays the general in charge of the Manhattan Project. As seen in the trailer, his heavy handed character almost gets to the point of over-acting. Thankfully he is allowed to be more than one dimensional. There still is the memory of Paul Newman playing Damon's character in "Fat Man and Little Boy". That movie made many bad decisions, one was to make Paul Newman an overdrawn movie villain.As I sat through the three hour running time, something occurred to me that was a revelation, I could actually hear and understand the dialogue! Finally someone convinced Nolan to turn the music down a bit. The music score must have been a huge undertaking. I think few people realise the amount of man hours it takes to go over footage only a few minutes at a time and carve out a music cue that encompasses many factors (character, story, location, time of day, mood, etc.), and not become derivative or repetitious. Ludwig Goransson displays a wide breadth of musical knowledge that Hans Zimmer never had. He uses a musical palette of many instruments and styles (including Zimmer).So the story gets around to the actual event of setting off the atomic bomb. I don't know why, but Nolan didn't want a computer simulation. The practical version failed to really invoke a sense of awe. Unless... Nolan wanted this movie to be less about the bomb, and as such only give scant details on its production, along with the tedious aspects of testing for two years. This film finds a lot of good intelligent interaction with the supporting characters, many are whom are physicists. The final act of the film focuses on the aftermath of the birth of the atomic age. We see how those other characters react to the event as well as to the pressure of politics. The red scare back then made it easy to make scapegoats out of innocent people.So of course you are asking, does it fail the two hour rule? Does this film justify its three hour running time? If you are Martin Scorcese, you can justify a longer running time, like "The Departed", because you are condensing an even larger story. Such is the case here, mostly. As important as politics are, I feel audiences don't find it entertaining.The supporting characters do a fine job of filling out the scope of this film. The film jumps around from Europe to Ivy League college campuses to the New Mexico desert. Meaningful conversations are written with a certain eloquence in mind. In other words, a lot of thought was put into the dialogue to add more subtlety about the greater meaning of what they are saying. Robert Downey Jr. Does a great transformation into a man who was the first commissioner of the Atomic Energy Commission. Not a very exciting man, thus played in a relaxed fashion by Downey. Emily Blunt has very little screen time in this film. Not much is explored about their marriage, and she has few lines for such a prominent actress in a seemingly prominent role. There are other familiar faces that pop up, which I won't spoil the fun. Cillian Murphy plays the role of his career. By far, Oppenheimer is a complex character, and some odd behaviour is shown. Murphy seems to be always in deep thought, and somewhat disassociated with the kind of everyday life most people have. Like being a proper parent.There was some light applause at the end of the nearly sold out showing I went to. Here is a chance to learn about an interesting piece of history, and in the process experience a refreshing break from the summer blockbuster sequel assembly line. I would only say some parts of the story could have been condensed even more, such as some of the politics. Nolan is certainly developing a reputation for retelling stories in a more exciting way. Many see Nolan transitioning into a serious director with Dunkirk and now this historical piece. Such as his inclusion of nudity (for the first time?) in one his films. There needs to be an artistic approach that makes sense when showing nudity, and Nolan shows that kind of maturity here.7 out of 10.

Oppenheimer is a film that tries to explore the life and work of the man behind the atomic bomb, but fails to deliver a compelling story or a satisfying conclusion. The film is too long, too slow, and too dense with technical and historical details that only a physics or politics student would appreciate. The characters are bland and unrelatable, the dialogue is dry and dull, and the cinematography is uninspired and boring. The film does not do justice to the complexity and controversy of Oppenheimer's legacy, nor does it offer any insight or emotion to the audience. Oppenheimer is a film that should have been left in the lab. One good scene which was impressive but left me very sober. It was anxiety inducing. Then 30 more minutes and I just hoped the movie will end. It's not just a "problem" with Oppenheimer but I noticed with other movies with similar running time. Even The Batman which I loved was slightly too long. Not exactly the same goes with Oppenheimer I felt like an editor and wanted to cut out the last 20 minutes. The movie could have ended on a more impressive note than it actually did. I also didn't really like Nolan's typical beige filter in it. The B/W segments felt refreshing. Weirdly my cinema's 70mm film projector went broke after 30 minutes in. (The first nude scene with Florence Pugh and Cillian Murphy). They talked about Freud and Jung and the movie was paused for 20 minutes, just to be replaced by the digital backup. That was an interesting experience. It was my first time seeing a movie in analog and I guess it was also a first time for a long time for the theater. It has its charms. The grain. The white flicker between cuts and the slight stroboscopic effect like a flip book. Anyways. That's all.

Unexceptional film making. I found it to be both anxious and oppressive as it relentlessly jumps continuously through what can only be described as long and exhausting. It's 3 hour runtime is taxing, fragmented and crawls by. This movie could be an hour less without having any real effect on the story. It is challenging to watch and will easily get away from the viewer.We are introduced to the father of the atomic bomb and the question of whether he was a communist or not. Theoretical physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer is recruited by the United States government to oversee a top secret operation intended to develop the world's first atomic bomb. The film attempts to convey the complexities of World War 2, cold war history, and to bring a quick end to the war. These are truly some of the most important events and questions of the 20th century and how it still affects everyone decades later.I'm left with the feeling that Oppenheimer just doesn't deliver. I certainly don't feel the need to rush out and see it again anytime soon. In fact, I'm sure I won't ever endure the painful 3 hour experience again. I guess I was expecting something a little more entertaining.

Not unlike Nolan's other films this is a Movie that must be seen more than once to fully grasp. I also found the acting to be overly dramatic as well when it would be just characters talking to each other.One last con is that the movie is 3 hrs long and it doesn't need to be that long, add to that the nonlinear story telling and it becomes a tough film to sit through.All cons aside, the film still has some of the best and most iconic scenes of the year, so if you're interested in the subject material I strongly recommend it but you need to go in with expectations that you are going into a 3 hr long talkie and not a summer action filled blockbuster.

The expectations that go into a Nolan film have obviously affected the end product of most of his more recent efforts, so much so that the great potential story of one of the most significant technological events in history becomes poorly told.From a historical perspective, so many significant events from the development of atomic weapons are left out, such as Heisenberg (Germany) almost killing himself during his own experiments, the exodus of great scientists to the US preceding the Nazi uprising, the Demon Core incidents after the War, and the celebrity status Oppenheimer achieved after the War. Zero historical footage is used in this film, which is worse for it as so much amazing stuff could be repurposed here. We aren't even allowed to feel anything about the atrocities of Germany, Japan, or the USSR at the time. In fact, a key reason Truman wanted to end the war with the bomb quickly was to keep the Soviets from making a mess of post-war Japan by claiming lands by invasion, which would have led to a partly communist Japan to this day.From a science perspective, little is told about the development of the bombs themselves, including the obstacles the scientists really faced and the achievements they made. No mention of the idea that the technology could also be used to save the world (nuclear power), being reason enough to push forward with the research, aside from keeping it out of Germany's hands, which was a real concern of the government.As such, this isn't a documentary. Not at all. Any of the aforementioned stuff would have made for a brilliant Nolan film...but I don't see him capable of makes a film with real science and history.Neither is it a character study, as the biopic title suggests. Rather it's a vehicle for Nolan to edit together trailer-type cuts across changing timelines for 3 hours. I found it tiresome and frenetic. While the acting is good, none of it makes us feel anything for the characters. While there was an opportunity to work on the morality angle for Oppenheimer, which was very much what the real man was about, the film glosses over this to focus only on the politics of the time, where the McCarthy era witch-hunts ended Oppenheimer's career as a quantum physicist. Even then, Nolan misses an opportunity to vilify those actions by the government, making no real statements there.The result of the 3 hours is the simple message that the genie cannot be put back in the bottle, and in Oppenheimer's mind, would end in our destruction.That said, all the high grades for this film come from Nolan fanboys, who write pretentious reviews for pretentious films.

My first impression of Oppenheimer was just how loud it all was. Not to criticize the beautiful tones found throughout, but the heaviness and intensity of the music never relented, except for an inevitable central sequence when we finally, mercifully, get a moment of silence. Silence between the pieces of score, and silence between hours of continuous, hyper-paced dialogue and sound design, which all combined sometimes approaches cacophony.The noise of it all sometimes seems an attempt to compensate for a misplaced idea that an audience wouldn't be able to sustain interest in this material without the distraction of a continuous soundtrack. I wish it would have appreciated more moments of quiet. And ironically, in spite of its relentlessness, Oppenheimer ends up the slowest, and most demanding of all Christopher Nolan films.This is not a bad thing. This film is full of smart, engrossing material and succeeds as a rich retelling of Oppenheimer's legacy and the vast network of brains who helped make his Manhattan Project a reality. Multiple viewings are warranted. The cast is spectacular and good use is overall made of them (when we can pin an actor down long enough to even notice their presence), and I can't really blame Nolan anyway, for wanting to spruce up hours of granular physics, debates and testimony into something as awesome as possible.Nolan's movies are gorgeous contraptions, made with exquisite care and a love of an old school sort of practical filmmaking, and they're always ambitious, always outsized. This movie left me with an odd feeling, which is that it was both too long and not long enough. Not long enough to really pierce the enormous scope of what Oppenheimer's life stood for against history, and yet full and stylized almost beyond the brim.

I fed into all of the hype and was extremely excited to watch this film. I will never get these 3 hours of my life back. In my opinion there was only one good scene and that was the explosion. The rest of the film is a convoluted mess with all the characters shaping up to be completely uninteresting(except for Oppenheimer himself) The acting was rather good but it doesn't matter when the characters are uninteresting. I've seen many movies and I think this takes the cake for the movie that was the least gripping/entertaining. How can you be expected to pay attention to a 3 hour dialogue slog of a movie when you can barely hear the actors talking? I don't think it was a theatre issue but if it was I apologize. The film is only good for about 10 mins, 1/10 should have seen Barbie.

Having forced myself to sit through "Interstellar" (2014), I was forewarned that this Auteur was more committed to the arty than to art. This episodic movie offers random scenes from the life of the father of the atom bomb at a very important historical moment. President Joe Biden has announced that we are at the brink of "Nuclear Armageddon," so this is a worthy contribution to a rich genre that began with Arch Obler's "Five" (1951). Its major virtue is the portrayal of the ant-Communist hysteria of the 1940s, which preordained the present anti-Maga hysteria, both crazes united in their conviction that nuclear war with Russia is probably inevitable, especially now that Russian agents, pretending to be Americans, are among us. The brief portrait of the diminutive haberdasher from Independence is highly amusing. Movie directors are tyrants on the set and in the theatres, where they may require 180 minutes of undivided attention, but, here, it's worth a sitting.

After having seen the high ratings, the interviews with the cast and the trailer, I was looking forward to see an accurate depiction of an important part of history, still shaping our world today.But the actual movie has nothing to do with the trailer; 2/3 of it deals with endless interrogations after the war about Oppenheimer's possible old communist links and his refusal to cooperate with the H-bomb development, so to find an excuses to revoke his security clearance and side-line him. And this in endless time-jumps back and forth.The actual 1/3 of the movie that deals with the development of the "gadget", the theory behind it and the practical problems to turn various theories into reality was only lightly addressed, barely scratching the surface of the development, the technical difficulties, the logistics, the organisation and the timeline.True, the film is called "Oppenheimer" and not "Trinity", "the Bomb", etc, but I felt that for 2 out of the 3 hours I was attending some courtroom interrogation about Oppenheimer, not a movie about the man and his team developing the technology while admitting various levels of doubt, guilt, conscience, etc.Yes the acting was very good, Cillian Murphy, but also, to my surprise, Matt Damon.But overall, this movie does not at all represent, in my humble opinion, what it is being sold to be.

The film is more about personal vendattas and attempts to grab political benefits than about the discovery itself.Much of the film is about hearings to damage Oppenheimer's reputation and career and the downfall of the person who did it.I hate to say it but it was a little boring. It's beautifully shot and superbly acted and not a bad film at all but for me it was a bit cowardly.I disagree with the reviews that say it brought up important ethical dilemmas and issues. The film only ever so briefly touches upon them. In fact the damage the bomb did is barely mentioned and the ethics are given a cursory glance at best. The only ethics I think it did quite well was to question if Oppenheimer really had an issue with continued and developed nuclear bombs for moral reasons or if it was about him retaining power.

Sorry but it just doesn't live up to the pre-game hype! And not worth the extra for an IMAX viewing of bland deserts and chalkboards full of maths symbols!Yes it tells a story of a complicated man, but too many stories jumping around back and forth with music score so overbearing in places was starting to give me a headache (earplugs stopped me walking out for a break)Strange though, with nearly three hours runtime, Nolan chose not to put a single Japanese actor in for a few scenes from their perspective in the aftermath?For me Downey Jr gave a standout performance as did Damon. Blunt's low amount of screen time was noticeable, as the wife in support of a brilliant but boring cerebral genius, who fared little better than Churchill in the post war years!Will watch again on the small screen to go back over details missed, in all that loud music & scene jumping..

Oppenheimer is a captivating war film that takes its audience on a mesmerizing journey through the life and times of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the brilliant physicist and key figure in the development of the atomic bomb. The movie's standout feature is undoubtedly Cillian Murphy's exceptional performance, which is nothing short of remarkable. His portrayal of Oppenheimer brings depth and intensity to the character, elevating the overall impact of the film.The storyline and underlying theories explored in Oppenheimer are praiseworthy. The movie delves into the moral and ethical dilemmas faced by scientists involved in the creation of such a powerful and devastating weapon. It deftly highlights the inner conflict within Oppenheimer and his colleagues as they grapple with the consequences of their actions.

Not gonna say it was a bad movie. But it was average at best. Despite the amazing acting, the movie falls short in every other aspect. The short scenes and continuous cutting and shifting from past to future where some scenes didn't serve any purpose or help to understand in fact it makes you more lost alongside the unnecessary characters. All of the previous added the 40-50 extra minutes that made it a boring film. Disappointed mainly because of the hype around it. But honestly a movie mainly about "bombs" had 1 bomb scene, and 90% was just meetings of people grilling each other with load music in the background.

I went in with a lot of expectation. Knowingly that this is a biography and it's based on an actual event that we already knew - an invention that changed the course of the world.So with a stacked casts consisting of some of the greatest actors of our time, 3-hour run time and all the hype surround this film, I came out feeling hollow and confused!It's overly long - the run time could be cut short to 2-hour or 2-hour 15 at most. The runtime and subplot are overstuffed!It's over-stylized - too many time jump (Nolan's signature) but I don't see the need of deploying this. It's overused and VERY SELF-INDULGING!!! And then... there is these black and white scenes that are supposed to represent something. I don't know what I'm suppose to watch, one moment I'm given the lecture on science and physics but the next it's all bureaucratic and political and conspiracies. And then there's drama and affair. It's just too much! I like movies that are non-linear, to serve the purpose of storytelling and for the twist. But this one, just NO!It's overblown - and overhyped. I know this movie is about atomic bomb and its impact to humanity but I cannot feel the real impact of it for the most part. Probably only towards the last 1 hour. The explosion scene is supposed to be the climax but I didn't feel it that way.At some point in the cinema, I felt like I needed to look up Oppenheimer on wikipedia and get over with it rather than to sit through the remaining hours of self-indulging piece of work that some may call it art. Yes maybe it is, perhaps too artistic to the point I don't know how to appreciate it?To be fair, the acting is really good but I somehow often got distracted with the overly long dialogues. It reminds me of Quentin Tarantino's Inglorious Basterds long dialogue but Nolan did not pull this one off!Great production, yes. But I can't say the same for the screenplay.Cinematography is beautiful but the jump cut to the "imagination" (supposedly) of the lead character is more distracting than it is to serve its purpose.Not forgetting also the soundtrack. It's trying to make the audience feel tensed but it did not do anything to me. I felt it's more distracting to me than to make me feel tensed or engaged.I'm a fan of Christopher Nolan's earlier works. Like Memento and Inception, both are very original and groundbreaking. Batman, Dark Knight and The Prestige are great movies.But not this one! So distracting that I kept looking at my watch and I'm struggling to connect with the story.It's like a bomb that did not detonate.

I saw OPPENHEIMER in 70-millimeter format. I wish I had liked it better, but I didn't. What I disliked most about it was the soundtrack. There was INCESSANT background noise that rumbled and roared and thudded (with a lot of Sensurround-style vibration) throughout the film. Sometimes it drowned out the actors, several of whom were hard for me to understand in the first place. The style of the photography was also off-putting. To make it seem like a documentary or a period-piece, sections of it were filmed in black-and-white or used filters to deaden the colors. I think all these gimmicks were there to disguise the fact that the script wasn't really very focused and was 3 hours long. The script is based on true historical events, and reality isn't easily shoehorned into a coherent plot. It was never clear to me exactly what the point was. There are a lot of good actors in this movie, but I didn't know who they were until I saw the credits! I still think of Matt Damon and Robert Downey Junior as young men, and they're NOT! I thought Downey gave the best performance in the film, though. The art direction and costume design seemed to accurately depict the period, although thanks to the cinematography, we'll never know what the true colors of anything were. (I wonder if the film-maker told these people that he was going to use stylized cinematography beforehand, or whether they found out when they saw the film.) I admire the film's ambition, and I think the issues it raises are things that people should think about, but I wonder if it would have been better if they had just told the story.

Cillian Murphy offers an assured and considered performance here as the man who is credited with developing the bomb that hastened the end of WWII in the far east. He is the increasingly acclaimed, eponymous, physicist who is made aware by Admiral Lewis Strauss (another strong performance from Robert Downey Jr.) that it just possible that the Russians have the A-bomb. Now Oppenheimer already suspects that the Nazis are also well on their way to weaponising the atom - his earlier education and career had introduced him to some of the prominent minds in the UK and in Germany who were quite capable of taking the theory forward; so he begins to pressurise the American government to begin it's own programme - and the "Manhattan Project" is born. Motivated/goaded/galvanised by the ambitious "Col. Groves" (Matt Damon) he assembles a formidable collection of scientific minds at a purpose built, desert, location which he christens Los Alamos, and over the next three years - and with $2bn to spend - they work on the science whilst plutonium and uranium are being simultaneously processed at an irkingly glacial pace! Given that much of this is reasonably well documented history, the actual plot here has little by way of jeopardy. Instead, Christopher Nolan attempts via his writing and direction to put some meat on the bones of the characters here. It's clear that Oppenheimer is a bit of a Lothario, but it's also clear that he can engender the loyalty of a variety of people with diverging views - not just surrounding the science of their project, but around the morals and ethics of creating something that - well, you can't get the toothpaste back into the tube. The latter portion of this drama focusses on the subsequent, communist-obsessed, witch-hunting that went on attempting to persecute and smear this remarkable and flawed individual, and it makes some interesting postulations about just who was pulling whose strings. It also has quite a penetrating resonation about it - not just, specifically, about Oppeneheimer - but about all of those post-event "enquiries" that rarely deliver an honest appraisal of what was done in the name of expediency at the time, but ends up more of a character assassination exercise by those who didn't do anything against those who did and had to. Though at times the pace of this thing helps to keep it enthralling, it is too long - at times it really does plod along. Perhaps an other, objective, eye on the writing/direction may have tightened it up without having to sacrifice any of the potency of the story. Maybe someone needs to tell Mr. Nolan that a three hour film isn't always required! That said, it's a gorgeous film to look at. The aesthetics are first rate and the entire sentiment of the film reeks of authenticity. I do think this thrives better on a big screen so try to see it as it was intended. It's though provoking, complex, characterful - and well worth a watch.

98% of the 3-hour long movie was talking, interrogating, flashing back and forth and some unnecessary sex scenes. Didn't show the bomb making process, how it was used, the aftermath. Yes of course I can Goggle for my own interest but that was the impression from all the hype and false advertising from this movie! The movie was super boring I couldn't wait for it to be over! Also Lewis Strauss played by Robert Downey Jr. Was very annoying, guy kept fixing his tie, button / unbutton and putting on and taking off his jacket, so pretentious! I regret taking my whole family to see this hyped up movie! Don't fall for this hype and this is definitely not appropriate for teens and younger.

Not sure if I was sleep deprived but I found the film somewhat grating. The score was great but relentless and too loud, it was hard to decipher the dialogue. The shots were very short and choppy. There was a lot of dialogue, so much so that it required an exorbitant amount of focus and got tiring very quickly. I understand the reason why they didn't depict the bombings on Japan as the film did not wish to glorify the bombings in any way. Running length was far too long.The psychological evaluation of Oppenheimer was very astute. The film reads as more of a psychological study of his mind and involves a lot of courtroom drama (he said, she said type of stuff). It is not an action film or even a historical biopic in my opinion.

My first review ever on here. And its is a warning. This movie is terrible.This movie had so much potential. With a 3 hour run time I expected dialog. I didn't expect 95% of the movie to just be dialog!I was expecting this to be somewhat like the HBO show Chernobyl but with the budget of a big time movie by Nolan. That show had good dialog along with great scenes of what happened after the meltdown.I was expecting the same from this movie. It is almost disrespectful to not show the anguish it caused and it would play into how Oppenheimer was haunted by the Manhattan project.Instead they did not show anything other than the testing of the atomic bomb and tried to show Oppenheimer as a victim rather than the engineer of death. So many missed opportunities, and to the point where it was flat out boring.

First of this is a good film and (as far as I can gather) generally accurateWith a plethora of stars, many in small parts, the acting is very goodThe first 2 hours go by in a whiz as I was totally enthralled, totally absorbedThis film is beautifully crafted and acted where it (dare I say it) goes slighly awry, is it is just soooooo long.I have to admit in the last 30 minutes I was wishing it would end. It's a bit of a marathon to watch and begins to run out of steam in the last part.Therefore for the first 2 hrs 8/10 but overall 7.5/10Would I watch this again ? No, for me it's a watch once (and well worth a watch) but i'm unlikely to do so again.

When it was good it was amazing but those occasional 20 mins of nothing just made it draaaaaagg but i saw another review say there were 3 really great scenes (you'll know the ones once you watch them) and how they're incredible but overall despite the scenes it went on for too long completely. 3 hours which essentially was 1 hour of incredible cinema and 2 of just confusing timelines, millions of physicists who all blend into one and florence pugh having 2 s** scenes and a slewer slide scene (really weird she actually took on the role tbh) but yeah prefered barbie tbh and ik shouldn't be compared but marketing really messed up releasing on same day so not really my fault! And befor letterboxd nerds say that barbie was just dopamine enjoyable and just cuz oppenheimer isn't constant fun doesn't mean it's worse : no! Ur wrong and idc.

Great movie but the hype is jus too much! The screen presentation is excellent but way too many conversations and talks rather than action and story . The scene in and out from past to the present makes it very difficult to grasp and I feel that it Should have been simple and plain ! Why is there no scene of the bomb in Japan 🇯🇵 ? This movie is so borimg that it should be banned!It's built arround interrogations and all we get to see is people talking in boring tones. There's no inriguing scenes, no diving into any person's life, no emotions. A biology book would be a lot more fun than this 3 hour long so called movie! I trusted the 8.8/rating so I decieed to watch this movie for our cinema night with my boyfriend. The first part was boring as f so we waited for the second part, turns out, it was the same s! I don't understand how anyone can publish or give a 10/10 rating for something like this! We were so bored that I told my boyfriend we should go out when there was 35 minutes left, he agreed and said "Let's f go, this movie is disgusting" out loud. After we went out, 35 people came out with us! There is no point in this movie, no story, nothing to be curious about, nothing to learn, nothing to feel. I saw only 2 good scenes, the silent test-bomb at Santa Fe, and showcasing how Oppenheimer felt inside while giving a speech to Americans about how proud he is to have bombed Japan.As someone who knew about Oppenheimer before, I expevted something a lot more interesting, teaching about quantum mecahincs, space and making us feel his loneliness, his depression and his traumas.He is basically a robot in the movie, just like every other character! I can remember I felt more intrigued when I watched his DOCUMENTARY!You can see what's so wrong about this movie if the documentary is more fun to listen to than the movie!This movie is such a killjoy. The part after getting out of the cinema at 1 AM and loudly listening to music in the var with my BF was more fun than the whole 3 hours!

This was definitely something I'd been looking forward to and was excited to see some 'real cinema'. What with all the excellent actors, top director, and interesting subject matter, I was ready to really 'feel something', and my initial feeling is a bit deflated, to be honest.The acting here is top quality, there's no doubt, and all the characters, of which there are what feels like millions, all have depth and plenty of important dialogue. But by the second hour, I had succumbed to the sheer volume of detailed exchanges and personal motives. They just throw it at you scene after scene, and for the first time in a movie, I wished I was at home watching a 5-part limited series where I could debate and analyze with my wife what the hell was going on at times.Christopher Knowlen is a master in my opinion because he creates such rich environments and thought-provoking movies like Interstellar and Inception that challenge the viewer while delighting them with a fast-paced story that is captivating to watch. This movie left me needing to watch it two more times to soak up every piece of detail, with none of the motivation to do it. The first 30 mins are so promising, and the visuals about the nature of reality are stunning and mind-expanding. This is short-lived before the reality of mechanics, ego, and politics are shuffled on our heads scene by scene.I will watch this movie again, I've no doubt, but not soon and not for money.

I am a Christopher Nolan fan, particularly drawn to his original works. Biography and real-life storytelling also intrigue me, which is why I'm quite familiar with the Oppenheimer story. Based on the trailers, I believed this movie would delve into the science of bomb-making and explore Oppenheimer's emotions. In an interview, Nolan himself stated that the movie revolves around Oppenheimer, with the supporting cast merely there to complement the main character.With this expectation, I was hoping to witness Oppenheimer's inner struggles portrayed in a way that was far more personal. My desire was to experience the movie through Oppenheimer's perspective. Unfortunately, the film took a different approach, focusing more on the outside world's perception of Oppenheimer and the political entanglements, which I found to be the least interesting part of his story. Such aspects would be better suited for an actual documentary where facts and information are sought. In cinema, we crave thrilling experiences.Many have praised the film's non-CGI effects, but personally, I found the actual Trinity bomb explosion effect to be underwhelming. A movie about the atomic bomb should evoke a sense of suspense and offer the most impactful portrayal of its consequences, not just for spectacle but to evoke a deep emotional impact.As a graphic designer and animator familiar with practical effects, I can usually distinguish between CGI and practical effects. However, the close-ups of this non-CGI explosion did not thrill me.After seeing the movie, I couldn't help but wonder why it didn't take a direction more akin to 'The Imitation Game.' I yearned for a focus on the science behind creating the device and the emotional struggles that accompanied it.

Oppenheimer isn't a bad movie. It's a good movie. It's just difficult to know just how good it is since the dialogue is constantly interrupted either by over the top sound effects or a self important and intrusive soundtrack by Ludwig Göransson. It isn't that Christopher Nolan thinks he's Michael Bay. There's only one explosion, but it is a big one. It's just that he might as well have been Michael Bay, exchanging explosions on the screen for an explosive soundtrack. I don't know if Ludwig Göransson thinks he's the new Vangelis or the next Hans Zimmer, but he is neither. They must have a great sound system in the studio's mixing room. It's just too bad the average Cineplex can't quite match it.I think he would have been better served if he had brought Zimmer onboard to do the soundtrack. He brought other people from the Batman movies. Gary Oldman is almost unrecognizable as President Harry Truman and Tom Conti is totally unrecognizable as Professor Albert Einstein. There are other Hollywood Heavyweights in other cameos as well. But they're all overshadowed by the intrusive overbearing soundtrack.If only Christopher Nolan had more respect for the audiences intelligence he might have given the dialogue a more prominent place in his film. Quantum Mechanics and Nuclear Physics are difficult enough subjects to tackle when you can hear and understand every word being said clearly and distinctly. But when you have music that is trying to create a sense of urgency and tension even in scenes where there is none, it's a bit like the snow he inserts into scenes where it isn't cold enough to see the actors breath. Obviously he is foreshadowing nuclear winter and fallout, but again, it's as intrusive as the persistent soundtrack, and more than a little ham-handed. Muck like the inserted nudity and sex scene trying to allude to Oppenheimer's life being laid bare before his detractors.Cillian Murphy's performance is excellent. Had this film been made a decade or two ago his part might well have gone to Peter Weller. He would have fit right in as the Doctor Buckaroo Banzai of the 1940s, especially when Naked Lunch like sexual and atomic hallucination intrude into the story almost as much as that bombastic soundtrack.Perhaps all the blasts of music, sound effects and shocking imagery are to keep the audience awake since you can't always hear the dialogue. Or, maybe, he thought the dialogue itself would put people to sleep, especially after the bomb is made and shipped off to Japan and the movie is only a little more than half over and the film degenerates into a courtroom drama against Oppenheimer by a Robert Downey Jr.'s bitter character, since it's filled enough science and political science to put the audience to sleep even with the intrusive music and hallucinations. It's hard to say for certain since I couldn't hear a lot of it.So I hope when the DVD comes out there will be instead of a Director's Cut, a Viewer's Cut, complete with options like a soundtrack that can be turned down. At least there will be Closed Captions, hopefully accurate ones, and not like the ones that seem be written for the deaf by the deaf. No, good ones where you can read what's actually being said. Only then will I be able to determine just how good this good movie really was. It was certainly better than the theater's sound system as it struggled to keep up. Perhaps they should resurrect the of Sensurround System from the 1970's that they used for movies like Earthquake and Midway with enough Cervwin-Vega speakers for a Grateful Dead concert. Maybe that would allow the audience to hear the dialogue above the intrusive score and atomic blasts. Otherwise it's like trying to watch a combination of a dramatic Broadway play with the entire New York Philharmonic on stage with the actors, punctuating their every line with fanfares and flourishes.Does this review seem overly long and monotonous? Well then Oppenheimer probably isn't your cup of tea. The "courtroom stuff" makes the "math stuff" seem interesting by comparison. It seems that Christopher Nolan wanted to give us an epic. It's certainly long enough to be one. But most of the film isn't IMAX worthy, even if the soundtrack requires their sound system. This could have been a Smart Movie, but I think Nolan made it just smart enough for intellectually challenged pretentious people to think it is. Or maybe I'm wrong and it's just me. But if I were you, I'd wait for the DVD, or Stream it. That way you can rewind missed dialogue and take breaks as needed in order to find out.

I'm disappointed with this movie I had gone to see this as part of the double feature and was excited. Christopher nolan never disappoints but he certainly did with this movie. To put it simply about an hour of this movie could have been shaved off there were parts in the film where nobody can hear what the character was saying due to some poor sound editing. Oppenheimer is fast paced in some scenes but is painfully slow in other scenes. The intimate scenes added nothing of value. This movie is overrated because big casts are in it thats all. Don't get me wrong I'm a huge fan of peaky blinders. This is just name tags attached its not genius and it certainly is not the best thing you will ever see. Once it reaches the big bang everything else in comparison seems bland. Just an average movie at best and its too long. Don't bother wasting your time.

Christopher Nolan really screwed up here. He joined the scores of other Hollywood movies where you can understand what the actors are saying only half the time. I didn't think it made any sense to switch between black and white and color. I think the sex scenes were gratuitous and unnecessary. They were more of a distraction. Don't get me wrong, I love watching naked women in movies, but this takes away from the storyline of this nonfiction film. I wish there had been some scenes from World War II in Europe. Yes, this movie was about only Oppenheimer, but to add a few scenes from the major events of the world at the time, the setting would've been better. The time period would've been more apparent. This is where the lack of clear dialogue makes the movie a failure. If you're not gonna show some scenes of Europe at war in WWII during this time, period, at least make the actors enunciate and sound clear.

"Oppenheimer," Christopher Nolan's ambitious adaptation of "American Prometheus," disappointingly falls short of expectations set by his previous cinematic marvels. The film is certainly monumental, but its expansive 3-hour length proves testing for the audience's patience. We anticipate a compelling narrative around scientific discovery, atomic theory, and the birth of the atomic bomb. Instead, Nolan swerves into a labyrinth of political intrigue, painting a shadowy picture of Oppenheimer as a communist.The film often feels more like a detached documentary than a stirring cinematic experience. There's no central plot to anchor us, and an unsettling absence of critical historical moments, such as the horrific bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. Instead, we wade through a tiresome mire of legal drama, which, while probably accurate, lends little to the cinematic spectacle we seek.Furthermore, the depiction of Oppenheimer is contentious at best. Nolan seems to lionize a figure whose scientific breakthroughs ultimately led to devastating loss of life. This tension between Oppenheimer's humanity and the grim aftermath of his work is a complex issue that the film fails to convincingly navigate.The film left a void where I expected the brilliance of Nolan's past works like "The Dark Knight Trilogy" or "Inception". After "Tenet" and "Dunkirk," this film lands as another unexciting addition to Nolan's recent oeuvre.In conclusion, Nolan's "Oppenheimer" is a colossal yet uneven historical drama. It stumbles in its storytelling and character portrayal, failing to fully grasp the enormity and gravity of its subject. Though well-intentioned, it ultimately fails to captivate or provoke thought in the way a film of this caliber should.

A Truman biopic with Gary Oldman playing the lead is what this film really left me wanting to see. Sadly, the Truman scene was maybe 5 minutes long but it was clearly the most honest dialogue in the movie.This movie is not about the Manhattan project. This movie is liberal
hand-wringing over two things: (1) having used the bomb and (2) the hunt to get communists out of sensitive government positions. I get that immediately following the use of the bomb people thought we had opened Pandora's box. But here we are 78 years later and neither we nor anyone else has used one again. And we now know communists were in sensitive positions. Yet the tears continue to flow.Beautifully shot, well acted, but boring. I guarantee you will google "How long is Oppenheimer" during the movie. You will also say, "Hey, why is the music so loud all of the sudden? They are just walking down the street."This was a bail and switch.PS ... whatever reviewer says this is the greatest war movie ever is high on crack.

Oppenheimer could have been a great movie. The problem is the script is weak. It's hard to understand and the jumping around in time gets confusing.I kept wondering why the movie was so long and finally figured it out in the final minutes when the whole point of the movie is revealed. Unfortunately, the creators miss the mark in the interpretation of this rather complex man. They were blinded by the political points they wanted to make. Oppenheimer is just another example of Hollywood demagoguery.I would wait for streaming before investing time and money to see this one in the theater. On the other hand, the acting and cinematography are well done.

After watching Oppenheimer, my initial impression was that the movie felt excessively long and slow-paced. However, from a theatrical standpoint, it is undeniably beautiful. The story revolves around Dr. Oppenheimer being interrogated due to security clearance issues, with flashbacks depicting his journey and contribution to the creation of the atomic bomb, often switching between black and white visuals. The dialogue is intense and weighty, which may appeal to some while potentially dissuading others who prefer more action and a faster pace.One area where Oppenheimer shines is in building anticipation for the main attraction of the movie, the bomb. Regrettably, the bomb-related action amounts to merely about three minutes. There is also the added element of Florence Pugh's presence, providing some eye candy for the audience.Oppenheimer feels like a showcase of cinematic prowess, portraying how exceptionally impactful a film can be. To fully grasp its depth, it may require watching in increments, pausing, and analyzing the intricate details of the story and character actions.In conclusion, while Oppenheimer may not be everyone's cup of tea, I must acknowledge its visual brilliance and rate it a solid seven out of ten.

This film falls well short of a perfect 10. Undoubtedly, it boasts commendable acting, a decent soundtrack, and an intriguing subject. Yet, regrettably, it devolves into a borefest, burdened by an overtly complicated plot. The story's conclusion seems within reach, but it cunningly extends for another hour, prolonging the viewer's endurance. While the performances shine, the movie's charm wears thin amidst the convoluted narrative. Honest enjoyment gets clouded by an unnecessary length, leaving one longing for a more concise, satisfying experience. In essence, it has potential, but its shortcomings overshadow its strengths.

It's a good movie, some have called it a 'masterpiece' and 'an important movie in our history'. It's watchable, the filming is beautiful and filmed in the Nolan style that most people love, it's a good story and the amount of famous actors is insane, clearly they fall over themselves these days to be in a Nolan movie. The film is long and although we'll written with some great performances I felt it lacks any real entertainment and tension with the exception of the test scenes, it feels a very political story. For me Nolan has clearly peaked, Batman, inception and interstellar where up there in most peoples top 5 of all time, Dunkirk, Tenet and now this are nowhere near that standard, it's worth a watch but don't expect an IMBD top 25 movie.

Nolan has promoted the movie around the theme of atomic bomb stressing the significance of watching it only in imax theatres. But in reality besides a 10 minute scene of bomb detonation, there is nothing in the movie to hold your interest. Its literally the biggest scam of a movie. Oppenheimer is a well made film. The music is amazing. The acting is phenomenal. The story upon which it is based is really interesting as well. The adaptation for the screen, however is blatantly somniferous. Taken into account the upward trend of magnificence in each consecutive Nolan film, this is an absolue low point. It contains the usual tricks: black and white different time lines; flashbacks to a happening undisclosed until the end; ticking tacking music; silence before complete blasting of your eardrums. But now with an A24 vibe... I can't imagine this film has lived up to anybody's expectations.

The week before I watched a documentary on TV about Oppenheimer so I new about his turbulent and interesting life. Was curious to see how Nolan dramatized it.From the first second on you are met with an fast cut editing style that make you feel you are watching a trailer. There are lots of conversations, which I don't mind, but its cut like they do in Youtube videos. Non-stop, back-to-back. No room for a silent moment, a scenic establish shots or a touching moment.No time to get close to "Oppie".After an hour or so I noticed I have never been so aware of sitting in a cinema full of people. Watching the ceiling. Oh, look, someone is getting up to visit the toilet.. Realized this movie is boring me to bits. Gave it another half hour. Then left.

Watching the trailer and Nolan's previous movies you would believe Oppenheimer is again a great movie with lots of action sequences and tension. However about 80% of the time there is just talking, discussing and investigating. The story is more about Oppenheimer 's life and believes then about building a nuclear bomb.Cillian Murphy shows he can absolutely play a leading roll and is absolutely brilliant. So I would recommend this movie but it's not about action it's more about his life. You can watch it on IMAX but due to missing action sequences you can see it on any screen.Nolan again proves he can make convincing movies with a great story.

I can't believe these other positive reviews are they for real? I feel like I'm reading the onion. This movie should have been great but it is too long. For context, I'm a fan of history and WWII, but this was difficult to follow. The storyline is convoluted with too many plot lines. I felt like I was kidnapped in that theater.On the plus side, the visual effects were great as was the use of sound and music. Some of the flashbacks were nice as were the various images of neurons and atoms. The acting was okay, but certainly not good enough to relieve the tedium of this movie.I'm mostly disappointed because of all the hype surrounding this movie and that I bought into it. I guess people are supportive of Hollywood given all the strikes, but the product is just so poor. With all these great TV shows around, Hollywood is just irrelevant. I mean in an age of smartphones and swipes, who thinks a three hour movie is going to work? Then there is the gratuitous nudity (another Hollywood staple) that seemed unnecessary early on in the movie but two hours later when they threw it in again for no reason I understood why.I can believe this has an 8/10 of here. Either they bought bots to write these reviews or they rounded up the staff to write excellent reviews. This movie sucked. Best part was that I got $6 bucks off the ticket.

Good Film but I did find it slow in places, seems to build and build to a slight anticlimax.Yes it's very good but I still feel it was missing a couple of ingredients in my view.I did not find it as none stop thrilling film as it could have been but don't get me wrong it's an excellent film and loved the Albert Einstein story. This Movie is overrated. Yes, the Cast is Top notch. Yes, the Score and the visuals are good.But the rest? This is basically House of Cards, the Movie. And i mean the bad, boring aspects of it, the political intricacies. I went to see the Movie for the technical aspects, the making of the Bomb. The Morale implications, which has so many parallels to todays AI dilemma: If we don't develop it, potential Bad actors will, and they will use it against us. Instead of focussing on that, we get to see a political trial that obviously is rigged- We all know it, the chatacters know it, yet we spend 2/3 the time of the Moving on it. This is insanely boring, as we know the outcome early on.Imagine this movie made 2 Years in the Future: This could have been part Biopic, part Statement around the current AI dilemma: If we don't continue development, bad actors will. If the A Bomb was the defining development of last century, AI is the one of the current one. What a perfect metaphor this one could have been, had it been done a bit later. That's what bums me the most about it.Like it stands however: In the end, movies should Entertain. Ideally, while educating us a bit. This movie does educate- but it fails to Entertain.

The acting in this movie is insane. Absolutely incredible. Everyone. The plot and the dialogue is too much. It's all over the place. I frequently had to ask my friend what somebody said. I found myself zoning out when they would talk. I felt like I had 3 hours of elevated heart rate. It's a good movie with a lot of impact, but it felt a little lost to me. Huge Nolan fan but felt a bit letdown on this adaptation of storytelling. As expected the edit had you moving to different times frames of the story, but to a fault. Sometimes less is more. It felt too disjointed in the story telling for me. It wasn't taxing to follow along and know where you were at in the overall story arch for most of the movie but it was enough that it really distracted from the story itself. I'd be curious to see the post production edit process and understand the thought process that goes into Nolan's specific style of story telling. The score at times is distracting and takes away from the movie. Less is more. Let the weight of the acting and dialogue along with camera angles and edit push the tension needed. Pumping louder and louder violin and other music and sound does build tension but to me felt overdone and unnatural. It really distracted and took away from the acting which is a shame. The lensing of the film is pure magic and I soaked it all in at a showing in 70mm film. It felt the full 3 hours and had me checking my watch to see how much time was left. I've seen other 3 hour movies and felt disappointed in reaching the end to quickly. It will win awards and I give big kudos on the filming, tackling this story and the acting. I think the film could have used some lighter moments in both expressing joy and humor to balance and tug the audiences around. The nudity scenes didn't add to the story and the one was a bit uncomfortable which is what he was going for in the scene. I most likely won't be rewatching the film but am interested in leaning a bit more about the story.

Where do I even begin with ''Oppenheimer''? This film was an absolute disaster from start to finish. I can't believe I wasted precious hours of my life on such a pretentious and uninspiring piece of cinema.First and foremost, the pacing of the movie was horrendous. It felt like the director was trying to bore the audience to death with excruciatingly slow scenes that seemed to go on forever. I found myself checking my watch every few minutes, praying for this never-ending ordeal to be over.The characters in ''Oppenheimer'' were as lifeless as cardboard cutouts. Despite the incredible historical significance of J. Robert Oppenheimer's life and the Manhattan Project, the filmmakers managed to suck all the excitement and intrigue out of the story. The protagonist's emotions were about as captivating as watching paint dry, and the supporting characters were so one-dimensional that I couldn't muster any empathy for them.Let's not forget the cringe-worthy attempts at romance that seemed shoehorned into the story without any real purpose. The love interest was so poorly developed that it felt like the actors were reading lines from a cheesy romance novel. It was painful to witness such forced interactions that added nothing to the overall narrative.Furthermore, the soundtrack was utterly forgettable, failing to enhance the emotional impact of pivotal moments in the film. A compelling score could have salvaged some of the lifelessness in the story, but alas, ''Oppenheimer'' didn't deliver on that front either.In conclusion, ''Oppenheimer'' is a colossal disappointment that squandered a fascinating historical subject with its meandering plot, lifeless characters, and overall lack of direction. Save yourself the agony and skip this snoozefest; Watch Barbie instead.

An informative and dramatic biopic on the father of the atomic bomb, but it's not as stylish or atmospheric as Nolan's other films.- - - -- - - - - -It's an engaging and interesting story covering powerful topics with some tension in the first half as they race to create the bomb followed by a 'legal drama' aftermath in the second. Superb acting performances from the varied cast and the science was demonstrated and explained well, but the sex scenes felt out of place and the visuals, although impressive, were too few and far between.Overall, i would score Oppenheimer as a seven out of ten.

Awful. Nolan is LOST. 2 hours and 40 minutes of meaningless dialogue, abrupt cutaways, nameless, empty characters and 20 minutes of real movie making/story telling. Robert Oppenheimer is an interesting, impactful figure in history, but clearly not worthy of a movie about his life if this is what we get. Nolan needs to find himself ASAP.

"Oppenheimer," directed by Christopher Nolan, offers a visually stunning biopic of the renowned physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer. However, beneath the surface of this historical drama, it becomes evident that Nolan's true fascination lies in exploring his own psyche through the avatar of Oppenheimer. The film delves into the physicist's inner torments, mirroring Nolan's obsession with apocalyptic scenarios seen in his previous works like "Interstellar" and "Tenet."From the outset, Nolan appears to use Oppenheimer's story as a canvas upon which he projects his own obsessions and anxieties. The physicist's involvement in the creation of the atomic bomb, paralleled with Nolan's tendency to create cataclysmic, world-altering scenarios in his films, reinforces the notion that Oppenheimer serves as a vehicle for Nolan's introspection.Throughout "Oppenheimer," the last hour takes a peculiar turn as it goes to great lengths to depict the inner struggles of a narcissist. This portrayal can be attributed to the fact that both Nolan and Oppenheimer have narcissistic tendencies. This similarity may be the key to understanding Nolan's fixation on Oppenheimer's psyche and his ongoing trial. As described by a psychologist, 'the life of a narcissist becomes an everlasting trial, akin to a Kafkaesque "process" where the punishment is the constant judgment and scrutiny of the self'. This portrayal could be a manifestation of Nolan's own self-awareness and the introspective torment that he experiences as a filmmaker and artist.By positioning Oppenheimer as his avatar, Nolan seemingly subjects himself to the same judgment that the physicist faced from the community he helped furnish. This creative choice adds an intriguing meta-layer to the film, where the audience witnesses Nolan's exploration of his own artistic and personal consequences.However, this self-indulgence comes at a cost. Nolan's apparent obsession with self-introspection might alienate parts of the movie-going public. Just as Oppenheimer faced criticism and backlash from the very community he contributed to, Nolan may find himself under scrutiny for his tendency to prioritize his own emotional explorations over a more straightforward, historically accurate biopic.Despite the film's enthralling visual spectacle and the captivating performance by its cast, "Oppenheimer" ultimately reveals more about Nolan's psyche than about the historical figure it claims to depict. Nolan's fascination with apocalyptic themes and his narcissism seem to overshadow the physicist's story, turning the biopic into a vehicle for self-expression rather than a faithful representation of history.

I want to say I am a massive Nolan fan and there is still a seedling of hope within me that we will get the chance to watch another masterpiece before I pass off the earth, however, I think those days are sadly gone.Oppenheimer was amazingly shot, structured well with obviously amazing acting but there was just one thing lacking - entertainment. I'm really not sure you would find this movie interesting. Maybe Oppenheimer purists, maybe physicists, maybe people who like to watch legal proceeding and just hours of dialogue. I hate to say this but the movie was just so boring. I was falling sleep and just ready to go home by the first hour, definitely by the second hour and by the third hour, I was merely a shell of my former self.What happened to the days of Inception, The Dark Knight, Interstellar. A fictional world where characters were developed who we grow to love, even in the short span of a few hours. I know this movie is more to go over Oppenheimer's life but frankly, I didn't care. This movie did not have to be made.I still sit with hope that there will be a masterpiece somewhere into the future to save us from this growingly bleak world. And you, Nolan, have the power to do it.

Hold onto your seats, movie enthusiasts, because "Oppenheimer's Insensitive Portrayal" takes you on a bewildering journey through historical misrepresentation and sensationalism. This film attempts to merge the scientific legacy of J. Robert Oppenheimer with the timeless wisdom of the Bhagavad Gita, but ends up veering into tasteless territory.The premise seems intriguing: delving into Oppenheimer's struggles during the atomic bomb's development while drawing parallels with the Bhagavad Gita's teachings. However, the execution falls flat.From the start, it's clear that shock value overshadows genuine storytelling. The Bhagavad Gita, a revered philosophical text, is carelessly reduced to a plot device involving explicit content. Rather than honoring its depth, the film offensively equates its teachings with intimate scenes.Cultural sensitivity should have been vital. Yet, the film dismisses the Gita's sanctity for controversy's sake. It raises questions about the filmmakers' intent: genuine exploration or deliberate provocation?This movie sparks reflection, but not as intended. Instead of bridging science, spirituality, and ethics, it leaves us pondering media's state, prioritizing shock over respect."Oppenheimer's Insensitive Portrayal" is a cautionary tale on approaching these themes. Let's hope future filmmakers honor history, science, and spirituality with respect, rather than choosing tasteless offense.

1) Nolan's Oppenheimer (2023) is a historically accurate film.2) But sadly, the movie feels like Made-for-TV drama! Interesting but not engaging enough!3) The focus should have been on making of the bomb! But, what we see is Oppenheimer's communist past, his messy love life, his trial and his tussles with Lewis Strauss etc.4) There is almost no science in the movie, just politics! Names of scientists are thrown randomly: Einstein, Bohr, Feynman, Fermi, Heisenberg etc. - but with no real character development & arcs. So the film feels hollow and pretentious.5) This movie is crammed with too much story! Every scene feels rushed. Every scene is loaded with dialogues. You move on to the next scene and its even more dialogue. Nolan is guilty of not letting any scene breathe by itself, and he does not allow the audience to absorb and process the scenes! It feels like a marathon of scenes trying to reach the finish line! So in the end, even a 3-hour run time is simply not good enough!6) The entire IMAX thing was a gimmick. The cinematography was nothing special. That's completely fine given the kind of movie it is. You can't really have any breath-taking shots when shooting a realistic biopic set in small to medium sized rooms (classrooms, labs, living rooms, offices, senate...). The only scenes with potential were the shots in the desert. But the filmmakers made a conscious decision to opt for realism. It's just that they hyped-up the IMAX experience so much that it felt truly disappointing.7) Nolan's film is neither a feature film nor a documentary, and is abjectly floundering in-between! A feature film even when re-telling history, must evoke emotions - one reason why filmmakers like: Spielberg (Saving Private Ryan, Lincoln, Schindler's List, The Terminal, Catch me if You Can, Bridge of Spies, The Fabelmans); Ron Howard (A Beautiful Mind, Cinderella Man); Brian de Palma (Scarface); Asif Kapadia (Senna, Amy) are a class apart!(Anurag Kashyap's Black Friday (2007) is a brilliant docustyled feature and an unique anamololy.)

2.5 hours of torture. Enjoyed only 30 minutes of science discussion. Whole movie was based on countries ideological battle. US thinks communism is bad for everyone and it will destroy humanity. US centric approach is always right, that's what they think. Whole movie is based on useless group discussions multiple times. Very well promoted. Boring and pathetic dialogues. Good watch if you have patience, scientific temper and desire to see a dramatized version of Oppenheimer's personal story.This is not a background movie, you'll need to actually watch the movie.It is not for everyone, if you want quick-action-satisfaction, this is not for you. The a-bomb explosion is not the main part of the story.The main story is about how Oppenheimer was involved in the twisted world of politics for speaking his mind. It is HIS story, not of the war or the project.For what the story is trying to show, it's very well done.I have rated it seven stars because while it was good, I do not think it was thought inducing or a movie that'll end up to become a classic, at least not in my books.

The movie was three hours long...and it seemed longer. I was looking forward to seeing an adult movie, but spend three hours watching a grey movie with ugly cinematography and didn't even notice the much talked about black and white photography, because it didn't contrast with the bland grey of the rest of the film. There was a big deal about it being filmed in IMAX, but it remind3d me of watching 8mm home movies, of a family you don't know, or really care to get to know.The lead actor was the old man from Poltergeist, and he even wore the same hat! Most of the cast was non-descript and interchangeable,, which only made the show harder to follow because they all looked alike and the bland photography and lack of color and similar outfits didn't help. The actors didn't really seem to help, as Robert Downey Jr. And Casey Affleck (whose only connection to acting is being Ben's brother) served mostly as wallpaper... there presence wasn't really needed as the movie was intensively dialogue driven ( as in, they could have just done an audiobook and I probably wouldn't have noticed).The movie was not as long as it was LOUD. Lots of booming noises, and yet, some of the dialogue was muffled and hard to understand. And there was a LOT of dialogue. It seemed as though this was intentional as the movie was more like a documentary than a drama where you are engaged by the actors and become involved in the story. It seemed as though the dialogue could have been more engrossing if they had just read a Statistics textbook out loud. It was very clinical, after three hours, you were told a lot about the characters, but as there was no chemistry or emotional involvement between them, you never feel it. In fact, they portrayed Oppenheimer as cold, and then tried to tell you he was a womanizer. It just didn't work...he did not come off as charismatic, yet he had numerous love interests. Physically, he looked like he hadn't quite survived a hunger strike and had the body of a 10 year old...not something anybody would be attracted to or want to look at, way too much for a whole documentary. Not that I cared to be subjected to his female love interests, as they were filmed in a way to delete any possibility of physical attraction. Christopher Nolan has received a lot of criticism for purposely not having sex scenes in his movies. It turns out he knows his weaknesses and set out to prove it with these unattractive scenes.As far as documentaries go, I'll wait for Ken Burns to make one that is involving and interesting.

Positives:
Cillian Murphy is amazing, Robert Downey Jr really shows up, The B&W photography is beautifulWeaknesses:
The analog Nolanisms are a distraction (Fincher contended with period-isms better in Manhunter using digital processes and CGI), Audio mix is muddled and hard on the dialogue, 70MM film stock is over-sold for a movie that largely takes plan indoors, the non-linear timeline gets a bit confusingBiggest problem:
Nolan's work in this film is extremely derivative, 1st 1/3rd directly quotes T Malick and A Beautiful Mind, Last 1/3rd (the interrogations) is very Lumet, The internal conflict noisey white-out bits is very Villeneuve (but, done badly), The first kissing scene in the desert is poorly and distractingly blockedGreat story, amazing performances, but a strike against Nolan as an auteur. All the previously referenced directors, even the ones working recently, developed a coherently new thing for audiences. Nolan really fails that attempt in this movie. While sitting in the movie theater, I pretty quickly wished someone else had made this movieWorth seeing for the acting and the story, not as an accomplishment in film-making or directing.

The movie is boring, too long, pompous... There were some monets where I was genuinely interested. However the overall imoression is a big dissapointment. If you know Chris Nolan movies, you will know the usual tropes
Non- linear story tellingGreat background score but loud at times making dialogue non-comprehensible-Studded star castSo what else is there to write a review about? Two words- Cillian Murphy. Murphy was so convincing I forgot he was an actor playing Oppenheimer. If this movie does not land an Oscar for Murphy, it will surely be a lost opportunity. Also notable are the supporting performances by Robert Downey Jr., Matt Damon and Emily Blunt.The biggest criticism I have on this movie, is that Nolan goes overboard with the non-linear story telling with too many time jumps making a relatively simple timeline too complex for an average audience to follow.Furthermore, it is important for anyone keen to watch this movie to know what the movie is about- it is a movie about the life of Oppenheimer, not about the bomb..Infact, Nolan shows very little of the Trinity bomb and the dropping the bomb on Hiroshima and Nagasaki...using a rather muted way to show the latter.. perhaps to respect the sensitivities of the incident. The story follows the tribulations and trials of Oppenheimer before and after the bomb so there are many panel discussion and committee hearing scenes that may bore some who are not interested in history. All in all it's an important story to be told and Nolan manages to tell it in the way only Nolan can.

A self-important movie, you'd be a social outcast if you diss it. But it deserves dissing. What is with filmmakers these days that they forget we need people to root for in a movie, even one based on the winners' version of history. Technical filmmaking is okay but people need people to connect to a piece of film.Cillian Murphy is an excellent actor but is wasted in this dreary, droning 3-hour indulgence. Save for maybe the fat Jewish friend who's always feeding Oppie, the rest of the cast may look like historical folks but there's ZERO character development here. Emily Blunt has one note - a scowl on her face for most parts. RDJ was probably roped in to lend his name in return for a sure Oscar nomination.This is not Nolan territory.I'd like to think he had his arm-twisted by the Jewish lobby to make this...have to bag the generational director for the cause. Good for him coz the same lobby will do everything to declare this movie a success and an important film in his canon.It isn't.When Titanic was released, it was accompanied by documentaries of the sunken ship as well. Docus for pondering, the movie for pleasure.Oppenheimer docus would probably serve us well. The movie not so much. So choose to spend your 3 hours wisely.

First, you don't have to watch it in imax. So, you can save lots of money. About the movie...Actors are good. Cinematography is good. However, the story is very hard to follow. You need prior knowledge about the politics of post second world war. Otherwise, you'll find yourself asking other who is this, why is he doing this, what does he refer to, etc. I enjoyed watching scientists struggling to make the right decision and materializing the consequences of their actions, but that is it. To summarize, a very overhyped movie. I believe someone will make a movie about oppenheimer in the future because this couldn't deliver.

"Tell don't show" boring . Required better writing, removing the entire story-line of security clearance.It watched as a pastiche montage of different timelines and some interesting visualisations of quantum physics.White male focused is an understatement. Male secondary characters had more nuance and depth than leading female characters. Does Chris just miss the days of male-dominant days when he was young?I walked out halfway through the film. Couldn't bear the fast choppy, no breathing space dialogue chain of characters just spelling everything out. Thanks goodness I did not commit to IMAX ticket, would not watch it again even on a small screen.

Superb acting by an incredible cast and great cinematography!BUT.I liked Oppenheimer less than all of Nolan's other movies (maybe more than Tenet, although the latter had some amazing action sequences).It requires a lot of attention for the whole movie (which 3 hours personally is a bit tedious). The movie is all dialogue with at least 3 timelines concurrently being depicted, quickly switching between them.Not sure what the hype for watching it in IMAX was for, (which is what I watched it in) as there are barely any scenes that take advantage of the immersive format.The soundtrack is great but not memorable. I guess there's a limit to how much you can do when directing a biopic.Fine for a one-time watch, I don't think I would ever dedicate 3 hours to Oppenheimer again.

Firstly, fantastic acting by Cillian and Downey. Amazing cameo by Gary Oldman. Rest of the cast were good nothing extraordinary. But my personal problem was the story makes a lot of jump cuts which is fine, but before going in the movie audience is expected to do a little bit of homework. Two hearings were going on in the beginning and only much later we are explained what's going on, but by that time I got exhausted just keeping up. Also once the explanation is given I didn't care enough. I usually don't check time or speak with anyone during the movie but it was very hard not to. I liked Downey's acting better than Cillian btw.

I went to see this movie because I'm Irish and think Cillian Murphy is amazing. I had no idea what the movie was about but wanted to support an Irish actor. I was really impressed by his unfailing acting ability (which has been flawless since the beginning of his public Career), Emily blunt also was brilliant and the other actors - but the writing and script structure was woeful.The whole movie was written from the pov of audience preknowledge bias, so for someone like me who has never heard of Oppenihemer or have any idea about physics or atomic energy, it felt like I entered into a story half way through. In media, you always start with the 'reset button' and make the assumption that the audience knows nothing and you bring them on a journey. A majority of people will not know about these things and so get lost trying to figure it out. There were actually people in the cinema googling things because it wasn't clear and we had no idea what they were talking about.Also, the length of the movie was madness... The story wasn't gripping enough to keep your focus for three hours. By 2hrs in people were checking their watches/phones to see what time it was. I think the sub plots and courtroom scenes with Robert Downey Jr (fab acting), could have been totally removed and if the focus had have been on one character and the story of creating the bomb and the moral dilemma he had, it would have been so much more engaging. The side story could have been explained in a few paragraphs at the end and saved us an hour of what felt like pointless b roll and a distraction from the real story which shaped humanity, not some petty narcissistic vengeance plot....Long movies such as Lord of the Rings keep you gripped the entire time because the storyline and plot is clear And engaging - this was so boring and disappointing script writing.The acting was fantastic, genuinely brilliant, but if they cut an hour out and stuck to Oppenihemer genius and the dilemma of living with what his intellect produced, it would have been Oscar worthy.

I enjoyed Oppenheimer, it's a very well made and well acted movie. I though Cillian Murphy and Emily Blunt were fantastic, Robert Downey Jr was good support.Not gonna lie though, the film suffered from the same thing all biographies do - they only ever shine a light on a small portion of the subjects life, I came out knowing only slightly more about Oppenheimer than when I went in.Also the film is 20 minutes too long, the sex scenes were unnecessary, some of the communist stuff became a slog and the bomb moment was kinda underwhelming.But I've recommended it to my friends and that's all a filmmaker can ask for I guess.

I just saw this late this afternoon in Astoria Queens, NY. Here are some observations:1) It goes into incredible detail about Oppenheimer's leadership and engagement with the group creating the atomic bomb, his troubled relationship with a woman named Jackie, and then after it was discovered that a Russian spy had infiltrated the project, the subsequent way in which he was mistreated as a communist sympathizer, which he wasn't.2) The acting by both Celian Murphy and Emily Blunt (not to mention others) was top notch.3) The film had way too much dialogue, especially of cerebral and technical natures, for the average moviegoer to follow. This slowed the pace down quite a bit, making the first hour, in particular, interminable! There could have been much less of it and put across in layman's terms.4) The soundtrack seemed to overpower what was going on on the screen at times.5) I believe the entire story could have been paired down and told in two hours, making it a more enjoyable experience for the audience.6) And the whole film seemed overly slick, almost as if the way it was made was meant to overshadow the story.
