Well made film. In all manners just fantastic. Nolan is exceptional. When Hollywood is taking itself out with politics instead of entertainment, Nolan saved the day and brought us a spectacle. As good as I hoped it would be. Fairly accurate story telling but very much biased. Here's how.Oppenheimer was a nationalist and a warpig. Making the bomb was completely unnecessary after Nazi Germany surrendered. " We made a destructive gadget to counter evil nahtzees " pretext doesn't apply anymore, nevertheless he still kept on working on the project. US's nuclear attack didn't make Japan surrender but Soviet's marching to Manchuria and then some gave the vapors to Japan's emperor. Whether he regrets his work or not, it doesn't matter. Oppenheimer is responsible for handing a genocidal weapon to the psychopathic US politicians all in hopes of either attaining fame or satiating his country's jingoist cravings. Oppenheimer through " international control" wanted the Soviets to not develop their own bomb and the Imperialist US to retain it's monopoly. Would've liked him more if he was an agent to the Soviet union. Rip Klaus Fuchs, the man who worked to ensure atomic weapons would not be the sole possession of one country. They should make a movie on such a brave and rational man. He sure was more logical than sorry a*$ Oppenheimer.I still don't get how Oppenheimer getting his security clearance revoked is more important than his work which wiped off 150,000 lives ,and got more coverage in the movie.Great flick when it comes to it's technical and performance aspects. Contrariwise, it's story could have done some tweaks here and there.

I really wanted to love this movie because I am a history buff and I wanted to see the story behind the bomb, and in a way I did get the story behind the bomb, but in a very confusing and boring way. The movie kept jumping around between time periods before the war and after the war, showing all kinds of scenes out of sequence, which if done right can be very effective, but in this movie it was done wrong, very wrong. A simple "1939" on the screen would've made things clear, but I guess we're just supposed to know. Even at the end of this three hour long marathon I was still confused about many of the scenes, and it wasn't just about the time periods, but the dialogue itself was confusing. Half the time I didn't know what or who they were talking about, and the last hour, after the bomb exploded, was not only boring and confusing, but also entirely pointless and the movie would've been better without it. In addition, they added in these scenes, presumably for dramatic effect, that were intended to show the character's emotions or thought process at the time, showing us what he was feeling but was not actually happening, and that too missed the mark for me. Much of it was just awkward and annoying. It wasn't all bad. The acting was very good, and some of the scenes were very powerful, but overall I'm still very disappointed in this movie. It could've been so much more entertaining.

I don't dislike many films but this one was awful. The score was completely overwhelming and constant, to the point where you couldn't hear most of the dialogue. Overall, a very good watch. Sadly, I was unable to see this one in cinemas, because I didn't realise I would need ID. Apparantly I don't look a day over 15, thanks I guess?? Oppenheimer felt like a VERY long trailer because of very short scenes and a constant blaring soundtrack. This movie is not all boring, it has some amazing moments. But it does not feel like a movie rather than a over explanatory trailer about a great movie. It constantly feels like it's moving either to fast or to slow. Sometimes you feel like you are just being force feed information at a rate that no human ever would find pleasing. Other times you almost fall asleep beacuse of the low tempo. The movie also focuses more on the political side of the manhattan project rather than oppenheimer himself. Therefore when any emotional scenes with oppenheimer and his close ones would appear you would just feel like the third wheel of a relationship that you barely knew existed. I personally feel this is the problem with alot Cristhofer Nolan's movies. I do love some of his work, but constantly i feel like i never really knew the characters that well. With Memento as a exception. Cillian Murphy as Oppenheimer did well enough. In the start of the movie he was very interesting and displayed alot of emotions through his acting. By the half and the end it more felt like i was watching some sigma male tiktok compilation. This really made the movie alot harder to watch than it should have been. The only emotions displayed by Cillian at the end was intensly staring in to the distance, so the marketing team was perhaps not lying. This was made even more clear when seeing Gary Oldman as Truman. In my opinion he outpreformed every single one with his scene. His face shifted so slightly with each new emotion and really had you at the edge of your seat. Cillian's intensive stare quickly became exposed of its shortcomings by this preformance. I could go into the visual side of this movie but we all know they are the best as always with Cristhofer Nolan so im not gonna waste your time with that. I am going to say that Ludwig Göransson made an absolute banger with the score to this movie and it truly made the whole experience alot better.

Oppenheimer" stays true to the life of the renowned physicist, but unfortunately, it falls short in delivering an engaging cinematic experience. The movie is incredibly fast paced in terms of the information it throws at you, and it never slows down. If you tune out for more than a minute, you'll be lost for the rest of the movie.The music and lighting, though dramatic, overshadows the scenes themselves, at times taking away from the movie's intended impact. Even more disappointing is the anticlimactic portrayal of the atomic bomb explosion, considering the two-hour build-up leading to it. I couldn't help but expect a more gripping and realistic portrayal of such a momentous event.Ultimately, "Oppenheimer" ended up being more of a political drama than a compelling exploration of the life and scientific contributions of J. Robert Oppenheimer. While it accurately depicts his journey, it left me longing for a more captivating movie experience.

I found the movie so boring, with a ton of exposition, unending dialog and undue screen time dedicated to the most boring issue which is his security clearance. How could a genius like Nolan not find a more cinematic way to reveal the the characters or consequences of strong opinions by scientific community, than a hearing, not just 1 but 2. . Also how can a movie about a scientist not have any meaningful or educative explanation of nuclear physics or anatomy of the bomb? Even the fictional setup in Inception was explained in a more detailed fashion.Some highlights that I wish they spent more time on:
1) Silence during explosion. Loved that it was an Easter egg for people who love science. It was a choice made not necessarily for an artistic reason but a scientific one, as light travels faster than sound. Wish there were more such.2) When one character tells Strauss that Einstein and Oppen were probably not talking about him, but something important instead. I wish Nolan applied that to his film and realized that spending majority of the movie on Strauss' trial is not as important when the world the movie is set in involves Oppenheimer, Einstein, Atom bomb, WW2, a world after the first nuclear attack, nuclear arms race, the dynamic of great scientific minds from the world coming together to build the bomb/advance science.3) Psychological complexity and catharsis: there were hints at what caused the eventual change of mind within Oppen towards the bomb, but it didn't seem organic to me. Was it triggered by Matt Damon's character ending communication with Oppen, or because of the way the test bombing looked, or hearing Truman announce the attack on Hiroshima on radio? Or meeting Truman?4) Terrific acting all the way.I am huge Nolan fan and my favs are Prestige, Interstellar, Dark Knight Rises.

I got hit by the hype train.It couldn't be different, though: a movie directed by Nolan (who made the all time greatest Interstellar) about the frontman of the project that conceived the doomsday weapon couldn't help but raise high expectations.Well, I fell off the horse.It seemed to be that the script was a little to hurried, specially in the early part, with many abrupt cuts; scenes that seemed interrupted. With all due respect, an horrorshow.The plot is good, after all it is based on one of the most fascinating stories of humanity.The use (I mean abuse) of the greatest scientific discoveries of the time to build a weapon with the potential to destroy the world is something that, I believe, will take centuries of meditation to be properly understood.But I don't know, something seems to be missing... I didn't feel that touch of wonder Nolan usually puts in his films, that we know so well from Interestelar, Inception or even Tenet.PS: For those who haven't read "un Verdor Terrible", by Benjamin Labatut, it's really worth it, as the book explores the boundaries between reason and madness of these characters involved with quantum physics (and with weapons of mass destruction, consequently).The movie is good, but the book is much better.

Worse than Tenet, feels like Nolan lost his capacity to direct, this time he definitely used stock imagery for the special effects in this film. Sound is even worse, you will leave the theatre with a constant high pitch in your ear. And let's not mention the dialogue wich is boring and repetitive. It cuts from one character to another and is more political than impressive. One more thing ...there are cheaper youtube documentaries on this subject that do a better job than this film. Hollywood's last breath and it smells like onions. I want my money back, don't be mislead by the "masterpiece" reviews, this belongs in the bin.

Oppenheimer portrais a very interesting time in history that you can't help but find intriguing, exciting and scary.But I left the cinema thinking this movie could have been made in a hundred different ways, the way this movie was made isn't in the top 20 of best ways.You are thrown into a story without an introduction to who and where, characters are not introduced properly, the movie jumps between 3 time periods without explaining that it does and when is what. Only half way through the movie I understand when the different time periods are.The movie is extremely rushed, as a suspenseful scene thretched over the entire movie, without you being able to catch a breath. Scenes are rushed where dialogue seem fake, rushed and forced.Unfortunately this movie is very poorly written. But because of the interesting topic it touches and good acting I give it a 7, as in it's intertaining. But wouldn't recommend people waste money on it in cinema.

I try to be honest and consistent with my opinions. I believe in critical thinking and I hope it is not a dying skill.This film is a grandiose homage to some of the greatest minds our civilization ever produced. Nolan's effort here is sincere but quite lacking in real drama. There is little to separate this from a docu-drama that felt a trifle exasperating.I have an engineering background and was familiar with the basic history of the Manhattan project and the prominent characters. I left the theater slightly disoriented with all of the names and actions of the subsequent political players who dominate over half of the film. That's over 90 minutes.I know this is a story about profound philosophical concepts, but I don't feel they were addressed adequately. The opportunity was missed. Instead we are shown a slightly confusing story of jealousy and persecution. The dawn of the Nuclear age is ultimately something we will always have to deal with. I don't feel this film emphasized that enough.Overall I was disappointed, slightly confused, and fatigued.

Not a big fan of this movie. Nolan has never been about emotional character exploration and a biopic without that feels off. It's not that it's a documentary style, factual biopic which has NPCs for characters that we're not supposed to know about like Dunkirk. That could have worked. But here it's actually about the characters and yet it's missing exploration of any interesting themes in the characters' lives.There are a few great scenes. Nolan is a master of those. But it doesn't take us deep into the mind of Oppenheimer, his guilt, his ptsd in a way that great biopics can do.There's a problem in the style of storytelling in general I think. The first half of the movie is a lot of rushed moments. Dialogues after dialogues like a highlight reel with no real theme that's allowed time to breathe and come out as a narrative anchor of the overall story.The trinity test is where the master truly arrives. It's where Nolan is in his comfort zone, immersing us in a high intensity scene. This is where the movie peaks in every aspect. This is really where it's a spectacular experience on the large imax screen.But otherwise than that, even visually this movie felt mediocre. The colour contrast felt weird in many of the scenes, either being too bright or too dark. It's a weird mix of some moments looking spectacular like you expect from Nolan in imax but others looking off like I've downloaded a torrent.Personally I really dislike Nolan's dialogue. I don't know if my taste has changed or it sticks out more here in a factual biopic but it's just not how people talk. It's smartass Hollywood line after Hollywood line as if the character knows there's an audience and he's trying to look cool in front of them.I'll revise my review after a second viewing if I ever get to that. But for now it's pretty mediocre.

The first 30 seconds was cinematic genius to introduce this movie, the other 25 minutes I sat through was insanely boring. The dialog was ok, the acting fine, but it felt serious, cold, and emotionless. Nothing exciting was happening, and I wasn't enthralled enough with what was going on to care whatsoever. This is a subject I know a fair bit about, and something I am interested in, and yet recognizing references and historical tie ins could not save this movie for me. No way I was going to waste another 2hours+ on this insanely long and insanely boring movie. Sure I didn't see the whole thing, but it did a terrible job engaging me, and burned 15 dollars from my pocket.

Oppenheimer is without a doubt a unique cinematic experience and I would encourage everyone to watch it on the big screen. However this movie is not made for everybody.Typically for Nolan, this movie expects a lot from its audience and if you have little to no historic knowledge you will have problems following the story. For me personally this historic accuracy was one of the best parts of the movie as I am highly interested in history.My biggest problem with Oppenheimer was definitely its storytelling. The pacing in Oppenheimer is incredibly high and its story is told in 6 different time periods. As the different time periods are not shown in cronological order, this can be confusing/hard to follow at times. There is also never a silent/slow moment in this movie where we can deeply delve into the mind of the tragic protagonist.Some of these slow moments would have improved the movie a lot imo as it would have helped to get a deeper character study of Oppenheimer, whose troubles and pangs of conscience are sadly mostly covered on a surface level.I would have prefered a complex character study but I dont think Nolan is the ideal director for this.All in all this movie is highly entertaining and definitely leaves an impact but I must say that I think the story of Oppenheimer could have been told in a better way.

Along with Barbie, this was one of the most hyped-up movies of the year, both films were released the same day, they are complete polar opposites, and the phenomenon spawned a social media trend called "Barbenheimer", to see both films as a double feature. I did not personally do this craze, I booked both films on the same day but saw them separately, I looked forward to this film with its darker subject matter, written and directed by Christopher Nolan (Inception, The Dark Knight, Dunkirk, Tenet). Basically (in linear order), in 1926, twenty-two-year-old (Julius) J. Robert Oppenheimer (Cillian Murphy) is studying at the Cavendish Laboratory in Cambridge, under Patrick Blackett (James D'Arcy), but he suffers from homesickness and anxiety. After Blackett forces him to miss part of a lecture, Oppenheimer injects an apple left for him with cyanide. The next day, he has a change of heart and narrowly prevents visiting scientist Niels Bohr (Kenneth Branagh) from eating it. Oppenheimer completes his PhD in physics at the University of Göttingen in Germany, where he meets Werner Heisenberg (Matthias Schweighöfer). Returning to the United States, Oppenheimer hopes to expand quantum physics research, and begins teaching at the University of California, Berkeley and the California Institute of Technology. He meets and is infatuated with biologist and ex-communist Katherine "Kitty" Puening (Emily Blunt), his future wife. He also has a sporadic affair with Communist Party USA member Jean Tatlock (Florence Pugh), but she had severe clinical depression and committed suicide, submerging her head in a partly filled bathtub. In 1942, during World War II, U. S. Army General Leslie Groves (Matt Damon) recruits Oppenheimer to lead the Manhattan Project to develop an atomic bomb after he assures the general that he has no sympathy with the communists. Oppenheimer, who is Jewish, is particularly driven by the Nazis, under Heisenberg's supervision, possibly trying to complete their nuclear weapons program. Oppenheimer assembles a scientific team including Edward Teller (Benny Safdie) and Isidor Isaac Rabi (David Krumholtz) in Los Alamos, New Mexico. There, a town is built in the middle of the desert, and the workers are encouraged to bring their wives who will work on site while the bomb is secretly created. He coordinates with other sites, including the Met Lab in Chicago, where he meets with nuclear physicists Enrico Fermi (Danny Deferrari) and David L. Hill (Rami Malek). He also visits Albert Einstein (Tom Conti) to discuss how an atomic bomb could trigger an unstoppable chain reaction that could destroy the world. When Germany surrenders and the war is approaching its end, there is doubt from some of the scientists of the project's importance, but Oppenheimer assures them that the bomb could be used to end the war with Japan. The atomic bomb is completed, and the countdown begins as the Trinity test, which takes place just before the Potsdam Conference on 16 July 1945. The detonation of the prototype device in the desert is a complete success. President Harry S. Truman (Gary Oldman) orders atomic bombs to be dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, forcing Japan to surrender. Oppenheimer is thrust into the public eye, including on the cover of Time magazine, as the "father of the atomic bomb." But Oppenheimer feels personal responsible and is haunted by the destruction and suffering. Oppenheimer meets Truman and urges him to close Los Alamos and not develop even more powerful weapons. Truman perceives Oppenheimer's distress as weakness and insists that, as President, he is responsible for the use of the bomb. Oppenheimer advocates against further nuclear development, especially the hydrogen bomb proposed by Teller. His stance creates disagreements in the middle of the tension building in Soviet Union that is leading up to the Cold War. Lewis Strauss (Robert Downey Jr.), chairman of the U. S. Atomic Energy Commission, resents Oppenheimer for publicly dismissing his concerns regarding the export of radioisotopes and for recommending arms talks after the Soviets detonate their first atomic bomb. He also believes Oppenheimer, when meeting Einstein, criticised him. Oppenheimer is called to a hearing where he is betrayed by Teller and other associates intending to remove him from political influence. Strauss exploits Oppenheimer associating with current and former communists such as Tatlock and his own brother, Frank (Dylan Arnold). Despite Rabi and several other allies defending Oppenheimer in their testimonies, Oppenheimer's security clearance is prematurely revoked. Oppenheimer's public image is damaged, and his policy influence is neutralised. Five years later, at Strauss's Senate confirmation hearing to become Secretary of Commerce, Hill testifies that Strauss has personal motives when engineering Oppenheimer's downfall. The Senate votes against Strauss's nomination. An enraged Strauss meets Oppenheimer in private, ranting against him being a hypocrite, saying if had the chance he would do it again because it made him important. In 1963, President Lyndon B. Johnson (Hap Lawrence) presents Oppenheimer the Enrico Fermi Award as a gesture of political rehabilitation. Oppenheimer and Einstein's conversation is revealed to have not been about Strauss, but the far-reaching implications of nuclear weapons. Oppenheimer ominously states that he believes his actions have indeed started a chain reaction that will destroy the world. Also starring Casey Affleck as Boris Pash, A Cure for Wellness's Dane DeHaan as Major General Kenneth Nichols, Jason Clarke as Roger Robb, Alden Ehrenreich as Senate Aide, Gustaf Skarsgård (Stellan's son) as Hans Bethe, Michael Angarano as Robert Serber, Jack Quaid as Richard Feynman, Josh Peck as Kenneth Bainbridge, Olivia Thirlby as Lilli Hornig, Matthew Modine as Vannevar Bush, Tony Goldwyn as Gordon Gray, Alex Wolff as Luis Walter Alvarez, Emma Dumont as Jackie Oppenheimer, Scott Grimes as Counsel, and James Remar as Secretary of War Henry Stimson. Murphy is perfectly cast as the title character, and he is supported by a terrific all-star cast, including Blunt as his supportive wife, Damon as the general, Downey Jr. As the businessman, Pugh as the sultry mistress, Branagh as a teacher, and Oldman as the President of the United States. Nolan is no stranger to big scale blockbusters and does a fine job telling the true story of the scientist who developed the atom bomb. The non-linear storytelling, scientific jargon and political stuff, and the three-hour running time test your patience, and I'm not sure what the point of the bits in black-and-white were, but for the tense first bomb test scene, its fantastic editing, visuals, and sound design (the delayed explosion genuinely startled me) is the highlight. It is very long and very chatty, but Murphy and the ensemble cast are all great, it is ambitious, dramatic, stylish, and historically interesting, a worthwhile biographical thriller. Very good!

I have to give Nolan a lot of credit: he is one of the few directors that always manage to fill the theater. The film is beautifully shot and highlights a lot of issues from American politics during the war time, together with some questionable choices that were made, in the name of putting an end to World War II. The director managed to portray really well the moral dilemma that a lot of scientists that worked on the H Bomb felt, realizing that they basically created a mass destruction weapon. There are never particularly gruesome images, but the editing together with the soundtrack, really highlights the terrible consequences that this invention caused. This movie has an incredible sound design, and there are some sequences that are just breathtaking. Nolan always delivered technically competent movies and he is unique in his genre: the practical effects on this one are absolutely jaw dropping."Oppenheimer" is three hours long and it has a pretty intense and interesting story. Unfortunately at times it focuses too much on irrelevant matters, such as the incredibly intense romantic life of the physicist, or the whole communist witch hunt made by a special commission towards the scientist, in order to discredit him. There are tons of scenes that are very repetitive and that they could have just been trimmed from the final cut. I have to be honest: towards the end I was really wondering when the flick was going to finish. Even though I enjoy longer movies that take their time to develop a deeper plot, this one was a bit too much even for a cinema lover like me. It is a solid 7.5 stars out of 10 and I definitely recommend it, as I think that after the disastrous "Tenet", here Nolan did overall a good job.

The token time twist Nolan uses was nothing more than a flashback which really didn't do much other than let us watch two movies simultaneously.The soundtrack was eh. There was only one stunning visuals scene, so IMAX is wasted. The story/characters didn't really have any emotional pull for me. Not like Interstellar, Inception, Prestige, Dark Knight. No real twist at the end that makes you think. Whoa!RDJ did great and was thr standout for me. Especially seeing him get away from being Tony Stark.Emily Blunt also had an amazing scene near the end but unfortunately her role was minimal in the story.The trailers made this out to be more of a thriller espionage style film, instead we get a lot of science talk no where near as cool as Interstellar and a lawyer hearing interrogation that isn't a trial with no tension.Bummer since I was really looking forward to this one. Just wait and rent it.

Oppenheimer is less of a movie and more of an experience. It tells the story of the man who was the head of the Manhattan project, and what his life was life before, during and after the creation of the atomic bomb.Much like the biopic of Elvis that acme out last year, this movie goes fast and throws a lot of stuff at the audience at breakneck speed- but when all is said and done you understand the story of Oppenheimer.The films strengths are the sequence that delve into the destructive nature of the weapons he built, and how that impacted the world and why he first championed them and later spoke against them and became an advocate for disarmament.The weakness of the movie is that the lead isn't that strong to hold the film together (although he looks like Oppenheimer) and it's not knock on the actor but he isn't really leading movie material for a major motion picture of this nature. You never really know or care much about Oppenheimer, more than you observe him and while that may have been the point it was hard to watch a three hour film about someone you can't really identify with.Some of Nolan's script choices in this film are kind of poor - such as he never lets us see Oppenheimer do much that makes us bond with him - and he never really establishes the relationship between Oppenheimer and his nemesis who puts the federal government against him.The great moments in the film is when Oppenheimer goes to talk to Truman - and Gary Oldman delivers big time in that scene and you really get a sense of how history transpired.Overal, Oppenheimer is a good Christopher Nolan movie and a thought provoking Biopic of an important historical character, but also a sort of spy thriller and a mystery wrapped into one. A few too many elements possibly - but it's never boring.Recommended if you like Christopher Nolan movies.

"Oppenheimer" is a captivating character study that sheds light on the life of the esteemed physicist, J. Robert Oppenheimer, while exploring the historical backdrop of the atomic bomb. The film's unique perspective focuses on the man himself, rather than solely on the bomb's development, cleverly reflecting its title's significance.Throughout the movie, Oppenheimer's intriguing journey takes center stage, drawing viewers into the complexities of his personality and the pivotal role he played in shaping history. The story gracefully weaves together his struggles, motivations, and ethical dilemmas, making for a compelling narrative that keeps audiences engaged.While the film's emphasis on the man behind the bomb is a refreshing approach, some viewers might find it slightly underwhelming due to its occasionally bloated run time. Certain scenes could have been tightened to maintain a more consistent pace, allowing for a more impactful viewing experience.The film is filled head to toe with a talented cast that
bring depth and authenticity to the characters, keeping the audience invested in Oppenheimer's personal journey. The cast, delivered compelling portrayals that truly breathed life into their characters. It's unfortunate, though, that some of the major actors seemed underutilized, leaving me yearning for more depth in their roles.In conclusion, "Oppenheimer" is a movie that offers a fresh perspective on history by shining a spotlight on the enigmatic scientist. Despite its occasional pacing issues, the film's unique focus on the man himself adds depth and intrigue to an already fascinating historical period. For those interested in character-driven narratives with a touch of historical context, "Oppenheimer" is a worthwhile and thought-provoking watch.

There's much that's praiseworthy of this movie. Illuminating a key, forgotten figure whose brilliance helped end WWII, exploring his very human side, and reminding us of the damage wrought by the McCarthy hearings, all good. The fears the physicists had, that the atom bomb would ignite the atmosphere and burn the world, and then their very real horror of what they'd wrought, also good. The context, established so well in Matt Damon's general, that the American people (as well as the other allies) were desperate to end the war, is made clear. The effects are all that you expect from modern moviemaking.So, the downside. The storyline is the investigation over whether or not to renew Oppenheimer's security clearance in the fifties, which is biased by competing scientists egos, by Oppenheimer's interest in Communism, in the Spanish Civil War, begets repetition. The last twenty or so minutes could be edited to five. So many well known actors pop up in bit parts it's hard to know who to keep track of. Cillian Murphy well portrays Oppenheimer, a deeply conflicted man who built the bomb, and actively planned where best to drop it, then was tortured by his choices until he was stripped of his clearance, effectively retiring him. Robert Downey Jr might have a best support nom, if the tedious hearing scenes don't under cut him.The soundtrack is godawful loud and sometimes obliterates the dialogue. There are clever art house bits here and there, and they detonate the test well, but avoid the bombing of Japan. Interesting choices. If this movie were cut down by thirty minutes, it might be great.

For most part, the rendition of dialogue is finally improved in this film compared to the last few Nolan outings. We're not yet back at Memento or Prestige fidelity, though, in dialog or the rest of the film generally. Those were his seminal greats, in my opinion. Sorry, but even The Dark Knight was not a truly great film overall if you deleted Heath Ledger from it.Back to the rendition of voices, though, while most of Oppenheimer is fine, there are still a few too many scenes that are ludicrously mixed with the droning swath of the music obscuring them. There are some basic concepts in sound mixing, of keeping frequencies separated, volumes conservative for certain elements, or even panning the music to the back channels while the front is left for the voices that Nolan still refuses to adhere to enough.Combining the persistent occasional sound issues with the misuse of ADHD-style editing that Nolan first started abusing in the third act of Batman Begins, this montage-like, cutty speed where now even dramatic scenes of intimate dialogue and developing relationships are subject to this. Too much of the acting is drowned not only in the music & sound design but in this frenetic, impatient, abbreviated quality... for what, to shave 10 minutes off the total run time? Absurd. To improve the pacing and rhythm? It doesn't; exactly the opposite. It didn't work for the third act of Batman Begins' action & climax or his other films since, and certainly doesn't work for scenes of barely comprehensible dialogue in a romantic relationship. Let the performances breath, for crying out loud!It's not every scene, though, and as I previously said, there's more of Nolan's older films in this than many of his other recent films. Some segments of Oppenheimer were wonderfully edited, great sound, and the problems didn't destroy the rest of the movie for me. It's still definitely worth seeing. Heck, finally, one of my biggest pet peeves addressed: we've got a depiction of the speed of sound in film or TV. That's practically an historic moment. The Star Trek & Star Wars franchises, war films, and terrorism/spy genres take note!A few more caveats before I end this:It's too hard on Truman, who was portrayed better by Gary Sinise, anyway. Truman was duped by people around him who did not accurately & fully relay to him the prior peace overtures and terms of surrender the Japanese had offered, which required such things as their emperor remaining, which eventually were essentially accepted anyway after the detonations on two targets chosen for 1) having real humans to check the effects of the weapons on, and 2) to test on two geographically-distinct cities for future planning purposes. Truman was also not told that the Russians were positioning to assault the islands and the Japanese were desperate to surrender to the USA and not Russia. Truman later in his life admitted he'd been deceived by those around him in order to cause POTUS to make a decision his underlings wanted.The film is too easy on Teller, who had much more to do with the attack on Oppenheimer's character than is even shown here. Teller continued to have a deep connection to extremely sensitive and compartmented programs that he wanted Oppenheimer to have no connection to, and was instrumental in the assistance to the nation of Israel in the development of their thermonuclear weapons.Finally, and this is not a caveat but a defense of the film, the Hindu stuff needs to be put in proper context: life, death, pleasure, pain. The little death, as the French call it. Not to mention Hinduism did not notably become puritanical until it had to start competing with Islam in the region. In its early days, they had temples of prostitution, and the Kama Sutra is in fact a compilation of older Hindu 'holy' writings & instruction on sex.

However, I am very disappointed that a movie that probably has cost a lot of money to make, did not even bother to check whether the Dutch (scene which was shot in Leiden) actually made sense. It was in fact, not Dutch, but German. This, especially considering that the timeline was during WW2, is shameful. WW2 was a difficult time for the Dutch, of which survivors, including my own grandma, are still alive. Older generations can take offence to this mistake, and it is just very sloppy.

Story is slow, characters are randomly referred to by partial names at different points (randomly referred to by first same, or last name on it's own).Lots of boardroom / inquiry scenes that were just not really all that interesting.Watched in 70MM IMAX and I noticed the film artifacts a lot more than I noticed the much higher resolution.In our screening we had a weird blob about the size of an up close character's pupil in the middle of the screen for 1/3rd of the movie. It was super distractive.The massive resolution is also partially offset by the jaggedness of 24fps whenever anything moves.Not a big fan of the constantly swapping between aspect ratios / black and white and colour.

A group of men in suits in different rooms arguing about the ethics surrounding the invention of the A bomb. The music, sound and absent of sound are marvellous depictions about the stresses of working on projects that are bigger than the ego. Yes the A bomb was awful and catastrophic but perhaps it served as a greater good invention required at the time. Was Oppenheimmer a good man? No one is truly good but just as in all businesses especially government, people can make you just as much as they can also break you. The symbolic ripples throughout, matched with the fast paced dialogue and glimpses of foreshadowing will leave you pondering did I just watch another rendition of Macbeth?

I want to preface this review with the notion that only Christopher Nolan could turn a topic like this into a 3 hour work of art.The first two hours of Oppenheimer were simply incredible. Nolan has an amazing way of keeping an audience engaged while also keeping the suspense high. I throughly enjoyed the drama and thrills the first two hours brought with itThe reason this movie isn't a 8 or a 9 is the last hour. The scenes with RDJ were quite boring and didn't contribute to the topic (IN MY OPINION). I know the last scene with Albert Einstein is sort of the cherry on the top of the plot, but I didn't enjoy the dragged out court case. RDJ did great but his characters' historical importance is subliminal compared to the rest of the characters.Cillian Murphy played a perfect J Robert Oppenheimer. It's not easy to play one of the most intelligent men in modern history. One of the most prolific scenes was the end where you could feel the pain and resentment in Murphy's eyes. For me, I hold a Christopher Nolan movie to high standards given his past work. Oppenheimer is very long movie. Certainly, while he (Oppenheimer) may have been cast in the media as central to the success of the Manhattan Project; clearly, it was a collective effort of scientists, not just one.Sadly, what is missing, unexplored in this dramatization, is the Japanese victims' perspective. We see, post WW2 uphoria, with Japan's surrender, in the American public eyes.I am not convinced this movie really comes to grips with the ignominy of the American political decision to use nuclear weapons on the Japanese general public. Rather, the story seems imbalanced. Surely, the key issue with nuclear weapons is not their power but their indiscriminate mass destructive capability. I'm not sure this victim orientated view is really given voice in this drama.

This movie cramped too much story, even it's 3 hour run time is still not enough.
