They would focus the story and let the scenes breathe. Nolan is technically brilliant but he's just an artsy Michael bay. A noobie film snob favourite. People love to sniff his farts because it made them think they are snobby film connoisseurs.

I've been a HUGE Christopher Nolan fan. Every movie he's made, Momento through Interstellar, I've loved. Flawed maybe, but loved them nonetheless. Movies that not only wow'ed me as a technical achievement, but moved me emotionally too. But lately...Nolan's films have taken a different trend. Stories that were once a perfect ratio of spectacle, plot, human drama and fascinating character work, have now been replaced with spectacle & plot-driven pieces devoid of character and heart.And Nolan's latest 3 hour historical epic, Oppenheimer is no exception. Mostly. Indulge me for a moment:Oppenheimer was of course competently written & directed, ie it hit all the historical story beats and had consistently great performances...but for me, the human touch was missing. The soul, if you will. To reiterate, It was a massive technical achievement: Great music, great cinematography, really unique tone. But that's mostly all it had to offer for me. And pair that with a grueling 3 hour run time, I have no desire to ever watch it again.Credit where credit is due, there are some excellent scenes. For instance: (slight spoiler alert, I guess? I mean, this all happened 80 years ago) The moment Oppenheimer gives his 'Victory' speech after the successful Hiroshima and Nagasaki bombing. The way they depict his inner turmoil and anxiety attack is beyond excellent. It's unique, it's heart-wrenching, it's beautiful. More of that, please.Additionally, I definitely loved what the movie had to say, it undoubtedly covered many profound ideas (though it'd be hard not to, due to the film's subject matter). HOWEVER, and this is my biggest critique...for a movie called "Oppenheimer" I never felt like we fully got into the headspace of our titular character. What was his true drive? What made him tick? (To clarify, Cillian Murphy's performance was phenomenal, this is only a dig at the writing).I think there's a great comparison to be made with The Imitation Game, the Benedict Cumberbatch-led WWII film from 2014). Our main character in that film, Alan Turing, is up against a near-parallel circumstance: a scientist/mathematician is hurled into a military setting he's not familiar with, to invent the world's first computer to decrypt German codes to help win the war before time runs out.But in The Imitation Game...I actually understand who Alan Turing is, and cared about him on a PERSONAL level. With both Alan Turing and Oppenheimer, I know they're doing what they're doing to WIN THE WAR. That's important. Obviously. But on TOP of that, in Imitation Game, I know what the task at hand means to him PERSONALLY. How he's been second-guessed his whole life, how much of an outcast he is. So if Alan Turing fails to invent the computer, not only do we possibly LOSE the war...but it's a PERSONAL loss. He's failed to prove himself in a world that's rejected him. And despite being a near-parallel storyline with Robert Oppenheimer, I didn't feel for him the way I should feel for a protagonist. And I'm confident all the historical ingredients were there. Just not utilized.Switching over to the external stakes: there was one core issue for me: Lack of urgency. During most of Oppenheimer's runtime, I nearly forgot WORLD WAR II was actively happening. Now I totally respect Nolan's decision to contain the story's perspective into one, small bubble. HOWEVER, it took away all the context for the WWII milestones that were occurring around the world! Excluding the marbles on the desk (reminding us about the enemy's plutonium supply), a few BREIF lines mentioned in passing, and one newspaper headline that said "HITLER INVADES POLAND", everything the enemy was doing during the war was out of sight, out of mind in this film. And because of this, I did not feel the urgency. I did not feel the stakes. Even though I knew, objectively, there was a TON of urgency, and a TON of stakes.... I didn't *feel* it. And that's the difference between a narrative story, and a history book. The audience shouldn't just logically understand something, they should feel it too.To play devil's advocate, because this film is a retelling of real historic events, it might not need to hit the audience over the head with those things to the degree I'm arguing for for. Most people are familiar with the events of WWII, so dropping a little blurb every now and then is often more than enough. But for me? Didn't cut it.Lastly, There were a lot of weird, borderline lazy instances of character intros and drops. The most egregious example being the character Rami Malek played (David Hill). The character was so subtly introduced in the briefest of scenes, then ended up becoming THE GUY who saves Oppenheimer during his final trial. And THEN, no follow up as to why. Maybe that was historically accurate? But unsatisfying and unresolved in the context of a narrative.All in all, these culminations of problems went up against my overall enjoyment of the film, then exasperated TENFOLD with its 3 hour runtime. Which is why Oppenheimer for me earns an underwhelming 6.9 out of 10.

There are two types of biographical films that can be made: one is a dry, realistic history lesson, and the other is a more exciting, though somewhat fictionalized, biographically inspired story. Oppenheimer is the worst combination of these two films. Based on the story, he is much more like Icarus than Prometheus, as he rose so high in his scientific career only to be burnt in political struggles.Unfortunately, it lacks everything that sets Nolan apart from other directors: the psychological game, symbolism, narrative symmetry, visual aesthetics, and dream-like cinematic experience. It's a typical creation that tries to compensate for its weaknesses with a star-studded cast. Even after three hours, we can't grasp the character, but at least we learn that nuclear weapons can destroy the entire planet. Who would have thought?

Acting, editing, writing, pacing, and character study are all top notch, and when the final scene arrived, it solidified its' status as one of the greatest biopics of all time.The ramifications and discussion are endless with the parallels between not only arms races with WMD's, but obviously also AI and how the current dabblers in AI are also leading to the destruction of not only hundreds of thousands of people, but now millions or billions. Just like the A-bomb, current AI workers are dabbling in perhaps even more catastrophe and destruction of lives and worlds, yet we know they will not wake up to it because they need a job, want to succeed financially like Oppenheimer, and want to pay their bills. Yet, their work, along with the Super, will inevitably lead to the extinction of humanity.Nolan has created a biopic timely masterpiece that many people cannot comprehend. And Einstein's appearance along with Teller, Heisenberg, and Bohr- chef's kiss.Nolan hasn't been this detailed and meticulous since Memento. Expect Nolan to take home Best Director and Murphy to win Best Actor at the Oscars next year.7/10.

I watched this 3 hour long movie which was mostly dialogue based with some very stunning cinematic moments. I felt the last hour was a stretch that could've been wrapped in half the time. Obviously the movie is relevant to regions of the world that were involved in WWII and revolves around an American figure who was able to produce the atomic bomb in remarkably record time. The controversies that surround his carrier and personal life was the center of this movie. I walked out feeling not being able to relate to most of it, except for the impact of his discovery on the nuclear proliferation in our current times.Not worth the 3 hours of watch in a theatre.

Oppenheimer is a very typical Christopher film in that it features many of his routine trademarks, strengths, and weaknesses. It has the loud, intense score and sound design that he is known for, which I found effective here. It has beautiful production design and cinematography. It has a wonderful and very deep cast. Cillian Murphy is fantastic. However, that wonderful and very deep cast includes very few women, and Emily Blunt and Florence Pugh are largely wasted.Oppenheimer isn't so much a history lesson as it is a portrait of the man. Yet in that regard, it still feels incomplete. Some aspects of his life seem quite clear: we can see that he is an engaging teacher and leader. However, the film doesn't really explore his personal relationships. Throughout the film, we are told that Oppenheimer's important personal relationships include Jean (Florence Pugh), Kitty (Emily Blunt), and his brother Frank (Dylan Arnold), but we are never really shown anything meaningful about them. In particular, we are never shown anything that illustrates why Oppenheimer is in love with Jean and Kitty. They were two very intelligent, complex, and interesting women, and it's disappointing that they are given so little to do. Additionally, you never see him actually interact with either of his children.In part, this movie is about the internal conflict caused by creating such a powerful weapon. In one sequence, Oppenheimer has a vision of people affected by the atomic bombs. Christopher Nolan's daughter has a cameo as a young woman whose skin is peeling off her face. Nolan explained the casting decision saying "...if you create the ultimate destructive power it will also destroy those who are near and dear to you. I suppose this was my way of expressing that in what, to me, were the strongest possible terms." However, Oppenheimer never seems to have that moment for himself. This destruction is never reflected back onto the people he loves. The people he sees in his visions are strangers.The film has so many really wonderful elements and some powerful sequences, but I found that the avoidance of his personal life left a gaping hole. Even though it's a three-hour movie (with good pacing), it still only scratches the surface.I do feel like this is a movie best seen in a theatre, largely due to the sound design. It's hard to recreate those big rumbling sounds and powerful silences at home.

Unfortunately for me this film was a total failure.I can't fault the actors who mostly do a good job (apart from RDJ who despite the prosthetics never convinces that he is anyone expect RDJ.) The blame here lies solely with Nolan who in his signature style creates an overlong, convoluted, poorly edited, tedious slog of a film.Although there are good scenes, they are a few and far between. Most are over in a matter of minutes and erratically jump to the next, sometimes spanning across multiple timelines, causing unnecessary confusion. We never spend enough time with any of the characters to learn much about them or form any kind of connection, thus leaving the film devoid of any kind of emotional impact.The main focus of the film is also on Oppenheimer's trial and communist connections post-war rather than the actual building and detonation of the bomb. A complete bait and switch from what was advertised to us. This would be fine if any of it was interesting but it's really not. It's dull as dishwater and it lasts for THREE HOURS.The score is too loud and overbearing, often drowning out the dialogue and not fitting in with the scene. Many have commented that the first 30 mins feel like an extended trailer, of which I agree. It really doesn't get much better after that.We actually left the cinema half an hour early because it had become completely intolerable at that point (having already contemplated leaving around 90 mins in). I should point out, I've been going the cinema for 25 odd years and I've only ever walked out on one other film. Can you hazard a guess as to what it was? Yep, Nolan's previous effort...Tenet.The mass praise and hysteria surrounding this is clearly unwarranted. It is a BAD movie no matter how you look at it, pure and simple. A snoozefest that will send even the worst insomniac to sleep. I'm astonished by all the positive reviews.After yet another dud, I personally will never see anything directed by Nolan again.

It was ok... I learnt some history, however, with the hype and Nolan I expected more. This movie felt lacking in cinematic creativity. The scenes of Oppenheimer experiencing internal turmoil whilst holding a tough exterior were great. I really liked the editing and effects during this speech scene and was wanting much more of it. I also hoped for more from the sound design throughout. It had beautiful cinematography as expected and the story is interesting enough but I don't think it will be a rewatch. It definitely didn't blow me away.With the marketing I was also looking forward to more of Pugh's amazing acting but felt her character was severely underdeveloped, especially with how important her eventual demise was.Murphy did a fantastic job and I adored seeing David Krumholtz on the big screen. I do feel like the film was slightly over saturated with famous faces and Nolan's friends. It was often a fun surprise to recognise so many people but with such small roles being taken by big names, I would have liked some up and coming actors to have that opportunity. In saying that, Jack Quaid will always be my favourite nepo baby.Towards the end it felt less like Oppenheimer and more like Strauss, however RDJ did a fantastic Stanley Tucci rendition.

I'm a movie buff. I love quality storytelling and Character development. This movie had none of these qualities. It was laden with music & sounds that were way too loud and completely distracting. Even to the point where, when you wanted to care about a character, you couldn't because the constant noise distracts. The acting and cinematography was good but if you don't know the story of Oppenheimer you will not understand. I recommend watching a biography of his life first so you can get a sense of what happened. This movie only touches on what actually happened. It's more of a courtroom drama..

I wanna start this review by warning you: the movie is long; there are long scenes of silence, contemplation and instrospection. A person who's not used to watching slow movies can still enjoy it, but there are plenty of senes that added very little and coulda been trimmed to make the movie shorter and more emphatic.My second complain is the over indulgence on Hans Zimmer's grandiose composition. This is not exactly a bombastic movie, yet there are at least 3 montage which do no progress the plot or show any substantial development on the charactersand are clearly there just to insert Zimmer's music. I found that very off putting. This isn't Inception or Interstellar where the music compliments the spectacle and creativity of the scene.This is still an awesome movie. Of special note is Robert Downey Jr.: The man can act. This is the very first time I see him actually act in a movie and he was great! The whole supporting cast is so good. A lot of known faces and other not so well known giving excellent performances. I'd like to also give credit to Emily Blunt, reminding us why she's such a household name.For the most part, this is a courtroom drama, but the little "action" there is in this movie, you'll get your money's worth of "Nolan". There's one particular scene where I felt really immerse and even started getting anxious to see what came next, the whole room felt it too! At that moment you are right there by Openheimmer's side hoping for the best. That was an awesome movie experience.Don't let my criticism fool you into thinking this is a bad movie. This was still the best cinematic experience I've had in the past 3 years. I just wished these little complains could be improved and turn this into a 10/10 movie.

The trailer and promotions of the movie seem to be about Manhattan project but on contrary it has too many sub plots pre and post Manhattan project. The political drama aspect explored in the movie remain very superficial and don't really grip the viewer.The viewer need to have knowledge of the political environment of 1950s in the USA. The movie doesn't give background before describing the events that occur during McCarthy era.There was also not much in the movie for big screens and iMax. The movie is more an abstract autobiography of Dr Oppenheimer.It is one time watch movie on the OTT and fell short of movies associated with Christopher Nolan.

I am a big Christopher Nolan fan and went to see Oppenheimer with great enthusiasm. The marketing campaign presented the movie as something innovative, something you should definitely see on IMAX to get unforgettable emotions, but unfortunately the movie didn't live up to my expectations. The movie is good, not a bad plot, very good performance of actors. But going to the movie by CRISTOPHER NOLAN, you expect more than 3 hours of dialogues to a tense melody and 1-minute scene of the "Test" atomic bomb explosion.Objectively speaking, the film is not bad.But subjectively - not the kind of film that you want to watch over and over again, like Interstellar, Inception or Tenet. In terms of cinematography, I didn't see anything new, and it's hard to come up with a beautiful picture when the setting is a small room with 5-6 people talking continuously.My verdict, if anyone is interested, is 7/10, for a good story, editing, and excellent acting.

Much like in Interstellar, at the most crucial moment Nolan's movie is fully dependent on false realities (station axis of rotation, not the black hole). In Oppenheimer they had not found any story with flesh in it, unless they did the following:1. Every physics scene is picked to only lead the viewer to think about Doom's Day2. Strauss is a villain. But not only that, the movie claims he is a villain that got played good by the hero Oppie. As everything in both the main interrogations and their results is about him preventing the Doom's Day. Successfully, although nothing worked, did it.3. Every other governmental career event that would show other methods of handling H-bomb matters, or with other people than Strauss, is not shown.4. They did not mention in any way that when Strauss wanted to block the trade of the so called 'isotopes', with other countries, that theese are medical imaging isotopes. Which do not form any part of a nuclear device, fission or fusion. This way it seemed that also on that day Oppenheimer was in work only to affect the superweapon balance of the world. In which Strauss was his main opponent.(Actually they also changed the original statement Oppenheimer made to the senate. Original ended mentioning vitamins, or another health product.)5. David Hill's hearing is shown as the pivoting point in Strauss' career. Script is doing everything to lead up to this moment by claiming that Strauss was always worried about 'who is the physicist' coming here. Hill is such a far-on-the-side character that he is just an extension of the Oppenheimer-blast-zone. In real life, he said particular words about the man in the other man's trial, but in the movie we watch it with the idea that he talks about what we know, about all the backstabbing.6. I don't know anything about Oppenheimer, but I read somewhere that we did not get the real person at all when it comes to his thoughts and solutions at specific moments of time. Or his skills with people and so forth.For some reason the movie shows that the hero's strength is in proportion to his visibility in media. Because it completely ignores the meaning of the politicians and government workers of all time who are in support of him, for say rational reasons. There's also somekind of a shroud over why after his defeat Oppenheimer wasn't active in academia. The comparative discussion with Einstein seems out of place. Because he thinks he is talking about academy, when actually the winner of the Enrico Fermi Award is chosen, in its last phase, by the whim of a cabinet member and then by the president.In general the movie has basic problems when it focuses on the communist trials. But every kind of viewer can tell from the start there is no trial mystery whatsoever. Main character is not expressing himself in a concrete manner and it looks like they avoid letting him show anything about himself. Even if we think the expressed man should be the thing in the above numbers, there is very little. Instead there are plenty hallucination, or that kind of, scenes that should tell us what kind of a person Oppenheimer is (not to mention what kind of a person everyone else is). Also we get to see more Oppenheimer's feelings after a personal loss, than in the job. I'm not saying that covering it differently would have been simple, and it would turn him into a complicated character (where the way it comes out, as exact dialogue or his reactions, you should have written as a fiction. Based on what you think a person that is actually like the Oppenheimer from historical record would be like).I would have made a more in-depth Manhattan Project movie, with different people's point of views. To make fiction there should be something (else) writen about why he got the Project. Would have also made a Trinity test from many camera angles and different slow motions, where for example the desert sand jumps up 10 feet and buries this camera. The Bomb itself seemed small even in a theatre. You need to push the camera right into it. When someone is listening to it or something.Rating is the lowest possible because, what I recall, the feature doesn't start with a 'some scenes are fictionalized for a dramatic effect' -warning.

Oppenheimer is a film that boasts amazing directing and clean visuals. Cillian Murphy delivers an amazing performance, one that truly deserves an Oscar. The dialogues of the movie are particularly noteworthy.However, the film is not without its flaws. The use of black and white shots doesn't seem to add much to the story, and the fast-moving timeline can be difficult to follow. It might have been more effective if the story was told year by year, with the trial and future scenes in black and white for better understanding.Additionally, while all of Nolan's films come with high expectations, Oppenheimer doesn't quite live up to them - with the exception of Interstellar.Overall, it's still a film worth watching for its amazing visuals and Cillian Murphy performance.

I simply can't like this movie. It wants to say way too much and says way too little about way too many things. It can't decide what it wants to be, so it's not really anything - not just for the viewer, but for the creator. And that's a problem. It's not good as a biopic: there are serious historical flaws in the story, which irritated me. I'm a huge fan of John von Neumann... anyone, who knows who he was understands why I mention him. As a drama? The movie can't decide the centre of the drama. It's too weak as a spy-story, too weak as a political drama, too weak as a personal drama. Not one aspect is worked out to carry the film. The strongest aspect was how many times in american history the "what you did 20 years ago is more important than who you become and what your expertese is" ruined people's lives. Or at least was used as a political rethoric against opponents. And I appreciated that, hence the 5 points. As a moral/personal evolution the moral conflict isn't built up, the "evolution of a scientist" dies away halfway and doesn't really connect with the "organizer scientist". The "science should or should not have moral boundaries" isn't worked out and built up, just comes and goes without a purpose. The only detactable personal evolution is the "man of future becomes the man of past", but somehow that remains too weak in the end, too. So the movie falls apart and not even the brilliant actors and the massively impressive explosion scene can hold it together.I couldn't help feeling how Nolan this time couldn't feel the fine line of balance... that "sometimes less is more".

Saw Oppenheimer last night! It was a lot to unpack so I'll try to be super direct:
1. The acting! Cillian Murphy, Robert Downey, Jr. And Emily Blunt will ALL get Oscar nominations, and may even win. This was by far Cillian Murphy's best performance, you can tell he dove into this character and really did his best and it shows. Robert Downey Jr. Played his character Lewis Strauss as well as he played Iron Man honestly. Emily Blunt played the extremely rough bitter wife and that was some of her best work I've ever seen her do. Even Matt Damon did great as well.2. I think this is the first time I've ever watched a Christopher Nolan movie where it had absolutely no action for three hours, really the only action moment was the bomb going off and that lasted for maybe five minutes. Disappointed that the biggest moment was not long enough for all the hype it was. It was amazing though.3. WAY too long. Like I said the fact that it had no action made the three hours really last. Movie could've been shortened by probably at least 30 minutes.4. Random nudity and sex. There were two scenes that had nudity/sex, one was maybe a minute, the other was maybe five minutes. Lots of boobs. Maybe it was trying to keep people entertained? I don't know but it was pointless and really random. Would have been better off removed so that it could've been PG-13 so millions of more people could've watched it. My sister and I actually had to go to the bathroom and missed the second five minute scene, perfect timing! Lol
5. Other than maybe Interstellar, this was hands-down, the best sound I've ever heard in a movie. It will win at the Oscars as well as every award show. It was absolutely amazing the sound of the score combined with the sound of brief moments you see containing explosions.It definitely is a well-made Chris Nolan movie, the guy doesn't know how to make a bad movie. It's not one that you would watch over and over again like Inception, Interstellar or the Dark Knight trilogy, but more like Dunkirk. Once in a while, where you can have the remote in your hand to fast forward, some of the extremely long dialogue and brief slutty scenes and turn on subtitles.

You will get a 3-hour movie that is not entertaining, not edifying, and not intellectually informative. The plot can be summarized in less than 5 minutes, therefore, you will get a lot of filling time when nothing really happens. Half o the movie is a combination of a boring meeting that never ends - you get one of these every day at work - and a mock trial. Moreover, add to it a lack of intellectual depth in all the conversations. The movie really misses the mark on all the aspects of plot/action, a shallow to no conversation/dialog between actors, unmoving/ordinary scenes, and a lack of character development. Add to it a continuous annoying sound that is meant to fill in stridently for the lack of emotion because the movie never gets going. If you don't like it, don't be afraid to recognize it because there is almost nothing to like. My recommendation is not to spend the time.

This movie was HUGE on dialog and nowhere near enough real action. Probably afraid to hurt anyone's feelings. The layer of music over top of the voice track was too much and made for too many missed words. All along I kept wishing for closed captioning so I could follow the story. For a 3 hour movie I completely expected more action. Sound decibel level was impressively loud. I expect some cinema grade loudspeakers got blown and probably startled a few Barbie movie goers in the theater next door. Time will tell if this was a hit. Might catch more streaming views so we can follow all the spoken words.

This film should not exist: bad storytelling, awful casting and boring concept. I have a degree in physics and I like long deep movies, but this movie is nonsense. Story could be told in 15 mins, not 3 hours. Wasted my time on 50 identical man in old hats arguing about nothing in desert. It is like a bad documentary. How did you spend that amount money on this? Maybe if you are a fan of Oppenheimer's life, you can find this movie interesting. And everybody from the movie crew is faking successful start - I am sure all of them are laughing at the audience who have to watch this movie for 3 hours. And I wish Christofer Nolan good luck on the next episode - "Oppenheimer 2: Oppy cannot decide what sauce to buy in supermarket" - it could be 4 hours. And "Oppenheimer 3: Oppy arguing with his neighbours" - ideally for 5 hours. Peace for all - I don't want to start a nuclear war in comments - just dropping a little thing :)

I'm not an action junkie, i said Schindler's list was good. But i asked once again? What is the real struggle in oppenheimer's life? Because he made the trouble himself. His womanizer behaviour, he makes fun of strauss making strauss framed Him. He's making a bomb that could kill millions of life but then regret doing so?When i watched this movie, all i think is "oh God, when will this unimportant drama ends? ". I thought this movie will end when America dropping bomb to Japan but no, all i see until The end of the movie was the hyperbolation of not so interesting life of an oppenheimer.And Nolan, you don't need a sudden high volume sound to demonstrate the " Experiment" or the "theories". You already get the point across. Or is this is an attempt from you to wake up the people who's sleeping on this movie? This movie is equivalent of watching tall girls on Netflix, both of the MC don't have a life struggle worth picked on the Big screen.My conclusion is, just like President Truman said, Oppenheimer is a crybaby. And so is Nolan, who picked an uninteresting life of an oppenheimer.

Everybody is pressured to saying that Christopher Nolan movies are great. Same happens for this one too. I had to sit through 3hrs of boredom and agony trying to figure out what this is all about.Average population is used to linear story telling and this movie made it so complicated to follow along. First 45 minutes was clueless. Last 45 minutes was politics. Somewhere in between they made a A-bomb.That's all I can say about this one. You have to follow the dialogues so closely to make any sense of it.A good percentage of reviewers are forced to give a high rating because they feel pressured to express their true opinion.Average movie goer is not going to understand the high rating of this movie nor the movie.

Why IMAX? Contrary to all of the previous Christopher Nolan films that managed to deliver intelligent stories and visual spectacle at the same time, there is nothing visually spectacular to behold here, yet they are announcing this as the "must see in IMAX experience". The movie is a political drama of people talking in rooms that has too many gratuitous nudity but almost nothing of The BOMB in action, which is what most people expect to watch on the giant screen given its premise and because it's a Christopher Nolan movie after all, the marketing clearly exploits those factors.The other factor going against the movie is its rating. The movie is R rated; a rating that could have been used to justify the showing of the destruction and horrors of the bomb that people expected to watch, specially during the scenes when Oppenheimer imagines them; just like Terminator 2 managed to do it splendidly over 30 years ago, but instead it is used to show those unnecessary sex scenes that could have been removed in order to get a PG-13 rating and sell more tickets to profit from the IMAX expense. I have heard that they decided to not be explicit on such destruction and horrors in order to "not offend anyone on the audience". Sorry, but it's a movie about making a bomb, that's what bombs do, create horror and destruction, and the movie clearly knows it, it's very well explained in its dialogue but it decides not to show it. When you choose to make a movie about such sensitive topic it is already too late to care about offending someone, everyone who is going to watch it already know what they are getting into anyway, so why not to remain objective and go all they way showing what you are supposed to show in a movie about "Oppenheimer"? Spielberg knew what to show and what not to show in "Schindler's List" and "Saving Private Ryan", both deal with sensitive topics and fulfilled audience and critics expectations.Talking about Spielberg, this movie it's like if "Jurassic Park" focused on the creation of the dinosaurs and the people who created them, they hatched, then the movie jumps in time until people return from the island and talk about what happened when the dinosaurs escaped, instead of showing us."Show don't tell", Nolan and Spielberg were great at it.Would that "Jurassic Park" version be interesting? Yes, but if you care more about genetics than entertainment, just as Oppenheimer is interesting if you care more about physics and politics, which is not many people among the general audience.But the movie was shot on IMAX, so it's clearly intended to the general audience but what is shown on it doesn't justify its IMAX format, and is R rated.So who was this movie for?The movie is long and there is not enough spectacle to keep the interest of general audience that come to see the explosion.It is also too expensive to have been made just to please a small audience that only cares about the politics behind the bomb creation.Christopher Nolan could have find the right balance to satisfy both audiences, he proved he can do it for almost 20 years in a row, but he had to eventually fail at some point, this is that point.It worries me the box office of this movie will put IMAX and film in general in a bigger risk of disappearing. It was meant to be the one to standardize it and Nolan was the one who knew how to do it the best.So in conclusion... Is the movie bad? No, but is definitively a lot less of what everyone is expecting when they see the words "Nolan" and "Oppenheimer" together.

Yes, it is a very average movie but hyped by the audience. Nolan fans have rated movie very well because they experienced the placebo effect. The movie is nothing special. I must acknowledge that the acting of every actor in the movie is top-notch. What I felt was bad, is the way storyline was presented; nothing creative was tried. Also, the movie is very dialogue intensive. At the end of the movie, I just felt that a lot of facts were poured into my head. Direction is slightly above average. From the perspective of students persuing science in graduation, the movie doesn't have much part of science; they could have showed how great Oppenheimer was in terms of his academic achievements and what all he did, instead, they choose to just say in a one-liner through dialogues!!!

Murphy is excellent and will obviously be nominated..rest of cast are also very good ...However movie is abit too long and a bit too melodramatic for its own good .Several sections of film could have been "excised" or at least shortened..I wont describe them but they are obvious ...Jump cuts ( im not sure what to call them) are distracting and
create some confusion ( some other viewers felt same ) .The focus on building bomb was interesting as was the attempt to "railroad" Oppenheimer.Typical Nolan ...over blown ... very noisy and hyperbolic...
However the "message" of film is well intended.Oppy was a very complex Man !

"Oppenheimer," Nolan's new film, is 4 stars maximum. And Cillian Murphy doesn't save the situation, only constantly widening his eyes in close-ups.It is a very difficult cinematic task - to film how people do science, so that there were no hackneyed formulas, sudden insights, complex gender relations and other banalities.And with Nolan, all these buffers follow one after another, and the result is a film about a typical conflict of professional ambitions in a closed research institute. In that sense, "Nine Days of One Year" rises head and shoulders above it.The only bright spot is Gary Oldman's two-minute role, in which he shows who is a great actor and who is not.

Christopher Nolan per usual produces a great film. The sound design is mesmerizing and shocking, and he depicts the madness, moral turmoil and hypocrisy of a very dangerous, erratic genius extremely well, and with stunning cinematography.Cillian Murphy does a good job at playing Oppenheimer, although I felt like there was too much riding on the back of his performance, which made its imperfections more visible. This isn't really shade on Cillian because he is a great actor it feels more like a directing issue. Emily Blunt does a wonderful job as Kitty, she does a great job of conveying the role of a woman who has lived so many lives and is beside herself and holding people accountable, without simply coming off as hysterical.Similarly all the scientists are well depicted, even though these are comparatively minor roles I found their acting convincing and engaging.Regrettably this movie is way too long, and becomes fairly confusing as it covers 2 separate hearings in tandem, and huge sections of the film are in black and white for no clear reason. It feels much like two movies cut together, rather than a cohesive whole.There are 2 scenes containing nudity, one of which is a sex scene, neither of which really contribute to the plot in any way other than informing us of the fact that those people have a relationship. If I'm going to be in a movie for three hours I'd rather my time were better spent.The sound design also suffers from some of the common issues of modern films: characters often mumble, or their speech is drowned out by the backing track.This film is also missing major characters, for example Fermi is mentioned only in passing. Nothing of Germany or Russia's work is shown from the inside, although this isn't necessarily a bad thing, the film is very much fixated on the perspective of the Americans looking out onto the world stage, it's just worth mentioning that you won't really get a global view of things.

One of the most excruciatingly boring films I have seen in a long time. No stakes, no dramatic tension, no investment in the characters. Just endless dry dialogue often overlaid with very loud music so it was hard to even hear what was being said a lot of the time. I fell asleep and was unfortunate enough to wake up again with still 2 of the 3 hours to go. If I hadn't been there with my family I would have left. Christopher Nolan seemed more intent on proving his own intelligence than being a good storyteller. The messing around with the chronology was an example of this, as for me it detracted from the story rather than enhancing it. A very important and potentially gripping subject but this film did not do it justice at all in my opinion.

Well, I am spoiled with 'The animation game'. Compared to that movie I give 'Oppenheimer' a six. Oppenheimers character was not as sound displayed is Turings... Cracking the German code is also not so controversial as developing an atombomb... Mixed feelings.Somehow the English dramaturgic effects works better then the USA effects. The impossible love story in 'The animation game' was also more clear. The background everlasting dramatic music was a little overdone. Is it so hard to do something without music? The interrogation was complex, long and perhaps near to reality, but for me it made the movie unnecessaraly long.

The film is a dull and tedious affair, with no sense of drama, emotion or insight. Nolan's direction is uninspired and bland, relying on clichés and exposition to tell a story that has been told better before. The cast is wasted, with no chemistry or charisma. The film is also too long, dragging on for nearly three hours, with no tension or excitement. People were literally sleeping in the hall, and I don't blame them. Oppenheimer is a disappointing and boring film that does not do justice to its subject or its audience. It is a waste of time and money. I give it one star out of five. I regret wasting my time.

This is a mini-series treated as a 3-plus hour movie. The direction, special effects, scenery, and editing are great. But the movie bogs down early with tedious, boring dialogue, pretentious posturing and emotional sterility which bleaches any life out of it. This is a tale about the creation of the atom bomb treated like episodes of Days of Lives. Murphy is flat and two-dimensional as Oppenheimer, though he looks the part. He has two or three expressions which are over-used.. Robert Downey Jr. Easily walks off with the acting honors.The script veers of into scenes that are not essential to the story telling. The high point is the test at Los Alamos but the movie plows on for an hour move giving us chapter and verse about how Oppenheimer was later abused by people he trusted.The film is over-stuffed with characters you struggle to keep straight and bitty scenes that add little to your understanding. For all its length, Oppenheimer remains something of a mystery at the end.. There is no reason for this film to run over 3 hours. You will be checking your watch by the end.

Looking at the review I was really excited to go and watch this movie.I shouldn't have bothered! So many historic fact missing, so did they not get radioactive effect from watching the explosion in the US of course they did never showed or mentioned, little mention of the impact on Hiroshima but no details, once again a film that portrays government has coward and need scapegoat to justify their actions, one question is how can you be Jewish and communist?Who cares about the love story and the cheating, it wasn't that relevant to the story.I had high expectations it didn't deliver I feel cheated.

I should not even mention anything about direction as we know the director and that's why we go and watch his movies. The story revolves around oppenheimers inner fight of need to create the bomb and guilt of after effects. He is passionate about what he is doing but after the test he goes to guilt and hence wants to stop the escalating and research on making more bombs. Please do not expect any mind boggling action and adventure from this movie. It does not even show how the actual bomb got dropped. Once the test was done the work got over for oppenheimer.I would however rate rocketry over this movie.I also am strongly against the sex scene having gita shlok and it should be removed immediately.

Starts off quick and awkward. Very hard to figure out what timeline you are in, throughout the movie. Apparently the future is in B&W, Totally not necessary, just confusing. I kept thinking "geez, we are not in your head, Christopher Nolan, get some details in order" Watching the documentary on Peacock was more enjoyable, and explained a alot. I can't imagine seeing this movie without watching the documentary first. I would have been completely lost, with it I was just merely lost. Too many, way too many characters to keep straight. If I had to choose a best character actor, I'd go with Matt Damon, although his first spout if anger was a bit off. There is much more to Oppenheimer the man, than what is portrayed. If I was streaming this 3 hour movie, I wouldn't have finished it. As it is, 4 people walked out of the theater before the 2 hour mark. Save tour time and money, and watch the documentary on Peacock.

Quite disappointed. Story and timeline were all over the place. If you have never hear of Oppenheimer, you are still quite lost because the story line missed connecting to the audience. Really felt like I wasted 3.5 hours on a nice Sunday afternoon.I'm really surprised that the story was missed so badly. I Mt feels like the writers strike had something to do with this but sadly it doesn't.What a great opportunity it was that was missed to bring some important history to those that have forgotten or were just unaware.Movie was 3 hours + the previews. It made it feel like I watched an old baseball game before the pitch clock.

I have really liked all of Christopher Nolan's movies so far, but I guess that had to end sometime. This movie is dreadful. If you think Oppenheimer's atomic creation is the biggest bomb you've ever seen, this movie will prove you wrong.You know when you're at a lecture and someone in the audience puts up their hand and says, "Well, when I was dining at Elton John's chateau in the Italian Riviera with Fran Lebowitz and Neil deGrasse Tyson ..." and you instantly hate them? That's the kind of person who gives this movie a 10/10.In practically every scene, Nolan introduces a new character for you to not care about and forget by the next scene. There were so many characters, all referred to by last name only, I couldn't keep track.Also, the music is incessant! I'm all for movie music, but it doesn't need to be constant. Plus it was SO loud, sometimes you couldn't understand what the people on screen were saying. In fact, it was so loud and in your face that it kept waking up the couple sitting next to me.Save your money on this one. Watch it when it comes on TV - if you have insomnia you need cured.Contrary to the popular adage, I WOULD recommend this movie to my worst enemy.

I love a Christopher Nolan film as much as the next fanboy and I was definitely intrigued. I haven't been this excited in a while that I purchased an Imax ticket months ahead of time. A 3 hours film length doesn't frighten me as long as the film flies by which only happens if a movie keeps you engaged the whole time. Unfortunately, I feel it was a little too long and should have ended soon after the atomic bomb was a success and Oppenheimer comes to grips with the powerful self-destruction creation he made. Instead Nolan chose to drone on about Oppenheimer's bureaucratic problems he encounters and beats a dead horse on the moral problems he comes to grip with. I felt it was answered enough in the previous 2.5 hours and I admit I was beginning to clock watch and wondering when it was gonna wrap up. All I can say is that Nolan is indeed the greatest director of this generation but peaked with Interstellar for me which was truly a top 10 film. That movie deserved multiple viewings with a similar runtime but keeps you engaged the whole time. This I feel comes up way short behind his other masterpieces such as Interstellar, Dark Knight, The Prestige, and Inception.

This movie was LOUSY. The scenes were ALL too dark, as in not bright enough to see much. The sound was not always clear. There were way too many characters to keep track of. We didn't know who these people were supposed to be. The time that events took place was all jumbled up. There was much to much jumping back and forth in time. The characters all looked alike. The physics information was geared towards 2nd graders. Sex scene at the hearing? Why was there a need to show naked bodies out of context? There was no focus - The bomb story, the science, the wife and girlfriend relationships, the hearings, background stories, the communist angle, Los Alamos. Too much touching on something a little bit but not enough.

I love most Nolan films including Tenet but Dunkirk left me disconnected resulting in a tedious experience. I much preferred Oppenheimer yet this emotional disconnect from the characters and plot was present at least to a lesser extent. The film is evidently meticulous in its production with outstanding acting yet it felt somewhat mechanical and disconnected amidst its pummelling of events. I was riveted by Dark Knight, Interstellar and Tenet yet Oppenheimer and Dunkirk far more so saw emotional resonance with the characters and care for the films outcome lacking. I've definitely had films belatedly connect with me on subsequent viewings, however, I am concerned personally with this and Dunkirk's style yet most including the Oscars are likely to say otherwise.

The title speaks for itself. I was very much looking forward to this movie. It took only 45 minutes for me to be ready to walk out. The only reason I stayed was the hope for the movie to get better or at least progressively come close to expectations. What we got was a directors personal interpretation and failed attempt at "art" that became painful to witness. A confusing plot that even at the end gave little insight to what was trying to be portrayed. This film tried so hard to be the Citizen Kane of it's time. This attempt fell far short of everyone's expectations at the theater. A quarter of the movie was bearable and the rest, downright disappointing. The whole movie is fixated on telling a confusing story of 2 peoples perspectives of events along with a personal vendetta, and a kangaroo Court. Oh, and I think at one point they actually talked about making a nuclear bomb or something but that wasn't the main story line to what the film was about. At the end of the movie I heard a fellow moviegoer say "What did I just watch". This film took 3 hours of my life I will never get back, Although it's probably going to win an Oscar.

The movie drags and drags until your last two brain cells stop working. It was painfully long. You even consider stepping out of the theatre. Apart from that the casting was great. Acting by Cillian, Emily, Florence, Robert Downey was exceptional. We actually feel that we are in the 1940s as the costume, makeup, set was perfect.The bomb making and testing scenes were awesome and it makes us feel everything is real. (Literally it felt the ground was shaking during these scenes)The storyline was simple. It followed personal and professional life of Oppenheimer also involving characters that were in and out of his life. Must watch in IMAX if you want to experience the cinematic beauty of this film.

The first hour of this film in particular has every cliché you've ever seen in a biographical movie come up again and again. What I found most annoying is this assumption that the audience can never understand any of the science involved in the story, so the makers substitute writing frantically on blackboards, cutting to sparks on a black screen, and the character being described as "brilliant genius", presumably because he can see the sparks whereas other people can't. Without any sort of context, the science is a meaningless abstract reference and the real story is lost. As for Cillian Murphy, he could have had a great career as a half forward for Nemo Rangers if he'd played his cards right and now look at him- sitting on an armchair stark naked in front of millions of people like an eejit.

First, it is a good movie overall with great actors and an interesting story. Second, it is highly overrated and most people (americans) out there see "Nolan" and start screaming it is the best movie of all times blablabla. This was adapted from a book so dont expect anything mindblowing in the story, it's just what it is: a biography.I was very disappointed in the fact that Nolan did not bring that amazing view of things as he did in interstellar or tenet and I was let down by the scientific details. I would have loved to learn more about the engineering challenges behind the project and also I was expected an original view of the atomic explosion. I really felt I learnt nothing new about that part of history and the movie was quite simple to understand without any big surprise at the end. But again it is a good movie, well made and interesting. I was just disappointed and I had much higher expectations mostly fueled by the high rating this movie received which is not justified.

This film has everything laid out. I have been looking forward to it for months. Like others, Nolan is one of my favorite directors, nay, probably my favorite director of all time. All the critics raved about this film. The trailer made it look like something that I could take my kids to for the discussion I expected we would have afterward - even if I had to cover their eyes during the nude scenes. I was expecting to come out of this picture blown away and I even paid $25 to see it with a friend in IMAX first just to double check it was tween friendly enough. Well, I am sorry to say it was an enormous let down. Was it a decent flick? Sure. The cinematography was good, the story is interesting kind of, but let's be real here, Oppenheimer himself is not the interesting part of the story, the bomb is. The fact that you have to murder tens of thousands of people in order to save tens of thousands more. What the bomb does to people who aren't vaporized when it goes off. This was just barely touched on in the film. There are no scenes of mathematicians working feverishly, no real feeling of how large of a project this must have really been. There are snippets of things here and there about the project, but this really is JUST A BIOPIC of Oppenheimer. And somewhat of this Strauss guy that history pretty much has forgotten. And truth be told, none of it was really that interesting to me. Feynman would have made a much more interesting film, IMO. So, was it OK? Yeah, it was OK. Am I glad I spent $25 to see this in the theater? Nope. This is a rental, if you have nothing better to watch. But do yourself a favor, go get The Dark Knight or Interstellar and watch that again - you'll be happier in the end. If you want something kind of along the same vein that's a better movie, see The Imitation Game. If you are looking for.a thought provoking movie, watch The Fog of War.

Oppenheimer - 7/10Saw this on opening day at a sold-out BFI iMax with James Acaster in attendance. Proper bombs of dread.Lots of anticipation for this one and I've long been curious as to how it justifies the 3-hour run time. I assumed that running that length would mean that we have multiple set pieces, but it really does just focus on the Trinity test. Hiroshima and Nagasaki happen off screen, and we instead focus on the Manhattan project and 'court room drama' that unfolds in the aftermath of the Trinity test.This is Christopher Nolan's JFK, with a healthy dose of The Social Network and a sprinkling of abstract imagery. I would have liked a bit more surrealism, but I guess Nolan would be well aware of what David Lynch achieved in Twin Peaks: The Return episode 8 so he keeps it restrained. It's more history lesson than blockbuster and I'm sure there are many people out there that expected a completely different film. The marketing made it look like it could be an action-packed race against time but it's much more academic and dialogue heavy.If you're interested in exploring Robert Oppenheimer's story in forensic detail, then this is the film for you. Just don't go expecting an all-encompassing retelling of the ending of the second world war.It's a very well-made film, but it's intense and a lot to take in. You must be in the right mood. I won't be in a rush to see it again and I certainly wouldn't be raving about it and recommending it to everyone. A slog, but an interesting and worthwhile slog.It will SWEEP at the Oscars.

I don't grasp what's all the fuss about this movie. Three damn hours of talking blah blah blah.. and one terribly shot nuclear explosion. I wish Barbie was not banned in the Middle East.Besides, its so funny that everyone was fighting to watch this BS film on a real IMAX! Come on guys, i wouldn't play this sheeyat movie on my old Panasonic radio. It's just so dumb film to watch. I'm pretty sure Nolan has no clue what's this film about. He probably thinks it's about WW3 or smothing LOL.Having that said, with all due respect, Nolan is not a genius and someone had to stop him from doing more garbage films.

So today I watched Oppenheimer and it was good. I was extremely excited for this one and my expectation meter was quite high but it turned out to be just good, not extraordinary or beyond expectation, it was a good movie.A lot of the things Nolan did right in this one: to begin with he remained very true to the source material. Also, he made everyone acted their hearts out which was quite an astonishing feat.Acting on the other hand was amazing, Robert Downey Jr. Will definitely get an Oscar for his performance so will Emily Blunt. Matt Damon was also outstanding but Cillian Murphy as J. Robert Oppenheimer was the star and his acting was beyond outstanding and it makes sense because it was a movie driven by acting and the script and Nolan made it look quite captivating.Now we'll come to some of the things I didn't like: I'm not a fan of Nolan's style of directing, although he did some thing differently in the first hour of the movie but then got back to his old roots and it felt like a sequel to Inception or any one of his movies.Also, for the life of me the way his characters talk. Dear Lord, no one talks like that in real life, he's got so much plot within a plot within a plot going that every single character tries to explain what's happening and what direction the film is taking.I guess I would've enjoyed the movie better if it wasn't that hyped to an extent where some people I know were saying "that was the darkest movie they have ever seen" which was clearly not the case.Anyways, I would recommend you to let the hype die a bit then watch it and you may end up enjoying it a lot more than I did or if you're really impatient then catch the hype train and see for yourself what I'm saying.Apart from a few things he did differently it was just another Nolan flick that people were dying for (including myself but I was roped in sadly) I came home a wee bit disappointed because I watched a lot of interviews on him taking a different direction and all but nope, walked right into that one.My rating 7/10
Peace.

Oppenheimers SnoozefestShort points
Pace is to slow
After the bomb goes off, movies drags on for
Another hour...
Constant back and forth without a hint of an
Explanation is exhausting
Overall boring inattentive filming
An Exercise of, Because I Can, from Nolan
What's imax worthy here?This story would have been better and had made more sense if all of Oppenheimers moral qualms would have been dealt with before the bomb goes off in the test. This way in the final act, the explosion could have been the bell that has been rung and can't be unrung. Adding Gravitas to the story. Instead, after the test bomb goes off, the movie grinds on for another hour...Although it is Oppenheimers story, as such the movie failed to portray the wider implications of Oppenheimers doing. The effects on Japan itself. With that, Nolan failed spectacularly to deal with this subject matter in a critical way. It deforms into a merely pseudo intellectual exercise of vapid grandeur.Imagine Germany produced a Movie about the concentration camps and merely brushes off the wider implications with, We needed to do it to end the war, like it's done in Nolan's latest work as justification for the US to commit this heinous crime, twice. Therefore, the attempt of portraying Oppenheimers guilt falls flat on the face for me, a mere afterthought, a noisy one at that.Soundtrack:
As seems typical with Nolan's efforts the soundtrack tends to drown out everything else in parts. Towards the end, when Oppenheimer is questioned by Strauss goons, there is this cacophony of noise so annoying and unnecessary it actually is painful. I get what Nolan tried to achieve. However he choose to submit the audience by literally have the movie shout at it and beat the audience into submission.The story telling here requires the viewer to pay one hundred percent attention for all of it. Even then a second viewing is needed. Haunting imagination that...The acting is great, shame about the scriptThis is a snooze fest of epic proportions, not for everyone.

The movie itself is not about the Manhattan Project. Its merely depicted. It instead heavily focuses on Oppenheimer himself. The movie is tasked with answering a single question throughout the entire movie: Is Oppenheimer a man to be trusted? The development of the movie is very well designed. Oppenheimer is a complicated man, with strong beliefs and who is entitled to those beliefs, and yet he is constantly interrogated for not just being the man who invented the atomic bomb, but for whether or not he is being loyal to America. Forces beyond his control and people who plot against him, but he has the wit and strength of a scientist who must prove to no one that he is in fact human.The plot since it tells the story of Oppenheimer is very well written. Its highly intelligent and has many twists. Its told in the past, present, future with referencing each many times. The beginning is a bit slow and theres a lot of science knowledge everywhere so any audience members that dont know a lot will end up being confused. But the dialogue is very intelligent and theres lots of it, frankly sometimes there too much of it to where it gets boring.However, the camera focuses mostly on Oppenheimers perspective, shots can be seen from multiple angles. The sound was thrilling, startling, loud, and suprisingly powerful. It captured the movie. Not just the bomb itself, but its like we are in Oppenheimer's mind breathing in his sights and hearing thoughts. The graphics are just as powerful that captures the attention of the audience.Overall, the purpose of this movie is a hidden message-to determine if Oppenheimer is trustworthy to science and to America. He is tasked with building a bomb, and he feels the weight of not entirely being thrilled about it. He is convicted of the humanity of killing a death weapon, that would at that time possibly destroy the world. The task is difficult because Oppenheimer is put into a difficult position for the sake of the war.But once the war is over, he feels the fear of others against him. Oppenheimer is after all only human. He expresses remorse and makes mistakes in the movie that shatters his family. He grieves for those who the bomb killed. He advocates for the freedom of having strong beliefs such as his. And so the movie must then answer the question, should America give him security clearance? Is he a good citizen?

Oppenheimer was an experience.The film, in many ways, was exceptional and clearly made by Nolan. However, compared to his other films, this one is a mixed bag.1. For a stacked cast filled with actors such as R. Downey Jr, Florence Pugh, Emily Blunt, and Cillian Murphy, you would expect the characters to be connectable. Well, not the case. There is no real emotional depth or storyline in this movie, which in succession caused it to lose intensity the farther you progress. Characters are rapidly introduced, all seeming to process some importance by the end in reference to Oppenheimer's final Security Check. However, during these final testimonies it is extremely difficult to feel any sympathy or connection with these characters. Though dramatized events in Oppenheimer's life are constantly explored, he still remains a distant protagonist. Emily Blunts character is one of the only characters to show emotional expression. I feel the point of historical bio-pictures is to make the characters more connectable, dramatized even.2. Though I see little to no one pointing this out, I feel like both nudity scenes in the movie were entirely avoidable. Both scenes added little to nothing to the plot, besides the reveal of Oppenheimer's affair, which could've shown without such,.3. Personally, I feel this movie doesn't quite convey the significance
of the events it follows after the initial bomb test. The non-linear typically Nolan timeline downplays the events. The bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki we only hear Truman over the radio? The announcement of the bombings almost initially passed over me due to the quiet audio during this scene as well. After watching a 3 hour movie centered around the atomic bomb, selfishly, I would've at least liked to have see at least one of cities get actually bombed. Flashing scenes between alleged communism and choppy dialogue left a quite boring and rather confusing second half. A whirlwind of heavy dialogue and different timelines/perspectives that ultimately conveyed a rather confusing story of Oppenheimer. For a viewer going into this movie with little to no previous knowledge on the psyche that came with the atomic bomb, you will be confused. This movie provides little to no exposition for characters political sides regarding the bomb or general morals. Typically, I understand not having a large amount of exposition for the sake of keeping the plot rolling. However, for a 3 hour movie this courtesy was not granted.4. Overall, the soundtrack wasn't stellar, though it was extremely loud. The constant intrusion of music and loud noises took away from the film itself. In many cases I found myself reaching to gasp bits of unintelligible dialogue.5. The cinematography in this movie was amazing, along with the set designs, and hidden details. Granted, there were your traditional terrific Nolan details which made the film gratifying, but overall maybe little to no impact.

So... saw the movie "Oppenheimer" last night on opening night. Happy to see that against "Barbie," a movie about history was doing relatively well-theater packed. But this movie was done in typical Christopher Nolan film, most shots lasting 5 seconds or less resulting in a jumping narrative style, that when combined with the technical jargon and the too loud "Hans Zimmer-like" soundtrack made it difficult to understand, even for a physics-degreed guy wearing hearing aids.Warning: spoiler alerts contained below!BLUF: they get the history mostly right, although they attribute certain conversations to the wrong people. Nolan says he did this for clarity in the reduction of number of characters, but in a movie with more than 30 main characters you are expected to track, I can't see how adding one or two more to correct the history would have hurt.Did I love it? Well, I liked it a lot. I loved the presentation of the physics. Brought me back to my two undergrad courses in quantum theory. Loved the discussion of whether the bomb would set the atmosphere on fire. That was one of the conversations attributed to the wrong guy-the actual guy who did those calculations was one of my grad school profs Robert Hamming. In the movie Oppie asks Einstein in one scene to do the calculation (never happened) and in another scene it was an unnamed character (likely my old prof) who tells Oppie that the probability is "near zero." Fun note: in one of my grad school courses "Hamming on Hamming" he went through those equations with us.And I loved seeing Tom Conti's portrayal of Albert Einstein. Having read all of Einstein's books in my undergrad days, Conti plays him exactly as I have imagined him.Another fun scene is when Oppie starts teaching his first class (Berkeley?) and tells his one student who is trying to understand quantum, "You're looking at it the wrong way." I wish I had that prof. I was looking at it the wrong way in undergrad too, but nobody was ever bold enough to tell me that.But I did not like the gratuitous sex, which added nothing to drive the story forward and seems to have been inserted just because it's what British filmmakers do.So back to the movie: It ran for 3 hours and didn't feel like it. There were slow parts but I never found myself looking at my watch. The chronology was difficult to follow despite jumping from color (paradoxically, for the sequences happening in the 1940s-1954) and black & white (for the Senate scenes with Admiral Lewis Strauss-played by Robert Downey Jr- mostly taking place in 1959). Strauss is the antagonist who never attended college, made enemies of Chester Nimitz, yet gets a Navy reserve "graveyard promotion" to rear admiral right after WWII and insists on being called "admiral" for the rest of his life. He has a giant chip on his shoulder throughout the movie, which apparently was accurate.Was the movie accurate from a historical sense? Very much so. Even some of the more contrived and unbelievable scenes (such as the "more useful than a sandwich" scene which humiliated Strauss) actually happened.If you put differences in Nolan's jumpy, distracting narrative style aside, his biggest miss with the movie is his failure to recognize that something can be "regrettable," yet one still may not regret it.This is the matter Nolan goes back and forth with Oppenheimer at the end. Does he regret the Hiroshima bomb? Oppenheimer does not say. Yet Oppie clearly feels that the need to drop the bomb was regrettable. Nolan goes back and forth with this as if it is a paradox, but it's not. Any sane human being regrets the fact that something substantial had to happen for the war to end. And as we cover in our episodes of "The Unauthorized History of the Pacific War" podcast, dropping the bomb was the least bad choice of many really bad options, one which actually minimized the loss of life necessary to end the war. Anyone who thinks otherwise has to ignore the facts of the conflict and many contemporary statements, most notably from the Japanese leaders themselves.Is "Oppenheimer" worth seeing? Absolutely- if for no other reason than we need serious movies to compete in the box office with comic book and toy movies else they will stop making serious movies.But whatever you do, stay to the end, that final scene with Oppenheimer and Einstein. The closing line of that movie may be one of the best lines for film ever written.

Christopher Nolan is a mastermind at coming up with novel concepts like in Inception, Memento and Tenet. That's what makes him Nolan in my humble opinion. He has also proved to be a genius when it comes to action fantasies like in The Batman Trilogy. Nolan is also the best when it comes to thrillers whether they are sci-fi thrillers such as Interstellar or war thrillers such as Dunkirk or psychological thrillers such as The Prestige and Insomnia. So he experiments with different genres and here he is, yet again, embarking on a whole new genre, biographical movies! Most biographical movies are boring, lame and empty but this one is the best biopic I've ever seen. I mean, the black and white scenes, the loud bombing in the IMAX theatre, the storytelling and the phenomenal score in the background, all of that fits together really well in a 3 hour screenplay that takes you away from reality and makes you lose your sense of time. When the credits rolled I was in shock knowing that 3 hours had just passed by because to me it literally felt like 30 minutes. It was unbelievable. However, I think Chris Nolan is poor at writing drama. It's his biggest weakness and unfortunately Oppenheimer is only about personal drama so it doesn't have any aspects at which Nolan could show his strengths. The drama in Oppenheimer was not deep enough and didn't hit hard enough. I would give it 7.5/10 but this website doesn't allow fractions so I can only choose between 7 or 8 and I went with 7 haha. I think you can find poor drama in all Nolan movies as well but that's not always obvious because most of his work is not about drama alone unlike Oppenheimer. The most obvious example is Tenet, it doesn't have any emotions or drama and If not for the brilliant concept in Tenet, the whole movie would have been a total waste of time. I don't know how can Nolan improve in drama writing. It's the only flaw in Oppenheimer. Nonetheless, I'm a big fan of Christopher Nolan and I enjoyed watching Oppenheimer.

I went to the theater with very high expectations, but sadly enough they were not met. Especially from Christopher Nolan I would have expected something better.The choice of telling the story out of order made it very difficult to follow especially if you do not know anything about Openheimer in advance. So I would really recommend to do a small research in advance to enjoy the movie more, since I had more questions in the end than answers.This movie also introduces so many people and names, which makes it almost impossible to remember them all and follow the story easily. In this story they could have easily left some people out that had no sufficiently large role. This movie would have been better for a series, to flesh out the characters that are there better. Or I would have removed everything about Strauss, because it made this movie way too long and did not really add anything to the story of Oppenheimer.The score and cinematography on the other hand were fantastic. The pacing will take you aback at first; Oppenheimer meets and divorces his wife within 5 minutes, but it's the price to pay to set the context for the two big moments later in the film.Understandably, it's hard to tell someone's entire life story in 3hrs while also creating enough drama to keep an audience hooked. Nolan chose to tell two stories, which is definitely engaging, but it ends up feeling like there's a first act, but then 2 3rd acts.There's also more ambitious filmmaking, but it comes off as a little self indulgent, especially with 2 awkward sex scenes posing as "art".With that said though, Nolan knows how to keep you engaged. There's a literal minute long countdown and I could feel my heart building with each second. Even after 2hrs, I still refused to allow my attention to slip thanks to the engaging cutting between scenes in multiple points in Oppenheimers life and building to a second crescendo.Last weird technical thing to note: the camera loses focus a lot, especially in the last hour. Clearly they were running at a low aperture on a medium format camera, but that meant even the slightest deviation on the focus was noticeable. I saw tons of shots where someone's ear or nose was in focus but not their eyes, because with such high ape rather you can't be off by a single cm.Definitly check out the film though, and obviously in IMAX if you can since I saw it in standard cinema and felt like I was missing out on something better.

Christopher Nolans Filmography is one of the most respected of all time. And I think it´s deserved. But this time Nolan did not nearly reach the level of his previous movies. Oppenheimer starts so confusing you can not grasp what is going on. The timelines switch almost randomly and scenes that feel important are stopped just to pick them up again at a random point later on.In addition to that, Robert Oppenheimer ist portrayed as a maniac-like man, who is obsessed with atoms and quantom-physics, which is shown through trip-like sequences. This man shown in the movie is nothing like the man I know from the interviews he gave post bombing. I do not see the man who spoke with tears in his eyes, regretting what he did.And to add to all of that, Nolan (of course) has to build in a twist. But this twist is so useless, it actually bothered me. Not every great movie has to have a twist but seemingly Nolan thinks otherwise.The movie does get better after the first one and a half hours. The skipping between the timezones declines a bit by then. But towards the end, when all the times finally come together, for me all hope was already lost. The end for me almost feels like a teaser for the cold war. The building of the rockets is seen and Oppenheimer constantly tries to prevent a arms race. That is not how Nolan used to work. And I know Nolan can do better. But he didn´t this time.Sadly, this movie was not was I expected. But you can´t always get what you want, right? And atleast all the actors did a great job, especially Cilian Murphy.

6.5 at best. I'm mid-60's in age and grew up with the fear of atomics. I've always been fascinated with this era and at some level, very interested in the technology used to develop and test the device, and the politics and military's demand to use during war-time. This movie did touch on some of the thinking present during that time leading to the decisions. I enjoy learning, reading, and watching anything to do with WWII. My father was in the war, so I have some ties to this. Growing up on the West coast (of CA) I was in close proximity to many of the research areas, such as Stanford, and Lawrence Livermore Labs.I tried not to fall into the over-hype of this movie prior to its release, but really looked forward to seeing it. The Regal "RPX" theater was maybe a third full (Sunday at 3:00p). The filmography was not necessarily impressive - top notch, but not outstanding or superior. Some of the edits were annoying, constantly flipping between different time lines, and using B&W vs. Color to help show "artistic license", I suppose. It was more annoying. I do like B&W, however and when done well, it's very impressive.The sound quality was the most annoying part of the movie. It was very, very loud at times. I noticed my 20-something son sitting next to me covering his ears perhaps 3 different times. Several others in the theater were doing the same. The music was unfitting for this movie. It really felt like music that would be used during a two-minute film trailer to advertise a new movie, however the music lasted 3 hours. It did nothing to add ambiance or mood to the scenes. It was a distraction at best. Some dialog was rolled over by the music and was missed.As a comparison, "Fat Man and Little Boy" (staring Paul Newman) is a much better story - compelling, sufficiently detailed in the technical aspects, and helped to tell the broader narrative of the teams that worked on this project. The scene showing the Trinity test was, frankly, a letdown. Others have commented here, so I'll let that one go.Matt Damon had some terrific moments early in the movie, but it wasn't sustained. Emily Blunt's character was muted, and somehow lost in some of her impact. The most moving scene was when she "watched" her husband with the other woman. Although the scene told a story, it was unnecessary. Better writing could have brought the audience to resonate with her despise and hate. Cilian Murphy's performance was terrific, but not Oscar worthy. Robert Downey Jr. Did an outstanding job and took me for a bit of a ride early on. I ended up flipping on his character, which at the end of the movie, not so subtly illustrates his motives. Not a good look for the man, but it was finally addressed in the way that the average movie goer could understand. It was refreshing to see Einstein portrayed in this movie, but I'm not sure if that was closer to reality or just the clever inklings of a writer.Overall, I'm glad I saw it, and it is still drifting around in my head - which is one good sign that it made an impact. I'll probably watch it again when available to stream at home....with sub-titles.
