Christopher Nolan's obsession with hyperbolic noise and graphics comes to a head in 'Oppenheimer' in a long-foreseen bang, but the aftermath is short lived.Cillian Murphy and, really, everybody's acting in this film was excellent. The set pieces, dedication to maintaining the historic aesthetic, and aging makeup were all awe inspiring. But why the mediocre score? The story didn't marry to Nolan's vision as well as he'd hoped.We all know that Christopher Nolan loves to try and strike a chord through loud moments (warranted or not) and breakneck pacing. Perhaps being limited to a 3-hour cut made it more difficult to follow and find relatability. Perhaps it was the uneasy feeling that Nolan tried to make a mountain out of a molehill. Do you remember Strauss and his "trial"? Do you know who he is at all? Do you care?The scientific and engineering focus left me wanting greatly. There was so much potential to explore the process of how the other 40,000 people attached to the Manhattan Project contributed and aided to help the U. S. create the atomic bomb. Instead, we're stuck suffering through all the low-key misdeeds of Oppenheimer to build up our internal conflict with the man and his actions. It's fun to see so many stars in various states, but is it necessary to tell a good story about the "Father of the Atomic Bomb"?A spectacle of sorts can be found in this film which many of us have craved since the summer blockbuster took a long absence. However, many of us were sated with Top Gun: Maverick last year and can do without the incessant preaching on how "war = bad, politics = bad". Were we supposed to feel tricked by an internal struggle against rooting for the success of Oppenheimer and his team's objectives?I'd rather not give credit to such fabrication. Nobody walking out of the theater was talking about how intriguing it was to be a fly on the wall for a board review of a security clearance hearing or some guy being raked over the coals on his relationship with Oppenheimer. No, they were talking about the very short (but sweet) bomb we waited 3 hours for and Florence Pugh's boobs.

Any art is a kind of medium that conveys an exciting idea in a mind to millions of minds. And if part of this attempt is successful, it would be a great masterpiece of art. Nolan has failed to convey that excitement since "Tenet," and Oppenheimer has also clearly fizzled out in that endeavor. The most disappointing aspect is the screenplay, which will not give you a sense of excitement at any point as the movie progresses.The movie is brimmed with endless dry dialogues, boring meetings in closed rooms, and frequently veers off into uninteresting subplots. But Nolan was successful in not letting the Oppenheimer character become supernatural throughout the movie.You will be shown the amazing dialogue between officers behind closed doors to discuss which cities they are going to bomb rather than how the dropping of a bomb affected the unlucky cities of Japan in reality. Nolan preferred melodramatic events on the surface to the deeper story nobody knows, which made the plot dull and boring all the way.The continuous saga of office discussions put me to near sleep, and that's when Nolan comes up with very loud music every now and then so that I don't have a chance to have a nice sleep.As a final word, the screenplay was very flat, and I didn't feel excitement at any point. But if you are a fan of endless closed room dialogue and drawing board discussions of making a bomb, this is the movie for you. If you expect some upbeat twists in the screenplay, sit back at your home, grab any book and coffee for a more enjoyable day.

The acting and production values are up to Christopher Nolan's standards. Cillian Murphy was a great choice to play J. RDJ moved seamlessly through the time shifts and was ultimately perfect as a foil to Oppenheimer. I won't get into any of the rest of the ensemble cast, but they all played their supporting roles quite well.So, why the six star review, then? Even at 3 hours, the film and character development felt incredibly rushed, and there were many aspects to this expansive story that weren't adequately fleshed out. To me, it would have been much more engaging as a 6 or 8 episode biopic mini-series. Oppenheimer didn't need to be IMAX film. The story was about his life's work and personal idiosyncrasies.At the end of the movie, I walked out of the theater to my car & never once said "wow!" While it was technically flawless, and was well cast, it never emotionally engaged me. YMMV.

The new film 'Oppenheimer' by Christopher Nolan premiered in big-screen cinemas worldwide. The biopic by the director, starring Cillian Murphy, has drawn a lot of attention in India as well, particularly for bringing up the sacred text Bhagavad Gita.J. Robert Oppenheimer, a physicist who is credited with creating the atomic bomb, is the focus of the movie. Oppenheimer was the head of Los Alamos Laboratory and a key player in the Manhattan Project, an initiative by the government to carry out research into the making of nuclear weapons.While Florence Pugh portrays Jean Tatlock, Cillian Murphy plays Oppenheimer. Murphy stated that he had read the Hindu holy scripture for the movie before it was released. So let's start with the good bits: A fascinating story well told and easy to follow despite the usual non linear format of Mr Nolan. I also thought it ended well and had great acting and a brilliant cast. I would have given it more stars had it not been overhyped so much which left me with my expectations too high. Now for the bad bits (with spoilers!): Watching any film on a Cinema big screen with surround sound is a nice experience. However, I am not sure why this film was a 'must see' on a big screen. I am guessing for the overhyped bomb detonation taking place two hours into the three hour film. I was expecting so much more from the detonation sequence, I did not time it, but it seemed to be over so quickly with a flash, fireball and some shockwave bangs. Mr Nolan missed a trick here as he could have made it last so much longer with so many more effects. Then it was back to the slow but well told drama for the last hour. So, with the exception of a couple of minutes in the middle a big screen is no more a required for this film than for a courtroom drama.

Great movie, but with a great fault; not a minor, but a major historical failure to show the central role that president Roosevelt played in the first years of the relevant period. Einstein and others convinced president Roosevelt that Germany was in the process of developing an atomic bomb and it was Roosevelt who decided to launch the Manhatten Project. It was also Roosevelt who sent a letter to Oppenheimer thanking him for leading the successful work in New Mexico. A film about Oppenheimer and the atomic bomb without a role for FDR is like making a film about The Battle of Britain without Winston Churchill.Yours Gideon Zlotnik.

I will keep my review very simple and absolutely honest.The movie is a biopic in its purest sense. Don't watch this movie if you think the Trinity test will be spectacular with great special effects. Nolan tried to achieve the blast with practical effects and that took a major toll on the seriousness of how violent Nuclear explosion can be. Basically there is only one explosion people go to the watch the movie. If someone is telling me they watched the movie just for the Dr. Oppenheimer's pov of life, I would say they are lying to themselves. Everyone on this planet have some philosophy of their own and a sob story. Oppenheimer's doesn't make him any special or more vulnerable than us. That's the essence of life.I did not go to the movie expecting it to be an action flick. Also just because I am a long time Nolan fan doesn't mean I can lie to myself convincing that's it's a spectacular movie. The movie is just blant. Over 90% of the movie is distracting with its cutting and showing different timelines while lacking consistency in story telling. Nolan is know to cut scenes and show past and future back to back without giving the audience gap to breath. This style of screenplay will work only for some movies but not all. I totally understand why Nolan had to do what he did, but it simply didn't workout that well.I am from India, and usually I know when it's a great movie by seeing our Audience reaction. 70% of the seats were full and I thought people would usually blast the theatre with screaming like monkeys do, like we do in all good movies. But this time, I watched a soul-less, exhausted audience. Most of them were not even bothering to stay and give the movie some attention.The other thing I want to talk about it's the sound track. As gorgeous it can be, it's frustrating and irritating to see Nolan using the same Dunkirk theatrics like the playing the foot stomping rail track sound again and again. To summarise what I saw1. A loud monotonous eerie sound track.2. Characters yelling half the time to make the movie look serious.3. A failed Trinity explosion practical effects.4. Too much screentime about the protagonist AEC hearing and potential indictment. (Honestly, who in this day and age would give a damn about how the guy who made the atom bomb coped with Govt Committees for a stupidest reason that he could be potential Communist? I mean, how could the director think people who are watching the film know how big of a deal it is to talk communist ideas in a Capitalistic nation during WW2?)5. An unapologetic scientist in real life, which the movie did a fantastic job to not give a F or care about him and why he had to do what he had to do. Nolan literally failed to make me feel sorry for Oppenheimer. Just, seeing him read a BS sankrit phrase, "Now I become death, destroyer of worlds" is meant to convince he is really sorry for killing 210000 people?6. A movie which seriously lacks flow of story telling.7. A 3 hours, loud, serial type of drama.Atleast to do some justice to the people who are about to watch this movie, I would say, try to learning the names of the characters in Oppenheimer's life and how influential they too are. This movie is not for an Average Joe with zero knowledge about scientists and their respective contributions. And the way Nolan introduced them like a high speed train into the movie is seriously bad.All in all, it's a good movie, but not spectacular.

Title: Oppenheimer - A Misguided Fusion of Themes [⭐]As a movie enthusiast, I approach films with an open mind, appreciating the art of storytelling and the diverse perspectives they offer. Unfortunately, Oppenheimer left me deeply disappointed and disheartened. While it attempted to delve into the life of the renowned physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer, the inclusion of an insensitive and inappropriate scene involving the Bhagavad Gita during a sexual encounter was an utter misstep that marred the entire film.The movie itself had the potential to be a captivating biographical drama, exploring the complexities of Oppenheimer's life and the moral dilemmas he faced during his work on the atomic bomb. Regrettably, the film veered off course, resorting to shock value by including a scene that was clearly intended to provoke controversy rather than add any meaningful depth to the narrative.To further exacerbate the situation, the scene in question incorporated the sacred and revered text, the Bhagavad Gita, into an intimate moment. Such a disrespectful portrayal not only trivializes a profound spiritual scripture but also demonstrates a lack of cultural sensitivity. It is crucial to understand that religious texts are sacred to millions and should not be misused for sensationalism or shock factor in any context.As an audience member from the region that the Bhagavad Gita holds significant importance for, I felt deeply offended by this blatant disrespect. It is essential for filmmakers to be responsible and thoughtful about the cultural implications of their work, especially when it involves elements so deeply intertwined with people's faith and beliefs.Despite any positive aspects the film might have had, the inclusion of this offensive scene completely overshadowed them, leaving a bitter taste that is hard to overlook. As a result, I cannot, in good conscience, recommend Oppenheimer to others. It is a shame that the potential for a compelling exploration of a remarkable historical figure was overshadowed by such careless and harmful choices.In conclusion, Oppenheimer had the opportunity to be a thought-provoking and respectful biopic, but it failed to live up to its potential. The inappropriate use of the Bhagavad Gita during a sexual scene has deeply insulted our region and undermined the credibility of the film. I urge filmmakers to exercise caution and sensitivity when handling religious and cultural elements in their storytelling, as such irresponsible decisions can alienate audiences and tarnish the reputation of otherwise promising works of art.

If i could give zero i would. Boring, long and waste of money. I was expecting more about how was the bomb designed and how he actually did. But nothing. I understand more from Wikipedia. I'm afraid the film "Oppenheimer" fell flat in more than a few areas. The most noticeable issue was the pacing; the movie was an exhausting, drawn-out affair that rarely managed to hold my interest. Rather than focusing on the most poignant parts of Oppenheimer's life and work, it was bogged down in needless minutiae.The characterization of Oppenheimer himself was another major flaw. For such a complex and historically significant figure, the movie offered a disappointingly one-dimensional portrayal. The acting was passable but lacked the depth and nuance necessary to truly capture the essence of this troubled genius.Finally, the storytelling was lackluster. Crucial historical events were glossed over or presented without context, leaving the viewer to grapple with a disjointed narrative that failed to communicate the significance of Oppenheimer's work. All in all, "Oppenheimer" missed the mark on several counts and ended up being a disappointing depiction of an otherwise fascinating historical figure.

I didn't see that something was really eating Oppenheimer - Murphy even after he realised the scale of his destructive creation. No obsession with atomic bomb or quantum physics was shown. Because what I, and assuming most, find it fascinating about Nolan's work is his brilliant ability to tackle the reality by twisting the rarely evoked imagination. Usually after watching a Nolan, I spend days to think about what I experienced and how it is feeding off my own muse. Unlike this, Oppenheimer dissappointingly, is a flat, uninspired, rushed but deadly long movie. Most characters had inadequate acting range. We all know what Cillian's acting range is, honest to goodness, do you think he gives even the half of it? I do not believe that its his inability but the limitations put by the long and non-linear scenario. All those good actors, which i find the casting so overwhelmingly loaded, scattered around the movie to give a five-minute glimpse without any depth.I am used to non-linearity of his scenarios, and enjoy it almost lividly, but this one seems dispersed and disorganised. The scenario must have been divided into different movies even if they wanted to. Oppenheimer and his relation to communist party, oppenheimer and his private affairs, oppenheimer and his academic affairs, oppenheimer and the politics etc. However, audience expected to get all this aspects in three hours in an amorphotic way. This is the reason why it felt so rushed and flat. For example, strauss and oppenheimer's relationship as interesting to begin with. This conexion loosely presented at the beginning which anyway ended up beig the main arch of the scenario. Not the bomb. I find robert downey jr's acting better than most only because his character was enabling him to put some range, he and emily blunt will get an oscar nomination for this same reason and it should be but not the rest. Also, i am failing to understand how florence pugh's name made it to the poster by only less than 10-min screentime while having very little to add the overall story of the movie, even if there is, that connection already made it to story by his relationship with his brother. I find this quite annoying. In contrast, jason clarke (roger robb) portraited a very well constructed acting and feed the main story grandly but not made it to the poster. He should deserved better.Lasst but not least, I find the scene where oppenheimer climb the tower to have a private moment with his bomb, incredibly underwhelming. I believe nolan very well has the ability to put out a twisting scene there to show the duality of a creator and his creation. Rather we saw him under shadows. Not enough. Almost felt like falling of a climactic moment.For all these reasons, the ending left a dry taste in my mouth and overall this movie will stay as a nuisance for me in his filmography.

When I first heard about the film "Oppenheimer," I was genuinely excited. The subject matter, exploring the life and contributions of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the father of the atomic bomb, seemed like a promising premise. However, my enthusiasm quickly turned into disappointment as I endured what can only be described as a dull and misguided cinematic experience.First and foremost, the pacing of "Oppenheimer" was excruciatingly slow. The film stretched on for what felt like an eternity, with lengthy scenes that added little to the narrative or character development. The director seemed more interested in showcasing their supposed artistic vision than in creating a coherent and engaging story. The result was a plodding and monotonous narrative that failed to hold my attention throughout its unnecessarily long runtime.Furthermore, the character portrayal in "Oppenheimer" was uninspiring at best. While J. Robert Oppenheimer was undoubtedly a complex figure, the film failed to capture his essence and instead reduced him to a one-dimensional and uninteresting protagonist. The script lacked depth and failed to delve into the inner conflicts and moral dilemmas that Oppenheimer faced. As a result, the character felt detached and distant, preventing any meaningful connection between the audience and the protagonist.The supporting cast, unfortunately, suffered the same fate. The talented actors were given little material to work with, and their performances felt wooden and lifeless. It was as if they were merely going through the motions, lacking the emotional depth and nuance necessary to bring the characters to life. This lack of character development left me feeling disconnected and uninvested in their fates.While historical accuracy is not always the most crucial aspect of a biographical film, "Oppenheimer" took too many liberties with the facts. It seemed more interested in presenting a distorted version of events rather than providing a nuanced exploration of Oppenheimer's life. The film played fast and loose with the historical timeline, distorting significant events and omitting crucial details. This disregard for accuracy undermined the film's credibility and left me questioning the validity of the story it sought to tell.In addition to the film's pacing and character flaws, the visual presentation was also underwhelming. The cinematography lacked creativity and failed to capture the grandeur and significance of the subject matter. The drab color palette further contributed to the overall dullness of the film. It felt as if the filmmakers had little interest in creating visually striking scenes or memorable imagery, which ultimately made the viewing experience even more forgettable.Lastly, the thematic exploration of "Oppenheimer" fell flat. The film failed to engage with the ethical and moral implications of Oppenheimer's work adequately. It barely scratched the surface of the profound questions surrounding the development and use of nuclear weapons. Instead, it seemed content with a superficial examination of the events, leaving me longing for a more thought-provoking and intellectually stimulating experience.In conclusion, "Oppenheimer" was a tedious and disappointing film. Its sluggish pacing, lackluster character development, historical inaccuracies, uninspired visual presentation, and superficial thematic exploration all contributed to a movie that failed to deliver on its promising premise. I cannot recommend this film to anyone seeking an engaging and meaningful cinematic experience.

This was a great film. I almost came out of the cinema thinking "I'd really like to see that film".What a shame for a film that is so poignant; a story that hasn't been told on the big screen before, and a subject that everybody should be familiar with.The performances and cinematography were breathtaking; I felt as though I was a living witness leading up to the events that forever changed the world so radically.What a terrible shame it was let down by the most fundamental filmmaking aspects: editing and music.

Nolan's Oppenheimer is a marvelous cinematic experience with stunning visuals, wonderful audio, good pacing and amazing acting performances. However, the film falls short in its underlying theme and story.Oppenheimer is a technical masterpiece and should be considered as the new standard in the technical aspect of film making. The overall audio-visual experience that the viewer can experience in a proper IMAX cinema is without a doubt one the best movie experiences ever created. With stunning cinematography and a soul gripping score, I was fully immersed in my theatrical experience from the beginning of the film, right up until after the Trinity launch. As the Trinity launch was the culmination of the build up from the first two hours of the film, I was left wondering how the story would unfold further and what would it entail as we learn more.To my slight annoyance, the third act revealed that the theme, and therefore the lesson of Oppenheimer was, that even the most brilliant minds cannot break from the shackles of governement control and must succomb to the necessities of the society they live in and the power that controls it. And yet, our most estemeed academics can forgive themselves for what they have created due to the fact that if they wouldn't make it, somebody else would and after all they only provide the gadgets, not use them as Truman told Oppenheimer. This theme echoes throughout the film and left a discouraged and sour taste in my soul.As Oppenheimer was working to create his gadget, he was becoming more and more tormented by his own creation and what it would unleash upon the world. As a side note, Murphy has perfected his craft in playing a brilliant, yet tormented soul that draws you in his melancholy and pulls on your heart strings effectively, while still liking the character even through his many flaws. As a I was saying before however, this inner torment of Oppenheimer was not enough to make him stop his work but on the contrary, he pushed on to create the most dangerous deterrant the world has yet to see. The most he did to try to stop the making of these bombs was protest a little against the H-bomb. And even then went on to work on that protect. A brilliant physicist just could not stop working on atomic weapons. Now if that doesn't break down your spirit, I dont know what will. In addition, the sisua of responsibility is bridges of with the simple act of Truman telling Oppenheimer to get over it. As if scientists are not responsible for what their creations do to the world. Add to that the fact that the film demonstrated just how crooked and corrupt the American government is and I just can't make myself feel good about this movie.From a Nolan fan I have to say that this film has the most grim message out of all the Nolan films and while the theme is important especially in these times, it would have been nice if the film would have offered some encouragement as well.

I wish I didn't see this movie.It was better in my imagination, fantasizing about what it could be.I can't even understand the advertising and marketing pre-release campaign.Both misdirected the average viewer but also the random Nolan's fan (even if they will never admit it).Soundtrack wasn't good.Why do you have to let me know that everything is dramatic with this constant noise in the background ?Is like listening to fake laughs in Friend, put there to remember you to eventually laugh.Storytelling went totally random in the last part, "the Lewis affair".Even if actors did a good job, at one point everything become confused.And not for lack of viewer's brain cells, but because of rushed storytelling.The climax to get to Trinity test was nice.But the test itself lacked real tension and visual.David Lynch showed a Trinity test in The Return with way more tension, for a TV show.And probably with the same budget they spent for Emily Blunt's haircut.In a time where people have zero attention span, in the era of Reels and TikTok, is a big gamble to make a 3 hours movie.It is also refreshing to see something like that, since we lack good movies.But, out of this context, Oppenheimer is nothing special.And is quite hard to admit it.I am sure it will get Oscar here and there, prizes everywhere, but it won't matter.

Oppenheimer Review (that absolutely nobody asked for):Acting 10/10
Directing 8/10
Script 3/10
Pacing 8/10
Structure 4/10
Emotion 3/10
Story 2/10Wonderfully acted out piece of propaganda.Matt Damon & Benny Safdie really stood out to me amongst the all star cast. Stellar performances.Cillian Murphy was hypnotizing to watch as always.RDJ will almost certainly get an Oscar nod.The talent in front and behind the screen did a fantastic job of drawing in the audience, I was on the edge of my seat half the movie!How did almost no other character in this entire film have any sort of negative feelings about the bombs dropping in Hiroshima & Nagasaki whatsoever, except for Oppenheimer. Nobody blinked an eye when they mentioned Pearl Harbor, and when news hit that Hitler invaded Poland all they said was "You've been upstaged." No emotion. Pathetically unrealistic.David Kromholtz had one of the only characters who felt true this whole movie.The movie painted Oppenheimer out as a martyr, and Truman (Gary Oldman) as the button man, which is just historically wrong. They literally brought Oldman in just to sell the biggest lie of the whole film."It wasn't you, it was me."Not a single mention of his occult involvement nor his influence and decision to drop those bombs.Lastly, because of what this movie both opened and closed with, the black & white narration of the film, it would seem be more pertinent to title this film:
The Hearing of Levi Strauss or something similar.A few masterful scenes cannot make up for this intentional catastrophe. Very disappointing.6/10.

The story of Oppenheimer is told in Nolan's way - with a great set of actors, non-linear screenplay, and overly done background music. Of course, the tunes taken out of the context would sound great. Oppenheimer, directed by Christopher Nolan, is a film that falls disappointingly short of its potential. While it attempts to delve into the intriguing life and contributions of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the renowned physicist and key figure in the development of the atomic bomb, the execution of the film leaves much to be desired. Here are a few reasons why Oppenheimer fails to deliver on its promise.First and foremost, the pacing of the film is sluggish, making it difficult for the audience to fully engage with the story. The narrative unfolds at a leisurely pace, often getting bogged down in unnecessary details and lacking a cohesive structure. As a result, the film struggles to maintain momentum, leaving viewers disinterested and disconnected from the subject matter.Moreover, the screenplay of Oppenheimer leaves much to be desired. The dialogue often feels forced and contrived, lacking naturalness and authenticity. The interactions between characters lack depth, and the exchanges fail to evoke genuine emotion or intellectual stimulation. As a result, the film feels flat and fails to fully explore the complex themes and ideas it aims to tackle.Lastly, the editing and overall structure of the film contribute to its mediocrity. The transitions between scenes are often abrupt and disjointed, hindering the flow of the narrative. Additionally, certain sequences feel unnecessarily prolonged, while others are hastily wrapped up, resulting in an uneven pacing that disrupts the film's coherence.In conclusion, Oppenheimer falls short of its potential due to its sluggish pacing, shallow character development, lackluster cinematography, weak screenplay, and flawed editing. While the subject matter holds immense intrigue and potential for a captivating film, this particular rendition fails to engage and inspire its audience. Despite its aspirations, Oppenheimer ultimately proves to be a lackluster cinematic endeavor.1/10.

Absolute TRASH, total waste of time, save your money, go watch barbie, must be way better than this one.Nolan I want my money back.Title: "Openheimer: A Cinematic Catastrophe"I hope you don't take it personally, but "Openheimer" is quite possibly the most dreadful movie I've ever had the misfortune of watching. From start to finish, it was an unmitigated disaster that left me questioning the very nature of filmmaking and how this monstrosity ever saw the light of day.The plot, if one can call it that, is an incoherent mess of random scenes and inexplicable occurrences. I couldn't discern a clear storyline if my life depended on it. It felt like the filmmakers were trying to be profound and thought-provoking, but instead, they delivered a pretentious jumble of half-baked ideas that left me more confused than enlightened.The characters in "Openheimer" are as lifeless as a sack of potatoes. I had absolutely no emotional connection to any of them, and their motivations were about as clear as mud. It's as if the actors themselves were bewildered by the script and had no idea how to portray their poorly written roles. Watching their lackluster performances was a painful exercise in endurance.The direction and editing were so haphazard that I couldn't tell if the film was going backward or forward half the time. Jump cuts and awkward transitions were used in an attempt to be edgy, but they only succeeded in making the film feel like a choppy mess. It's evident that the filmmakers were aiming for an avant-garde approach, but instead, they achieved a level of incompetence rarely seen in cinema.The cinematography in "Openheimer" is nothing short of an eyesore. It's as if the director of photography had never operated a camera before and decided to experiment during the actual shoot. The result is a visual nightmare of poorly framed shots, out-of-focus scenes, and an overuse of shaky cam that made me queasy.As if the cinematic abomination wasn't enough, the soundtrack added insult to injury. The music, if you can call it that, consisted of discordant noises that assaulted my ears and made me wish for the sweet sound of silence. It felt like the composer was playing a prank on the audience, trying to see how much auditory torture we could endure before walking out of the theater."Openheimer" is a prime example of filmmakers trying to be "artsy" and "intellectual" without having a clue about storytelling or the craft of filmmaking. It's a slap in the face to moviegoers who expect even a modicum of coherence and entertainment value from a film. This cinematic catastrophe should be avoided at all costs, and I can't help but feel sorry for anyone involved in this embarrassing disaster, from the actors to the crew who wasted their time and talent on such an appalling project. Save yourself the agony and find something else to watch-anything else would be a step up from "Openheimer."

I want to love this movie as much as I do the other Nolan films, but I can't quite get there. First off, the acting is incredible, it does feel like a period piece, and the cast is A++. True to its name, this is really a film about Oppenheimer's life, with all the good and bad included. It does a very good job of showing the existential issues related to the bomb, and it is a heavy film in the way you would expect.But there are some places where things could have been improved. First, the film is LONG, like really long. While everything is rightfully included for a reason, this film does not have the same rewatch value that other Nolan movies have. In the last part of the movie it feels like Nolan is kind of rushing to wrap things up, which I didn't appreciate. There's some pretty unnecessary nudity, which feels really out of place in a Nolan movie. I get that we need to explore all of Oppenheimer's life, but you can include that without being so explicit. The movie is an intellectual endeavor and takes some brainpower to watch, and while other Nolan films are this way, this one somehow feels different.The trinity test is insanely cool though, and worth seeing in IMAX. Certainly a film for cinephiles, and like I said, the acting is superb with beautiful, expertly crafted sets. Overall, very good, but just so long and heavy.

I didn't like this movie.There was too little theory to call it interesting or science popularisation - something I really liked in Interstellar.There was a number of factual mistakes, actually unacceptable for a historic movie.There was background music throughout the entire film, which gave it a dramatic effect. Though, to my taste - if you get to the point to require music to give the dramatic effect, your story is weak.There was this nonsensical timeline back and forth, where the most recent time was shot, for whatever reason, in black and white - I don't even care why, I just didn't like the the timeline hops.Ultimately and most severely, the glorification of making and using a mass killing bomb - regardless of the intentions of the creators, philosophical dilemmas that haunt them later, catchy lines thrown around by literally everyone in the film - is atrocious and barbaric.Especially during the scene of preparation for the final test, I would like Nolan to show the peaceful citizens of Hiroshima, who didn't know that their days were last, and nothing that they did actually mattered, because they would've been blown up by these scientists.Overall: Terrible story, bad visuals, decent play by a load of very strong actors, distracting music, too much of Cillian Murphy closeups, factual errors, no moral balance.I wish I hadn't spent time I watching this.

As an admirer of Nolan, I came into this movie with big expectations. While it had its merits, I couldn't help but feel disappointed.What I expected to be the biggest and most pivotal scene in the movie, and probably the most anticipated was The Trinity Test explosion. The tension in waiting for the sound of the explosion after already seeing it, was immense, and gave viewers an understanding of just how far they had to be to not be hurt by this new weapon, but the actual sight of the explosion simply wasn't enough, there was no grandiosity, it didn't feel like I was watching and explosion that would go forth and change the world.Nevertheless, the glimpses into the mind of Oppenheimer were truly captivating, offering tantalizing insights into his brilliance and complexities. However, I wished there were more of these moments to fully immerse myself in the genius of such an extraordinary figure.The film had incredible acting performances, with each character(my favourites being Matt Damon and Emily Blunt). However, the narrative failed in providing sufficient backstory for viewers less familiar with the historical context of the physics setting, scenes like meeting Heisenberg, or Bohr arriving at the Los Alamos, felt lost on certain viewers.The movie had a documentary-like quality, rich with information, yet I found myself yearning for more context and clarity. It felt like an opportunity to learn, but somehow missed the mark in providing a cohesive educational experience.

Boring movie
Don't recommend."Oppenheimer," the much-hyped historical drama, directed by a renowned filmmaker, has been making waves in the cinema world. With an abundance of positive reviews and high ratings, the film has been hailed as a patriotic masterpiece. However, after experiencing the movie firsthand, it becomes apparent that the praise is far from justified. "Oppenheimer" suffers from significant flaws that undermine its historical integrity, and while it does offer some valuable insights into history, it fails to captivate the audience's attention, ultimately proving to be a disappointing and time-wasting endeavor.The primary issue with "Oppenheimer" is the authenticity of its content. While historical dramas often take creative liberties to enhance storytelling, this film goes far beyond that, bending and distorting historical facts to suit its narrative. This reckless approach to history raises concerns about the film's integrity as an accurate portrayal of the events surrounding the Manhattan Project and the life of J. Robert Oppenheimer. By misrepresenting key events and personalities, the movie strays from being a reliable source of information, which is a significant drawback for those looking to learn more about this crucial period in history.Another glaring problem with "Oppenheimer" is its reliance on misplaced patriotism. Rather than delving into the complex and morally ambiguous aspects of the story, the film chooses to paint Oppenheimer and his team as unflinchingly heroic figures, all in the name of fostering a sense of national pride. This shallow portrayal not only disrespects the nuances of history but also reduces the characters to one-dimensional stereotypes, robbing the audience of a more profound emotional connection with the story.Despite its lack of authenticity and overemphasis on patriotism, "Oppenheimer" still manages to provide a few valuable history lessons. The movie offers glimpses into the scientific breakthroughs and challenges faced during the development of the atomic bomb. Moreover, it sheds light on the ethical dilemmas that plagued the scientists involved in the project, grappling with the consequences of their inventions and the devastation they could bring upon humanity. These insights into history are undoubtedly enlightening, but they come at the expense of a coherent and engaging narrative.Regrettably, the movie's failure to captivate its audience is its most damning flaw. Clocking in at an excruciatingly long runtime, "Oppenheimer" struggles to maintain a compelling pace. The lack of a cohesive plot and the meandering storytelling make the movie a tedious watch. Even the most dedicated history enthusiasts may find it challenging to stay invested in the film's plodding narrative, further compounded by its artificial and superficial approach to character development.While the film's production values are undeniably impressive, with stunning cinematography and convincing period settings, these technical achievements cannot compensate for the movie's underlying issues. A visually captivating film is only as good as its story, and in the case of "Oppenheimer," the lackluster plot undermines its aesthetic appeal.In conclusion, "Oppenheimer" is a disappointing movie that fails to live up to the hype surrounding it. Its inauthentic portrayal of historical events and reliance on shallow patriotism detract from its credibility as an educational piece. Moreover, the film's slow pace and lack of engaging storytelling make it a tedious and time-wasting experience for many viewers. Despite the movie's few redeeming qualities, such as providing insights into historical facts, it ultimately falls short of delivering a compelling cinematic experience. If you're looking for a genuinely enriching and enjoyable historical drama, "Oppenheimer" may not be the best choice.

I am an avid movie viewer and have a long history and passion for cinema. I've watched several of Nolan's films in the past and have on the whole enjoyed them.When I first saw the trailers for and heard about Oppenheimer I was very excited as it seemed like it had the potential to be a true masterpiece. And while the movie wasn't bad, it wasn't what I was hoping for.First of all my praise for the film. The acting was superb as both Murphy and Downey displayed incredible talent and emotion on screen and all the rest of the cast echoed this. The cinematography was beautifully done and the musical score complimented it well.My main issue with this film consists in the storytelling and writing of this film. There were far too many parts that dragged on and contributed little to nothing as far as the whole story and would've best been removed. As well as sections that were completely unnecessary and or not tastefully done (such as Oppenheimer's continuous infidelity throughout the film). On the other hand there were parts that I believe should've been added so as to clarify certain aspects of the latter half of the film and bring more emotional cohesion.Honestly during the film I was wondering about the time (a very rare occurrence) throughout the film.Additionally, I have read other reviews which have been under the assumption that history buffs or people who are interested in the field are even more likely to enjoy the film. I can attest to the fact as not entirely true, as I myself am studying history currently in university and my love of history didn't sway my issues with the film or enhance it, but viewed it, simply, as I would any other film (that is just for the benefit of the reader to see where my perspective may lie).As a final thought, Oppenheimer was a good film that I was expecting much more from and let me down in many ways but still exhibits shining qualities. I went away from it feeling very little and don't think I would either recommend nor dissuade someone from watching it.

At the beginning, I think that most people thought that this movie is about the nuclear bomb and there will be many explosions, and I am one of the people who thought that there would be explosions, because of the marketing and the hype in this film were saying this, but it is very logical that there will be no explosions other than the experimental explosion unless Oppenheimer Participated in the war but he didn't, I may not like biographical films much unless I am interested in the person, and in Robert Oppenheimer's life I am more interested in the nuclear bomb. Perhaps if the movie was about the nuclear bomb and focusing on it, it would have been better, i missed the first 10 minutes of the film but the beginning was normal for me like any other biography, I like the conflict with his life , with jean and his friend and kitty, and the interior conflict that caused after they dropped the bomb in Hiroshima, This shows you the act that comes with regret later on, The climax in this film was so powerful and touched me and deserved to watch it on 70mm IMAX screen but only this scene d: ,The speech scene after they dropped the bomb, After that there was an inner struggle scene that Nolan showed us visually in a very cool way, i see that 3 hours is a lot for this film , it could be better than that in my opinion, the cinematography and the soundtrack ill not say anything about it i mean it's so good ofc, the editing style i didnt like it so much and i feel like it's messy, And I think Nolan is obsessed with time and decided to use editing to play between past, present and future, it's not like the editor is bad or something no but i felt this method didn't work with me, When I missed the 10 minutes, I felt that I had missed something because i didnt understand what happened when they went to the B+W , so I started thinking about what I missed, and then at the time I was thinking about, the future tense appeared and I said holy shit wtf is this, and I missed the time while thinking about what i missed but i got it quickly because I know Nolan he loves to play with time , but i think people don't know him they will take a lot longer to realize what is happening.Overall i liked the film and deserved to be watched especially if you interested in Oppenheimer's life or if you are a filmmaker.

Christopher Nolan's Oppenheimer is a sweeping, epic, and visually stunning film that tells the story of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the man who led the Manhattan Project to develop the atomic bomb. The film is long (nearly three hours) and complex, but it is also incredibly engrossing and thought-provoking.Nolan's direction is masterful, and he uses his trademark visual style to create a film that is both visually arresting and emotionally powerful. The film is shot in IMAX, and the images are stunning. The film's score by Ludwig Göransson is also excellent, and it perfectly complements the film's visuals.The performances in Oppenheimer are all top-notch. Cillian Murphy gives a tour-de-force performance as Oppenheimer, and he is supported by an excellent cast that includes Emily Blunt, Matt Damon, Robert Downey Jr., and Kenneth Branagh.Oppenheimer is not an easy film to watch. It deals with some heavy subject matter, and it is not afraid to show the dark side of science and technology. However, it is also a film that is ultimately hopeful, and it suggests that even the most destructive forces can be used for good.Overall, Oppenheimer is a masterpiece. It is a film that is both intellectually stimulating and emotionally powerful. It is a film that will stay with you long after you have seen it.Here are some of the things I liked about the film:The performances were all excellent, especially Cillian Murphy's performance as Oppenheimer.The visuals were stunning, especially the IMAX scenes.The score by Ludwig Göransson was excellent.The film dealt with some heavy subject matter in a thoughtful and intelligent way.Here are some of the things I didn't like about the film:The film was long (nearly three hours).The film could be slow-paced at times.The film's ending was a bit ambiguous.Overall, I highly recommend Oppenheimer. It is a film that is both intellectually stimulating and emotionally powerful. It is a film that will stay with you long after you have seen it.

Start off by saying before watching the movie, I didn't even know the movie title was of the main character,, and I didn't even know who Christopher Nolan was or his work until after watching the movie and looking it up. Instead I had heard it's about a movie about war and supposedly a 'masterpiece'.After watching the movie, here's what I did/not enjoy...PROS
Some amazing acting from the cast, Cillian Murphy, Matt Damon and Emily Blunt were particular standouts for me.I did enjoy the dialogue content, but I hated its delivery (see below).CONS
Rapid fire edits throughout the entire movie made it very difficult to follow the storyline, I don't think more than 3 or 4 mins was spent on each scene - which was not enjoyable for a 3hr long movie.VERY dialogue heavy - combined with the fast edits above, it felt like they were trying to cram too much into 3 hrs. And it's okay to have fast conversations in each scene, but then it jump to the next fast-paced conversation scene, and the next and so forth. There was no time to digest the weight of what just happened!Poor visual storytelling - the fast edits + dialogue heavy script combined made it feel like the cinema format was not properly delivered, and it felt like I was being 'told' what was happening, not 'shown'. Based on this, I probably could've just listened to this movie like an audiobook, and had the same experience.No emotive storytelling either - when I finally figured out Oppenheimer was a person (and the main character) I thought this would become an emotional story about his life, relationships, aspirations and fears. Instead, it felt more like a rapid-fire roll call of his personal and work resume - almost like a documentary.Strange sound design in some parts - there were some parts when the actors were speaking (eg Emily Blunt) and I had no idea what she saying, so much so it made me wish the cinema had included subtitles!! Surely I could expect more for a $100M movie?I'm struggling to understand how on earth this movie is considered a 'masterpiece'? Not a movie I'd watch again...

Ok let me start by the obvious ratings which were thoroughly written and explained by the previous reviewers. I will be brief:
Oscar for best Direction : Christopher Nolan
Oscar for best performance by an actor in a leading role: Cilian Murphy
Oscar for best Screenplay : Christophe Nolan
Oscars for best supporting actor : Matt Damon and/or Rober Doweny Jr
Oscar for best editing : Jenifer Lame
Oscar for best music : Ludwig Goransson
Oscar for the most unnecessary casting to an unworthy Oscar holder: Rami Malek
Etc etc etc...
So why the 6 then: Because the film is unnecessary. Its about something that already happened, and we are all aware of (take for example the atomic bomb first testing scene in Los Alamos). It's a biography of a person that we cannot relate to because his character (as depicted in the film) is two-dimensional. The film's subject matter is boring. Its very well written but its unnecessarily too long. And finally because it didn't manage to provide) any sort of feelings (well ok apart from some arousal in the unnecessary sex scenes). I believe that Nolan's next film should be about Psychedelia and it's influence to humanity in a Philosophical, Sociological and Spiritual level (as Kubrick did in 2001: A Space Odyssey). I'm sure that with a film like that, he will be able to use show his full spectrum as a Director and as an artist.

Oppenheimer is a long, slow-burning film that is not for everyone. The film is over three hours long, and it can be quite dull at times. However, the soundtrack is excellent, and the film's middle section is particularly well-done.The film tells the story of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the physicist who led the Manhattan Project to develop the atomic bomb. The film is well-acted, with Cillian Murphy giving a standout performance as Oppenheimer. However, the film's length and slow pace can be a major drawback.If you are a fan of Christopher Nolan's films, you may enjoy Oppenheimer. However, if you are looking for a more exciting or fast-paced film, you may be disappointed.Here is a more detailed review of the film:Pros:
Excellent acting, especially by Cillian Murphy
Beautiful cinematography
Excellent soundtrack
Thought-provoking themes
Cons:
Too long
Slow pace
Mind-numbingly dull at timesOverall, Oppenheimer is a well-made film with some excellent performances. However, the film's length and slow pace may be a major drawback for some viewers. I would recommend the film to fans of Christopher Nolan's films, but others may want to wait for it to be released on streaming.

Saw Oppenheimer in IMAX format. It's a decent enough biopic but itvsuffers from an unjustified grandiose directorial style. Nokan's insistence on film vs digital and penchant for unnecessary melodrama make it seem like more of a major work than it actually is.
